Volume 46 of The Collected Letters of Thomas and Jane Welsh Carlyle covers Thomas Carlyle’s letters from January 1869 to April 1870. It also includes any Mary Aitken letters written on TC’s behalf in that period. Most of TC’s longer letters in this volume are to his family in Scotland, particularly to his brother John A. Carlyle. His shorter letters are often about social arrangements for visits, either in London or to Lady Ashburton in Melchet, Hampshire, or about publishing arrangements with Chapman & Hall or John Forster. The shorter letters perhaps predominate because of his increasing difficulty with his handwriting, reducing TC often to using a blue pencil. But longer letters were also written, at this point drafted by TC, then written out by his niece Mary Carlyle Aitken, who now lived with him. Later he was to learn to dictate to her. Giving as full a picture as possible of TC’s life at this time, we have added many quotations from the copious number of letters written to TC that have survived. We are also fortunate to be able to continue our use of TC’s journal, which often gives a more unmediated picture of his feelings and reactions than his letters do, as well as giving more detail as to what he was doing and who was visiting him. In addition, ensuring the continued presence of JWC in The Collected Letters of Thomas and Jane Welsh Carlyle, we include two appendices of JWC letters found too late to have been included at their chronological places. [In the Carlyle Letters Online, the letters that appear in Appendix One and Appendix Two have been moved to their appropriate chronological location.]

The inclusion of two appendices in this volume reminds us of JWC’s epistolary talents. Appendix One is of letters written to her friend Isabella McTurk (later Dinwoodie), and Appendix Two is of letters written between 1850 and 1866. Appendix Two is mainly short letters about arrangements or with excuses for refusals, although as always they are highly characteristic of JWC. “So under this pressure of astonishing work excuse brevity and illegibility / Love—oh dear no it was affection—Affection then and respect to Mr Gaskell and a kiss to Meta and ditto to yourself dear Woman” (JWC to EG, [21 Nov. 1851], Appendix Two), she wrote at the end of a dashing note of excuses to Elizabeth Gaskell. Appendix One, containing JWC’s letters to Isabella McTurk / Dinwoodie, reminds us of the early, fully developed epistolary style of Jane Baillie Welsh. Isabella McTurk was one of many women friends to whom JWC wrote, and these previously unpublished letters (donated to the National Library of Scotland by Isabella’s daughter Mary Agnes Dinwoodie) give fine examples of the satiric energy used in descriptions of JWC’s surroundings.
The earliest letter (4 Nov. 1823) shows the friendship between two young middle class women in Scotland in the early 1820s who were, of course, piano playing; it includes JBW’s transcription of part of the piano music for “Rance [ranz] des vaches,” the Swiss cow-call used as the basis for more than one formal piece of music. We also include two letters from Grace Welsh (JWC’s mother) to Isabella Dinwoodie; they show the closeness of the Welsh family’s friendship with the McTurk family and Isabella herself [see GW to IMD, 19 Feb. 1838, and GW to IMD, late Feb.]. Most of Grace Welsh’s letters to JWC are lost, but Isabella here is written to like a surrogate daughter, and these two letters, showing Grace Welsh as a fine as well as a sarcastic letter writer, can probably be read as exemplars of Grace Welsh’s letters to her daughter. We have been able to include in this appendix a reproduction of a portrait of Isabella Dinwoodie [JBW to IMD, 21 April 1848], very kindly donated, 2017, by one of her descendants, John Beddoes, to the Edinburgh Carlyle Society; we also include Jane Baillie Welsh’s pencil sketch of Grace Welsh [4 Nov. 1823], which was previously owned by Dr. James Gillan (also Isabella’s descendant and uncle of John Beddoes), and is now owned by Ian Campbell.

TC is, of course, the main concern of this volume. He was continuing his collecting and light editing of JWC’s letters during the months covered. His references to how much he missed her were still present in his journal but were perhaps less acute than previously; he wrote less directly about her virtues as a letter writer in his journal of this time than he had earlier in his reminiscences of her (1866) and in his journal of 1866–68. Then he extolled her skills (see, for example, his famous passage on her letters, Carlyle, Reminiscences 161 [cited in TC to MRSSU, 10 July 1866, note 3], and, in his journal; see 45:71–72TC to RST, 30 Nov. 1867, 96TC to LN, 18 Feb. 1868, and 207MAI to MEW, 3 Dec. 1868). In this volume he commented on the fact of his editing (particularly the dating of letters) rather than on JWC’s talents as a letter writer; these talents were now self-evident, and his task of collecting the letters for publication after his death were increasingly seen as an inevitable part of his later life’s work. To Thomas Erskine, after thanking him for visiting Betty Braid in Edinburgh, TC wrote about his “work” on the letters: “I still keep working, after a weak sort; but can now do little, often almost nothing;—all my little ‘work’ is henceforth private (as I calculate); a setting of my poor house in order; whh I wd fain finish in time, and occasionally fear I shan’t” (TC to TE, 11 Feb. 1869). Here he made the acknowledgment of his “private work,” echoing the way in which JWC’s letters are viewed now as her “private writing,” as opposed to TC’s “public” career of published writings. He retained a yearning to do “real” writing: “With a little health after it, perhaps there are some Last Words to my sunk generatn in me still. If not, no more, and it shall be enough. In late nights, thinking of these things, I have come to that view; and it is something helpfully fixed for me” (TC’s journal, 29 April 1869; privately owned).

TC articulated what he was doing, July 1869, in one of his letters requesting JWC’s letters, in this case to Betty Braid, the old servant from Haddington to
whom JWC had remained close: “For this long while past I am busy collecting all her letters, getting them copied, dated, made legible to friends that may survive me. There is often mention of you, you may guess how kindly;—if you have any of hers to you, as I think is likely, it would be a great favour to send them or such of them as you think the best” (TC to BB, 14 July 1869). During 1869, TC gathered in various other collections of letters from, for example, John Forster and Isabella Simmonds. His family in Dumfries had already helped with copying and dating some family letters, late 1868 (see 45:197TC to JRID, 12 Nov. 1868, and 215–16TC to JAC, 22 Dec. 1868). TC remained troubled by difficulties in dating JWC’s letters, writing his first journal entry in 1869, 14 February, about how “busy” he was in dating and sorting them:
div1.q: Am busy, what I fondly call “busy” with those “Letters”; progress almost none: ah me, ah me! I feel it to be as my sacredtask; and that the time is short; yet the obstrucns and paltry impedimts in me and abt me prove so numerous, so continl. I am only got to Craigenputth yet; and have stood there almost stockstill, or painfully shuffling hither & thither witht real advance for a week past. I have lost the tone of care and sincerity;— must, must recover that. (See 13TC to [TDI], 17 Feb. 1869)
div1.p: Later he was to express his grief at the approaching end of this task, as though it presaged a second parting from JWC:
div1.q: In spite of impedts, we are now getting done with that sacred Task; in a month more (if permitted still) I can hope to see the whole of those dear letters lying legible to good eyes (with the needful commentaries &c). … Ah, me; and now there is at times a sharp pang, as if this were a second parting with Her; sad, sad, this too! … Oh my lost lost One; lost, and none left to help me ever agn! ([24 July 1869]; see 64TC to JAC, 26 July 1869)
div1.p: By late September 1869, TC commented in his journal: “The ‘Task,’ in a sort, done; Mary finish my Notes (of 1866) this very day;—I shrinking, for weeks past, from any revisal or interference there, as a thing evidently hurtful, (evidtly anti-somnial even!) in my prest state of nerves.— Essentially, howr, Her Letters & Memorials are saved” (see 80TC to LLA, 1 Oct. 1869). This reference to JWC’s “Letters & Memorials” seems to indicate that he had already decided what any publication might be called; J. A. Froude (who “had no conjecture as to what it was” that TC had been working on) wrote in Carlyle’s Life in London: “This is the last mention of these ‘Letters,’ &c, in the Journal. … It was tied together and laid aside for the present, and no resolution was then formed as to what was to be done with it” (Froude, Carlyle 4:382–83). TC himself had promised Isabella Simmonds nothing was to be done soon with the letters:
div1.q: Those precious Letters are all lying punctually locked up in Chelsea; waiting yr return. I am greatly obliged by yr loan of them. … Niece Mary has taken Copies of those you sent, as was my object in asking for them: but you may trust me there is no vestige of intention to print anything; on the contrary, a strict prohibition,—at least and lowest till all whom it cd personally concern are out of the scene. (TC to IS [IEB], 4 Sept. 1869)
div1.p: Mary Aitken was now living permanently with TC, and one of her main tasks had been transcribing many of JWC’s letters. TC saw her as an always willing “little” helper, as doubtless she was, but her own feelings were expressed to a friend, 10 Feb. 1869; she was looking forward to the arrival of JWC’s cousin Maggie Welsh for a visit:

I have never seen her; but I have no doubt we will be very good friends for all that. And she will be good company for me for I confess sometimes the days seem long & my copying gets monotonous and then I threaten to get quite too homesick & go to immortal smash. (10 Feb. 1869; MS: Harry Ransom Center, Univ. of Texas)

Given Mary’s considerable involvement in the work of putting together the text of JWC’s letters, it is perhaps unsurprising that she should have felt so invested in the provenance and legal rights and wrongs of the speedy publication by Froude after TC’s death of JWC’s Letters and Memorials (1883) as well as of TC’s Reminiscences (published very soon after TC’s death, February 1881).

There were always more letters to be collected and dated; Forster’s own work over summer 1869 meant that he could not sort his and his wife’s letters from JWC until October 1869; TC’s commentary, as he took them up to read, indicated the mixture of pain, loss, and religious feeling with which he approached her memory:
div1.q: A mournful fascinatn to me, the reading of them! I felt bereaved, as if I had lost Her agn when they ended. My feeling on that side, I think, is never like to abate at all. Sorrow not so lacerating, poignant, but almost deeper and tenderer than ever. Interwoven, incorporated (I might say), with all of religion, of love, devoutness, goodness, that is in one. Let it accompy my now lonesome steps till I die. (11 Nov. 1869; see 93TC to JAC, 23 Oct. 1869)
div1.p: Clearly, JWC’s death in 1866 and TC’s sense of grief after that underpinned many of his own increasing feelings of mortality. In 1869, shortly after the anniversary of JWC’s death, he lamented the illnesses affecting his friends and deaths of some of them:
div1.q: Anniversary ‘April 21:’ I was at the spot [Hyde Park] this time: have since repeatedly been.— Ld Stanley dying; poor sculptor Munro (at Cannes) dying;—the excellt Surgn Syme (of Edinr) struck by apoplexy (lost his brave good Wife &c); Dickens (playacting or ‘reading’, to excess) within an inch of being struck:—what scene this is! (29 April 1869; see 42TC to JAC, 28 April 1869)
div1.p: Dickens himself was to die, to the shock of TC and many others, 20 June 1870 (see vol. 47). The death, 5 October 1869, of Eliza Stodart, friend of JWC’s youth, led TC into expressing an unusual fellow feeling for her husband, David Aitken: “Poor ‘Bess Stoddart’ (Mrs D. Aitken, once of Minto), a young intimate of [JWC’s] (some years older than She) was suddenly summoned two weeks ago. … [P]oor Aitken left suddenly alone too! They were a commonplace pair of people; but Death has made them also tragic to me” (11 Nov. 1869; see 105TC to JAC, 12 [11] Nov. 1869). Six months later, he was lamenting the death of one of his and JWC’s old friends, Thomas Erskine: “Ever since Tuesday morng I have had that sad & solemn time in Edinr prest to me. Our good, and dear old Erskine gone away from us” (TC to WSM, 24 March 1870). TC continued to mourn JWC, somehow intertwining his feelings about her with his feelings about worship; by collecting her letters as well as recording his memories, his memorializing of JWC became his substitute for religion:
div1.q: Thursday next is the anniversary of my irreparable Loss. Four years ago now; and the sense of it not lightened or lessened,—on the contrary brot home to me, practically sore and sad, many times every day I live. Indeed at no moment is my Lost One absent from me; but lies behind every thot I have or thing I do,—even in the presence of other people, when it is expected that I am to have totally forgotten (as they have done) the Calamity that came. Ah me, ah me. And yet there is occasionally (as this morning) a blessed balm in this mournful remembrance; a sacredness, something more like ‘worship of God’ than anythg else I do. (16 April 1870; see 196–97TC to JAC, 22 April 1870)
div1.p:
As well as his own feelings of mortality compounded by the deaths of others, and the continuing sense of loss of JWC, TC felt most beleaguered by his sleeplessness and the loss of capacity for writing with his right hand. One of Mary’s other main tasks was, at times, to make a final copy of TC’s letters for sending and, unsurprisingly, TC felt hampered by this change of practice and his letters of summer 1869 were much preoccupied with it; he wrote to Betty Braid, 14 July 1869: “For the last year my hand has been very shaky, sometimes refusing altogether to write for me; so that I am obliged to employ the hand of a good little Niece, who is very ready that way;—as you may see here; but I have never yet got used to writing by dictation”; and to his brother:
“today I have tried to write a line to the Revd Bearer; but was obliged to give it to Mary to copy after all. The loss of my poor pen-hand is a grt misery, whh I must reconcile myself to. I sometimes think of trying to learn with the left; for dictating (at least hitherto, with Mary, who is so soft, too, and so willing, if she only understood!) altogr refuses to prosper with me!” (TC to JAC, 11 Aug. 1869). He was no more successful than JWC had been (see 42:69–71JWC to TC, 8 June [1865]) at learning to write with his left hand. He wrote to Ralph Waldo Emerson: “you see I am reduced to pencil! & ‘write’ with such difficulty (never yet cd learn to ‘dictate,’ tho’ my little Niece here is promptitude itself, and is so swift and legible” (24 Feb. 1870). These letters provide a useful summary of TC’s struggles with his writing and his shaky right hand. The new difficulties were a material change in his capacities that struck at the heart of his being a writer. But he was not without wit in describing the problem; he wrote to Lady Ashburton: “My hand can write today,—abt as fast as it once cd have engraved on some soft metal” (19 Aug. 1869), and then refined the image to his brother: “I have taken such a time over this, e.g.; cd have engraved it (on lead) sooner” (TC to JAC, 3 Nov. 1869).

His main health problem, continuously referred to in letters and his journal, was sleeplessness. Letter after letter complained. He wrote after a week with Lady Ashburton at her country house, Melchet, April 1869: “I was at Melchet lately for a week; all imaginable kindness &c &c,—but was obliged to leave, in a week, for absolute want of sleep. Can’t go (nor have been genlly for years past) to such places any more. Small sacrifice, or none. The idle talk of mankind is grown quite unwelcome to me” (see 37TC to RSTFC, 12 April 1869). John A. Carlyle, now TC’s most regular correspondent, often heard TC’s complaints: “The truth is, I am fallen agn into one of my great gulphs, or abysses of sleeplessness” (TC to JAC, [5] June 1869). But both John and Mary had their own views about TC’s sleeplessness. John, somewhat tartly (although he had been sympathetic enough to TC’s complaints of sleeplessness at Melchet), wrote: “I suffer a good deal myself in that way, & both Jamie at Scotsbrig, & Jean here also suffer; so I suppose there must be something of a family sort in the matter” (JAC to TC, 16 April 1869; see 43TC to JAC, 28 April 1869), putting TC’s sleeplessness firmly into the context of family tendencies. Mary Aitken shared her own interpretation of TC’s sleeplessness with Lady Ashburton (that TC slept too much in the evening) after TC’s return from Melchet: “We are fairly settled down here again & I think my Uncle looks much better than he did before going to Melchet—& he is sleeping pretty well. I think the great mistake he made at Melchet was transacting the most of his sleep before, instead of after, going to bed” (see 37TC to RSTFC, 12 April 1869). TC claimed some improvement during fall 1869; after taking a drug recommended by Dr. John Chapman, he wrote to John: “my sleep, I begin to really believe, seems to be on the improving hand. No drug swallowed for, I think, almost a fortnight now, and no night utterly bad” (TC to JAC, 12 [11] Nov. 1869).
But a few days later, he thought his sleep was more precarious, describing it humorously to Lady Ashburton: “My path (towards common Sleep) is like that of the Moslem Soul towards Paradise,—on the Edge of a Sword” (TC to LLA, 16 Nov. 1869). He was socially aware enough to understand that he owed Lady Ashburton a great debt for her attempts to help him to health as well as in other ways; writing to her after another stay at Melchet, February 1870, describing himself as “one whose real place now shd be the Hospital of Incurables,” acknowledging that “Melchet, I clearly perceive, has done me good, not harm; & good not bodily only: let that be a shadow of reward for yr immensity of trouble!” (TC to LLA, 23 Feb. 1870). But he continued complaining vociferously about his perceived lack of sleep.

TC’s main work during the months covered by this volume (other than collecting and editing JWC’s letters) was the preparation of the library edition of his Collected Works for publication; he complained about this project but nonetheless entered into it thoroughly. It had begun in 1868 (see 45:10TC to JAC, 16 July 1867), ending in 1871 with the final volumes of Frederick the Great (vols. 24–30 of the library edition). Chapman & Hall in 1868 was completing the publication of the uniform (cheap) edition of TC’s works with Frederick the Great (vols. 17–23, published 1869), but simultaneously was pushing ahead with work on the more up-market library edition. Forster, always protective and helpful to TC on business matters, produced a formal agreement between TC and Chapman & Hall, which TC and Frederic Chapman signed, and Forster witnessed, 29 April 1869. TC acknowledged his gratitude in his journal: “Today I meet Forster & Chapman, to sign Bargn of ‘Library Editn,’—good Fr takes inexpressible pains abt all that; strange really, and compelling thanks!” (29 April 1869; see 44TC to JAC, 28 April 1869; see also TC’s agreement with Frederic Chapman, 29 April 1869). From the continuing editions of TC’s works, he was clearly a successful author for Chapman’s; the agreement with Chapman makes clear exactly what TC was entitled to from this edition and how much his publications were an ongoing money maker, for TC as well as the publisher. During this volume (covering 1869–April 1870), TC was concerned with page proofs for the library edition’s earlier volumes. There was also much time given to possible illustrations: “‘plates for library Editn,’ much paltry trouble with that thrice-insignift matter” ([28 Sept. 1869]; see 81TC to LLA, 1 Oct. 1869). The apparently interminable procedure continued of sitting to George Frederic Watts for the portrait that had been commissioned by Forster specifically for one of the frontispieces. Originally intended for the very first volume of the library edition, Sartor Resartus (published early 1869; see 45:186–88TC to FC, [17 Oct. 1868]), it became the frontispiece to volume 1 of Critical and Miscellaneous Essays (see below). By November 1869, TC was complaining: “Proofsheets go on, and bother of Prints, of improved Watts Portrait &c &c; but there is nothing of real interest in all that to me . … Plenty of proofs of the world’s respect &c &c; … whh of course is
better than the opposite while I remain here, but is singularly grown a matter of indiffce too” (11 Nov. 1869; see 107TC to JAC, 12 [11] Nov. 1869). This shows that TC was quite aware of his reputation being sustained by continuing publication of new editions even though he was producing no new writings.

Watts’s struggle to produce a satisfactory portrait of TC had begun in June 1867 (see 44:209TC to GFW, 8 June 1867); his attempts were restarted in 1868, and TC continued sitting for him despite his many complaints about the painting and Watts himself (see 45:142TC to JAC, 30 May 1868, and 195TC to CPH,31 Oct. 1868). TC and Forster had faced the inevitable, late 1868, and used instead the reproduction of Elliott & Fry’s 1865 photograph of TC (that JWC had liked) for the frontispiece to Sartor Resartus. Watts’s struggle to produce a satisfactory portrait continued into 1869 with more complaints and criticisms from TC. TC wrote a note on a letter to Forster: “Watts’s Blotch-Portrait (‘last sitting’ to be, Friday next [15 or 22 Oct. 1869], 2½ p.m. to end at 4 forever).— So distracted a monster of Painting I have never seen before: ‘Cross betn’ a Lunatic & an Imposter—no fraction of me recognisable in it. Fie!” (see 87TC to MAI, 10 Oct. 1869). Watts’s ill-fated portrait was finally engraved for the frontispiece to volume 1 of Critical and Miscellaneous Essays (volume 6 of the library edition, 1869) (see TC to JAC, 6 March 1869, and 19). Famously, Watts painted three portraits of TC, possibly simultaneously, one with hands (now in the Victoria and Albert Museum; see 45:193TC to CPH, 31 Oct. 1868), commissioned by Forster for £150 (see 45:126–27TC to JF, 6 May 1868), another completed portrait, without hands (now in the National Portrait Gallery, London; see 45:140TC to JAC, 30 May 1868), and an unfinished portrait (now in the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford; see 45:frontispiece [Viewable in the CLO on the table of contents page for volume 45]). In all his references to and complaints about the sittings, TC only once referred to there being more than one portrait and even then it was an oblique reference. In March 1870, he wrote to John A. Carlyle about Amelia Robertson Hill’s bust of him (see 43:166TC to JWC, [5 and 8 April 1866]): “It is very considerably worse than Watts’s first Picture of me; & that is saying a grt deal” (see 167TC to JAC, 4 March 1870). This implies that he at least knew of the existence of a second portrait by Watts, presumably the other completed one. Most of his comments about the portrait were clearly made about the one Forster commissioned as TC makes them either to Forster himself or in his journal in relation to the portrait still not being ready for the intended frontispiece.

Chapman & Hall’s library edition is clearly part of TC’s legacy (just as JWC’s letters and memorials were to become her legacy), an assertion of his importance and continuing relevance to the cultural life of Britain (and the English speaking world generally) in the nineteenth century. TC’s own thoughts were turning to possible bequests. In December 1869, TC willingly complied with a request from Haddington for a set of his works for the town library, describing it in his journal as: “a Bequest from Her (‘the noblest Daughter Haddn ever bore!’)” (see 132TC to TK, 18 Dec. 1869). Another part of his own legacy was his decision (in
the course of this volume) to bequeath his accumulated library of books from the writing of Cromwell’s Letters and Speeches and Frederick the Great to a North American college. TC was particularly aware of this material at this time as he was preparing Cromwell for its new library edition (1870) and Frederick, first for its inclusion in the uniform (cheap) edition (1869) and then for the library edition (1870–71). He began formally discussing this book legacy, May 1869, with his new acquaintance, Charles Eliot Norton, who reported TC’s words:
div1.q: “I suppose there never was a man who had so much to do with books as I have, who owned so few. … But in writing about Cromwell and Friedrich I have chanced to get together some things not wholly worthless nor yet easy to find, and I’ve thought I should like when I die to leave these books to some institution in New England, where they might be preserved, and where they would serve as a testimony of my appreciation o’ the goodness o’ your people toward me and o’ the many acts o’ kindness they have done me; and perhaps you can help me to have this rightly done.” (Norton’s Letters 1:336)
div1.p: Norton suggested, 24 May 1869, “the Library of Harvard College, Cambridge, Massachusetts” as the most suitable beneficiary; TC wrote his assent on the reverse of Norton’s letter (see 49TC to JF, 26 May 1869) and proceeded to implement his plan in correspondence with Ralph Waldo Emerson and Norton over the following winter. He had Mary Aitken make two catalogues, one kept in Cheyne Row, the other sent to Emerson:
div1.q: For benefit of my Survivors and Representatives here, I retain an exact Copy of the Catalogue now put into yr keeping; so that everything may fall out square betn them and you, when the Time shall arrive. … [S]o soon as I hear from you that Harvard accepts my poor widow’s mite of a Bequest, I will proceed to put it down in due form, and so finish this small matter, whh for long years has hovered in my thots as a thing [I] shd like to do. (TC to RWE, 24 Feb. 1870)
div1.p: TC assumed that his legacy would be overseen by his younger and closest brother, John A. Carlyle:
div1.q:
I hope you will find everything clear as can be; and it is to you dear Brother (if you Survive me as is natl and desirable) that I trust for fulfilling everythg as if I were myself still here. … Accept my thanks while I can still give them!— To set my house in order, is surely very becoming,
now when I have as it were fairly ceased all working of the old sort. (TC to JAC, 19 March 1870)
div1.p: But, however well TC set his house in order, it was not to be John who carried out his wishes as John was to die before him in 1879. It was to be TC’s niece Mary Aitken (who had written the catalogue of the books) and Alexander Carlyle, by then her husband, who took charge of that responsibility. The material now makes up the extensive Harvard Carlyle Collection (HCC).

TC was less active socially from January 1869 to April 1870, his movements and activities apparently curtailed; nonetheless, as can be seen in his letters, he continued to think about trips he might take, tasks he might accomplish. He continued a pretense of living like a hermit, writing to Edward FitzGerald, “I am becoming a land hermit as much as you are a sea one” (31 Oct. 1869), and expressing resentment at intrusions on his time in person or by letter. His domestic life was now mainly organized by Mary Aitken; his housekeeper was still Sarah Warren who had one servant girl to help her. Where JWC had used TC’s life and the running of 5 Cheyne Row as material for her narratives, TC paid so little attention to it that it is hard to be sure even what the current servant girl was called; Jean Aitken referred to her as Charlotte in 1867, but it is not known whether she was still in the household 1869–70. Even trouble between Sarah Warren and Mary Aitken (presumably caused by a fear on Mrs. Warren’s part that Mary was accruing too much household power) was only referred to in passing by TC in his journal (20 Nov. 1869; see 114MAI to CAW, 19 Nov. 1869). Mary Aitken had come for a visit, fall 1868 (see 45:172TC to SWA, 17 Sep. 1868, and 177TC to JAC, 26 Sep. 1868), staying on to become TC’s main support and companion. As she wrote to a friend, February 1869: “I have been very busy all the time with copying. … I never went any further with my intention of going home (indeed you would be surprised how very many of my intentions I can not get accomplished); but have quietly remained at 5, Cheyne Row” (10 Feb. 1869; see 32TC to JAC, 20 March 1869). Presumably the family and she felt that life in London offered more opportunities for her than being a pupil teacher in Peebles, which she had been February–September 1867 (see 44:163TC to JCA, 24 Feb. 1867, and 45:35TC to JAC, 21 Sep. 1867). Living with her uncle provided her with a life plan, and, in due course, a life partner, as she was to marry, 1879, her Canadian cousin Alexander Carlyle, both of them remaining with TC until his death in 1881. From the start, she was made welcome by TC’s friends, part of his trips to Melchet, his dinners with the Forsters. Forster even used the same nickname for her as TC, “Child of Nature” (see 51TC to JAC, [5] June 1869). TC himself, clearly fond of her, seemed to cast her in a kind of substitute role (however inadequate) to JWC, mildly patronizing as he was; “You are a clever enough creature when you keep on the alert,” he wrote to her, 19 July 1869, while praising her to his friends: “my little Niece here is promptitude itself, and is so swift
and legible,—useful here as a cheerful rushlight in this now sombre element, sombre, sad, but also beautiful and tenderly solemn more & more, in whh she bears me company, good little ‘Mary’!” (TC to RWE, 24 Feb. 1870). While TC may have been casting her into the role of a supportive or submissive young relative, whom he saw as there to help him in his declining years, there are signs that Mary had her own character and opinions, with social outings independent from TC, including visits to JWC’s old friends the Reichenbachs and their children (who were near to her in age). In that same letter to a friend (who, according to the letter, knew Geraldine Jewsbury), Mary wrote of one of her visits to the Reichenbach household:
div1.q: We were going to have a very pleasant evening a good many young ladies & one remarkable green young gentleman; but I most unfortunately did not know there were to be any others so had told Uncle I would be back early & came off about nine. I was very much disappointed not to hear Miss Rh sing. They were most kind and I liked them very well. Didn’t you think Reichenbach Jr. a handsome youth?!! There was a girl there who monopolized him however most effectually. (10 February 1869; MS: Harry Ransom Center, Univ. of Texas)
div1.p: She also told her friend that she had attended John Ruskin’s lecture at the Royal Institution, “The Flamboyant Architecture of the Valley of the Somme” (29 Jan. 1869; see TC to LLA, 9 Feb. 1869).

In his life as in his writings, TC was seen as powerfully exaggerated in his style and effects, described as such by reviewers, readers, visitors, friends, and JWC. His journals contain flashes of self-knowledge; he wrote in his journal, 14 March 1870, about a visit to Broadlands: “I really was wild of tongue; a barbarous sincerity in me, clean agt polite rule” (see 160TC to LLA, 23 Feb. 1870); and, during April 1870, he saw himself as others saw him, describing himself: “T. Spedding is here; walk with him last week; my style of talk to him, so fierce, exaggerative, scornful of surrounding men and things is painful to me to think of now” (1 May 1870; see 198). But what this description misses (as readings of TC’s works can also miss), was the exaggerated humor that could accompany his wild pronouncements. It is probable that, as he entered into his last full decade, he felt that there was little laughter in his life, but nonetheless in face of the sharp humor that still existed in his letters, it is unlikely that TC as a companion, “fierce, exaggerative, scornful” as he might be, was completely lacking in humorous satire or even laughter. This volume may show TC’s strong sense of himself as declining in health and powers, but nonetheless his letters show him as vigorously engaged with his publications (even though no longer writing new works), aware of his sense of grief over the loss of JWC, but using
it to drive his collecting and editing of her letters, his final memorial to her, as well as fully engaged with his friendship circles, however much he might complain about their demands. The volume, in the appendices of her letters, also gives us a reminder of the amusement and engagement shown by JWC with her life.

div1.p: January. TC complains of sleeplessness and the difficulty of writing with his right hand, which now trembles. He writes to his brother John A. Carlyle about possible remedies for their health problems. He is reading Robert Browning (11). He thanks Z. J. Piérart for the Drame de Waterloo (18), and William Denovan for The Temple of Isis (19). TC writes (20) a dedication for John Forster on his copy of the new library edition of Sartor (11).

February. TC writes James Syme to console him in bereavement (5) and to Lady Ashburton promising to try and help elect a friend of hers to the Athenæum Club (9). TC sends money to John A. Carlyle to send to their half-brother, John, in Canada (9). He thanks Thomas Erskine (11) for visiting Betty Braid in Edinburgh, and tells him he has spontaneously returned to the Lord’s Prayer to console him in his sleeplessness. He helps Friedrich Althaus with annotations in his translations of Frederick (12). Maggie Welsh arrives for a month’s stay in Chelsea (16). TC continues to be involved in the controversy over Governor Eyre; he writes to Eyre (20) with encouragement, but declines to attend any meetings of the committee defending him.

March. TC declines the Border Counties Association’s invitation to take part in the Sir Walter Scott Centenary celebrations (2). He has an audience with Queen Victoria (4) arranged by Lady Augusta Stanley: “it is impossible to imagine a politer little woman” (11). He complains to his brother John of ill health, but makes progress with Charles Robson the printer in proofreading and preparing the library edition of his Works (6). He writes a full description of his royal meeting to his sister Jean Aitken (11). He thanks Richard Herne Shepherd, who has been copying some of TC’s early essays from magazines (15), and sends money to James Aitken Jr. to help the Baillie family (16). He writes courteously to J. S. Mill, returning books, though they have been estranged for many years (16). TC agrees to meet Charles Eliot Norton, telling Tyndall: “I am far from disliking Americans that are likeable” (20); they met in the evening (22).

April. TC spends a week with Lady Ashburton at Melchet Court (2–10). Sleepless and with a shaking hand, he complains to his brother John about health, but proposes they send money to Canada for their sister Jenny Hanning (15). He writes to the artist Joseph Henderson about a portrait, from photographs,
of JWC (23). He writes John (28) about mortality, the deaths of Syme’s wife in Edinburgh and Tom Stewart in Dumfriesshire, and about Dickens narrowly escaping death due to exhaustion from overwork. In his journal he also mentions other friends, dead and dying, and the anniversary of JWC’s death. Mary Aitken goes to Liverpool to see her brother James, sister Margaret, and mother, Jean Aitken, who is also visiting there (22–30).

May. Mary Aitken and Maggie Welsh are both working on copying JWC’s letters. TC asks his brother John to check his annual bank statement (6). Watts’s portrait of TC is engraved for the frontispiece of Critical and Miscellaneous Essays; he calls it “decidedly the most unsufferable ‘Picture’ of me there has yet been.” Sir Arthur Buller dies. TC has been reading the life of Sir William Hamilton, another old friend. He congratulates Forster on his life of Landor; Maggie Welsh leaves Chelsea (26).

June. TC writes his brother John about his poor health and sleeplessness; with Maggie Welsh gone, the spare room is now available, and he invites his brother to come to London for a holiday. Froude is going to Ireland (5).

July. TC tells his brother John he has received a miniature of Frederick, and that Tauchnitz has reprinted Life of Schiller. Lady Ashburton talks of TC holidaying at Addiscombe (3). He thanks William Fraser for a handsome present of books (8) and sends two photographs of JWC to Betty Braid in Edinburgh on JWC’s birthday (14). He and Mary spend a day in Addiscombe (14) in preparation for a longer visit. He thanks his brother John for reporting on affairs at Craigenputtoch and tells him that with Mary’s help he hopes to complete his “sad task” of editing JWC’s surviving letters “before many weeks” (15). TC leaves for Addiscombe for a holiday (18), returns to London (22), then goes back to Addiscombe with Mary (28). He writes Betty Braid in Edinburgh to thank her for sending some of JWC’s letters (22).

August. TC and Mary return to Chelsea (7). Brother John arrives in Chelsea to visit (16). TC writes to Ruskin inviting him to visit and praising his Queen of the Air (17). He writes Lady Ashburton (who is on a tour in Scotland) about arrangements for cataloguing her books in Melchet (19). He thanks young James Aitken for taking care of his money-gift to Mrs. Baillie (22). TC, John, Mary, and the two Chelsea servants, go to Addiscombe for a holiday (30).

September. TC thanks Isabella Simmonds for the loan of some letters of JWC’s, which he has had copied (4). From Addiscombe he writes Froude (who is in Ireland) complaining of sleeplessness and unwillingness to make long journeys; he tells him that Ruskin has visited, and that he has “a ray of real Heaven” in him (14). Lady Ashburton is in Lochluichart; she had considered selling the property, but decided against it. The party return to Chelsea
(20) from Addiscombe, “a Hermitage whh is & was so like Elysian for a sick soul” (15).

October. TC tells Lady Ashburton he has had plaster casts made of his hands under Woolner’s direction “in obedience to yr imperial command” (1). John is still in Chelsea. TC urges Ruskin to visit at Chelsea. TC visits the Princess of Waldeck (7), whom he met at Menton. Mary Aitken goes home to Dumfries, early Oct., where her brother Tom is gravely ill (7). TC contacts Tennyson with an enquiry from Margaret Oliphant; and writes inviting her to call in Chelsea (8). Tom Aitken dies 13 Oct. (15). The Watts painting of TC has one last sitting (15). John A. Carlyle goes home to Dumfries (21). TC writes Mary Aitken telling her not to hurry, but to come back to Chelsea when family conditions permit, and wondering if her mother, Jean, might also benefit from a visit to London (19). He tells John he is “very gloomy and lonely” but has been saved from sleeplessness by a sleeping draught from a Dr. Chapman (23). TC dines with the Forsters (24), and Watts visits (25) to ask for one more sitting (28). TC tells Anthony Sterling that the engraving of the John Sterling portrait is “tolerable” (31).

November. Mary returns from Dumfries (2). TC offers £10 for a testimonial to Syme in Edinburgh arranged by Charles Murchison, but declines the offer to attend the public meeting (9). Thomas Ballantyne visits (11). Lady Ashburton takes TC to visit Lady William Russell (11) “where I have long been due.” TC thanks Lady Ashburton for a present of grouse, but declines her invitation to visit, pleading sleeplessness as an excuse (16). He thanks his sister Jean for arranging for clothes to be made for him and sends money for her to give to Wilhelmina Cunningham (16). After a three-year gap he writes to R. W. Emerson and on the same day to Charles Eliot Norton to propose bequeathing his books on Cromwell and Frederick the Great to Harvard Library. TC and Mary visit the Forsters (22). He thanks Charles Appleton of Oxford for sending him a book to review but refuses (23), and sends Charles Murray information about a portrait and quotation from Goethe (23). He wants Forster’s permission to photograph a rare print of Cromwell (29).

December. TC continues to try to organize illustrations for the Library Edition of his collected works (2). In addition to sleeplessness he complains to his brother John of a “disordered interior,” and tells him of his offer of a bequest of books to Harvard (10). He thanks Lady Ashburton for presents of game (17). Illustrations for the new edition continue to take much of TC’s time and energy. He sends a copy of his collected works to the Town Council of Haddington as a memorial of JWC (18). He writes his sister Jean in Dumfries with a new-year gift, and reassures her that the trouble between Mary and Mrs. Warren seems to be improving (22). He thanks Kenneth R. H. Mackenzie
for his translation of a life of Bismarck (29). Ruskin writes (30) asking to visit with a young relative “tomorrow” (31).

January. TC writes (1) to wish his brother John a good new year, complaining of intermittent sleeplessness and dark wintry weather. He and Mary “dined at Forster’s (perforce) on Xmas.” He is still concerned with choosing pictures for the library edition. He writes again to Emerson about plans for his Harvard bequest, and thanks him for sending his recent book (4). He forwards Norton’s letter to his brother John and talks of the recent letter from their brother Alick in Canada; he and Mary are to dine at the Froudes with Ruskin “no help for it” the following day (6). He writes to thank Althaus for a present of his book on Britain (7) and to Daniel Wilson for his life of Chatterton (10). He sends an affectionate letter to Alick in Canada bemoaning the state of “this wretched blockhead & beggar of a world.” He finds writing very difficult and dictation to Mary still clumsy (12). He thanks John Hunter for the present of a book (14) and hesitates over Lady Ashburton’s invitation to Melchet Court (18). He writes his brother John (22) that life for him is “empty and stagnant,” and he finds “neither strength nor heart for work.” He and Mary are to dine with Forster and Dickens the next day (23). Mary is helping to find a governess for Lady Ashburton’s daughter. He writes John that his “lame hand hinders all free writing” and restricts him to proofreading and very little letter-writing. He found Dickens “very cheery” though showing signs of “some permant nervous damage” from his U.S. reading tour (28).

February. TC and Mary go to Melchet Court (6) with Lady Ashburton, and TC enjoys riding in the country air. He thanks Emerson for his letter and is pleased that he and Norton are in agreement on “that small Harvard matter.” He asks Emerson to express to Norton his “lively gratitude” (14). Back in Chelsea, he writes Lady Ashburton to thank her for two weeks’ holiday in Melchet Court. Caroline Davenport Bromley calls (23). He formalizes with Emerson the arrangement for the bequest of his books, sending him a copy of the catalog (24). He writes to thank the author of The Collier’s Widow (28).

March. TC thanks Norton for all his help in arranging the Harvard bequest (2). Writing to John who is visiting Edinburgh, TC sends his best wishes to Thomas Erskine, who has been unwell, dismisses John Hill Burton as a historian, sends good wishes to David Masson, and derides Amelia Robertson Hill’s bust of him (6 [4]). He vigorously denies a suggestion he is a “pantheist” (7). He is arranging for a “vignette” of Cromwell’s death mask (8) and is enjoying Casimir Maremma, sent to him by Arthur Helps (8). He thanks Josephine Shaw Lowell for sending Harvard Memorial Biographies (10). He tells John about a dinner at the Forsters and his meeting with Sir George Grey, ex-Governor of New Zealand (15). He sends John a letter received from
Norton and mourns the approaching death of Erskine (19). Still working on illustrations for Cromwell, he thanks Frederick Anderson for his pencil sketch with its “force and spirit,” though he questions its accuracy (20 [19]). Thomas Erskine dies (20). TC writes to reassure Emerson after an accident had delayed the U.S. mail from Britain (24). He thanks Sir William Stirling Maxwell for his “beautiful, I might say splendid, Book” (24). TC writes Sir George Grey (25), reporting his discussions with Lord Derby on emigration and suggesting Grey visit Lord Derby to discuss more fully the whole question. Mary writes to Maria Henshaw (previously Maria Price) regretting that TC cannot find copying work for her sister and telling her that “one of my brothers is here” (James Jr.) and is just leaving (28). TC writes again (30) to wish Lord Grey success in the Newark by-election where he is standing on the emigration question.

April. TC writes to a young man discouraging him from taking up a career in literature (1). He tells John of his walk with Tennyson (2). He visits a dentist for an extraction (4 and 5), and he is anxious to see Lady Ashburton before she leaves London (5). He writes Emerson (6) concluding the arrangements for the Harvard bequest, and urging there should be no publicity. He writes David Davidson in Haddington thanking him for sending details of the death of Erskine and telling him that Betty Braid had also sent him an obituary (7). He tells John about his tooth extraction and says that “roaring London has got very loud again … though I cannot say it contains almost anything I care much abt.” He reports that the previous day Lady Ashburton had taken him and Mary driving, to Norwood and Dulwich, and that Peter Swan of Kirkcaldy had called, that Emilie Venturi is coming that evening, and Erasmus Darwin and Frances Wedgwood the following day (12). TC writes to hurry the engraver who is copying Cromwell’s death mask (13). Letters come from Canada, and TC suggests to John that they might help finance their younger relatives there. He walks unwillingly with Allingham and Tait in Hyde Park on the anniversary of JWC’s death (21). The warmer weather disagrees with TC’s health (22). He continues to have trouble with Chapman over prints for the library edn. TC walks with Thomas Spedding in the last week of April. He contemplates a holiday with sea air to improve his health (29).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 11 Jan. MS: NLS 526.85. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I have got yr various messages, all punctually, many thanks; and must at last send some word of ansr;—shd have done so, and wd, long ago, had my hand &c been more compellable or less unwilling!TC now suffered from a shaky right hand; see 45:179TC to CDB, 4 Oct. 1868.— Except the miserable story of my sleeplessness, continuing with only one week of interval for nearly 3 months, I had indeed almost nothing to say; and that may be some excuse for me; such a thing being fitter silence, so wretched was it and at the same time so incapable of help from those who had pitied me most!— — I dare not yet brag; but am very thankful to report on that head that, once more, the worst seems to be over. For a good few nights, I have not had one of the old intolerable type; go to bed with less and less terror; and indeed, for 4 or 5 nights past, have had little or nothing of that nervous shivering & palpitatg, whh is the soul of the misery, tenfold worse than any other feature of it. Let us hope, this is ended or ending, and things got to their old level with me agn. Not a very high level;—but might so easily be lower, and ever lower, to such depths as we know there are!— You too, it appears, have been having a bout of this, in yr fashion;Jean Aitken wrote, 1 Feb.: “The Dr has not been so well as usual. Slept very ill for some time & was guy ill to do with, but seems to be a good deal better of late. He wants nothing said about it.” and I am very glad you too have discovered what the ways of “charcoal” are (a false friend as it appears to me),TC had tried charcoal for his digestive problems; see 44:195–96TC to JAC, 11 May 1867. John A. Carlyle wrote, 13 Dec. 1868: “The full teaspoonful of Brandy, added to that small dose of charcoal … seems to prevent the harrowing sensation in the lower bowels which charcoal leaves behind it,” adding that this method seemed to work for himself (MS: NLS 1775C.292). or at any rate, have got yr enemy too cast out for the prest. To be careful, careful, & to take plenty of exercise: I find no other recipe at all. Of Woolmer’sJoseph Benson Woolmer (1827–75), surgeon, of 71 Warwick Sq., Pimlico; TC had consulted him recently; see 45:215TC to JAC, 22 Dec. 1868. many suggestns (whh I reckoned wise in their kind) there turns out to be only one that I can follow out:—that of “12 camomile flowers put in a tumbler of cold water for 24 hours,” and then drunk in the morng as a kind of bitter!An infusion of chamomile flowers, often prescribed to aid sleep and helpful for anxiety and stomach disorders. This at least does me no ill (I think, but am not quite sure even of this); “variatn of diet” I think really good, too, and wd fain try farther, but alas, can’t contrive: all his other appliances (especially “camphor julep,”Camphor julep, made by mixing camphor with sweetened wine, spirits, or water, was also used to aid stomach disorders. whh I thot for three or 4 nights was
a beautifl & sovereign thing) I have had to renounce utterly; and now depend, like poor Susie Hawkins,Presumably Susanna Hawkins (1787–1868; ODNB), poet, da. of John Hawkins, blacksmith at Burnswark, nr. Ecclefechan; she had lived at Relief, Hoddam parish, near her brother Ben Hawkins (b. ca. 1782), also a blacksmith; see 9:285TC to JAC, 12 Aug. 1837. “joost on pure Natur.” Camphor might perhaps have some chance with you, who are stronger, or with Jean? Their sister Jean Aitken. I take it to be far safer than any form of opium or such things; once or twice it seemed to be, not a sedative only, but a glorious carminative too,—hope treacherous, as usual, on the 3d trial or 4th. No medicamt is simpler, at any rate— But we will say no more of these things; no more, for very shame!

Chapn is coming out with the “first vol of Libry Editn” on Friday 15th;Chapman & Hall, TC’s publisher, was publishing the library edn. of TC’s works; see 45:10TC to JAC, 16 July 1867. Vol. 1 (pbd. 15 Jan.) was Sartor Resartus, with a frontispiece of Joseph Brown’s engraving of Elliott & Fry’s April 1865 photograph of TC (see 42:frontispiece and 45:127TC to JF, 6 May 1868, and 186–88TC to JF, [17 Oct. 1868]). John Forster wrote, 17 Jan.: “On Friday I went to Frederick Chapman’s—and thought the Library ‘Sartor’ altogether a most satisfactory start. A very handsome type & volume. I was much pleased with it.” TC gave Forster a copy of this edn., writing on the fly-leaf: “To John Forster Esqre. (Palace-Gate House), my ever-helpful friend,—without whom this Editn, and much else, had never been: gratefully, T. Carlyle, Chelsea 20 Jany. 1869” (FC 1380; pbd: Forster Collection. A Catalogue of the Printed Books Bequeathed by John Forster, Esq. LL.D [1888]; CSA 31 [2015/16]:43). Forster wrote, 24 Jan.: “How much I should be affected by the words you have written on my “Sartor” you will know—happily for me, as I could hardly succeed in telling you.” Robson is on Voll. 7 & 8,Charles Robson, TC’s printer. Vols. 7 and 8 were part of Critical and Miscellaneous Essays, vols. 6–11 of the library edn.—sent me 8 sheets Saty last, whh is as much as I want weekly. Forster has taken his Wife to Torquay (But I will inclose him).Presumably a letter from John Forster. On his return Forster wrote, 17 Jan.: “[B]oth of us better: the smaller one [Eliza, his wife] not so decidedly as the bigger: though, since our return, the smaller has had the advantage.” The wind is easterly since yesty morning; perhaps the dry will suit us better than the wet has done. I walk daily, with punctuality; 3 out of 4 times, alone, whh is the mournful best, in genl. Am reading Browning’s new “Poem”Robert Browning, The Ring and the Book (1868–69); it was pbd. in 4 vols. from Nov. 1868–Feb. 1869. at nights; I told him (to his amazet & chagrin) one day, “No son of Adam had ever written Poem or Book on such a plan before.” Wedded to his idols; let him alone! I am now got to my real task,The collecting and annotating of JWC’s letters; see 45:71–72TC to RST, 30 Nov. 1867, 196–97TC to JAC, [ca. 4 Nov. 1868], and 215–16TC to JAC, 22 Dec. 1868.—actually busy with it; as MaryTheir niece Mary Aitken returned to London with TC, Sept. 1868; see 45:177TC to JAC, 26 Sept. 1868, and 189TC to LLA, 18 Oct. 1868; she was helping with copying JWC’s letters; see 45:207MAI to MEW, 3 Dec. 1868. is & has been,“[B]een” repeated with a line over it at turn of page. —and does it very well. A good little Child; nothing can be more assiduous, cheerful, faithful: universally a favte (tell her Mother from me). A
Book is coming, heavy Volume “on Mines”The “heavy Volume ‘on Mines’” is unidentified. for Jas Aitken;James Aitken, their brother-in-law. Mary is just gone with it to Chapns,Chapman & Hall had a regular book delivery to Edinburgh; see TC to JAC, 3 Nov. railway to bring it from Edinrside this week. Blessings to all. Yrs everT. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Z-JP [ZJP], 18 Jan. Pbd: Shepherd, Carlyle 2:280–82. Zephyr-Joseph Piérart (1818–79), psychical researcher and spiritualist, prof. of the College of Mauberge, founder and editor of La Revue Spiritualiste 1859–64.
div3.head: TC TO ZEPHYR-JOSEPH PIÉRART

docBody.p: I duly received you[r]Drame de Waterloo, and have to return you my thanks for your kindness in that matter.Piérart sent TC a copy of his Le Drame de Waterloo: Grande Restitution Historique (Paris, 1868), 16 Dec. 1868. He wrote: “If, as I hope, reading this gives you pleasure … I would be very happy to receive … an acknowledgement in the form of a letter in your own hand” (ed.’s trans.). Piérart sent the book in thanks for his great enjoyment of TC’s French Revolution (1837).

I have read the book with not a little interest: it brings before me again with a strange vividness, and with a new precision and certainty of details, the final scenes of a very great ‘drama,’ which acted itself in my young mind fifty years ago,Presumably the ending of the Napoleonic wars with the battle of Waterloo, 1815. TC wrote a poem on Napoleon, 1822, in response to a poem of JBW’s; see 2:109TC to JBW, [ca. 17 May 1822], and 114JBW to TC, [25 May 1822]; now untraced. and is still one of the new epochs of the world’s history.

I recognise especially your love of accuracy and certainty, your great outlay of research and studious examination, laborious reading of documents, otherwise repulsive rather than interesting;—and in result I can report to you my clear conviction:

1. That Napoleon’s campaign ended in four days so tragically for him, by Napoleon’s own mismanagement, by the fact, which you have rendered evident, that he was hébété [stupefied, numb], sunk in somnolence, negligence, and not himself any more.Piérart wrote that his purpose in writing his book was to refute Napoleon’s lies: “I prove that he alone deserves blame for the disaster and not, as he has claimed, his lieutenants, or the fates, or treachery” (ed.’s trans.). Describing Napoleon on the eve of the battle of Waterloo, Piérart quoted from Lazare Carnot’s Mémoires: “[I]l est devenu somnolent, lui qui savait dormir et s’éveiller à volonté [He has become somnolent, this man who knew how to sleep and how to awake of his own will]” (Piérart 222). Lazare Carnot (1753–1823), French politician and engineer.

2. That in subsequent times he, with unconscious and now and then with conscious mendacity, endeavoured to lay the blame on others—Grouchy, Ney,Emmanuel de Grouchy (1766–1847), 2d marquis of Grouchy, French general and marshal, commander of the reserve cavalry of the French army at Waterloo; Michel Ney (1769–1815), duc d’ Elchingen, French marshal, commander of the left wing of the French army at Waterloo. &c., and has now, as his fate was, been convicted of that sad offence, and will have to pay the penalty before the whole world.

In young years, especially in the Hudson Lowe time,Sir Hudson Lowe (1769–1844; ODNB), army officer and colonial governor, governor of Saint-Helena, 1816–21, responsible for guarding Napoleon. Because Napoleon had previously escaped from Elba, Lowe kept him very strictly confined, which at the time TC thought unnecessarily cruel; see 2:154TC to JBW, [ca. 1 Aug. 1822]. I was greatly an admirer of the Great Napoleon; but I confess, for a long while back, the essential mendacity, egoism, charlatanism, of his procedure and relation to the world, have been more and more apparent to me, and the greatness of him, even as a soldier, been steadily diminishing. ‘A great General?’ as Kleber said: ‘Ah, yes! a very great General—a General of 10,000 a month! Ce petit coquin [the little rascal], no bigger than my boot!’“[Kléber] n’avait pas craint de condamner Bonaparte lui-même une impatience qui prodiguait le sang des braves; il l’avait appelé un général à 10,000 hommes par semaine [He was not afraid of criticizing Bonaparte himself for impatience, which had cost the lives of many brave men; he referred to him as the general of 10,000 men a week]” (Claude Desprez, Kléber et Marceau [Paris, 1857] 219); Jean-Baptiste Kléber (1753–1800), French general, who accompanied Napoleon in the Egyptian campaign, 1798–99; François-Séverin Marceau (1769–96), also a general in the French revolutionary wars.
With many thanks and good wishes,
docBody.closer: I remain, dear Sir, Yours sincerely, T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-WD [WDE], 19 Jan. Addr: 2017 Franklin Street / Philadelphia / U.S. PM: London, 19 Jan. 1869. MS: photocopy, source untraced; most of the letter is written in Mary Aitken’s hand. Pbd: American Scotsman (date unknown); Western Daily Express, 19 Oct. 1869; Spiritual Magazine, Nov. 1869: 519–20; Shepherd, Carlyle 2:282–84. William Denovan (1836–1912), born in Aberdeen, emigrated to Philadelphia, U.S., about 1856; Swedenborgian philosopher and author.
div3.head: TC TO [WILLIAM DENOVAN]

docBody.p: At last I receive your pamphlet:Denovan’s The Temple of Isis ([Philadelphia, 1868]); see 45:201TC to WDE, 24 Nov. 1868. and have read it, with what attention and appreciation I could bestow.

Considerable faculties of mind are manifested in it: powers of intellect, of imagination; a serious earnest character; here and there a tone of sombre eloquence, and vestiges of real literary skill. But my constant regret was, and is, to see such powers operating in a field palpably chaotic, and lying beyond the limits of man’s intelligence! These are not thoughts which you give; they are huge gaunt vacant dreams,—for ever incapable by nature, of being either affirmed or denied.

My clear advice, therefore, would be, Give up all that; refuse to employ your intellect on things where no intellect can avail; to sow good seed on realms of mere cloud and shadow! The highest intellect which issues in no certainty has completely failed. The world of practice and fact is the true arena for its inhabitants; wide enough for any or for all intellects of men;—and never lay more encumbered with sordid darkness, and pernicious delusions, than even now. Real intellect might write with advantage on such things;—better still perhaps, it might remain silent, and bend its whole force on illuminating one’s own poor path in such a wilderness; on more and more clearly ascertaining, for at least one earnest man, What to do, and How to do it.Denovan replied, 17 Oct.: “I have taken the liberty of giving publication to the kind letter you sent me, feeling assured that as it has benefitted me, so it would many others. … When I received it I was struck with its truth—it was the sudden revelation of what only otherwise a long lost regretful time might have caused to dawn upon me. I at once determined to act upon your advice—if there can be little intellectual use, there shall be no intellectual waste. My debt is beyond any expression of gratitude.” TC wrote on the reverse of Denovan’s letter: “Denovan self; no ‘Paper’ come (Ohe, jam satis [enough of this]!).”

ProbablyFrom “Probably” the letter is in TC’s hand. you will not adopt this advice, almost certainly not at once; nor shall that disaffect me at all. Yr Tract I found throughout to be rather pleast reading, and to have certn interest: nothing in it, except one small Sectn, treating of a thing I never mention unless when compelled,—the thing whh calls itself “Spiritualism” (& whh might more fitly beFrom “be” to “wishes,” the letter is in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature at the end. called “Ul[t]ra-brutalism,” and “Liturgy of Dead-Sea Apes”)—was disagreeable to me.TC was sent a clipping of the letter printed in Western Daily Express, 19 Oct., by George Tommy, 23 Oct., with a question as to whether he had ever investigated “the phenomena of modern Spiritualism”; see TC to GT, [25 Oct.].

div3.sourceNote: TC-JS [JSY], 5 Feb. Pbd: Robert Paterson, Memorials of the Life of James Syme (Edinburgh, 1874) 292–93; Scotsman, 16 Feb. 1874; Shepherd, Carlyle 2:284–85. Text: Paterson.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES SYME

docBody.p: My heart is sore for you, ever since that lamentable news arrived.James Syme’s wife, Jemima, d. at their home, Millbank House, Edinburgh, 1 Feb. She had been ill for some time (see 45:196TC to JAC, [ca. 4 Nov. 1868]) with disease of the ovaries. Their son James Syme Jr. wrote, 3 Feb. to tell TC of the death. Oh, what a loss, what a loss!—the brightness of your life, as it were, suddenly extinguished,—changed into mournful memories,—unspeakably mournful,—though, by degrees (if you could believe me) beautiful too, and even blessed! A loss to you meanwhile which is immeasurable and irremediable. Alas! alas! I myself, little did I think it was the last I was to see of that bright, affectionate, beneficent, and noble spirit, in this world.TC stayed with the Symes in Edinburgh after his hernia operation; see 45:161TC to JF, 2 Aug. 1868.
I judge well you will rally yourself, and bear in silence, like a brave man, the inexorable and inevitable; but it is sore to flesh and blood. May God bless you and keep you!

Words of condolence, I know sufficiently, are idle, often almost worse, and I will add no more of them. I wished you to understand that perhaps no one of your many friends more deeply sympathises in this saddest of events.Syme replied, 8 Feb.: “What you say is too true—I feel indeed that the light of my life has gone out. … I am very grateful for your letter—which I value as a tribute to [Jemima Syme] who I believe was as near to perfection as any human being can be”; TC wrote on the envelope: “Syme (alas, for him too!) ‘’ 3 feby 1869”; he sent the letter on to John A. Carlyle, writing on it: “(Keep, or return).” —Yours ever truly,

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 9 Feb. MS: NLS 526.86. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Accept this wretchedest of Letters: it is all I can do for the three or 4 you have kindly sent;—all, in the utter hurry &c I am in!—

I clearly believe, Brr JohnJohn Carlyle, their half-brother, farmer in Canada. “will be the better for £10,”—or even for £20; poor old soul, in the Canada solitudes, after his long toilings: he will soon be incapable of receiving anything from us, we of giving him anything. I inclose here another draft for £10, if you will please to negociate & send it, along
with yr own, or by itself, if you have not determined upon that for Thursday coming.John A. Carlyle wrote, 7 Feb., that their brother Jamie had been visiting, and they had read him “Alick’s last letter to you, Brother John’s to Jean. He thinks John is most likely rather hard up, supposes £10 might do him good & increase his comfort in his solitary old days. He is now not far from 80, & I feel also that such a sum might be useful to him & shall probably send it by the post of Thursday first which is the Canada post day.” TC recorded in his checkbook: “9 feby 1869 / to Dr Carlyle (for old Brr John) / £10 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). John A. Carlyle replied, 12 Feb.: “I sent off the £20 to our brother John on Thursday last, & think it can hardly fail to be of some use to him in his solitary old age.” This is the sole errand of my Letter; and beyond this it has not a word to say just now. It is literally, except three shaky lines to poor Syme (whose unexpected ansr I inclose,—poor cut-down man!), it is the one Note I have written for weeks. Cdn’t write, and even the hand wd not,—pestering me greatly in my poor work;Presumably his work collecting and annotating JWC’s letters. scarcely a week sufficing for the “work” of a day or day-and-half!— I have not yet got anything written even to Erskine: pray explain to him if you write agn.Both TC and John A. Carlyle corresponded with Thomas Erskine, and they sent each other Erskine’s letters to read. Erskine wrote to TC, 25 Jan.: “I have not seen or heard of the Doctor for a long time. I suppose however that he is still in his old quarters near Dumfries—& engaged in his old pursuits.”

Add to all whh, I have another Note to write today (see Ly Ashbn inclosed); and, and,—I lost all my sleep last night (2½ hours net my allowance, and zero afternoon before),—tho I am not so very miserable as often, in that predict!

Item Maggie Welsh is coming this day week.Tues. 16 Feb. Maggie Welsh wrote, 11 Jan., with reports on all the family she had seen recently; she had left her brother Walter in Auchtertool in Dec., visited her sister Jeannie Chrystal in Glasgow before traveling to Liverpool to stay with her brother Alick and family at Sandown Park, Wavertree. While there, she crossed the Mersey to Birkenhead to visit Margaret Aitken, now living with James Aitken Jr. She told TC: “It is very kind of you dear Mr Carlyle bidding me to come to Chelsea. … [I]t will be a great pleasure to me to have a peep at Chelsea & you again.” “For one calendar month,” I endeavd to make poz;Word unexplained; possibly a badly written “less.”— cdn’t quite be off altogr!
Mary is well, and cheery and useful. Good be with you all, you dear and kind one. Affectely ever,—The signature has been cut off.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 9 Feb. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I will endeavour to do my duty in the matter of “C. ChambersCharles Harcourt Chambers (1826–76), political writer and translator. He had originally been entered for membership of the Athenæum Club, 19 May 1857; a ballot was held 22 Feb. He received 175 votes for and 5 blackballs, and was duly elected. Lady Ashburton had been asked by her sister, Mary Frances Anstruther (1819–1913), to enlist TC’s help (28 Jan.; MS: NLS Acc. 11388), but TC did not sign Chambers’s ballot certificate. TC himself had been nominated by Lord Ashburton and accepted, March 1853; see 28:74TC to MAC, 12 March 1853. on the 18th”; if he is a gentn of fair exterior, distinguished for nothing (whh we will not hope), he has nothing to fear there; if not, there is liability to something! Lowe was blackballed,Robert Lowe (1811–92; ODNB; see 28:195TC to JWC, 9 July 1853), politician, leader writer for the Times 1851–68, chancellor of the exchequer 1868–73. He was twice entered for membership of the Athenæum Club, but was blackballed in a vote, 8 March 1858; he eventually was elected to the club, 15 Dec. 1868. for example; item an excellt Candidate of my own proposing,TC nominated John Rutter Chorley (1806–67; ODNB; see 19:135TC to JWC, [early Aug. 1845], 22:30TC to JAC, 8 Aug. 1847, and 45:1TC to JAC, 1 July 1867), poet and scholar of Spanish literature, for membership of the Athenæum Club, Feb. 1866, but Chorley was blackballed; see 43:122–23TC to JRU, 14 Feb. 1866. my first there, who is to be my last too, for endless time!

There exists no excellt or really good French History, of many that I have tried or even read,—Except President Hénault’s Abrégé Chronologique de l’Histr de &cCharles Jean François Hénault, Nouvel abrégé chronologique de l’histoire de France, 3 vols. (Paris, 1774); for TC’s copy, see 7:22JC to JSM, 28 Oct. 1833, and Carlyle’s House 78. (above 100 years old now, often edited, and full of real pith, exactitude and insight; three very small hand-volumes,—really worth yr having, if you have it not. For little MaryMary Florence Baring, Lady Ashburton’s da. at prest I fear it might be too abstruse,—unless indeed you were preceptorially reading it with her; in whh case, not at all!— Perhaps yr best resource for her will be Sismondi; his big Book (not very very big either, 2 thick voll. I think) on that subject, and along therewith, or by itself if you prefer, the “Précis,” whh he himself made of it, in one vol.Jean Charles Léonard de Sismondi, Histoire des Français (1821–44) and Précis de l’histoire des Français (1839). See also 1:259–60TC to MAL, 7 June 1820, and 2:115TC to JBW, 27 May 1822. One or both of these, will probably be yr best.—

I am terribly ill off for sleep, now & then; busy also exceedingly, so far as weak strength reaches,—hand also very shaky and mutinous. I have not written one line (for many weeks past) whh was not indispensable,—like this, e.g.

Maggie Welsh is coming;Maggie Welsh was staying with her brother Alick in Liverpool; see TC to JAC, 9 Feb. joins the Child of NatureTC’s nickname for Mary Aitken. and me this day week, “feby 16”;—stays “for one month.” So that till “march 16” there can be nothing
of Melchet;Lady Ashburton’s house in Hampshire. true as is my longing thitherwd (now and for years past),—so soon as you give me signal.
Give my love to Marigold. I am yrs & hers,

postscript.p: Child of Nature curtseys to the ground: she saw yr Ladyship that night at Ruskin’s lecture;John Ruskin’s lecture at the Royal Institution, 29 Jan., entitled “The Flamboyant Architecture of the Valley of the Somme” (Ruskin’s Works 19:243–77). I not, being safe at home here.

div3.sourceNote: TC-TE, 11 Feb. Addr: 9. Albyn Place / Edinburgh. PM: London, 11 Feb. 1869. MS: New College Lib., EUL. Pbd: William Hanna, ed., Letters of Thomas Erskine of Linlathen, 2 vols. (Edinburgh, 1877) 1:323–25; Shepherd, Carlyle 2:285–87; Symington 127–29 inc. Quot: Wylie 285–86; Wilson, Carlyle 6:210. TC originally dated the letter 12 Feb., and then changed it to 11 Feb.; date confirmed by PM; pbd. sources all give the date as 12 Feb.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS ERSKINE

docBody.p: I was most agre[e]ably surprised by the sight of yr hand-writing agn:Erskine wrote to TC, 25 Jan. TC omitted an “e” in “agreeably.” so kind, so welcome! The Letters are as firm and honestly distinct as ever;—the mind too, in spite of its frail environments, as clear, plumb-up, calmly expectt, as in the best days: right so; so be it with us all, till we quit this dim sojourn, now grown so lonely to us, and our Change come! “Our Father whh art in Heaven: Hallowed be thy name: Thy will be done”;—what else can we say? The other night, in my sleepless tossings abt, whh were growing more and more miserable, these words, that brief and grand Prayer came strangely into my mind, with an altogr new emphasis; as if written, and shining for me in mild pure splendour, on the black bosom of the Night there; where I, as it were, read them word by word,—with a sudden check to my impatt wanderings, with a sudden softness of composure whh was much unexpected. Not for perhaps thirty or forty years had I once formally repeated that Prayer;—nay I never felt before how intensely the voice of a Man’s Soul it is; the inmost aspiratn of all that is high and pious in poor Human Nature; right worthy to be recommended with an “After this manner pray ye.”For Jesus’s instruction and the Lord’s Prayer, see Matt. 6:9.— —

I am very thankful that you went to see poor Betty;Erskine wrote from 9 Albyn Pl., Edinburgh, 25 Jan.: “I have been in Edinburgh for a few days & have paid [Betty Braid] a visit. I found her as usual, very kindly & very full of the past, & quite patient under the present burden of life, & piously studying the lesson contained in it.” she is one of the most venerable human figures now known to me in the world. I called there, the
first thing after my bit of surgerySee TC to JSY, 5 Feb.; TC’s visit to Betty is unrecorded. in the neighbd, end of july last; I seemed to have only one other visit to make in all Scotland,—and I made only one.TC visited JWC’s grave in St. Mary’s Church, Haddington, 25 July 1868; see 45:162TC to JF, 2 Aug. 1868. The sight of poor Betty, mournful as it is, and full of mournfullest memories to me, always does me good.— So far as I cd any way learn, she is well enough in her humble thrifty economics &c: if otherwise at any time,—I believe you understand that help from this quarter wd be a sacred duty to me.

I am still able to walk, tho’ I do it on compulsion merely, and witht pleasure except as in work done. It is a great sorrow that you now get fatigued so soon;Erskine wrote: “I have been more seriously ill in point of health than I ever was in my life—& though now pretty well again, I find that I cannot walk half-a mile, without a painful feeling of fatigue”; he could no longer read as he had cataracts in both eyes. and have not yr old privilege in this respect;—I only hope you perhaps do not quite so indispensably need it as I? with me it is the key to sleep, and in fact the one medicine (often ineffectual, and now gradually oftener) that I ever cd discover for this poor clay tabernacleCf. 2 Cor. 5. of mine. I still keep working, after a weak sort; but can now do little, often almost nothing;—all my little “work” is henceforth private (as I calculate);His work on JWC’s letters. a setting of my poor house in order; whh I wd fain finish in time, and occasionally fear I shan’t.Later in 1869 and in 1870 Mary Aitken catalogued all TC’s books preparatory for donation to Harvard after his death (see TC to JAC, 10 Dec., and elsewhere), and TC discussed the bequest with John A. Carlyle (see TC to JAC, 19 March 1870).— — Dear Mr Erskine, good be ever with you. Were my hand as little shaky as it isWord repeated with a line over it at turn of page. today, I wd write to you oftener. A word from you will ever be welcome here!Erskine wrote: “You know that a line from you is always most welcome—& that all which relates to you is interesting to me.”— Yrs sincerely & much,

div3.sourceNote: MA-FA [FAL], 12 Feb. MS: Nigel Althaus. Hitherto unpbd. Letter written by Mary Aitken, dictated by TC with an addition by him at the end.
div3.head: MARY AITKEN TO FRIEDRICH ALTHAUS

docBody.p:
My uncle, Mr Carlyle, bids me say, in answer to the questions in your note,Friedrich Althaus was working on the German translation of Frederick, after the death of Joseph Neuberg, 22 March 1867; see 45:50TC to FAL, [15 Oct. 1867], and he sometimes had trouble with TC’s idiomatic turns of phrase. The “North German Correspondent” of the Newcastle Courant reported, 19 Feb.: “The fifth volume of the Life of Frederic the Great, King of Prussia, has just appeared in a German dress. It is no easy matter to translate the works of Mr Thomas Carlyle, and the Life of Frederic II. presented more difficulties than almost any other of his writings to the German translator. For it was necessary that Mr Neuberg should re-examine the sources of the author’s information in order that he might give the very words quoted, and not a translation of a translation. The death of that talented gentleman, who had carried down the work successfully to the conclusion of the fourth volume, caused a long lapse of time to intervene before the appearance of the fifth; and it was feared that the undertaking would have to be given up, or that at least no translator could be found capable of filling the place of Mr Neuberg. He has, however, fortunately found a worthy successor in Mr Althaus, and the fifth volume, which has just appeared, is fully worthy of a place beside its predecessors.”
that Plugson means the son of (Pflock [wooden peg or plug] or Stöpfel [stuffing]), and is merely intended to indicate a coarse stupid Manchester“Manchester” inserted in MS in another hand, probably Althaus. man; Undershot is the name used by manufacturers for a mill-wheel supplied with water from below; as overshot is the name for one supplied from above. Plugson of Undershot may be said to be emblematic of Manchester Commercial Philosophy. It is more fully treated in Past and Present (Chap. X &c)Plugson of Undershot first appeared in Past and Present (1843), Bk. 3 Ch. 10 (Carlyle, Works 10:188–95); TC then refers to him in Frederick; see Carlyle, Works 19:11.— [-indecipherable words in TC’s hand] to Cobden & BrightRichard Cobden (1804–1865; ODNB), manufacturer and politician, and John Bright, both exponents of free trade, and active in the radical politics of Manchester at the time TC was writing Past and Present.

‘Sarmatia’s fall, unwept, without a crime’ is in reference to these lines in Cambells “Pleasures of Hope”:Thomas Campbell (1777–1844; ODNB), Scottish poet; in “The Pleasures of Hope,” The Pleasures of Hope; with Other Poems (Edinburgh, 1799), he wrote of the tragedy of the partitioning of Poland in the 18th century, using Sarmatia, an ancient name for an area of the near east, to mean Poland (Pleasures of Hope 30).
“Oh bloodiest picture in the Book of Time!
Sarmatia fell, unwept, without a crime.”“The Pleasures of Hope” ll. 375–76; these lines are incorporated in Frederick (Carlyle, Works 19:44), hence Althaus’s enquiry.
Campbell“P” inserted in another hand. was a great enthusiast about Poland, & was very popular in England fifty or more years ago; in another place he says:

“And Freedom shrieked when Kosiusko fell.”“The Pleasures of Hope” l. 382. Tadeusz Kos? ciuszko (1746–1817), Polish-Lithuanian military leader and engineer; he fought in the Polish-Lithuanian struggles against Russia and Prussia, and on the side of the colonies in the American Revolutionary War. His fall is illustrated in “The Pleasures of Hope,” Pleasures of Hope 30 opp.
I think the only thing that has prevented the sense being quite clear, is the want of a comma after fall.

closer.note: Althaus continued to call on TC for assistance; Wilson noted: “One afternoon in March Althaus called about three with questions on the last volume of Frederick” (Wilson, Carlyle 6:189). Althaus later wrote of the visit: “It seemed as if I had never seen before so bushy, so venerable a head: the thick gray hair hung low over his forehead, the beard was brushed toward the face, the eyebrows fell thickly over the deep-set gray eyes. Later, he took a comb from his pocket and combed his hair all the way toward the front and then back against his brow; but the bushy gray setting of the weather-tanned face impressed me as characteristic. Within, it seemed to me, lay something solitary, withdrawn from the world, veiled. I often wished that he would throw off this shock of hair completely and let his face freely emerge: only then would he be seen as he is” (F. Althaus, “Erinnerungen an [Recollections of] Thomas Carlyle” Unsere Zeit 1 n.s. [June 1881]: 838; trans. John Clubbe, ed., “Thomas Carlyle: A Biographical Literary Portrait by Friedrich Althaus,” Two Reminiscences of Thomas Carlyle [Durham, NC, 1974] 10).
