According to Wilson, TC congratulated “Althaus on the completion of his self-imposed task” and asked him to call again “whenever he liked or had anything to ask” (Wilson, Carlyle 6:190).

postscript.p: —fall, unwept, witht—Added and bracketed by TC beside Mary Aitken’s signature.

div3.sourceNote: TC-[TD] [TDI], 17 Feb. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd. This letter is possibly written to Thomas Dixon (1831–80), cork-cutter from Sunderland and working-class activist.
div3.head: TC TO [THOMAS DIXON]

docBody.p: I never heard of Holcroft’s Translatn of Friedrich’s works;Thomas Holcroft (1745–1809; ODNB), writer, dramatist, and translator; his trans., Posthumous Works of Frederick II., King of Prussia, 13 vols. (1789), was from Oeuvres posthumes de Frédéric II, roi de Prusse, 15 vols. (Berlin, 1788), which TC used in writing Frederick; TC’s copy HCC. but there is reason to suppose it will be tolerably good; Holcroft was an honest kind of man, and in this particr task of his there was nothing to hinder his doing it,—a task nowhere difficult.

Hugh Elliot’s view of Miller ArnoldHugh Elliot (1752–1830; ODNB), diplomat and adventurer, British minister at Berlin 1777–82. Although he appeared several times in Frederick, he was not mentioned in connection with Miller Arnold. For TC’s discussion of the Miller Arnold lawsuit in Frederick, see Carlyle, Works 19:222–46. (whh I have entirely forgotten, if I ever read it in the ignorant Book whh treats of Hugh)Emma Eleanor Elizabeth Elliot-Murray-Kynynmound, b. Hislop (ca. 1824–82), countess of Minto, A Memoir of the Right Honourable Hugh Elliot (Edinburgh, 1868); she was Hugh Elliot’s grandda.; the book had been privately printed in 1862, and TC probably received a copy then. She related the story of the miller, but did not give Elliot’s view of the matter (Memoir 194–97). is worth no attentn,—nothing but the rumour of Aristocratic Berlin, I suppose, whh one knows already.

I forwarded yr Letter to Mr Rawlinson; but had no expectatn he wd find the Plan more feasible than I. Here is his Letter, a very indignant Piece;Robert Rawlinson (1810–98; ODNB; see 40:213JWC to TC, [29 Aug. 1864]), civil engineer; his main work was in health and sanitation administration, but he was also involved in public relief works in Lancashire 1863–69. Rawlinson wrote, 29 Jan.: “Miss Jewsbury has handed to me the Sunderland newspaper article by Mr Thos Dixon. I fail to see its practicability.” The article, possibly with an accompanying letter, was presumably concerned with the government and poor-relief; Rawlinson continued: “Governments seem to me to know little about Governing. … Any tradesman governing his business in the manner free states are governed must end in bankruptcy. … ‘How to deal with the able-bodied poor’ How indeed—but something comes before this—How to deal with an entire State, Kingdom or Empire? ” TC wrote on the letter “Confidential. Please return immedly—T.C.” Andrew Symington and Dr. R. Angus Smith (1817–84; ODNB), Scottish chemist, visited TC, late Feb.: “That evening he was indignant at those he called ‘the Government mis-managers—Bright, Gladstone & Co.’… He reverted to Dixon, the Sunderland corkcutter, and to certain information we had procured for him” (Symington 90–92). the essence of whh seems to me dreadfully true— — In haste (not likely to write agn, tho’ wishing you always well),Dixon had been writing to TC since Aug. 1862; see 38:168JWC to TC, [27 Aug. 1862]. In thanking Dixon for a present for his birthday, Dec. 1866, TC requested “an altogether silent continuance of our mutual relatn” (see 44:102TC to GMO, 5 Dec. 1866), but Dixon continued writing to him; see 45:89TC to [RAS], 25 Jan. 1868.

closer.note: TC wrote his first journal entry of 1869 on 14 Feb. about the continuing difficulties of dating and sorting JWC’s letters: “Am busy, what I fondly call ‘busy’ with those ‘Letters’; progress almost none: ah me ah me! I feel it to be as my sacredtask; and that the time is short; yet the obstrucns and paltry impedimts in me and abt me prove so numerous, so continl. I am only got to Craigenputth yet; and have stood there almost stockstill, or painfully shuffling hither & thither with t real advance for a week past. I have lost the tone of care and sincerity;—must, must recover that. On, on, thou wretched laggard, witht loss of another moment. ‘Crowds of beggars,’ import t or importunate invasive persons,—stamp not in vain rage over them: quench thing with them; and Forward!” (TC’s journal; privately owned).

div3.sourceNote: TC-EJE, 20 Feb. MS: Mitchell Lib., Sydney, Australia. Pbd: Workman 100–102. Quot: John Morrow, Thomas Carlyle (2006) 159. For Edward John Eyre, and the background to this letter, see 44:43–45TC to HH, 23 Aug. 1866.
div3.head: TC TO EDWARD JOHN EYRE

docBody.p:
Yr letter duly came to me, with the bad news.Edward John Eyre wrote, 5 Feb., to Granville George Leveson Gower (1815–91; ODNB), 2d earl Granville, colonial sec. 1868–70, requesting reemployment: “During the whole of this time I have been shut out from re-employment in the public service, and I have had entailed upon myself and family all the anxiety, inconvenience, and expense which necessarily resulted from the circumstances under which I have been placed for so long a time. … [I]n consequence … of legal proceedings being pending against me, I have been wholly without official income or pension, and not having private income sufficient to maintain a large and expensive family, have been compelled to live upon my capital. … Such is the result of 25 years’ faithful public service, and of a conscientious discharge of my duty as Governor of Jamaica at a time of great public peril and emergency. … Submitting my case to your Lordship’s just consideration … I would again respectfully inquire whether your Lordship can now hold out to me the prospect of early re-employment as a Governor? ” (“Correspondence between Mr. Eyre, ex-Governor of Jamaica, and Colonial Office, since his removal from Governorship of Jamaica, and Expenses of Proceedings in Courts of Law,” House of Commons Papers, 43 [1872 (56)]:34). He received a reply, 12 Feb., from Sir Francis Richard John Sandford (1824–93; ODNB), assistant under-sec. of state for the Colonies: “I am directed by Earl Granville to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th inst., and I am desired to express his Lordship’s regret that he cannot comply with your request, to hold out to you the prospect of early re-employment as a Governor” (“Correspondence between Mr. Eyre, ex-Governor of Jamaica, and Colonial Office,” 43:45). See also TC to JAC, 20 Feb. Poor Lady Murchison’s
Funeral,Charlotte Murchison, b. Hugonin (1788–1869; ODNB), geologist, m., 1815, Roderick Impey Murchison (1792–1871; ODNB), geologist and geographer; she d. 9 Feb. I understood, was to be yesterday; today I will leave this letter, with my card, at Sir Roderick’s door.The Murchison home was at 16 Belgrave Sq.

Under the melancholy circs, I cd not but at once agree to go and take his place at last Committee:Sir Roderick and TC were both vice-presidents of the Eyre Defence and Aid Fund; meetings were usually chaired by Sir Roderick. however, on getting thither I found they all confidently expected that Sir Roderick wd take his place agn “on Friday 26th” (that is now, Friday next); and were clearly of opinion that nothing cd be done except adjourn till that day. With some difficulty I got them persuaded to at least order yr Solicitor,James Anderson Rose (ca. 1820–90), attorney and solicitor, 11 Salisbury Street, Strand. who was in attendance, to inquire of the prest Ministry, Whether they intended to maintain the Promise made by their Predecessors as to paying the Expenses of these distracted Lawsuits you have been exposed to?The conservative government, June 1866–Dec. 1868, had indicated that they would consider paying Eyre’s legal expenses; since 3 Dec. 1868 there had been a liberal govt., under Gladstone, which eventually repaid Eyre’s legal costs in July 1871. For further details, see “Correspondence between Mr. Eyre, ex-Governor of Jamaica, and Colonial Office, since his removal from Governorship of Jamaica, and Expenses of Proceedings in Courts of Law”; House of Commons Papers (1872 [56]), vol. 43. This point will, therefore, be in a state of clearness for next meeting. A Letter from Sir Rk was read, in whh he informed us of the Applicatn made in yr own person to Ld Granville; & seemed rather to regret that you had not waited “till friends had talked to the Ministry” &c &c,—whh, in my own private opinn, wd have made no difference whatr in the poor result now become indisputable to us.

I am not expected, nor is it in the least fitting, especially for myself in my weak state of health &c, to attend any more meetings of Comee, of Subscribers, or whatr busss there may be,—of whh indeed I have known absolutely nothing for above a year past, and can or could take no useful part in the discussion of. My own clear notn, as perhaps is known to you, wd have been, especially since “Jamaica Comitte”The Jamaica Committee had been formed to prosecute Eyre; although they initiated several legal actions, Eyre was never brought to trial; the committee was disbanded 1868. got evidently knocked on the head, & ignominiously flung out as dog’s meat, by the genl People of Engld,—that we shd have taken a more courageous, declaratory, and as it were aggressive attitude; virtually that of appeal to said people of Engld, as the one “Authority” that had any chance to help us. But as that proved to be my own opinn only, I willingly left it,TC drafted a petition for the Eyre Defence and Aid Committee to present to parliament, Jan. 1868; see 45:85TC to DL, 22 Jan. 1868, and Workman 98–100. as the Ostrich does her egg in the desert,Cf. Job 39:13–15. and went my ways.

I more than sympathise with you, my dear Sir, in this Ld Granville matter: in fact I regard the conduct of the “Govt” (so-called “Govt”) towards you all along since yr heroic service, with a mixture of indignatn and contempt, whh is absolutely painful to me,—and whh I sedulously avoid all tempatatns or opportunities to express publicly, indeed dare not (and will not) trust myself“My” repeated with a line over it at turn of page. to speak of it in public! That is quietly my resolutn, as matters stand.

From the prestt Ministry, so long as it sticks togr, howr loud the demand, there can be no response but one: they will not crack themselves in two, disgust their Brights &c,John Bright, John Stuart Mill, Thomas Huxley, Charles Darwin (1809–82; ODNB), naturalist, and Thomas Hughes (1822–96; ODNB), social reformer and writer, were among English Liberals who formed the Jamaica Committee; see 44:45TC to HH, 23 Aug. 1866. to mend the most flaming injustice. But they don’t last forr. Courage, courage! &c Yrs

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 20 Feb. MS: NLS 526.87. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:381.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
It is an absolute shame not to have written to you sooner, and now to write such a scrap. But I have been very “busy” last week,—sleeping better, and eager to snatch one or two hours from the futile pluister of the 24, whh too often won’t yield me even that: and now for the last two nights, I have been sleeping ill agn; and have had to spend all my time (sorrow on it!) in ansring a
Letter from Eyre,See TC to EJE, 20 Feb. whh I had little busss with, & whh wd have been work for 15 minutes, had my hand been obedt as of old. Tomorrow, howr, there will be got 10 Proofsheets:—better a wee word than none, while time is, howr. Only striking 3; that is yet all.

Poor Sir Rodk Murchison has lost his Wife; he petitioned me, above a week ago, to provide for him in Comee; I cd not refuse,—tho’ nothing was done, except agree to “wait for Sir Rk.” Eyre, meanwhile, had been himself appyg to the Govt: “Reemployt, speedily; after all these dead-cats & gallows-ropes wagging at me so long!”—“No,” ansd Ld Granville; “can’t, don’t intend to!” Upon whh a great despatch from Eyre, lying here almost a week past;—to be left at Sir Rodk’s door today (all enclosures in it), and a short Letter sent to Eyre himself. I hope I have made it courteously plain to everybody, that I don’t purpose to write another word on the subject, still less to speak any syllable at Comee or other meeting,—decided even to ignore all such, and keep myself absent and silent. Heighho!
Maggie Welsh is here since Tuesday; do very well, Mary & she. Will last till March 16; I hope, no longer.

A Parcel of Books went off for John a day or so since; among them are some Parcels whh I thot perhaps you wd look at.John Aitken, their nephew; John A. Carlyle replied, 23 Feb.: “The parcel of Books for John arrived yesterday morning … & he was proud of your present of the sixteen volumes of your stereotype Edition. I too have looked into some of the Pamphlets of your parcel.”

Huxley’s Lecture on ProtoplasmT. H. Huxley, “On the Physical Basis of Life,” Fortnightly Review, Feb. 1869, 11:129–45. (did you see it? Dr Russell has it, last Fortnightly)TC sent Dr. James Russell the Fortnightly Review; see 42:166TC to JWC, 1 Aug. 1865, and 43:89JWC to MR, 25 Dec. [1865]. is getting talked abt. Quite disgusting and painful to me;—tells me nothing new either (howr logical & clever) that I didn’t know before; viz that to the eye of clay, spirit is forever invisible.— Pah, nasty, needless too! “A little lower than the angels,” said Psalmist David:See Ps. 8:5. “a little higher than the tadpoles,” says Evangelist Huxley.Huxley began: “I have translated the term ‘Protoplasm,’ which is the scientific name of the substance of which I am about to speak, by the words ‘the physical basis of life.’” He acknowledged that for many people “the conception of life [is] something that works through matter, but is independent of it” (129). He concluded by justifying the materialist investigation of life, while insisting that materialism as a philosophy of ultimate existence was no more legitimate than spiritualism: “In itself it is of little moment whether we express the phenomena of matter in terms of spirit; or the phenomena of spirit, in terms of matter; matter may be regarded as a form of thought, thought may be regarded as a property of matter—each statement has a certain relative truth. But with a view to the progress of science, the materialistic terminology is in every way to be preferred. For it connects thought with the other phenomena of the universe, and suggests inquiry into the nature of those physical conditions, or concomitants of thought, which are more or less accessible to us, and a knowledge of which may, in future, help us to exercise the same kind of control over the world of thought as we already possess in respect of the material world; whereas, the alternative, or spiritualistic, terminology is utterly barren, and leads to nothing but obscurity and confusion of ideas” (11:145). John A. Carlyle replied: “I have not seen Huxley’s article, & perhaps it is hardly worth reading. Let him try how dark & base a view of man he can take, so long as it is permitted to him! One does not need to have anything to do with him or his views, which may be inevitable for a time just now.”
Adieu, dear Brr,—love to Jean & you all!

div3.sourceNote: TC-TU, 2 March. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd. Thomas Usher (1826–1902), writer and law clerk; founder, 1865, and sec. of the Edinburgh Border Counties Association and sec. of the Edinburgh Sir Walter Scott Centenary celebration.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS USHER

docBody.p: I cannot myself take any share in the “Scott Centennary”;The centenary of Sir Walter Scott’s birth was 15 Aug. 1871; celebrations were held in many Scottish towns, the largest being in Edinburgh, 9 Aug. 1871. but if it, or any other enterprize of the Border-Counties Associatn, can practically achieve a few Bursaries in Edinr UniversityNo such bursary was ever established. for the encouraget of young talent in Scotland, I shall right certainly esteem that a blessed result, and always wish the operations leading to it every success.
I have the honour to be / (tho’ in much want of time)

postscript.p: F.TC wrote “F” in error for “T.” Usher Esq, Secy to &c &c

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 6 March. MS: NLS 526.88. Quot: A. Carlyle, NL 2:251–52; C. R. Sanders, “Carlyle’s Pen Portraits of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert,” Carlyle Past and Present, ed. K. J. Fielding and Rodger L. Tarr (1976) 231.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Since you say nothing, I struggle to believe that nothing is much going wrong with any of you; but, for my own share, I must write today in very shame,—unwilling as my hand &c are, now and always. It is astonishing what an obstructn to me, in every kind of work, this poor old tremulous right-hand now is! Cuts off full ⅔ of my progress in whatever I am doing where it has a
part to play. Well, well; it has stood steadily by me a long long while; how cd it stand forever? Forever, nothing will or can stand!——

In regard to sleep, I had five bad nights abt the time of last writing; but agn sprawled and struggled out of them, and am a natural creature, or nearly so, in that importt respect for almost a fortnight past. No bragging, howr! Last night, by the pitifullest of accidts (rising to crush in my window-wedge, when the east-wind gave sudden warning),—I missed by a hairsbreadth; and got off with the forfeit of only ¼ or ⅓ of my night: no worse than usual, this morning. The sad fact is, my peptic faculties are sunk to a low & almost lowest ebb; I must calculate on their going altogr by faster or slower degrees.— I struggle to hang by my “Work” (I daresay you guess what),Although TC was working on the library edn., as detailed below, his real “work” was on JWC’s letters; see TC to [TDI], 17 Feb., and TC to JAJR, 16 March. were it only with 3 fingers; & generally do get a particle or two of it done every week-day: every sunday there come 10 or so proof-sheets, whh occupy me (insigniftly) the whole day. Two hours of walking, sickly and sluggish at first, but gradually mending, occupy me next; after whh, dinner and mere soporific stupidity, with two “walks” more, and something of reading, mostly altogr stupid in quality and in executn, bring me to bedtime, and haply to oblivn till a new day. We have now cold dry March weather; whh I think promises to suit me rather better.— Robson prints well and steadily at this New Editn: but I cannot get to care anything abt it: dull much of it; much of it sad (in the sense of mournful and loving; wae, wae);—all of it a poor thing, to have proved one’s conquest in life! Yet one shd be thankful for it too; and in truth I partly am withal. Forster is getting up the most precise documentary signed settlets &c with Chapman & Robson,John Forster acted on TC’s behalf with Chapman & Hall; see 45:10TC to JAC, 16 July 1867. For the signed settlement with Chapman & Hall, see TC’s agreement with Frederic Chapman, 29 April. so that no doubt can exist (were we all removed in a day) as to what the bargain and the whole state of affairs were and are at any time:—the good Forster! A very precise little Cockney EngraverWilliam Holl the younger (1807–71; ODNB); see 45:182TC to JAC, 9 Oct. 1868. came ten days ago (and spoiled my day) with his Proof of Engraving from Watts’s Picture: very ugly and extravagt (absurd eyes especially, & inconsistt with the rest) it all appeared to me: but Forster likes it well; and I readily can say meinetwegen, meintn [so be it, so be it]!For the slow progress of George Frederic Watts’s portrait of TC, commissioned by Forster, see vol. 45. For the engraving, used as frontispiece to vol. 1 of Critical and Miscellaneous Essays (1869), vol. 6 of the library edn., see above.— Nayther di tha ill na guid!Coterie speech; see 18:83JWC to TC, [25 June 1845].—

figure.p:
Thomas Carlyle, portrait by George Frederic Watts, 1868, engraved by W. Holl,
Thomas Carlyle, Critical and Miscellaneous Essays (1869)

docBody.p:
Hoho! Here is Froude;—and there was the one grand thing of all to tell you: interview with Sacred Majty, thursday last, at “The Deanery”The meeting with Queen Victoria was at “The Deanery” of Arthur Stanley, dean of Westminster, and arranged by his wife, Lady Augusta Stanley. TC noted in his journal: “It was Thursday 4 March 5–6½ p.m., when this pretty ‘Interview’ took place” (TC’s journal; privately owned). John A. Carlyle replied, 7 March, saying they were all very glad to hear from TC, but did not mention TC’s meeting with Victoria. by
preappointt a week before. I one of four,The four called to an audience with Victoria were TC, Robert Browning, Sir Charles Lyell (and his wife, Lady Anna Maria Lyell), and either Harriet or George Grote (it is not clear in TC to JCA, 11 March, which of the Grotes TC thinks of as part of the “four”). Victoria noted in her journal, 4 March: “Augusta Stanley had invited the following celebrities to meet me: Mr Carlyle, … Mr and Mrs Grote, old acquaintances of mine from Kensington … Sir C & Ly Lyall … & Mr Browning” (Queen Victoria’s Journals [Princess Beatrice’s copies]: http://www.queenvictoriasjournals.org). For TC’s detailed account, and biographical details, see TC to JCA, 11 March. —and I may partly think the main one perhaps. Sacred Mty was very good; thing altogr decidedly insignift, do tiresome; and worsened a kind of cold I had (and am still dropping with on this very sheet). Of all whh I will not say a word more, unless specially desired by some of you!TC wrote, [15 March]: “Sister Jean has got a brief sketch of the thing,—on her earnest request” (TC’s journal; privately owned); see TC to JCA, 11 March. For a carte de visite of Victoria, 1861, by Charles Clifford, pbd. by Cundall, Downes & Co., see above.—

figure.p:
Queen Victoria, carte de visite, 1861
© National Portrait Gallery, London

docBody.p: Tell Jean she might write, tho’ I don’t. Give my kindest regards to her & household wholly. Ever yr affecte Brr

div3.sourceNote: TC-RH, 7 March. Pbd: Colbeck Radford Manuscript House catalog 23 (May 1932). Robert Harrison (1820–97; see 36:biographical notes), librarian of London Lib. Note written on TC’s visiting card.
div3.head: TC TO ROBERT HARRISON

docBody.p: To Mr. Harrison (London Library), Rev. F. Newton (Kelly Rectory), Onger,Rev. F. Newton unidentified further. Presumably either TC or the cataloger misspelled “Onger” for Ongar, town in Essex. wishing to inquire abt subscribing, T.C.7 March 1869.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 11 March. MS copies: Frederic Harrison Collection, LSE Lib.; Univ. of Reading Lib. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:252–55 inc; C. R. Sanders, “Carlyle’s Pen Portraits of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert,” Carlyle Past and Present, ed. K. J. Fielding and Rodger L. Tarr (1976) 231–33; G. B. Tennyson, A Carlyle Reader (1984) 493–95 inc. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:182–86. Both MS copies are in unknown hands; text from LSE Lib. MS.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
Mary, I find, has inserted for you a small letter, along with the one that belongs to the Dr. I have nothing of my own in the form of news beyond what
that “child of nature” will have said. All busy here, March East wind snell as possible, (one’s new cape not useless) but not unwholesome with its fine dry cold instead of the wet tepid puddle we have long had—and in consequence sleep a little better than then. But my present business is exclusively to tell you something of the “Queen’s interviewThurs. 4 March; TC wrote, 15 March: “Queen was really very gracious and pretty in her demeanour thro’out; rose greatly in my esteem, by everythg that happened, did not fall in any point” (TC’s journal; privately owned). —for which great object I have only a very few minutes—swift then—if my poor hand but would!

“Interview” took place this day gone a week: nearly a week before that, the Dean & Deaness (who is called Lady Augusta Stanley, once Bruce an active hard & busy woman)Arthur Penrhyn Stanley, dean of Westminster, and his wife, Lady Augusta Stanley; before her marriage she had been one of Queen Victoria’s ladies-of-the-bedchamber, and continued friendly with her. drove up here, and in a solemnly mysterious and half quizzical manner, invited me, for Thursday 4th 5. P.M. “must come,” a very high indeed highest person has long been desirous &c &c. I saw well enough it was the Queen’s incognita; & briefly agreed to come. “Half past four. Come you!” & then went their ways.

Walking up at the set time, I was there ushered into that long drawing room in their monastic edifice. I found no Stanley yet there: only at the further end a tall old gear pole of a Mrs Grote,Harriet Grote; “Gear pole”: “Irish-weaver implement” (TC’s note in A. Carlyle, NL 2:253). JWC earlier used the forms “geerpoles” (16:12–13, noted as “thin upright poles upon which a mason might hang his gear”), and “gearpoule,” TC citing an “Irish Emigt” as source in his note (16:331). the most wooden woman I know in London, or the world, who thinks herself very clever &c, the sight of whom taught me too, & perhaps others;Both copies have these words (from “the sight”); but A. Carlyle prints, either because he thought it made more sense or possibly because the original MS had this, “taught me to expect others” (NL 2:253). as accordingly in a few minutes fell out; GroteGeorge Grote. & wife, Sir Charles Lyell & do.Sir Charles Lyell (1797–1875; ODNB), geologist, and his wife, m. 1832, Lady Anna Maria, b. Horner (1808–73); both long known to both Carlyles; see 12:335TC to JAC, 24 Nov. 1840, and 23:210JWC to JW, [29 Jan. 1849]. Browning & myself then I saw to be one party “Better than bargain;”!Phrase from David Garrick, The Irish Widow (1772) II, ii. these will take the edge off the thing if edge it have! which it hadn’t nor threatened to have. The Stanleys & we were all in a flow of talk, and some flunkies had done setting coffee cups & tea-cups of a sublime pattern when her Majesty punctual to the minute glided softly in, escorted by her dame in waiting (a Duchess Dowager of Athole)Anne Murray, b. Home-Drummond (1814–97; ODNB), dowager duchess of Atholl, lady-of-the-bedchamber and close friend of Victoria’s. & by the Princess Luise
(sic)TC’s “sic”; Princess Louise (1848–1939; ODNB), 6th child of Victoria and Albert; artist, sympathizer to the women’s movement; at this time Victoria’s social secretary. A. J. Symington reported to TC on Louise: “‘a kind-hearted, nice, bit lassie, with no pride about her; but several times I saw her taking a curious side-glint at me, and no doubt she was wondering in her own mind why on earth she was consigned to the care of such a rough old curmudgeon as I am, instead of to somebody or other more like herself’” (Symington 72). According to Wilson, she later visited TC at Cheyne Row; see Wilson, Carlyle 6:187. For a photograph, 1868, by W. & D. Downey, see 24. decidedly a very pretty young lady & clever too, as I found in speaking to her afterwards.

figure.p:
Princess Louise, albumen print, 1868
© National Portrait Gallery, London

docBody.p: The Queen came softly forwards a kindly little smile in her face, gently shook hands with all the three woman, gently acknowledged with a nod the bows of us male monsters; & directly in her presence everybody was as if at ease again. She is a comely little lady, with a pair of kind clear and intelligent grey eyes; still looks plump and almost young (in spite of one broad wrinkle that shews in each cheek occasionally): has a fine soft low voice, soft indeed her whole manner is, melodiously perfect: it is impossible to imagine a politer little woman nothing the least imperious, all gentle, all sincere-looking unembarrassing, rather attractive even—makes you feel too (if you have sense in you) that she is Queen.Gerald Blunt, rector of St. Luke’s, Chelsea, later recalled TC telling him of the meeting: “I was very much struck with the Queen’s appearance. No one could doubt, when she came into the room—came swimming into the room—that she was the greatest lady in all the land” (Reginald Blunt, Memoirs of Gerald Blunt of Chelsea [1911] 97). For a carte de visite of Victoria, 1861, see 20. After a little word to each of us (to me it was “sorry you did not see my Daughter (Princess of Prussia)Princess Victoria Adelaide (1840–1901; ODNB), princess royal, eldest child of Victoria and Albert; she m., 1858, Prince Frederick William of Prussia (1831–88). or “ah sorry” perhaps, which led us into Berlin PotsdamAfter her marriage Princess Victoria lived in Berlin, which she disliked, later moving to Potsdam, which she preferred. For a photograph of her, see 25. &c for an instant or two.

figure.p:
Princess Victoria Adelaide, albumen print, 1863
© National Portrait Gallery, London

docBody.p:
To Sir Charles Lyell I heard her say “Gold in Sutherland”Gold had recently been discovered in Kildonan, Sutherland, by Robert Nelson Gilchrist (1821–77), a native of Kildonan, who had spent 17 years in the goldfields of Australia. The Times reported, 27 Jan.: “Here, in Helmsdale … there is a small colony of diggers, who travel ten miles every morning to the scene of their gold-seeking, and return the same distance each night, both journeys being performed on foot…. [A]bout two months ago Mr. Robert Gilchrist … found some gold in the alluvial deposit of the burn … which … flows down through the strath, and into the Helmsdale River. The quantity found by Mr. Gilchrist was by no means considerable; but the news of his discovery has spread abroad with considerable exaggeration, and the result has been that each day during the last week large numbers of diggers have collected in a wild and bleak country, where from sunrise to sunset … they have endured intense hardship in the hope of finding nuggets which would make them independent for the rest of their days.” See also R. M. Callender and P. F. Reeson, The Scottish Gold Rush of 1869, British Mining 84 (Sheffield, 2008). but quickly & delicately
cut him short in responding—to Browning “are you writing anything? (who has been just been publishing the absurdest things!Robert Browning had just pbd. The Ring and the Book; see TC to JAC, 11 Jan. ) to Grote I did not hear what she said, but it was touch & go with everybody, Majesty visibly without interest or nearly so of her own. After this I say, CoffeeBoth copies have these words (from “After this”); A. Carlyle includes, either because he thought it made more sense or possibly from the original MS, “This done, Coffee” (NL 2:254). (very black & muddy) was handed round: Queen & three woman taking seats (Queen in the corner of a sofa—Lady Deaness in opposite corner, Mrs Grote in a chair intrusively close to Majesty, Lady Lyell moderately at the diagonal corner) we others obliged to stand & hover within call. Coffee fairly done Lady Augusta called me gently to “come & speak with her Majesty” I obeyed first asking as an old infirmish man Majesty’s permission to sit, which was graciously conceded.According to Gerald Blunt, TC said: “I am an old man, Ma’am; excuse me, I must sit down” (Reginald Blunt, Memoirs of Gerald Blunt of Chelsea [1911] 97). Nothing of the least significance was said nor needed: however my bit of dialogue went very well, “What part of Scotland I came from”? “Dumfries” (where Majesty might as well go sometimes) Carlisle, Cair Lewel, a place of about the antiquity of King Solomon (according to MiltonCf. John Milton, The History of England (1670) bk. 1; Milton recounts the legendary history of Britain, whose early kings were supposedly descended from the Trojan hero Aeneas, and shows the timescale relative to events in the Bible: “Leil [king of Britain], a maintainer of Peace and Equity. … He built in the North Cairleil [Carlisle]; and in the daies of Solomon.” whereat Majesty smiled) Border BalladsBorder ballads were those ballads traditional to the Scottish-English border; TC would have been familiar with them from his upbringing; JWC would also have sung some of them when she played him “Scotch tunes” (see 30:272Ellen Twisleton’s Account of Life at Craigenputtoch, [Nov.? 1855]); Victoria’s familiarity might have been mainly through Sir Walter Scott’s Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (Kelso, 1802). (and even old Jamie PoolJames Pool of Borgue, Annandale schoolmaster; see 7:165TC to JAC, 18 May 1834. slightly alluded to not by name) Glasgow & grandfather’s ride thither, ending in mere Psalms: & streets vacant at 9½ p.m.For TC’s recollections of his grandfather, Thomas Carlyle (1722–1806) (although not of this particular incident), see Carlyle, Reminiscences 17–20. For the danger of being arrested “for being idlers in kirk-time” by officers if found on the street during church service, see Scott, Rob Roy (1818) chap. 20, para. 2. hard sound & Presbyterian root of what has now shot up to be such a monstrously ugly cabbage-tree & Hemlock tree!”The bark of the cabbage-tree was used as an emetic, and hemlock is a powerful sedative. TC may have been referring to divisions and fanaticisms in the Presbyterian Scottish churches; his only other use of “cabbage tree” in this context was in relation to Edward Irving flourishing as “a green cabbage tree … among the fanatical classes”; see 5:330TC to JWC, 15 Aug. 1831. All which her Majesty seemed to take rather well. Whereupon Mrs Grote rose good naturedly,
bro’t forward her husband to her own chair, cheek by jowl with Majesty, who evidently did not care a straw for him, but kindly asked “Writing anything” & one heard Aristotle now that I have done with PlatoGeorge Grote, having completed Plato, and the other Companions of Sokrates, 3 vols. (1865), started working on a book on Aristotle but died before he finished it. (but only for a minimum of time) Majesty herself (& I think à propos of some question about my shaking hand) said something about her own difficulty in writing to dictation, which bro’t forward Lady Lyell & her husband mutually used to the operation. After which, talk becoming quite trivial, Majesty gracefully retired with Lady Augusta & in ten minutes more returned to receive our farewell bows, which she did very prettily & sailed out as if moving on skates & bending her head to us with a smile. By the underground RailwayThe London Underground District Line opened Dec. 1868; TC would have taken the train from St. James’s Park station, nr. Westminster, either to Sloane Square or South Kensington station, both about the same distance from Cheyne Row. I was home before 7 & out of the adventure with only a headache of little moment. Froude tells me there are foolish mythsTC wrote in his journal: “This penny-a-line Patch is now circulating, but incorrect &, tho’ well-meaning, worthless” (TC’s journal; privately owned); attached was a clipping from the Dumfries Herald, 12 March, which stated that TC and Browning “so far as intellect is concerned, stand head and shoulders above their contemporaries.” TC commented: “That of Browning, ‘head & shoulders, in point of intellect’ (just ending his Ring & Book) is wonderful to read!” (TC’s journal; privately owned). The Dumfries and Galloway Courier reported, 16 March: “Her Majesty had on Thursday the pleasure of becoming personally acquainted with two of the most distinguished writers of the age, Mr Carlyle and Mr Browning. … [T]he interview was one of a very pleasing and characteristic kind.” about the poor business, especially about my share of it, but this is the real truth, worth to me in strict speech all but nothing, the myths even less than nothing.TC wrote in his journal: “The ‘Intw’ was quietly very mournful to me; the one point of real interest, a sombre thot; ‘Alas, how wd it have cheered Her bright soul (for my sake), had she been here! To me, with such prospects close ahead, it cd not be much, and did indeed approximate to melancholy well-meant zero” (TC’s journal; privately owned). Victoria recorded in her journal, 4 March: “I drove alone with the Dss of Atholl to the Deanery at Westminster, Louise soon joining us there. Augusta Stanley had invited … to meet me: Mr Carlyle, the Historian, a strange-looking eccentric old Scotchman, who holds forth in a drawling melancholy voice upon Scotland & the utter degeneration of everything! He has a very broad Scotch accent” (Queen Victoria’s Journals [Princess Beatrice’s copies]: http://www.queenvictoriasjournals.org).
Tell the Dr I intended him but it is already (horrible to think) half past 4. Adieu dear sister

div3.sourceNote: TC-RHS, 15 March. Addr: 5 Hereford Square / Brompton. PM: 15 March 1869. MS: William R. Primrose, Dundee, Scotland. Pbd: Shepherd, Carlyle 2:21–22. Richard Herne Shepherd (1840–95; ODNB), bibliographer; see TC to RHS, 1 Dec. 1868.
div3.head: TC TO R. H. SHEPHERD

docBody.p: I am obliged and gratified by yr loyal alacrity to help; but really quite ashamed at the amount of useless trouble you have had in copying these Newspaper things!Shepherd had been making copies of some of TC’s essays from the Examiner and Spectator of 1848. They are not introducible where you suggest;Shepherd introduced the letter: “While the Library Edition of [TC’s] Works was passing through the press, the present writer, who then enjoyed the privilege of frequent personal intercourse and of occasional correspondence with Carlyle, ventured to suggest to him their possible inclusion as further ‘Precursors’… or as Appendices, to the Latter-Day Pamphlets—a recommendation which he was apparently unable to entertain but to which he vouchsafed the following not ungracious reply” (Shepherd, Carlyle 2:21). Shepherd himself pbd. six of TC’s articles in Shepherd, Carlyle 2:365–406. and I believe they are but a fraction (proper fractn perhaps) of the large mass whh lies safe in the whale’s bellyCf: Jonah 1:17. still! Howr, I will keep them in retentis [among reserved things], with thankful memory of you.

closer.note: TC, with Maggie Welsh’s and Mary Aitken’s help, was continuing his work on JWC’s letters; he wrote, 15 March: “Seemed to have got thro’ to the end of the ‘Lecture Period’ in London (abt1839), when on a search by Maggie Welsh and Mary,—a large bundle of early Letters, and of later, turned up; whh demand strict examinatn, and, so far as suitable, intercalation! The like has happened twice before, on a smaller scale. Stand to the work (probably thy last in this world); let no obstructn turn thee back!” (TC’s journal; privately owned).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JA Jr. [JAJR], 16 March. MS: NLS 1763.301. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES AITKEN JR.

docBody.p: Inclosed is crossed cheque for the poor BaillieJames Baillie, cousin of JWC’s mother; TC noted in his checkbook: “16 March 1869 / to Jas Aitken (Baillie) / £10 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). demand; I see clearly they know it is I,—but it is better (indeed indispensable) that you officially keep them completely in the dark.TC sent money anonymously to Baillie and his wife, Anna-Maria, through James Aitken Jr.; see 44:119TC to JAC, 6 Jan. 1867, 45:116TC to JCA, [11] April 1868, and 45:178–79TC to JAJR, 2 Oct. 1868. For the rest, I suppose there is no danger, this time, of yr burying the thing into oblivion, for 3 weeks, in yr coat pocket!

figure.p:
Four undated photographs of Jane Welsh Carlyle
Thomas Carlyle Papers, 1865–1896, Rare Book & Manuscript Library,
Columbia University in the City of New York

docBody.p:
In a day or two you will receive from some Bookseller’s Parcel, a little German
volume;Unidentified further. whh I doubt not you will like to have, and keep in memory of me. Send no ansr to it, except some hint to MaryJames Aitken Jr. wrote to Mary Aitken on the reverse of TC’s letter: “From the other side you will see no answer was wanted or I shd have written to Uncle of course—Maggie omitted to mention it in her last to you. … The Book came day after Uncle’s letter.”
Mary is very well; I too a degree better than thro’out the muddy winter I was.

closer.note: Robert Scott Tait apparently painted a portrait of JWC from photographs; TC wrote, 15 March: “Strange Likeness (of Her) done by Tait from some Photographs whh I had never seen. Profile, not a little resembling,—indeed like altogr that dull & total failure in regard to the nose. It stood on the table for two days, poignantly recalling her to me, and always with a kind of shock as tho that stupid exaggeratn (quite exaggerated, and all character & charm of expressn lost out of it) came under my eye. In a day or two I returned it to Tait:—they are trying at Glasgow for a better:—alas, alas, a poor conquest; sad and poor at the best!” (TC’s journal; privately owned). The photographs used by Tait not further identified; presumably not the four pasted on one page, Thomas Carlyle Photograph Albums, vol. 4, since TC commented underneath one of them: “4 of Her: all bad,—this the worst”; see above. For the Glasgow artists, see TC to JHEN, 23 April.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JSM, 16 March. Addr: Care of Mrs Grote / 12. Savile Row / 16 March; the letter was evidently delivered by hand. MS: NLS 618.114. Pbd: A. Carlyle, CMSB 186–87.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN STUART MILL

docBody.p: Here are Two VolumesJohn Evelyn, Memoirs illustrative of the Life and Writings of John Evelyn, comprising his Diary and a Selection of his Familiar Letters, ed. W. Bray, 2 vols. (1818). TC had borrowed these vols. while working on Cromwell; see 17:166TC to JSM, 9 Nov. 1843. whh have stood many years on the shelves here, occasionally admonitory to me, at times almost upbraiding. They belonged to yr FatherJames Mill (1773–1836; ODNB), Scottish political philosopher. (as I remember); and have doubtless a value far beyond the intrinsic.

figure.p:
John Stuart Mill, undated photograph
Thomas Carlyle Papers, 1865–1896, Rare Book & Manuscript Library,
Columbia University in the City of New York

docBody.p: If I knew specifically yr address at Blackheath,Mill replied, 12 April: “I have just received, through Mrs Grote, the two volumes of Evelyn, together with your kind note. The former I had entirely forgotten. The latter would have revived, if they had ever been dormant, many old memories and feelings. Blackheath Park, Kent, is a sufficient address.” Mill had ceased being friendly with the Carlyles around the time of the later years of Harriet Taylor’s marriage to John Taylor (1796–1849) and Mill’s subsequent marriage to her, 1851, partly because Mill assumed that they (and other friends) disapproved of his relationship with her; see 26:51–52TC to JAC, 29 March 1851. TC and Mill also increasingly disagreed politically. Vol. 2 of Thomas Carlyle’s Photograph Albums contains an undated (possibly recent) carte de visite of J. S. Mill with TC’s “!” inserted by the name; see above. there is perhaps something else that I might beg permission to send.A. Carlyle suggested that TC perhaps wished to send Mill a memento of JWC, as this was their first communication since her death, April 1866 (A. Carlyle, CMSB 187). In his last letter to Mill, March 1866, TC had included a friendly message from JWC; see 43:132–33TC to JSM, 13 March 1866.

With many ineffaceable remembrances and kind wishes & regardsMill concluded his letter: “any communication from you—not to mention your bodily presence—would be always most welcome.” These were apparently the last letters they wrote to each other.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 20 March. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. The letter is written on two sides of a torn sheet, and it seems likely that on the other half of the sheet was the letter from Wilhelmina Richardson; see below.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I am sorry my hand is agn grown mutinous, now when I meant to write to you more at large, and the time itself is almost up.

The Canada letters, especially Alick’s, are very good: poor Alick, with his head grown white, whiter even than was. He seems to be very cheerful, too, tho’ always full of mournful seriousness, in fact one of the most serious men I have ever known. If there is anything one cd do to be of any real assistance or advantage to him or TomTom was the oldest of Alick’s nine children. John A. Carlyle wrote to James Carlyle Jr., 21 March: “Last week we had two interesting letters from your uncle Alick & his son Tom in Canada, & sent them on to Chelsea. They have come back today” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). See also TC to JAC, 9 Feb. or photographs of Alick and Janet Carlyle and of Tom Carlyle, see 42:222TC to JAC, 14 Sept. 1865, and 223TC to JAC, 14 Sept. 1865. or any of them, right welcome wd the suggestn of it be. But I fear there is nothing?—

We are all as usual here, tho’ the weather is fickle, blustery, cold, then wet &c to the full height of the season.—I am to go for Melchet on Thursday next, Miss Bromley appointed to escort; last stage is Romsey;Lady Ashburton’s house in Hampshire; see TC to LLA, 9 Feb.; Caroline Davenport Bromley was a mutual friend. Romsey is about 72 mi. (116 km.) S of London. “Thursday next” was 25 March but TC went Fri. 2 April. He wrote, 15 March: “Am for Melchet, it seems, in abt ten days. I wish I was home agn! That kind of enterprise has not prospered latterly, and I had as good as given it up: but, this time, I was bound” (TC’s journal; privately owned). train 2 p.m., express;—no difficulty abt the journey. But the power of sleeping &c when there is a little questionable! Nothing for it but to try, to try! Maggie & MaryMary Aitken wrote to a recently married friend (otherwise unidentified), 10 Feb.: “It does seem shocking that all these months I have intended writing & never done so. … I have been very busy all the time with copying. … I never went any further with my intention of going home (indeed you would be surprised how very many of my intentions I can not get accomplished); but have quietly remained at 5, Cheyne Row.” She reported that Maggie Welsh was coming “next Tuesday [16 Feb.]”: “I have never seen her; but I have no doubt we will be very good friends for all that. And she will be good company for me for I confess sometimes the days seem long & my copying gets monotonous and then I threaten to get quite to homesick and go to immortal smash” (MS: Harry Ransom Lib., Univ. of Texas). Maggie Welsh was apparently helping organize household tasks as TC’s London bank checkbook noted: “17 March 1869 / to Margt Welsh (for House &c) / £50 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). stay here (busy enough)They were copying JWC’s letters. till I come back. “April 6” is the extreme limit.—Melchet
Court / Romsey / Hants: that is the Address; whh Mary shall repeat to some of you when I do go.John A. Carlyle replied, 21 March: “I am glad you have resolved to get done with that visit to Lady A. & I think may very likely do you considerable good.”

Forster was here an hour since; busy very, setting all things straight, and rivetting them as with clink-nails, betn Chapman & me. He has lost a certn Emerson Tenant (fellow-Apprentice &c of his) in a very tragic way;Sir James Emerson Tennent (1804–69; ODNB), 1st bart., politician, traveler, and writer. Born James Emerson, he assumed the name Tennent on the death of his father-in-law, William Tennent (d. 1832), whose estates he inherited. He was called to the bar at Lincoln’s Inn, 1831 (although he never practiced); he presumably knew Forster through Lincoln’s Inn, although Forster was not called there until 1843; Forster lived there until his marriage, 1856. Tennent d., 6 March, of a sudden and unexpected stroke. TC met Emerson (as he then was) in Paris, 1824; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 308; for the visit, see 3:178–88TC to JBW, 28 Oct. 1824. his own health appears rather to be improving.—— Frank Cunningham called the other day when I was out; meaning nothing, I am sure. Ever since his paltry appearance in that Letter to Forster,Col. Francis Cunningham (1820–75; ODNB), soldier and literary editor; there had been some unexplained difficulty the previous year between Cunningham and Forster; see 45:116[11] April 1868; see also TC to JCA, 16 Nov.c’est un homme chassé [he is a hunted man].

Tell Jean I wd have her take in hand for me this Lr from “Wilha Richardson,” poor soul. Write that I bid her say how deep and loving is my memory of her Mother, my interest in her too (sadly obscured as she is),Jane Wilhelmina Richardson (1801–82), always known as Wilhelmina, and her mother, Catherine Eliza Richardson (1777–1853; ODNB), poet and novelist; the Carlyles knew them in the late 1820s when at Craigenputtoch. The last recorded contact was when JWC visited Wilhelmina in Aug. 1862; see 38:166–67JWC to TC, [27 Aug. 1862], and Wilhelmina wrote a letter to TC shortly after which he sent it on to JWC; see 38:232TC to JWC, 3 Oct. 1862, and 235JWC to ET, 4 Oct. [1862]. At the time Wilhelmina was living in Maxwelltown, on the N bank of the river Nith opposite Dumfries. —that I have read her “Poem” (Jean may “revise” it if she see good). In short, I commit the affair to Jean; if she judged it wise, I wd ask her to go & see the poor forsaken “Wullie,” who is to me a tragic relique to me.“[T]o me” repeated by TC. —— Not a word more, dear Brr,—except perhaps one to Jamie as he passes,“[P]asses” repeated with a line over “pass” at turn of page. That I was very glad to hear of the Stumpy trees getting fairly stuck in, as I hope they now all are.John A. Carlyle replied, 21 March, confirming progress at Craigenputtoch: “Last night I had a note from James Jr telling me the planting at Stumpy corner had been satisfactorily completed. … Of Scotch Firs & Spruces 1100 each, of Birches 1000, Alders 800 & of Larches only 100–in all 4100 trees planted.” With love to all, Yrs ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JT [JTY], 20 March. MS: Royal Institution, RI MS JT/1/C14. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN TYNDALL

docBody.p: Bring yr American down on Monday Evg if you can (8½ p.m.);—tell him I am far from disliking Americans that are likeable;Charles Eliot Norton, American author and journalist visiting Europe, expressed a wish to meet TC to his friend Mountstuart Grant-Duff (1829–1906; ODNB), politician and author. John Tyndall wrote, 20 March: “There is an American gentleman;—a gentleman I believe in the true sense, really gentle and cultured who longs to see you.” Tyndall later recalled: “Grant-Duff … informed me that an accomplished American friend of his was very anxious to know Carlyle, but that he was held back by the notion that Carlyle disliked Americans. I was able to say on the spot that this was an error. From my own direct questionings I had learned that the feelings of the old man were those of gratitude rather than of dislike. At a time when his own countrymen, failing to recognise his need of a form of expression suited to his genius, had set him down as merely eccentric and wayward … America … had opened to him her mind, her heart, her purse. Still, to make assurance doubly sure, I told Grant-Duff that I would go down to Chelsea and make myself acquainted with Carlyle’s present feelings. I went, and mentioned this conjectural dislike of Americans. ‘What nonsense!’ he exclaimed; ‘bring him down here immediately’” (Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 25). Norton had already heard a great deal about TC from various friends, including James Fitzjames Stephen; Norton wrote to a friend, 1 Jan.: “[Fitzjames Stephen] is a great friend of Carlyle’s, and walks with him often on Sunday afternoons. He says Carlyle is habitually in a state of very cheerful despondency, appropriate to the most wilfully dyspeptic man in her Majesty’s Dominions. He is growing old, and has to be humoured a good deal. He is more extravagant in talk than ever; but one would rather hear him talk for two hours than any other man in London,—‘and besides, he is so kind, with a real hearty kindness’” (Norton’s Letters 1:314). on the contrary, I feel a natl blood-relatnship to them, and am sad when they are not of that pleasant category.Norton described the meeting in his journal, 23 March: “Carlyle came in, in look like his recent photographs, save that there is less of despair and despondency in his actual countenance, and less wildness and uncouthness in his hair and aspect generally. His frame is large, his head is heavy and seems to have bent his broad shoulders, but there is nothing either in look or manner to suggest the feebleness of age. He is seventy-four years old, but he seems younger than his years. His hair is iron grey and he was dressed in a grey woolen wrapper buttoned round his chest and falling like a long dressing gown to his very feet, which were cased in slippers. No one could see him without being impressed by the massive shape and strong lines of his countenance and with the force and brilliancy of his deep-set eyes. He received us quietly and pleasantly, with a certain air of shyness, I fancied” (Norton’s Letters 1:323). TC talked to Grant-Duff about recent parliamentary debates, which he called “the miserable degradation of the faculties of man in such a convocation of discoursers” (Norton’s Letters 1:324); Norton noted: “All this talk was lightened by the play of Carlyle’s face and by the laugh with which he showed his own sense of the fun in the sallies of his extravagance or his humour. He would seem to be desperately in earnest in his objurgations when the humour would surprise him, as it were, in spite of himself and he had to give way to it” (Norton’s Letters 1:325). Norton concluded his journal entry: “It was half-past ten when we came away. The old man came to the door with us and out on the step, where he stood talking, bareheaded, in the moonlight, leaning forward, with one hand raised, as he urged upon Tyndall the consideration of a new theory he had propounded as to the cause of the internal heat of the earth. It was a striking and picturesque view of him” (Norton’s Letters 1:327).

Two Papers of yrs I read; clear as azure & sunlight, both of them; sequel to the 2d is one of the things I look forward to;—the first, with its clean spiritual radiancy, and pure sky-blue of subject and treatt,Tyndall was a prolific lecturer and writer, and it is not known to which articles TC refers; one of them was probably “On Chemical Rays, and the Light of the Sky,” Fortnightly Review (Feb. 1869): 226–48, a distillation of his three articles in the Proceedings of the Royal Society of London (Dec. 1868): “On a New Series of Chemical Reactions Produced by Light” (92–102), “On the Blue Colour of the Sky, the Polarization of Skylight, and on the Polarization of Light by Cloudy Matter Generally” (223–33), and “Note on the Formation and Phenomena of Clouds” (317–19). The other was possibly Tyndall’s paper on the “Scientific Limit of the Imagination,” delivered to the British Association at Norwich, 19 Aug. 1868 (although it is not known if or where pbd.); Tyndall was preparing a second paper, “Scientific Use of the Imagination,” to be delivered to the British Association at Liverpool, 16 Sept. 1870. Concluding the second lecture, Tyndall echoed one of TC’s favorite expressions: “‘Two things,’ said Immanuel Kant, ‘fill me with awe: the starry heavens and the sense of moral responsibility in man’” (John Tyndall, Essays on the Use and Limit of the Imagination in Science [1870] 51). was a kind of antidote to the
Huxley Protoplasm,See TC to JAC, 20 Feb.; for photographs of Huxley and Tyndall mounted on the same page in vol. 6 of the Thomas Carlyle Photograph Albums, see 35. one of the vilest clever doggeries I have ever read; a true douche of stable droppings, from whh I am hardly yet quite washed. Pah!—

figure.p:
Thomas Huxley John Tyndall
undated photographs
Thomas Carlyle Papers, 1865–1896, Rare Book & Manuscript Library,
Columbia University in the City of New York

docBody.p: Tell me as soon as you can when yr Lectures do begin. I have a kind of reason; being bound for Melchet soon.
In superlative haste, and with such a hand! / yrs ever truly / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-AM [AMAC], 6 April. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd. Written on Melchet Court headed note-paper. TC probably sent the letter to Percival for forwarding: “A. Macmillan Esq, Publisher, Bedford Street (?) Covent Garden London” was written on the reverse.
div3.head: TC TO ALEXANDER MACMILLAN

docBody.p: The Revd W. R. Percival,William Robert Percival (1826–76) was ordained as a congregational minister, 1862, then moved to London, 1866, where he was ordained into the Church of England. a young Clergyman of the Church of Engld, with whom I once latterly had some agreeable discourse,Percival wrote to TC, 13 July 1868, from St. Helen’s, Lancashire, saying how much he admired him and would like to meet him (MS: NLS 1769.57). and had known before, from some reported lecturings &c of his,Percival lived for some years in Carlisle and was a friend of Mary Smith (1822–89; ODNB), teacher and radical, one of JWC’s correspondents; see 37:49–50JWC to MS, [late Nov. 1860], and 41:205–06JWC To MS, 10 April [1865]. Smith was a great admirer of Percival and reported his sermons in the Carlisle Observer (see Mary Smith, The Autobiography of Mary Smith, Schoolmistress and Nonconformist [1892] 231–46). She possibly sent some of her pieces to the Carlyles; see also 39:244–45TC to JAC, 15 Nov. 1863. for a man of vigorous and honest mind,—is desirous, for various reasons, of doing something for yr Magazine; and, with that view, has prepared a short Paper “On Poetry and Working People”; whh this Note, accordg to promise given, is to introduce for him to yr notice. I unluckily don’t know yr now Editor;Macmillan’s editor, 1868–83, was George Grove (1820–1900; ODNB), writer. There is no record of Macmillan’s publishing anything by Percival. therefore must give you personally this trouble.

The Paper itself I have not read, and can say nothing of: I only engaged that it wd not be rejected witht real examinatn, and consideratn of its qualities and symptoms; nor perhaps, even in that worst case, if you saw promise
in the Author or in it, witht something of suggestn or advice whh might avail him on a future occasn.

Pray absolve me honourably from this promise; I will take it as one of the many favrs you have done me.Probably a reference to JWC’s friendship with Alexander Macmillan and his family; she stayed with them, June 1865, when she was ill with a painful arm; see 42:58JWC to TC, [3 June 1865]. —— I am not well to-day; my very hand (as you may perceive) refuses to write more than what is absolutely indispensable.
docBody.closer: I remain always / Yrs sincerely,T. Carlyle

bibl.person: Robert Scott Tait OR FREDERIC CHAPMAN

div3.sourceNote: TC-[RST or FC] [RSTFC], 12 April. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd. Recipient conjecturally identified as Robert Scott Tait, because of TC’s reference to the autotype process, but might otherwise be Frederic Chapman, because of his involvement in the illustrations for Frederick.
div3.head: TC TO [Robert Scott Tait OR FREDERIC CHAPMAN]

docBody.p: I am just returned from a week of “country recreatn”TC visited Lady Ashburton, 2–10 April; he wrote, 29 April: “I was at Melchet lately for a week; all imaginable kindness &c &c,—but was obliged to leave, in a week, for absolute want of sleep. Can’t go (nor have been genlly for years past) to such places any more. Small sacrifice, or none. The idle talk of mankind is grown quite unwelcome to me” (TC’s journal; privately owned). Mary Aitken wrote to Lady Ashburton, probably Tues. 13 April, after TC’s return from Melchet: “We are fairly settled down here again & I think my Uncle looks much better than he did before going to Melchet—& he is sleeping pretty well. I think the great mistake he made at Melchet was transacting the most of his sleep before, instead of after, going to bed” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). —whh turned out to be mainly “a week of want of sleep”;—and am completely done up for the prest! So that, alas, there is nothing for yr kind offer of Thursday Evg, but Impossible, Impossible!—

I hear nothing abt those Autotype things; from the BoilersAutotype was a new process for reproducing pictures; it involved using hot water to wash away a layer of chemicals to expose a print; the “Boilers” were presumably the people who were working the process with hot water. TC may have been referring to stereotypes for the library edn.; see TC’s agreement with Frederic Chapman, 29 April. or elsewhere, still nothing;—and have come to the resolutn of giving up the intolerable and seemingly endless haggle of [word illegible] promise-breaking and confusion;—and will request you now to get my Two PrintsPossibly of frontispieces for the library edn. sent down to me without further delay (they were promised me back “in 3 days,” and it is now 4 months!)—that so I (who am quite unfit for such continued irritatn and botheratn) may wash my hands of the dirty affair altogether.— Please attend to this, and much oblige

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 15 April. MS: NLS 526.89. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I had two very pleast and welcome Notes from you; whh I wd have replied to sooner, and at greater length,—but really I was not able; I may actually say so! At Melchet I had first two good nights of sleep, spirits much risen in consequence;—but directly on the 3d night not a wink of sleep at all—nor ever aftds, struggle and precaution as I might, a sleep to call tolerable. In short I cd do no good whatr there, complete as was the kindness to me, and incessant the bother: so I came off on Saty evg,10 April. under Woolner’s escort,—and escaped a certain “Dr Carpenter”Probably Alfred John Carpenter (1825–1892), physician and propagandist for the cause of sewage farming; he lived in Croydon, near Lady Ashburton’s farm at Addiscombe. John A. Carlyle replied, 16 April: “It was well to avoid Carpenter whose talk would have been utterly intolerable to you unless he has changed.” &c, whh was desirable Here too I have already two good nights (the latter of them yesternight, thank Heaven); and two shockingly bad (zeros indeed or nearly so): had you seen my handwriting yesterday, it wd have struck you!—— —— In brief I have had a quite alarming kind of time with want of sleep these many months; ever since Septr abt half of my sleep changed into mere vigilance, woe, and misery now & then rising to the heights! Whh has set me on various grave reflexns;—and questns, “Is there no remedy, then? None but the one infallible?” &c &c But I am not going to entertain you with that today;—simply with Jenny’s Canada Letter,Their sister Janet Hanning, living in Hamilton, Ontario, had asked for financial help towards buying a house; she was to purchase a site and build a house; see TC to JAC, 3 July. whh came at breakfast time.

figure.p:
Thomas Carlyle’s check stub, 17 April 1869
Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.p: Pray read it, weigh it; for I mean to go by yr decisn. I am for myself perfectly ready, and even desirous, to send either the half or the whole of the money for that “House &c,” if you think the enterprize a sound one. Sound for them, still more than for me or for us?— Rare indeed are the occasns when one can really help a Br or Sister by money;—and a right good and welcome investt, it certainly is in that affirmative contingency!—— Study the thing, therefore; and tell me what we are to do.John A. Carlyle replied, 16 April: “I have fully considered Jenny’s proposal, & I conclude it will be proper to send her the money she asks for, & I purpose sending it by tomorrow’s post. … For one thousand Dollars the sum is £225, & you can repay me the half ( £112 .. 10) if you chose. … I mean also to send the money in Jenny’s own name & not her husbands, & to tell her it is for herself.” TC recorded in his checkbook: “17 April 1869 / to Brr John (my half of Jenny’s Canada Cottage: faustum sit [good luck to her]! / £112 .. 10 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook: MS: NLS 20573); see above. John wrote to Jenny, 17 April: “Our brother has forwarded to me your letter of 1st April, desiring me to decide what I think best in regard to your request for the loan to purchase a house of your own in Hamilton. And I enclose an order of £225. … The order is for yourself & will require to be signed by you, & I should like to have the house bought in your name too, & for yourself. As to establishing the Store you speak of, I should strongly advise you not to attempt anything of the sort” (MS: Yale). John then wrote to TC, 20 April: “I received your cheque today. … I also wrote again to Jenny, enclosing a scrap of your note to shew her that you entirely agreed with me in regard to having the house bought for herself.” They presumably wanted the house in Jenny’s name alone because her husband, Robert, had never been trusted since the years when they lived separately, 1841–51; see 13:206TC to AC, [1 Aug. 1841].

Poor old John’s LetterJohn Carlyle, their half-brother (see TC to JAC, 9 Feb.), wrote to John A. Carlyle, 18 March: “I am thankfull that I have it in my power to answer your kind letter and likely wise my good Brother Thos his kind present and yours have come safe to hand. I have thought some times that I was not like one of the family, but now there is a brothery love kindeled in my bosom that will never be forgot” (MS: NLS 1775D.20). The letter went on to describe his earlier life in the U.S. (“No sabbath kept by the settlers”) and then his immigration to Canada where he felt much more at home; see 12:228TC to AC, 15 Aug. 1840. was very good; bid Jean write to him,—why not to me too!— Tomorrow (if it is Canadn Postday?) Mary shall fire off a word to poor Jenny (and her “ague” poor little soul), intimating that she shall have ansr in a week more.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JH, 23 April. Pbd: Shepherd, Carlyle 2:235–37; Wilson, Carlyle 6:193 inc; Hilary Christie-Johnston, Joseph Henderson: Doyen of Glasgow Artists 1832–1908 (Melbourne, Australia, 2013) 21 inc. Joseph Henderson (1832–1908; ODNB), Scottish portrait painter and also, from about 1871, of seascapes; trained in Edinburgh, he settled in Glasgow 1853.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH HENDERSON

docBody.p: The picture is beautiful (colouring, finish, &c. all excellent);Henderson had been commissioned to do a portrait of JWC from a photograph; Percy Bate wrote about the commission: “Glasgow folk did not … pay too lavishly at that time for either pictures or drawings, and Joseph Henderson, with domestic claims increasing and sitters few and infrequent, did not disdain the production of likenesses painted from photographs. Many of these doubtless survive; of one of them, at any rate, a pleasant souvenir still exists in the shape of a letter from Thomas Carlyle [see TC to JH, 8 May]” (P. Bate, “Introduction,” The Art of Joseph Henderson [Glasgow, 1908] 14). Henderson was also a watercolorist, so possibly it was a small watercolor portrait sent to TC as he mentions its coloring, rather than a photograph of an oil painting. The portrait is untraced. and has a great resemblance,—though to me almost a distressing one, the expression being such a failure! In general, I find the look of the face to be sickly, suffering, and even querulous,—which latter it surely never was. The photograph, as I have always read it, has something of a gentle stoical smile; nothing of complaint, though perhaps there is visible also enough to complain of. Such at least was the habitual expression of the face in such situation.

I am too little of an artist to say what detail, or details (probably something very small) would quite rectify the picture; I was struck, first of all, by the smallness and comparative insignificance of the eye,—and have sent Mr McNabAlexander Macnab (b. ca. 1822), Glasgow photographic artist and portrait painter; his studio was at 92 W. Nile St., Glasgow. a different photograph, hoping he might himself see the defect there, and what was to be done about it. The eyes, in every face, are the chief feature; but in this face they were in it infinitely so,—bright hazel, radiant with
many meanings. The new photograph which shows both the eyes,Apparently the photograph of JWC used by Henderson was a side view and that sent to Macnab a front view. Neither photograph is identified. gives truly what the habitual expression there and otherwise was.— I still think something could be done on that eye, and perhaps on the immediate surroundings of it, to supply what is wanting there.
I also notice the top part of the cheek (where it joins the nose), as having something slightly swoln-like, which is untrue, and perhaps hurtful? Nothing else can I specifically suggest.

If Mr. McNab, by diligent inspection of the photograph, and judicious consideration of these poor hints, can guess or see what is wanting, and do it, he will confer a favour on me not to be forgotten while I live.TC noted in his Dumfries bank checkbook: “17 May 1869 / to Ar M’Nab, Glasgow, (PHOTOGh:—alas!) / £2 .. 2 .. 6” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).
23rd April 1869.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 28 April. Addr: Miss Orrock’s Lodgings / 73. George Street / Edinburgh. PM: London, 28 April 1869. MS: NLS 526.90. Quot: A. Carlyle, NL 2:256–57.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Yr Lr of Monday was expected; all the welcomer, when it duly came,—tho’ there was one sad bit of news. Poor Syme;On 6 April James Syme suffered a stroke, which rendered him partially paralyzed. John A. Carlyle wrote, 25 April: “I have not seen Syme yet. He had a shock of apoplexy some three weeks ago, which made him insensible for a few instants only, but since then he has not returned back to town or seen any patients at Millbank.” what a fateful contrast since we were there! He told me, his poor Wife had bidden him, in her last hours,Syme’s wife, Jemima, d. 1 Feb.; see TC to JSY, 5 Feb. Not grieve for her, but save himself by standing stedfastly to whatsoever of work he had to do; and this, he said, was what he had resolved to try and effect. As he has been doing, and on the last day was conspicuously doing (it seems),—when in one moment he is struck down, as by a bolt from the Blue!John continued: “On the day on which the shock occurred he had done two rather serious operations at the Infirmary & also one in private, with all his usual dexterity. The shock took place at his town house, & he would have fallen heavily had not his servant caught hold of him.” I cannot get him out of mind. That fine new drawing; that perfectn of health, success, and human well-doing,—gone in one flash!— I fear by the lingering & weakness in so active and elastic an old man, the case is very questionable; and his
work at any rate must be impracticable farther. But let us trust he will still live; perhaps in clearness and good health, with perfectly prudent care, whh I shd expect to be likely from a man of his charactr.John continued: “It is the opinion of all the Drs … that Syme will not be able to resume practice without danger of relapse, but may with proper care continue well. He got his proposals for the new Infirmary (about which Mrs Syme had been anxious too) triumphantly carried after great exertions about a month ago, so that it will be easier for him to retire.” Syme had wanted the new Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh built in a more healthy location; see 45:204TC to JAC, 26 Nov. 1868. If you see him, say on my poor part everything that is kind and ever-grateful; my deepest sympathies are with him, if alas these were good for anything.

Poor Tom Stewart, too; we were greatly shocked by the sad surprise, after yr preceding hopeful Letter.Thomas Stewart, the husband of their niece Margaret, d. 20 April. John A. Carlyle wrote, 16 April, that Stewart was “desperately ill from fever, on Saturday & Sunday [10 and 11] especially. … A very favourable report came on Tuesday, & on Wednesday the Dr thought all danger past.” He then wrote, 20 April: “We have just been surprised & shocked to hear that Thomas Stewart died at four o’clock this afternoon. At the end of last week he was thought to be out of danger, but must have got out of bed on Sunday & caught cold for he was seized with inflammation of the lungs on the evening of Sunday & the Dr sent for, & died in consequence of that inflammation.” I wrote a little Note to Mary:Their sister Mary Austin, Margaret Stewart’s mother. let us hope Margt, a clever active creature, may be able still to manage there.Margaret had three surviving children and was pregnant; her son Thomas was b. 27 May; they lived at Ernhirst, about 5½ mi. (9 km.) SW of Dumfries.

Dickens, I find by Forster who was just here, has narrowly escaped death (if he yet have escaped) by rushing abt “on his readings,”—in chase of still other thousands of pounds, whh he needed so little! That wd have been the sorriest of all these tragic endings,—traditional mockery thrown in as an ingredt!— Poor Ld Stanley is now past hope.TC noted in his journal: “Anniversary ‘April 21:’ I was at the spot this time: have since repeatedly been.—Ld Stanley dying; poor sculptor Munro (at Cannes) dying;—the excellt Surgn Syme (of Edinr) struck by apoplexy (lost his brave good Wife &c); Dickens (playacting, or ‘reading,’ to excess) within an inch of being struck:—what a scene is this!” (TC’s journal; privately owned). The 21st of April was the anniversary of JWC’s death in Hyde Park; the previous year TC had been out of London at the time; see 45:115TC to JCA, [11] April 1868. Lord Stanley died in London, 16 June. Alexander Munro (1825–71; ODNB), sculptor; m., 1861, Mary Carruthers; his bust of Lord Ashburton was exhibited at the Royal Academy in 1860; see 41:120JWC to LLA, 7 Dec. [1864]; -Munro’s father-in-law, Robert Carruthers (1799–1878), Dumfriesshire born journalist and writer, wrote to TC about Munro’s serious illness; TC wrote on the envelope of Carruthers’ letter: “Carruthers (poor Munro!) 22 April 1869.” Dickens had begun a farewell tour of readings, 6 Oct. 1868, but by late April 1869 his doctors had ordered him to rest because of exhaustion.

Mary has been off in Livpl; glided off, on the sudden, on Thursday last, to meet her Mother, see Margt (who was ill of some complaints)Mary Aitken; her mother, Jean Aitken, was visiting her son James and da. Margaret who now lived in Liverpool; see 45:94TC to JCHA, 14 Feb. 1868. Jean returned to The Hill 6 May. &c &c: is not
coming back till Saty,—left free on this side to come when she likes. From or of her Mother I hear nothing,—except that she is rather sleeping ill.John A. Carlyle, 16 April, had sympathized with TC’s complaints about insomnia at Melchet (see TC to JAC, 15 April), mentioning that he, their brother James, and Jean also suffered from insomnia: “I suffer a good deal myself in that way, & both Jamie at Scotsbrig, & Jean here also suffer; so I suppose there must be something of a family sort in the matter.” Margt, it seems, is better agn.— — When Maggie Welsh is to go, I don’t know,—and rather wish I did. I fancy it may be soon after a certn Glasgow Photogrh Portrait (whh has been here once, but cd not please me) has been got done.Presumably Joseph Henderson; for TC’s first response, see TC to JHEN, 23 April; for his response to Henderson’s 2d attempt, see TC to JHEN, 8 May.— Ah me, ah me; I often feel I am best, when left absolutely alone in the ditch, to my own sad and stern reflexns there.

Since Mary went I have had my very worst bit of sleeplessness: out of 5 nights only 2 with real sleep,—of whh happily last night was one. Otherwise I cd not have written today either. This new questn of sleep is sometimes like driving me desperate; but can’t either, nor shall!— I want from you a dozen of pills,Presumably hop pills, which TC used to help him sleep; see 40:37. John A. Carlyle was currently in Edinburgh, and he replied, 29 and 30 April: “Just now I am going to get the Pills & will send them along with this.” It is likely that he got them from Duncan, Flockhart & Co., pharmacists, at 52 North Bridge and 139 Princes St., Edinburgh; see 43:23JWC to BB, 27 Oct. [1865]. for one thing; don’t forget,—I have now only one left

Say to Dr BrownDr. John Brown, old friend of John A. Carlyle, had dined with them in Edinburgh when TC was staying with the surgeon Syme for his hernia operation, July 1868; see 45:161TC to JF, 2 Aug. 1868. Brown was one of the doctors attending Syme; see also 40:106TC to HL, 29 May 1864. something kind from me: my“My” repeated with a line over it at turn of page. affecte respects & love to Erskine.— I sent 3 Copies of the new (small & cheap) Friedh in 7 voll. to Edinr,—one to John Gordon, do to Masson & to Laing.John A. Carlyle had been seeing many of their mutual friends while in Edinburgh; he had visited Thomas Erskine several times and went with him to visit Betty Braid, 24 April; he also saw John Gordon (1797–1882; see 35:biographical notes), David Masson, and David Laing.
Adieu, dear Brr; it is striking 4 / Yrs ever / T. Carlyle
TC’S NOTE

In a quiet street nr Covent Garden, one sunny day, with a considerable straggle of audience, I found this artist, industriously fiddling and singing, what seemed to be a succinct doggerel Histy of Man (in Paradise as yet). Artist was not very old, but wanted the front teeth, was rather dirty, had a beard of 3-weeks, &c, and for the rest a look of great assiduity and earnestness in his vocatn; insisting on longs & shorts with clear emphasis by fiddle and voice. These were the words I heard (accentuated as here):

lg.l: “’E ’ad all things was p[l]east in life
The all-wise grĕat Creator (with a deep italTC wrote “ital” above “deep”; presumably for “Italian.” scrape of the fiddle)

docBody.closer: Ay de mi, how strange at this moment (29 April 1869)!As part of his continuing work on JWC’s letters, TC wrote this note, 29 April, as a footnote to one of JWC’s letters to Jean Aitken, ca. 11 Oct. 1843; JWC described an old man in the vicinity who sang the song “He had all that was pleasant in life / But … he wan-ted a wife,” accompanying himself on the fiddle; see 17:152–53JWC to JCA, [ca. 11 Oct. 1843]; first pbd: Letters and Memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle, ed. J. A. Froude (1883) 1:266. TC wrote in his journal, 29 April: “I have been dreadfully tormented agn (agn & ever agn, since Septr last!),—busy too, at all available moments, with Her Letters; my one consolatn, in the worst days, that I do something then,—lest it be left at last un done, and none alive able to do it! Unless this sleepless new misery leave me, it is my last task here below. To Her, of no use,—none, alas none!—neverthels must, if I live to be done. … Perhaps that mournful but pious and ever interestg Task; escorted by such miseries, night after night and month after month;—perhaps all this may be wholesome punisht, purificatn, and monitn, and agn a blessing in disguise? ” (TC’s journal; privately owned).

div3.sourceNote: TC’s agreement with Frederic Chapman [AFC], 29 April. MS: Bodleian Lib., Oxford Univ. Dex 316. At the top of the document is written, in another hand: “The whole of the text of this agreement is in the autograph of JOHN FORSTER, (who was a Barrister at Law), & witness to the agreement.” “ £50.0.0” was also written at the top in yet another hand; this appears to have no reference to anything in the document, so was possibly the price asked for, or paid by, the Bodleian.
