docBody.p: Memorandum of agreement made this 29th day of April 1869, between Thomas Carlyle Esq of No 5 Cheyne Row, Chelsea, of the one part, and Frederick Chapman, publisher, of 193 Piccadilly, Westminster, carrying on business under the title of Chapman and Hall,TC wrote in his journal, 29 April: “Today I meet Forster & Chapman, to sign Bargn of ‘Library Editn,’—good Fr takes inexpressible pains abt all that; strange really, and compelling thanks!— Time now to dress for going on that errand” (TC’s journal; privately owned). of the other part, for the publication of a new edition of Mr Carlyle’s works to be printed in demy octavo, and called “The Library Edition of the works of Thomas Carlyle [no closing quotes]; on the terms and conditions hereinafter stated:—namely:—

I. That, for the first edition of one thousand copies of each volume, Frederick Chapman shall pay to Mr Carlyle the sum of thirty five pounds (£35) and shall bear all the expense of printing, stereotyping, and paper; of binding, advertising &c;—in short all the expense attending the publication.

II. The stereotypes of the several volumes, as each successively is published, are to be the property of Mr Carlyle:Chapman & Hall wrote to Robson & Son affirming that the stereotypes were to be TC’s property, 29 April: “Memorandum … To Messrs. Robson & Son [TC added: “Printers, 32 Stainton Terrace, Princes Road, N. W.”]… The stereotype plates of Mr Carlyle’s Works, Library Edition, for which we have paid all costs incurred by you, have become the property of Mr. Carlyle under an Agreement this day executed; and you will take Mr. Carlyle’s order, in future, absolutely respecting them / Chapman & Hall” (MS: NLS 20752). TC wrote on the reverse of the memorandum: “(Robson, & Stereotypes of Library Edn) n.b. has all my stereotypes of every editn, all mine wholly, & in his keeping (cases too are!)— T.C. 27 Feby 1870.” assignment of the same to be made by Frederick Chapman at the respective dates of publication of the volumes in their order.

III. That for all reprints Mr Carlyle undertakes to lend to Frederick Chapman the stereotypes to print from, and Frederick Chapman agrees to pay to Mr Carlyle for their use, a royalty of two shillings and fourpence (-2s-4d) per copy on the volumes published at nine shillings (-9s-) and one shilling and eightpence (-1s-8d) per copy on the volumes published at seven shillings and sixpence (-7s-6d)

IV. The Royalty on the first thousand copies printed of each volume to be paid to Mr Carlyle half-yearly, and settled by a bill at four months; and the royalties on all reprints to be made up half-yearly, and to be paid as the number of volumes printed by a bill at four months.

V. For all copies sold to America at half-price Mr Carlyle agrees to receive one half of the amount on each volume above specified for royalty, namely, one shilling and twopence (-1s-2d) per volume for the volumes published at nine shillings (-9s-) and tenpence (- -10d) per volume for the volumes published at seven shillings and sixpence (-7s-6d). It being further understood and agreed that Mr Carlyle is to have access at all times to the trade books of Frederick Chapman for the purpose of ascertaining the number of copies that may have been, under this section of the agreement, sent to America.

VI. This agreement to be determinable at any time by either of the parties to it, upon nine months notice given by either; and after such notice shall have been given, no reprint is to be made without Mr Carlyle’s permission expressed in writing.
In Witness whereof the aforesaid parties have herewith set their hands this 29th day of April 1869.
In the presence of
John Forster
docBody.closer: Thomas Carlyle Fred: ChapmanJohn Forster, TC, and Frederic Chapman each signed the document.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 6 May. MS: NLS 526.91. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Yr Last Note from Edinr was very interesting; I have since from Dumfrs had two (one this morning), for whh also I am obliged. Syme, I am thankful to see, we may expect to struggle thro and get into health agn, if not into much activity.John A. Carlyle wrote, 29 April: “I have seen Syme again this morning & had a walk with him through some of his hot-houses, which contain curious plants in which he takes much interest.” He reported, 30 April: “Syme has grown considerably thinner. His right hand & the whole of his right side are quite sound. He looked cheerful.” He then wrote, 5 May: “This morning I have a note from Dr J. Brown, dated last night, which gives a favourable report of Syme & shews how prudently he manages himself.” Poor old Erskine too,—poor old Betty, &c &c—ay de mi.

This Adamson’s yearly Acct;Samuel Adamson, manager of the British Linen Co. Bank, Dumfries, where TC had one of his accounts. came yesterday: and I send it off for yr deliberate inspectn,—since I can give it none effectual. Pray see into the bottom of it (as you can); on yr report, I will return Adamn’s circular certificate.Presumably a legal acknowledgment of the accuracy of the account. John A. Carlyle replied, 7 May: “I have taken your Account to the … Bank … found it quite correct, exchanged vouchers & signed for you, so that you need take no farther trouble in the matter at all. Balance in your favour 15th April 1869 £1535 .. 5 .. 5 as Adamson says. … [Y]ou might mark this in your cheque Book for your own convenience.” In fact John himself wrote in TC’s checkbook: “Cheques up to this one (March 16/69 inclusive) examined by me, & compared with Messrs Adamson & Symons & Accounts (paid up to15th April)—all of wh I found correct, leaving Balance to Credit £1535 .. 5 .. 5 on the 15th April 1869 / JAC” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).

Mary is here, safe enough, since Friday; I hope her Mother will come to hand with you today in good conditn. Poor Maggie Welsh wont stay long now, I suppose; meanwhile she is copying along with Mary,Maggie Welsh was helping Mary Aitken with the copying of JWC’s letters. and is otherwise (politely & modestly) zealous to help. Poor Maggie, I am really wae for her, in the wreck of Walter, Mary (still worse perhaps),Maggie’s brother Walter Welsh, minister at Auchtertool, Fife, was deeply in debt; see 45:170TC to AWE, 13 Sept. 1868. Maggie and her sister Mary usually lived with him. John A. Carlyle wrote, 15 June: “Of late I have had a good deal of correspondence with Mrs Chrystal [Maggie and Mary’s sister] about her sister Mary who has been taking opium &c for many years in excessive quantities. It was first prescribed to her in small doses, for some illness … & it appears she has gradually been increasing the quantity.” There were to be consultations with various doctors; John continued: “Mrs Chrystal is to write again … & tell me the final decision they have come to in the matter. The details were all very painful to me, & I kept from speaking about them to you on that account.” Although at the time of this letter TC may not have known details, he clearly knew that Mary Welsh was suffering in some way. and the poor Manse genlly!— Walter is for trying to let the Manse during the summer months, by way of gaining a £20 or £30,—the only honest method he has.

I am sleeping better for the last 4 nights, the last 2 especially I wish it wd continue! The pills came punctually; I sup latterly oftenest on a few spoonfuls of brown-soup;—but that doesn’t quite suit either. I am to try arrow-root. Nothing “suits,” I fear!—

Watts’s “Portrait” is engraved;For the engraving of Watts’s portrait of TC, see TC to JAC, 6 March. and will come out, mo[n]th after next: decidedly the most unsufferable “Picture” of me there has yet been (in my own poor opinn). A delirious-looking mountebank, full of violence, awkwardness, atrocity & stupidity,—witht recognizable Likeness to anything I have ever known in any feature of me!For TC’s earlier, equally critical, views of the picture, see 45:195TC to CPH, 31 Oct. 1868.— Fuit in fatis [It was in the fates]:—what care I, after all? Forster is much content, with the Picture at least (I think with the Engraving itself),—and with the “150 guineas” too! The fault of Watts is, a passionate pursuit of “strength,” while he himself, poor fellow, is gone mainly into flaccid weakness.— Never mind, never mind.

Poor Arthur Buller is dead; suddenly, I cannot yet hear how.Sir Arthur William Buller (1808–69; ODNB; see 2:4–5TC to JCE, 12 Jan. [1822], and Carlyle, Reminiscences 269), former pupil of TC (1822–24), judge in India, and Liberal M.P. for Devonport 1859–65, and Liskeard 1865–69; his mother, Barbara Isabella Buller, b. Kirkpatrick (1788–1849), was a cousin of Catherine Phillipps, b. Kirkpatrick (1802–89; see 3:166–67TC to JCE, 4 Oct. 1824), with whom TC had recently become re-acquainted; see 45:191TC to CPH, 24 Oct. 1868. Buller d., 30 April, in 6 Half Moon St., Piccadilly. Abt a month ago I saw him, after long abeyance. Eheu eheu.— The Life of Sir Wm HamiltonJohn Veitch, Memoir of Sir William Hamilton, Bart. (Edinburgh, 1869). John A. Carlyle wrote, 2 May: “I called also for Lady Hamilton, but found she had gone out & saw only Miss H. who told me the Life of her Father was to come out yesterday.” Lady Janet Hamilton, b. Marshall (1802–77), her da. Elizabeth Hamilton (1840–82; ODNB), philosopher and educator. TC’s reminiscence of Hamilton, dated 19 Feb. 1868, was included in the book; see 45:92–93TC to JAC, [12] Feb. 1868; see also Carlyle, Reminiscences 427–33. TC knew and admired Sir William Hamilton (1788–1856; ODNB), philosopher, in the 1820s and 1830s. is here; read, not quite bad: shan’t I send it you? Speak a word.— From ErnhirstMargaret Stewart’s farm; John A. Carlyle wrote, 5 May: “Jamie of Scotsbrig has just called. He and James Jr are both going to Ernhirst, & James & a brother of Margaret’s husband are to see the Laird here & settle for some new footing for Margaret, that brother’s name being still in the Lease.” James Stewart, Thomas Stewart’s 2d brother, was the brother named on the lease. In the event, the lease was not finalized until Nov.; see TC to JAC, 3 Nov. news wd be welcome. Yr affecte Br

div3.sourceNote: TC-JH [JHEN], 8 May. Facsimile: Hilary Christie-Johnston, Joseph Henderson: Doyen of Glasgow Artists 1832–1908 (Melbourne, Australia, 2013) 21. Pbd: Shepherd, Carlyle 2:237; Percy Bate: “Introductory Essay,” The Art of Joseph Henderson (Glasgow, 1908) 14; Christie-Johnston, Joseph Henderson 22. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:193.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH HENDERSON

docBody.p: To Mr Henderson, Artist / Glasgow

Dear Sir,—You have with much delicacy & patience, followed all the hints I gave;For TC’s “hints,” see TC to JHEN, 23 April. The portrait is untraced. and surely I owe you many thanks. The Picture is decidedly improved;—evidtly the best Likeness I shall now ever get.
May yr Art always prosper with you! with many good wishes, I remain

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 26 May. Addr: Palace-Gate House / Kensington. PM: London, 26 May 1869. MS: Spencer Lib., Univ. of Kansas. Quot: CSA 31:47.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: and may you find poor Madame, at least, “a little better,”Forster visited his wife, Eliza Ann, who was staying with Elizabeth Sophia Landor (1815–89) at her home in Bishop’s Tachbrook, Warwickshire; he wrote, 23 May: “I returned to Tachbrook to see my wife; who came on a visit to Miss Landor ten days ago, and has since been so unwell that she has only managed to be out twice during her stay. She is now however a little better, and proposes to go back to London on Tuesday [25 May]. I go to Worcester tomorrow … until Wednesday afternoon—when I hope myself to return home.” Elizabeth Sophia Landor was the niece of Walter Savage Landor (1775–1864; ODNB). as she professed to be yesterday! Surely, surely this fine summer weather (rain now quite gone, I hope) will do her good!— Wd I were as sure of that as of the next sentence I am to write here.

Most certn it is, nothing has gone wrong in my relatn to Landor and his Life. I finished the Book two weeks ago, with increase, not diminutn of my respect for the many merits it has. A “monumental” work I call it; such its solidity, precision, massiveness, completeness;—a very mausoleum to the ungovernable old Hero; far beyond what he cd have expected; and a noble discharge of yr duty to him.John Forster, Walter Savage Landor. A Biography, 2 vols. (1869); see 45:18TC to JF, 17 Aug. 1867. Forster had been a friend of Landor’s and was his literary executor. See also 44:130TC to JF, 24 Jan. 1867. Forster wrote, 23 May: “I ought not to be so selfish, and I have been trying to take for granted that you don’t like the second volume of L—less than the first—but somehow I think I should like just to have one word, when you shall have been able to read it.”— This I shd have said in some form; and daily
meant to do so;—had not daily the mutinous hand (sorrow on it, and on me!) forbidden. For it tethers me in all ways; and I can hardly get the least of a task done till the hour itself drives me out.

Look in for a moment any day, you find me till 3 p.m. (too often 4!)—and the tongue has no unwillingness. Froude, I think, is gone to Ireland: he said he had written to you.Froude rented Derreen, Co. Kerry, a house in Ireland, for the summers; see TC to JAF, 14 Sept. Forster was seeking Froude’s help in obtaining a Civil List pension from the prime minister, William Gladstone, for Geraldine Jewsbury. Forster wrote, 16 May: “I have no doubt whatever that we shall get Miss Jewsbury’s name upon the next list; and meanwhile, if she should indeed be quite disabled from work, it will be easy so to anticipate her claim as to make it in no degree painful to her.” Forster reported, 27 May: “I saw Coleridge, the Solicitor General, last night, and spoke to him very urgently as to our memorial for Miss Jewsbury. He went into it, I am glad to say, very warmly—for Miss Jewsbury’s sake as well as ours—and said he’d use whatever influence he had with Gladstone at once about it”; Sir John Duke Coleridge (1820–94; ODNB), 1st Baron Coleridge, 1874; lawyer, liberal politician; M.P. for Exeter from 1865; solicitor gen., 1868–71, then attorney gen., both under Gladstone. Jewsbury was suffering from problems with her eyes; she did not receive a Civil List pension (of £40) until 1874.
Maggie Welsh is gone two hours ago; poor Maggie, I am sorry abt her too.— Till last night I have not missed sleep altogr for above 3 weeks.
Enough, enough; come tomorrow as you promise. Yrs ever

closer.note: Forster wrote, 16 May, telling TC of the death of his “dear old friend Dyce. … He was so good, so scholarly, so gentle—and knew so much that seems nowadays passing completely out of knowledge.” He continued: “[He] has left his books, & many curious things—to the Kensington Museum. His library of old English plays is, I believe, quite unique. I am his executor.” Alexander Dyce (1798–1869; ODNB), literary scholar; TC last met him at Forster’s house for his (TC’s) birthday dinner, 4 Dec. 1865; see 43:66TC to JAC, 5 Dec. 1865. TC had also been considering what to do with his library of books used for the writing of Cromwell and Frederick. On a walk with Charles Eliot Norton, early May, Norton described TC’s conversation in detail, including TC’s thoughts about his books: “I suppose there never was a man who had so much to do with books as I have, who owned so few. … But in writing about Cromwell and Friedrich I have chanced to get together some things not wholly worthless nor yet easy to find, and I’ve thought I should like when I die to leave these books to some institution in New England, where they might be preserved, and where they would serve as a testimony o’ the goodness o’ your people toward me and o’ the many acts of kindness they have done me; and perhaps you can help me to have this rightly done” (Norton’s Letters 1:336). Norton wrote to TC, 24 May, with his suggestion for an appropriate beneficiary in the U.S.: “I believe that your wishes would best be carried out were you to leave the books you propose to give, to the Library of Harvard College, Cambridge, Massachusetts” (Norton’s Letters 1:339). Norton quoted TC’s affirmation of his intention, written, “so illegibly that the quotation must be incomplete,” on the reverse of his letter: ‘n.b. I do intend that all the Friedrich books … and likewise all the Cromwell ones … shall go as a Bequest in the way indicated by Norton here. Very cern. that to whoever comes after me! T.C” (Norton’s Letters 1:339). TC’s intentions took formal shape from Nov. through Norton and Emerson; see TC to RWE, 18 Nov. and later letters. This collection became the Harvard Carlyle Collection (HCC).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, [5] June. Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N.B. PM: London, “TOO LATE” [part of the stamp], 5 June 1869; Dumfries, 7 June 1869. MS: NLS 526.92. Quot: CSA 31:47. John A. Carlyle replied, 9 June: “Your letter which I received yesterday was dated only ‘June,’ & till your note to James came this morning I had not observed the London post-mark on the cover, ‘Too late June 5.’” The letter, collected too late to be sent on Sat. 5 June, was presumably sent Sun. 6, delivered to Dumfries, 7 June, and delivered to The Hill the next day.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I have recd all yr Letters & news; and find it very good [of] you to keep patiently writing, time after time, witht getting any response from me: I guess you know what is the reason; that it cannot be my want of will, but my want of power most probably!Since TC’s last recorded letter to John A. Carlyle, 6 May, John had written four letters to him. However Mary Aitken wrote often, both to her mother and to him, with news of TC, so presumably he felt less need of writing regularly, particularly given his difficulties with handwriting. Whh is indeed the fact; this time especially I have been waiting, every day, the last fortnight, for a fit hour; and, by one poor cause and another, cd not find one. My hand itself is a very great obstructn, in this as in all respects; and that is not the only or the chief one, at prest! The truth is, I am fallen agn into one of my great gulphs, or abysses of sleeplessness,—whh I begin to discover are partly periodical (dependt on accumulatn of &c &c, I supose?) my last was while Jean & Mary were at Liverpl)See TC to JAC, 28 April.,—and in the last 7 or 8 nights, I have had of tolerable simply one (far enough from good, even that); and that was not yesternight, as, for yr sake withal, I had hoped it might have been!— Well, I will write today, all the same, if only to tell you that I cannot write. In effect we are “changing our dinner-hour to 3 p.m.,” resolute to carry it out (some change being clamorously indispensable),—and all new roads, as you know, being rough, are liable to produce tumbles. Persevere, howr; one must fairly try; then, if a failure, try somethg else, &c &c— I will at least write no more abt this base matter. That I can clearly do!—

What I had of essentl to say, is that Maggie Welsh is gone; that the upper-room is vacant, the house quieter than usual, the future very uncertn; and that the questn rises, Have you no notion, this year, of a glance at Babylon agn? To you also London is grown much of a vacancy; little of living left in it for you but myself; but while I am here, there is still something. I fear I shall not at prest be good company (tho’ perhaps not quite so bad, as you might fear); nor do I think it probable you or anybody, in the way of Doctoring cd do me much good,—tho’ possibly, on earnest study and examinatn you might a little? It is
not on this ground howr that I will venture to ask you;—but only, as above, to ask what yr own feelings are?John A. Carlyle replied, 9 June: “As to my going to London at present except for your sake, I had no intention of doing so & no wish whatever, though very sensible of your kindness in asking me to come. I do not think there could be any profit either to yourself or me in my going. What I should advise is, that you quit London & its noises & turmoil, & come here again for some months, as the only thing likely to relieve you from those painful fits of sleeplessness.” Jean Aitken wrote, 9 June: “I find that we [herself and John] are both of one mind as to the advisability of you coming at once down to your old quarters here as soon as you and Mary can muster.” TC wrote on the back of her letter “invites to Dumfrs (june 1869)—.” Jean wrote again, 13 June, a long and persuasive letter detailing all the benefits to him of coming to Scotland. John then wrote, 15 June, apparently surprised that TC had not taken their advice: “But if you cannot take that advice, I hope you know that I shall be ready at all times to go at once & try if it be possible to do anything for you at Cheyne Row. All of us suffer more or less from sleeplessness & can sympathize with you under the miseries of it.”—

Froude is off to Ireland;—happy Froude. ‘Company’ enough I might still have; but gen[er]ally it profits me little. Miss Bromley’s went all to smoke; preceded by a night of no sleep whatr,—had to be followed at once by druggery and telegram.Caroline Davenport Bromley; presumably it was an invitation for him to visit her at 32 Grosvenor St., her London home. Forster’s “tomorrow night” stands also condemned ever since!Forster added a postscript, 1 June, to his 30 May letter: “We shall see you, with the ‘Child of nature’ on Sunday [6 June] at 6.” Patience, patience, and shuffle the cards.Cf. Cervantes, Don Quixote, pt. 2, chap. 23. Forstr has just with intense labour done a Life of Landor; and is considerably chagrined that I don’t much like either Landor or it. No remedy!— Wd you like to see the Book? It is diligently, even candidly and faithfully done (can be comfortably read if you adore Landor’s “genius,” and by skipping if you don’t): so much I have testified to himself, and will not more.Forster wrote, 30 May: “If, when you have read this letter, you will goodnaturedly forgive my having troubled you with it, that is all I wish. Of course you will not think of answering it. / I ought not to have asked you yesterday whether my second volume had at all moderated your unfavourable judgment of Landor as a writer—but I was sufficiently punished: for I came away much ‘down in the mouth’ by what you said thereon, and … a little self-reproachful for not at once having attempted to make the small protest which I now venture to … make. / I understand … so well, the point of view … which such a thinker and writer as you are entitled to take, in passing judgment not on Landor only but men greater as well as less than he, that I never myself presume to question it—and in the cases, which indeed are very, very few, where I should ever have desired to do so, I have thought it much more becoming to be silent. So unspeakably great are my obligations to you, so poor a thing without you and all that I owe you I should think my whole life to be, that I have never heard an opinion of yours from which I differed without a sorrowful self-misgiving—and I really don’t think I could get on at all if I fancied I had not a little bit of favourable esteem from you, to rest upon always. / It is not that your few words swept out of court me and all my poor laudation of poor L—/ [But] you expressed a sort of wonder that, to such a man as Julius Hare, L—should seem so and so—as if others’ praise surprised you less. Well, but I really think I know as much about English literature as Hare, and have the right at least to stand on no lower level;—and I wanted further to say that, though I have hardly so exalted views of Lȁ … I ought not to have hesitated … to repeat, even in the presence of your censure, that my late careful reading had increased, not diminished, my own admiration of many parts of his writings.” Julius Hare (1795–1855; ODNB), author and Church of England clergyman. Lady Ashbn is lost,—Paris or somewhere;—to me no
matter, as things go.— — Tom’s Letter of this morng gives us his mother under ‘tic,’Their nephew Tom Aitken; John A. Carlyle does not mention Jean Aitken being unwell in his reply, so presumably she had soon recovered. “Tic” (short for tic douloureux): severe facial neuralgia with twitching of the facial muscles. in bed till 2 &c: how is she? And alas poor Margt at Ernhirst and her new Baby,Their niece Margaret Stewart, whose husband d. 20 April; see TC to JAC, 28 April. Her son Thomas was b. 27 May. John A. Carlyle reported to Jenny Hanning, 3 June, that Jean Aitken was just back from a quick visit to Ernhirst: “Margaret has been confined of a son, & feels as well as could be expected. She has now 3 boys & 1 girl who is eldest & about 9 or 10 years of age” (MS: Yale). Jean Aitken wrote to TC, 13 June, that Margaret’s father, James Austin, was staying with her at Ernhirst, while their son, James Austin Jr., managed the farm. —wae, wae! And poor Syme,John A. Carlyle had been sending TC regular reports of Syme’s condition; he wrote, 31 May, quoting a letter he had received from Dr. John Brown: “I think his system is getting more reconciled to its condition & doing its best. … [H]e is feeling more interest in his reading & in ‘affairs’; but his arm & leg don’t gain power & he is thin & oldened.” John continued: “It seems to me doubtful now whether he will ever be able to walk again; but it is a great mercy that all his mental faculties are left as clear as ever they were.”—God help us all! Yrs ever affT. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[CR] [CRO], 25 June. MS: W. Hugh Peal Collection, Univ. of Kentucky Libs. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO [CHARLES ROBSON]

docBody.p: No 2

Return these two Scraps;A fragment of TC’s writing has been clipped to TC’s note to Robson; it was apparently draft notes for TC’s discussion (written 1854) of the failings of the Berlin galleries in their European holdings: “Alcibiades or much less Romulus with She-wolf, or goatfooted Pan & Cy / No Pericles, no Cicero or Sylla is worth half the notice, upon whom the poetic intellect of Europe (so dreadfully spellbound, not to say hagridden, in its operations) has been busy these 1000 years, to the neglect of native heroisms, and things evidently sent of Heaven. A case to make men weep.” TC’s finished version was written alongside his description of Antoine Pesne’s painting, “The Little Drummer”: “in those expensive Halls of ‘High Art’ at Berlin, there were, to my experience, few Pictures more agreeable than Pesne’s” (Carlyle, Works 12:372–73). Pesne’s painting, engraved by Francis Holl (1815–84; ODNB), from a copy owned by Lord Ashburton, was used as the frontispiece for vol. 1 of the first edn. of Frederick; for the reproduction of the painting, see 53 and Carlyle, Works 12:370; see also 41:88–89JWC to LLA, [2 Nov. 1864]. Alcibiades (ca. 450–404 BC), Athenian politician; Romulus, legendary founder of Rome; he and his twin, Remus, were thrown into the Tiber, washed ashore, and then suckled by a she-wolf; Pan, Greek god of shepherds and flocks, half man, half goat; Pericles (ca. 495–429 BC), Greek statesman, general, and orator; Cicero (106–43 BC), Roman philosopher, politician, and lawyer; Sulla (138–78 BC), Roman statesman and general. The second “Scrap” is untraced. —and send me (quàm primùm [as soon as possible]) yr correct computatns and best deliberate suggestns.

figure.p: Thomas Carlyle, History of Friedrich II. of Prussia, Works (1897) vol. 12

docBody.p: ‘10 voll’ these must infallibly be;The library edn. of Frederick was to be in 10 vols. —as few breaks of ‘books’ as possible (Here seem to be 5, i.e. as often as not!)—
Send me clearly written list of voll.—where at what p. of copyTC inserted “at what p. of copy” above the line. each begins, and how long it is to be

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 3 July. MS: NLS 526.93. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: You have written to me twice witht ansr; and I can’t expect a third, it seems? I meant to try agn today, at any rate;—and, by ill luck, an interruptn has occurred; and I must put you off agn with a line,—tho’ my hand seems a little steadier, if still very slow.— Bad luck to it! here is another interruptn too!

My sleep, I wd fain hope (but dare not), is a little better; I have had 3 successive nights of tolerable sleep; 1 per week has been the usual allowance, and no “good night” yet come, for 3 weeks past. Whh has kept me miserable enough,—tho’ sticking to my work steadily as the one clear course I had. May it now be altering for the better!

The Frh “miniature” has arrived; a pretty enough old thing. I must trust to the inclosed Letter abt itJürgen Edward Pfeiffer wrote, 15 June: “A friend of mine, Major von Kessel … to whom I mentioned that I saw you riding sometimes in our neighbourhood writes me to the following effect: ‘You say you see Carlyle sometimes … he interests me so much; his work on Frederick II is so excellent … I should so much wish to give Carlyle a token of my esteem. I have a miniature of the great Frederick which I would wish to give him. … Advise me friend, shall I come at him direct with a letter? Would you show me a great act of friendship, call upon him & represent to him my desire. A miniature picture of the great King of his age—which he once gave himself away… I wish to place at the feet of the highly prized Carlyle—as a token of my esteem. His book hits always the nail on the head and is so powerful and charmingly conscientious and true.’” Pfeiffer concluded: “Not having the advantage & happiness of being known to you, I fulfil the wish of my friend in this way. I should be glad to know what to answer.” Jürgen Edward Pfeiffer (ca. 1813–89), wealthy German tea merchant, living in Putney with his wife, m. 1850, Emily Jane Pfeiffer, b. Davis (1827–90; ODNB), poet. Gustav von Kessel (1811–85) wrote in German from Berlin, 22 June, enclosing the miniature of Frederick; see TC to MAI, 20 July. TC wrote “No 1 (return” on the letter, and sent both letters to John A. Carlyle, as John replied, 4 July: “I read your two enclosed letters, & have them still, to be sent back if needed.” John then wrote, 9 July: “I at once send back the Prussian Major’s letter which was very interesting to me & all the rest for whom I translated it—a very sincere recognition indeed of what you have done for Prussia.” (whh is good) for amusing you a moment,—
and pleading my apology of such brevity! It is pretty much the one pleast “event.”— Tauchnitz too has reprinted Schiller, witht Engravings (& sent me £25)! do you know of anybody whom a “Copy” of that cd profit? I don’t;—but must, for civility, allow him to send one or two.Christian Bernhard Tauchnitz (1816–95), Leipzig printer and publisher; see 42:239, and Tarr 187. TC noted in his checkbook: “10 june 1869 (from Tauchnitz for Schiller), Paid in / £25 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). John A. Carlyle replied, 4 July: “As to the reprint of Schillers Life, I would let Tauchnitz send a dozen copies. Jean & John say they would both like to have copies, & so would I myself.” He is handsome abt the “Prints” too: but no one of them suits me; they will have to go back.TC was looking for further pictures for the library edn. of Frederick; John A. Carlyle wrote, 4 July, that he had a copy of William Engelmann, Chodowiecki’s Sämmtliche Kupferstiche (Leipzig, 1857) that he could send to TC, which might have useful prints in it. Daniel Chodowiecki (1726–1801), German artist and engraver; TC had looked at many of his pictures while researching Frederick; see 27:326TC to LOA, 7 Oct. 1852.
There is always talk abt Addiscombe; Lady An was here late last night; very kind and urgent;—“will send her carriage this very night, for my Yes or No then”
Here is Tait,Robert Scott Tait. a third interruptn in waiting. Impossible to continue. “Out, out,” the one response! Mary will address &c. My blessings on you all.

closer.note: John A. Carlyle also enclosed, 4 July, a letter from Janet Hanning: “Two days ago the enclosed came from Jenny. You will see by it that she has found site for a House & contracted for the building of it.” For her request for financial help, see TC to JAC, 15 April.

div3.sourceNote: TC-WF [WFR], 8 July. MS copy (by unknown hand): NLS 573.98. Hitherto unpbd. William Fraser (1816–98; ODNB), genealogist and archivist, who lived at 32 Castle St., Edinburgh.
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM FRASER

docBody.p:
I have this morning received the two beautiful quartos, which your obliging letter of yesterday announced to me. They are among the beautifullest
volumes I have seen; beautifully printed, illustrated, and indexed,—in short, victoriously edited, and made clear to every reader.William Fraser, ed., The Red Book of Grandtully, 2 vols. (Edinburgh, 1868). The book consists of charters and letters, dating from the thirteenth to the nineteenth century, relating to the Grandtully branch of the Steuart family, together with a history of the family written by Fraser. I promise myself a great deal of entertainment and historical instruction in examining those curious old documents and correspondences, here brought to light in such a legible form. I beg you will convey to Sir William Drummond Steuart, Baronet, my lively sense of the great honour and kindness he has been pleased to do me, of which I shall not fail to entertain a grateful and pleasant memory henceforth.TC was sent one of the hundred copies of the book, which were printed privately for Sir William Drummond Steuart (1795–1871), 7th bart. of Grandtully, soldier and adventurer; he traveled through the American frontier country for several years in the 1830s and again in the early 1840s.

For indeed I had already a kind of shadowy relation to Murthly and its owners:Murthly Castle, about 9 mi. (15 km.) N of Perth, one of the seats of the Steuarts of Grandtully, and the birthplace of Sir William Drummond Steuart. in my young days, near half a century ago, I lived once a summer and winter in that neighbourhood, and often enough heard of Murthly and its then Lord in the house where I lived (Kinnaird, near Logierait);TC lived at Kinnaird House, near Logierait, N Perthshire, May 1823 to June 1824, as tutor to Charles Buller (1806–48; ODNB) and Arthur William Buller (see TC to JAC, 6 May); see 2:362TC to JBW, 25 May 1823. The Bullers rented Kinnaird House from Chalmers Izett (1765–1840), a prominent Edinburgh hatter. At that time Murthly Castle was owned by Sir William’s father, Sir George Steuart (1750–1827), 5th bart. of Grandtully. and within the last ten years I have, through an old thin pamphlet of Letters by Lady Jane Douglas StewartLady Jane Stewart, Letters of the Right Honourable Lady Jane Douglas (1767); see 37:45–46TC to JAC, 19 Nov. 1860. —which you also seem to know of,—made the acquaintance of the Husband of that famous Lady, whose letters dating often from Chelsea, where I now am, touched me deeply;Lady Jane Douglas Steuart (1698–1753; ODNB) lived in Chelsea, 1750–52, while her husband (m. 1746), Col. John Steuart of Grandtully (1687–1764), was in prison for debt. and in fact rendered it privately impossible for me to believe, or surmise that such a Lady Jane was capable of any baseness, or deliberate mendacity whatever. Upon which, indeed, I fairly ended my study of “the Douglas cause.”“The Douglas Cause” refers to the dispute over the inheritance of the Douglas estates after Lady Jane’s brother, Archibald Douglas (ca. 1694–1761; ODNB), 3d marquess and 1st duke of Douglas, refused to recognize her sons as legitimate heirs and entailed his titles and estates on his nearest male relatives, the dukes of Hamilton; the case was concluded, 1769, in favor of her elder son, Archibald James Edward (1748–1827); see 37:45–46TC to JAC, 19 Nov. 1860. Fraser related the story in The Red Book of Grandtully 1:clxxv—ccxvi. See also James Boswell, The Essence of the Douglas Cause (1767).
With many thanks to all parties concerned in this pleasant Gift to me, I remain, Dear Sir

postscript.p: That you are next to undertake the Nithsdale ArchivesFraser researched and edited many books about the great families of Scotland; perhaps he had told TC that he was to start work on The Book of Carlaverock. Memoirs of the Maxwells, Earls of Nithsdale, Lords Maxwell & Herries (Edinburgh, 1873). John A. Carlyle replied, 9 July: “The Wm Fraser who sends the Grandtully book I used to meet frequently at Sir Jn Maxwell’s of Pollock some years ago. Sir John promised me a copy of the Maxwell book wh Fraser speaks of but forgot to give it to me in time. Fraser … has had much experience in making Family Books.” Presumably the book he speaks of was Fraser’s Memoirs of the Maxwells of Pollock, 2 vols. (Edinburgh, 1863). Sir John Maxwell (1791–1865; ODNB), 8th bart. of Pollock, landowner and politician. cannot but be good news to the curious in that region. What you say of Craigenputtock I already practically knew! If you, in the course of your further researches, should meet with any notice of an Estate called CollistonColliston or Collieston, a farm 3 mi. (5 km.) E of Craigenputtoch; TC and JWC long presumed that Craigenputtoch once belonged to the estate of Colliston, and that it had been owned by John Welsh (1568? —1622; ODNB), minister of Ayr and son-in-law of John Knox (ca. 1514–72; ODNB), and that John Welsh was JWC’s ancestor, giving her a family connection to John Knox. But it was owned by his father, John (d. 1600), and then by his brother David Welsh; see 5:362TC to JWC, 24 Aug. 1831, 32:71JWC to MS, 11 Jan. 1857, 38:201JWC to MR, [8 Sept. 1862], and Carlyle, Reminiscences 108. (now reduced to a small farm of that name in Dunscore Parish); and find, what I suspect, that Craigenputtock was of old the moorland appendage part of Colliston, it would be interesting to me to have that query confirmed.

div3.sourceNote: TC-BB, 14 July. MS: NLS 3278.144. Hitherto unpbd. The letter is written in Mary Aitken’s hand.
div3.head: TC TO BETTY BRAID

docBody.p: This is a day sad and sacred to both of us;JWC’s birthday, 14 July 1801. and except myself I know that there is none more lovingly mindful of Her who is gone from us than you always are.

I send you two Photographs, not knowing whether you already have them—enclosed also is a little trifle of money that you may get them framed or do what else with it that may be agreable to your feelings.TC recorded in his checkbook: “12 july 1869 / (To Betty) / £3 .. 3 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).

For this long while past I am busy collecting all her letters, getting them copied, dated, made legible to friends that may survive me. There is often mention of you, you may guess how kindly;—if you have any of hers to you, as I think is likely, it would be a great favour to send them or such of them as you think the best.Betty replied, 18 July, thanking TC for the photographs and money; see TC to BB, 22 July.

I heard of you twice from Mr Erskine; and that you continued patient quiet and mournfully affectionate as ever. Mr Erskine, you are aware, always has a great regard for you. He is himself very old and frail of body; but in mind as clear and beautiful as ever.Thomas Erskine wrote, 2 July: “Now that summer has really commenced, I am preparing to return to Linlathen for a while. … Before taking this step however I feel a call to speak a word to you. … I always remember that Mrs Braid is to be regarded by me as a bond connecting me with past memories & with you, to whom those memories must specially belong. I called on her the other day & found her as usual occupied with the past. There was a Mrs George Welsh with her, to whom she was shewing the photographs of the old Haddington burying place—I observe that she never speaks above her breath whilst she is looking at these memorials.” Margaret Welsh, b. Kissock (1803–88; see 43:280), widow of JWC’s paternal uncle George Welsh (1793–1835), lived in Richmond, nr. London; JWC visited Margaret Welsh frequently, the last visit only two days before her own death; see 43:213JWC to TC, [21 April 1866].

For the last year my hand has been very shakey, sometimes refusing altogether to write for me; so that I am obliged to employ the hand of a good little Niece, who is very ready that way;—as you may see here; but I have never yet got used to writing by dictation: I will add nothing more at present; this being all the essential.
May God’s Blessing be on you, dear Betty, and on us all; till we also arrive in that still country where the tears are wiped from every eye,Cf. Rev. 21:4. and there is no trouble or sorrow any more.

closer.salute: Dear Betty, Yrs alwaysThe last line is in TC’s hand; the bottom of the sheet has been cut off, where there presumably was a signature.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 15 and 16 July. Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N.B. PM: London, 16 July 1869. MS: NLS 526.94. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:257–59 inc. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:192.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I was much obliged by yr copious descriptn of Craigh and its affairs:John A. Carlyle reported on the improvements at Craigenputtoch, 12 July: “Yesterday James Aitken, Annie, Tom & I went early to Craigenputtock, & staid there about eight hours. The day was very favourable, & we walked through most of the woods & fields before dinner, which was at two o’clock; & in the afternoon we went to the top of the Hill. I never saw the whole place look so well & orderly. In the woods all the necessary drains have been restored, so that the roots of all the trees that are left now stand in firm ground, instead of being half-afloat as in former years: & the rotten branches have been knocked off & cleared away so as to give the winds less chance of making farther havock. And the dike of that part which is ready for replanting in autumn has been strongly rebuilt & all rubbish of old trees & roots removed; so that planting can be done whenever the proper time comes. The new triangular plantation of Stumpy looks thriving, & plenty of the plants are growing well—especially spruces & birches. / The new meadow has got an excellent dike, & even this year—before draining & lime have taken full effect—will have a considerable crop of hay. And on the old meadow, which in Common’s time had the unsightly & ill-filled drains, there is an excellent crop of hay from the dunging of last year. The walls of the dwelling-house were ‘pointed’ about a month ago with good mortar, the green space in front has been cleared of docks, & rhododendrons &c. planted in it here & there; & the garden got forty cart-loads of fresh soil put into it last spring & is now deep enough for growing anything. Most of it this year is occupied with greens, cabbage & potatoes. / It gave me considerable comfort & satisfaction to find everything in such good order. Young James seems to have a real talent for managing things of the sort both thriftily & effectually, & his father too is always there at the right time to give good advice, & takes interest in everything that is required. An old moss on the hill, which Alick used to make use of—about 600 paces from the dwelling-house—has been opened again this year, & plenty of good peats got out if it & stacked within the threshing-mill shed. And Jamie has a theory that quite incomparably good peats can be got there by going deeper, & had resolved to have a few ‘cast’ this morning by way of trial, the weather still being very droughty & the situation high & open. He meant to begin this experimental casting with his own hand. / All the stock of sheep & cattle looked healthy & thriving, but the proportion of lambs is rather smaller this season than usual.” poor old Moorland Home, the obstructed but kindly Days I had
there shine out on me from afar with a strange pathetic brightness in the vanished Long-Ago; & it is perennially interesting to me, tho’ probably enoug[h] I shall never see it agn. Beautiful but wae, very wae!

Mary and I are very busy here doing all we can to finish our sad TaskCollecting and copying JWC’s letters; see TC to JAC, 11 Jan., and TC to RHS, 15 March. (while time yet is); and indeed are far on; and hope we shall be thro’ it, in a rough form, before many weeks. It has been, & is, to me a kind of religious duty all along, and is naturally one of the mournfullest I ever had. Perhaps it has had somethg to do with the miserable want of sleep &c that has persecuted me for almost ten months now, fit after fit?John A. Carlyle wrote, 23 July: “I think you are right in supposing that you have partly caused [your sleeplessness] by working too hard at that task you have now in hand.” I am glad to report myself improved in that respect. For near two weeks now I have had no utterly bad night, but always got some reasonable pittance of sleep,—tho’ every night still I go to bed with the dismal uncertainty whether there will be any. ((Hoity-toity, here is intrusion and fatal interruptn come! Wandering fools, cd they not have
sauntered elsewhither? Nowhere cd they have been less welcome, or done less good!— This must stop then till tomorrow))TC’s double parentheses.

The day before yesterday we spent at Addiscombe, and returned in the evg: this is the first, and “trial visit,”—all the others went to smoke, by Lady Ashburtons “accidents,” such as are ever happening in that kind quarter! “D.v. [Deo volente]” she always says; and D. [God] is almost never “willing”! (I must try pencil agn:TC wrote most of the letter in blue pencil, but the lines from “Friday, 16 July” to “‘willing’!” were written in ink.— this hand, this hand; many days it absolutely won’t write at all; but I am learng to write by dictatn, must alas!)— Addiscombe was altogr lovely; we were driven out (2 ½ p.m. instead of “noon”), and driven back to this door (10 p.m.);—a complete “rest-day,” whh did us both visible good. The fixed settlt then was that Lady A. was to quit London, Saty (tomorrow) afternoon, & with her child, who is there, continue there,—taking us and luggage out with her. And something like this I, for my own share, determine it shall be, London and its empty broiling tumult are becoming quite intolerable to me. Mary, too, poor little soul, will oftener have nothing of meat kind to dinner,—tho’ she ate well enough at Addiscombe, and yesterday, here:—howr, the little [Mary] comes down today; & fixedly says “she has not clothes,”TC omits “Mary.” Presumably Mary Aitken meant that she had no clothes suitable for wearing in grand company. so with her there will be difficulty, uncertty. But as for me,—after Monday (at Dumfries, Sunday), don’t direct any Letters to me here, unless you hear agn! Let that be fixed.— Lady An talks of “Loch Luichart”Kinlochluichart, Lady Ashburton’s Highland estate, about 34½ mi. (60 km.) NW of Inverness. for herself & child very soon, by sea to Aberdeen, &c &c,—after whh Mary and I, “witht clothes,” can stay at Addisce till our copying is done;—& that is my wish & intentn at prest. What next? what next? I cannot say at all; but so far is clear.— — I take little heed of my Editn,The library edn. of TC’s works; see TC to JAC, 11 Jan.care little abt it, merely read the Proofs, so long as I last. The Frh PicturesAdditional images were added to the library edn. of Frederick the Great. too are all under way, of whh you (and Jean) shall soon I hope see some evidce.— — Is not this my own Program in abundance? I shd like now to hear whatr of definite there is abt yours. Surely if you mean Vichy,John wrote, 7 July: “I often fear that I must go again to Vichy to try if it will help me as well & more permanently than it did last year.” He spent a month in Vichy, 1868; see 45:130TC to JCA, 18 May 1868, and 145TC to JAC, [10] June 1868. you ought to get under way the sooner the better? No 5 with all its poor resources is always open. Quite a tolerable place for “shade,” “quiet” &c,—& Londn itself is now fast emptying. I had that Lr
from Erskine a week ago;Erskine wrote 2 July. —must really dictate” something to him tomorrow. Froude’s Note is his first from Ireld,See TC to JF, 26 May.—hat nichts zu sagen [of no importance]—burn both the notes, if you read them or not. Adieu, dear Brother; it is dreadfully hot even out here beside the Water Butt,In summers, TC often sat in the garden near the water barrel trying to keep cool; for a photograph of him writing beside it, see 32:187TC to JWC, [15] July 1857.—& I must bid you all Adieu! Yrs everT. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-MA [MAI], 19 July. MS: NLS 1763.302. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO MARY AITKEN

docBody.p: Thanks for yr glegness in sending me the Specs (whh I was much in want of),—and also in noticing the Pigeon-hole Key, as I expected you wd, when it flashed into [me]Word omitted. in the night-watches that are just past! You are a clever enough creature when you keep on the alert.

The only other things I miss among my luggage are: 1° the Keys, of my writing case, and of my Portmanteau itself. These two keys and a third along with them, all on one ring, you will find by opening the top of the old Desk or Bureau in my Bedroom (Mrs Warren knows how); that top part open, you will at once see one of the small internal drawers labeled “Keys”: pull that out, you at once find the 3 keys,—put these into Letter carefully, and send them.— 2°, As to the second thing missed, it is the Dornersmark;Victor Amadeus Henckel von Donnersmarck, Militärischer Nachlass, 2 vols. (Leipzig, 1858). TC was sent a copy by the author’s grandson, Count Leo Henckel von Donnersmarck (1829–95), 22 June: “accompanied by a letter from him, enclosing copies of five letters from Prince Henry of Prussia to the author” (see HCC:13). Victor Amadeus Henckel von Donnersmarck (1723–93), Prussian army officer. and the von Kesselletters:For the von Kessel letter, see TC to JAC, 3 July. no express hurry abt sending these,—till there be an opportunity, whh probably there soon will.
As to any letters that may come for me, open the unpromising ones, and jot a word of report upon them; send the others in a cover with yr bits of news.

I got perfectly well hither yesterday, warmly welcomed &c; found no stranger here but a harmless George von BunsenGeorg Friedrich von Bunsen (1824–96); see 40:166TC to JWC, 4 Aug. 1864; his family were old friends of the Carlyles. (who posts this in London for you this afternoon); and had a pleast enough time of it till midnight,—two sound hours of sleep after dinner by the way. Thro’ the night, terribly
much missed sleep; only at last, after bathing &c, got two shortish nightmare snatches; and rose altogr betn 7 & 8 to saunter thro’ the fields till near 10 & breakfast. In spite of whh I really feel as if improved,—such the freshness, beauty, quiet of the new element I am got into! Tonight I intend some slight alteratns in my bedroom, considble do in my diet; and will try again with all my skill to arrive at sleep here, whh is the one thing I want for being better here than anywhere else. Courage, courage!—
There was, and is, considerable inquiry abt your little Person; and I see, if I can cure sleep, there will be nothing for you but “come, come away!” whether with many “clothes” or with few!—
You may if you like forward this to yr Uncle and mother, with any additn of yr own that may suggest itself. My kindest regards, they know, go with it;—and curiosity abt yr uncle’s “Vichy” &c &c

closer.salute: Yr affectionate tho’ grimmiestThus in MS. /

div3.sourceNote: TC-MA [MAI], 20 July. MS: NLS 1763.304. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO MARY AITKEN

docBody.p: It wd seem you didn’t get till this morning my Note of yesterday, whh Bunsen volunteered to post. It wd have been better, had I said, “Thank you very much, but the Note will of itself go at 3 p.m., if I leave on the hall-table here!”—Our first delivery here is at 10 a.m.;—that I suppose brings anything from London that has been put in the Pillar before 7 a.m.

I write now to bid you at once gather all the Dornerermark Letters and the KesselLady Ashburton asked Georg von Bunsen to translate TC’s 22 June letter from Gustav von Kessel (see also TC to JAC, 3 July.). Bunsen wrote, 23 July: “I have read with great interest the honestly appreciating letters of Major von Kessel and Graf Henckel, & send you a copy, with translation, of the former as desired in Lady Ashburton’s letter, for which I beg you will tender her Ladyship my most sincere thanks.” Kessel wrote: “Honored Sir, You have allowed me to lay at your feet a small token of appreciation—of that appreciation, which not I alone, which a large class of persons in Prussia feel daily for yourself and your fine purpose in (writing) history, but finds no opportunity of expressing. / It is true indeed—our writers are scarcely readable, the whole is pervaded by an atmosphere of ghastly ennui, of apparent as well as real to-the-bottom-of-the-matter-going, so that the reader hardly knows how to get along & must exhibit an almost uncommon degree of character & energy. … / As regards the small Medaillon enclosed, (I have only to say, that) the King frequently gave away his portrait in this shape & (etui or) case. My Father, who served still under Friedrich II from 1776 to 1786 in the bataillon of guards at Potsdam, told me of it frequently.” TC gave the medallion and Kessel’s letter to Lady Ashburton; he wrote on the letter: “To Louisa, Lady Ashburton / (with the miniatureof frh accompanying): 1869 / in memoriam.—T.C. (1869)” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). Do to make a Post Office parcel of them, addressed to

Herr George von Bunsen / Abbey Lodge / Hanover Gate / Regents’ Park—
accompanied with a note of precept to the same Herr V. Bunsen, who is to leave town on Thursday, to be punctual in returning them to you at Chelsea— I have the honor as you perceive, to have My Lady as Amanuensis,Lady Ashburton wrote to TC’s dictation from “Do” (para. 2) to “word!” will not write another word!
docBody.closer: Yr affecte/ T. CarlyleThe salutation and signature were in TC’s hand.

div3.sourceNote: TC-BB, 22 July. MS: NLS 3278.150. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO BETTY BRAID

docBody.p: Dear Betty,

I have got safely the precious PapersTC had asked Betty Braid to send any letters from JWC she might have; see TC to BB, 14 July. TC wrote in his journal, 24 July: “I wrote to poor old Betty, on the ‘14th’;—that was a work that rewarded itself; it brot me 7 or 8 letters whh I spent yesterday in dating & revising” (TC’s journal; privately owned). you sent me; and am greatly thankful for them, and for the kind letter you wrote with them.Betty Braid wrote, 18 July: “i send you many thankes for al your kindness to us. al is right the money and the two licness lick [likeness like] life but alas oder me [O dear me], may we have gres [grace] and pashens [patience] granted to us … i am gretly obliged to you for sendin for the leters i culd not give them to any wan [one] in this worald but your own self every thing that I have that was your wifes is verey der to me. … mr Asken [Erskine] is verey kind to us and verey much pleased with you and he sayes he will alyes lick [always look] after us for mrs Carlyle sake.” The words in square brackets were written by TC above the words (without brackets); he wrote on the reverse of the letter “poor old Betty / (on 14 july 1869): very excellt”; he then wrote on the envelope: “(poor old Betty, july 14, 1869 / worth keeping).” My Niece is not at hand;—and I, you see, cannot write farther at prest. All good be with you ever, dear Betty, & with those dear to you.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 26 July. MS: NLS 526.96. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.dateline: Chelsea, 26?TC’s “?” above the 6 in “26”; Mon. was 26 July. july (Monday 3 p.m.)
docBody.p:
—This note, whh came this morning, may interest you for a moment. Good that the poor old soul has got to her home at last!TC’s letter was written on the back of a letter from Jean Otthenin, [ca. 20 July]; Jean and her da. Margaret had recently gone to live with her da. Irma and her husband, Jean Charles Durival, in Vassy, Haute-Marne, France; see 45:110TC to JAC, 24 March 1868. Perhaps you
may write a word to her,—tell her of my hand, of the impossibility of “fancying her 90”; knowing always that she was abt my own age!Jean Otthenin wrote that she hoped TC and also John A. Carlyle would visit her: “I look upon you both as my best friends.” She had been living in Edinburgh for some years, where she had become friendly with John. Jean continued: “How much surprised I was, when I heard you thought I must be near ninety—thank God I want a Great Many years before I reach the age of 90 years.” TC had known her since childhood, and she was aged about 70.— Vassy, I suppose is in “Departt Marne,” I suppose, when the Macmillan comes?Perhaps TC regularly sent her copies of Macmillan’s Magazine.

Probably there is a Letter from you at Addisce all this while: I left, not quite from choice, nor yet quite unwillingly, on Thursday last; was to return “D.V.” with Mary on Saty; am still here, expecting a “D.V.” agn tomorrow,—but not with any assurance, nor much care! Thank Heaven, I have agn got a bit of dayswork done (in spite of the bad yesternight)TC wrote in his journal, 24 July: “We (Mary & I) shd have been at Addiscombe now; and are still calculating to be:—but oh the neverending fluctuatns, the botheratns, and confusns of the ‘Others’ round me, even of those that are full of bountiful intentns and exertns on my behalf! This very day, for instance, I am not at Addiscombe, but snatched away from it … and by other short-comings, promise-breakings, and unpunctualities, am totally witht the means of getting any work done; wh wd have been the one consolatn for my bad Day” (TC’s journal; privately owned). TC returned to Addiscombe 28 July. and the quiet & regularity are both rather superior here, the “impetuous” tho’ most beneft element being fairly out of the game!Presumably a reference to Lady Ashburton. But Mary & I are laying our heads togr to be always alone at Addiscombe, & busy till 3 p.m., &c &c. In some two weeks the House then will be empty for us; if we can but hold out till then!— Direct thither at any rate. We are fast ending our mournful Task,The collecting and editing of JWC’s letters. TC wrote in his journal, 24 July: “In spite of impedts, we are now getting done with that sacred Task; in a month more (if permitted still) I can hope to see the whole of those dear letters lying legible to good eyes (with the needful commentaries &c);—for whh ot not I to be thankful as for a ‘chosen mercy’! Ah me; and now there is at times a sharp pang, as if this were a second parting with Her; sad, sad, this too! … In fact, this has been a heavy-laden miserable time, impeded to me as none ever was by myself and others ‘Others,’—since Octr last. But I will speak of it no more. Thank God if this Thing be got done” (TC’s journal; privately owned; Froude, Carlyle 4:381–82 inc). —the end of it, to me mournfullest of all. n.b. The Town is quite “empty”; weather scorching enough, but bearable; my sleep surely not worsening of late.
docBody.closer: Adieu, adieu ye loved ones all!—T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 23 [30] July. MS: NLS 526.95. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.dateline: Addisce Farm, 23 [30] july 1869TC wrote 23 July in error; he was in Chelsea then; he returned to Addiscombe with Mary Aitken, 28 July. This letter is in answer to John A. Carlyle’s letter, 23 July, sent to Addiscombe.
docBody.p: Yr kind Letter was lying here,—on Wedny Afternoon when we did at last get out. Thanks for yr constant punctuality. I had written to Erskine (by dictatn); but it was addressed to Linlathen,& he hasn’t got it.John A. Carlyle wrote, 23 July, enclosing a letter from Thomas Erskine: “I … told Erskine that you meant to write him some ten days since, but might not have succeeded in getting it done.” Erskine had intended moving to Linlathen for the summer, but had not yet done so.

This is now the 3d day we have been here agn: her Ladyp is for “Battle (Duke of Cleaveland’s)Battle Abbey, Battle, East Sussex, an estate belonging to Harry George Powlett (1803–91), 4th duke of Cleveland, and his wife, m., 1854, Catherine Lucy Wilhelmina, b. Stanhope (1819–1901), widow of Archibald Primrose (1809–51), Lord Dalmeny. tomorrow till Monday),—unavoidable!”—but we don’t mean to stir from our work here; being in hopes to manage & do well. The first day and night were to me very bad: day of black pouring rain (much refreshing the poor thirsty Earth to be sure,—and now making us wish for another such);—and in the night two pairs of fellow creatures dining with us, The Grotes,Harriet and George Grote; see TC to JCA, 11 March. & one Harcourt M.P. with his snaffle of a Boy,Sir William George Granville Venables Vernon Harcourt (1827–1904; ODNB; see 34:111JWC to TC, [9 Aug. 1858]), lawyer and politician, M.P. for Oxford, 1868–80, and his son, Lewis Vernon Harcourt (1863–1922; ODNB). His wife, m. 1859, Maria Thérèse Lister (1835–63), had d. giving birth to their son. —none of whom are the least charming to me. Consequence was, thro’ the whole night I didn’t sleep one wink,—& was down deep all yesterday! By rigorous care, howr, I agn got a fairly good sleep last night; and agn am in hopes.

Mary does famously and is a favte: all is kind and obliging round us both; the country &c is quite lovely;—and we have had two days of an actual endeavour to work. I have been on horseback: very nice Pony whh I know;A pony, nicknamed “Rubbish,” belonging to Lady Ashburton, that TC had ridden previously at The Grange and at Seaton; see 41:191TC to JCA, 18 March 1865. but till tomorrow a right saddle (instead of borrowed wrong one) does not get to hand.— It is uncertn when the Highland journey takes effect,Lady Ashburton’s planned trip to Kinlochluichart; see TC to JAC, 15 July. & all these flunkies & noises disappear. But I shd think, within two weeks our Task will be quasi-ended (first rough editn done); and I shall be at liberty to dispose of myself as I will. Mark that among yr data.
The Lady is waiting, “to go & walk with me on the Heath;—so I end abruptly. Mary, I believe, is writing to some of you. My love to one and allTC’s signature has been cut away.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 11 Aug. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I have recd all yr Letters; the last of them here on Monday morng: thanks, thanks. We are in hope now to have a sight of you in person before very long. Twelve months, if we cd help it, is too long an absence, at our time of life!TC last saw John A. Carlyle in Scotland summer 1868, when he went for his hernia operation; see TC to JSY, 5 Feb.—

This Letter of poor Alick’s with the Card inclosed came to me at Addiscombe;TC’s letter was written on the back of a letter from their brother Alexander Carlyle, 16 April, introducing his clergyman, Rev. William Cochrane (b. 1831) of Brantford City, Ontario: “Our much esteemed Clergyman Mr. Cochrane being about to start on a tour to your side of the water, I beg to introduce him to your kind consideration as being intimate with the whole family here.” He continued: “Please thank the good Dr. for his kind present which arrived safely a few days ago” (see TC to JAC, 20 March). today I have tried to write a line to the revd Bearer;TC’s attempt at a letter to Cochrane read: “Chelsea, 11 Augt 1869—/ Dear Sir, / For my Brother’s sake and yrs, I.” At the top he wrote: “(The failure!).” Mary’s copy of the complete letter is untraced. but was obliged to give it to Mary to copy after all. The loss of my poor pen-hand is a grt misery, whh I must reconcile myself to. I sometimes think of trying to learn with the left;When JWC had a very painful arm in 1865, she tried strenuously to learn to write with her left hand; see 42:69–71JWC to TC, [8 June 1865]. for dictating (at least hitherto, with Mary, who is so soft, too, and so willing, if she only understood!) altogr refuses to prosper with me!—— If you wanted to send any Parcel Canada-way, or had anything to say to this revd messenger, there is still time for you to Paisley;Perhaps TC intended “to write to Paisley.” or indeed perhaps he will pass thro’ Dumfries on his route sea-ward. Our dear old Alick,—alas, alas!—

We came away (unwillingly let go) from Addisce, Saty afternoon; sent home with post-horses, and other superfluous tokens of regard and regret. Had I been a little stronger! I might have done well there: but the perpetual flurry and jumble of all things there,—continual arrival of new plans, new persons (uniformly boring & unwelcome to me), &c &c,—proved too much, and beckoned me visibly homewards. Sunday and Monday last, in my old den
here,—tho’ I had slept completely and even heavily,—were among the weakest days I ever had, moreWord unclear; possibly “mere.” nausea, futility & weariness in every fibre of me: today & yesterday I am a degree better; and feel coming to at least The old pass agn. When Lady Ashbn actually “goes for Ross-shire,”Lady Ashburton’s estate at Kinlochluichart is in Ross and Cromarty, previously Ross-shire. or even whether at all, seems totally uncertn:—so I dismiss Addisce, and as a practicality adopt London, whh taken for all in all, is indisputably the better,—and indeed quite a feasible place: clean, cool, vacant, and in this House (or my back room of it) quieter than anywhere else.— My mournfullest of Tasks is, in a sense, done;Word repeated at the top of the new page; TC wrote these final lines to John on the reverse of his failed letter to Cochrane. in two days time, I cd be ready to wrap that up, and leave it for the prest;The work on JWC’s letters; John Forster wrote, 10 Aug., that, “after this fortnight,” he would be available at home: “when those letters shall be dated for you, and you may probably be still accessible at Cheyne Row.” —but there is no “whither-ward?” that does not menace me with new misery of body, and grief of soul: so I try to improve a little my positn here, or at lowest stay in it rather than do worse. Adieu, dear Brr, dear Loved ones all! I hope to be a little better before long. Yrs ever / T. CarlyleForster also wrote, 10 Aug., in relation to Watts’s portrait of TC: “I have been much exercised in spirit by your sufferings in connection with the poor picture, especially remembering what I formerly said to you in connection with the Portrait Gallery. Now I only wish to say that nothing shall be done respecting it except what you may yourself desire, and that I hope to concoct a letter to Watts which may probably save you further botheration about it.” Presumably Forster had expressed a wish for his commissioned portrait of TC by Watts to go to the National Portrait Gallery. In the event, Watts left his other completed portrait of TC to the National Portrait Gallery; Forster’s was left to the V & A.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR [JRU], 17 Aug. MS: Helen Viljoen. Pbd: W. G. Collingwood, Life of Ruskin (1893) 2:92–93 inc; Ruskin’s Works 19: lxx—lxxi; Cate 146–47. Quot: Tim Hilton, John Ruskin: The Later Years (New Haven and London, 2000) 155.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p:
Yr excellt kind & loving little Note from Vevey reached me;Ruskin wrote, 1 May, from Vevey, Switzerland: “I have been travelling every day … I could not write before—nor now—for the sunshine and fresh air of the last four days have made me dull with their excess of brightness.—only just this word of thanks. … I’ll write again soon. / I was very thankful to be with you again.” but nothing since, nor even precise news at second hand, whh I much desired. The blame of my not answering and inciting was not mine, but that of my poor rebellious
right hand,—whh oftenest refuses altogr to do any writing for me that can be read; having already done too much, it probably thinks! I did practically want a little thing of you at Baireuth if you shd pause there: Photogrhs of Two Portraits of Wilhe[l]minaTC omitted “l.” Friederike Sophie Wilhelmine (1709–58), margravine of Bayreuth, sister of Frederick the Great; see 35:52TC to FC, 14 March 1959. TC knew portraits of her, one as an adult (reproduced Carlyle, Works 16:frontispiece.), and another Pesne’s painting of her as a child in “The Little Drummer Boy”; see 53 and TC to [CRO], 25 June; but TC presumably referred to other portraits of her as an adult. whh I had heard of;—but the right-hand mumbled always, “You can do witht them, you know!” & at length I lazily assented.

What I wish now is to know if you are home,Ruskin arrived home late Aug.; he wrote, 2 Sept.: “I am home at last—I only got your lovely letter today—it was sent to a wrong address abroad.” and to see you instantly if so— Instly! For I am not unlikely to be off in a few days (by Steamer Somewhither)TC and John A. Carlyle were discussing the possibility of going on a trip. Andrew Symington visited TC, 13 Aug.: “[TC] said he much wished to sail somewhere with his Brother for a few weeks. To-morrow, he goes to say ‘Good-bye’ to Lady Ashburton; and his brother the Doctor is to arrive on Monday” (Symington 120). See also TC to LLA, 19 Aug., and 31 Aug. agn miss you. Come, I beg. quàm primùm [as soon as possible]!—

Last week I got yr Queen of the Air,Ruskin’s Queen of the Air (1869), subtitled “a study of the Greek myths of cloud and storm” (Ruskin’s Works 19:281). Andrew Symington also noted: “That evening, on going in, I had found Carlyle reading Ruskin’s ‘Queen of the Air.’ He strongly recommended me to get it, adding, that … it was all deeply and tragically true. He said it contained some of the very best and truest things. The passage on liberty and the house-fly Carlyle read aloud to me, marching about the room and declaiming it with great gusto. … Carlyle added, that when Ruskin stuck to facts, and looked at things as they were known to men, or described scenes in Nature, he was great and had prodigious power” (Symington 108–12). and read it. Euge, Euge [well done]! No such Book have I met with for long years past. The one soul now in the world who seems to feel as I do on the highest matters, & speaks mir aus dem Herzen [to me from the heart], exactly what I wanted to hear!— As to the natural-history of those old Myths I remained here and there a little uncertn; but as to the meanings you put into them, never anywhere All these things I not only “agree” with, but wd use Thor’s Hammer,The mythical hammer, Miölnir, of Thor, the Norse god of thunder. if I had it, to enforce and put in action on this rotten world. Well done, Well done!—and pluck up a heart, & continue, agn & agn. And don’t say “most of yr thots are dressed in shrouds”:Ruskin wrote, 1 May: “I have the Sartor with me also—it belongs to me now—more than any other of your books. / I have nearly all my clothes to make, fresh—but more shroud-shape than any other.” many many are the Phoebus-Apollo celestial arrows you still have to shoot into the foul Pythons, and poisonous abominable megatheriums & Plesiosaurians that go staggering abt, large as cathedrals, in our sunk Epochs agn.Phoebus Apollo, the Roman name of the Greek sun god, Apollo; the Python was a huge mythical creature born from the mud left behind after the great deluge, whom Apollo slew with a hundred arrows. Megatheriums (giant ground sloths) and plesiosaurs (large marine reptiles) were real creatures, now extinct.
I have had a great deal to do with insomnia, &c &c since that last Wedny evening;—come back, I tell you, while it is still time. With kind regards to the dear old mother.Margaret Ruskin.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 19 Aug. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I hope you got safe to Greenock that “morrow morning”; safe to Oban;—and that this will find you all safe, and beginning to flourish, dear little Marygold and you, amid yr native mountns at Loch Luichart.Greenock, port on the S shore of the Firth of Clyde, 23 mi. (37 km.) NW of Glasgow; Oban, port on the W coast of Scotland on the Sound of Kerrera (leading to the Firth of Lorn), 93 mi. (150 km.) NW of Glasgow. Lady Ashburton was presumably traveling by sea; she was to visit the Lochalsh area on the NW coast of Scotland, about 114 mi. (183.5 km.) N of Oban, before traveling on to her estate at Kinlochluichart; see TC to LLA, 31 Aug. The weather, since yesternight, has grown very cold here; but naturally it will come round agn, both here & yonder, and sunshine still lies ahead. Don’t be discouraged for a bad beginning, even if it be bad.

Burgess,Andrew Burgess; see 45:185TC to JTY, 13 Oct. 1868. Mary Aitken wrote to Lady Ashburton, [8 Aug.]: “[Uncle] called … for Mr Burgess; and found that he is in Norway at present; but he is to be back tomorrow week & will then call on Uncle & he (Uncle) will then write and tell you what he says” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). I have seen twice, the final time yesterday; his Program, whh begins fulfilling itself 2 days hence (“Monday next”), will, I hope, seem satisfactory to you; it is here inclosed for yr keeping. His Plans and Intentns about the Books and their arranget, cataloguingLady Ashburton apparently wanted her library at Melchet to be catalogued. When the collection was sold in 1912, the auction catalogue listed “valuable works on natural history … a fine series of works by Thomas Carlyle … an interesting autograph letter of Robert Browning; a verse and signature in the autograph of Goethe; works on political economy, finance, etc.; writings of Ruskin, Browning, Rossetti, etc.” (Catalogue of the Library of Louisa Lady Ashburton [1912]). &c &c seemed to me judicious, sound, lucid & complete,—with visibly a fair chance of their being honestly and punctually fulfilled. I bade him “at once write to BaileyJames Bailey (b. 1809), Lady Ashburton’s butler. at Melchet”; he assented, but said he cd quite dispense with By for the first week of the busss; and wd appear there punctually on Monday, and go ahead, independtly of
Bailey for the week ensuing. So that I think you need have no farther trouble, on that poor score; but may leave it to its own velocities and courses henceforth. In six weeks hence it will stand finished (I do count and believe);—and unless you want it, at any date, quickened, you need not even write (unless, by chance, written-to). On the head of Payt I had some pressure to exercise; but found Burgess wd regard (on my suggestn “3 or 4 guineas a-week”) “three guineas” a week as suffict.Lady Ashburton wrote, 23 Aug.: “Didn’t I seize upon your letter out of a packet of about 30 … & ain’t I as grateful as I ought to be, for the trouble you have taken for me? —1000 1000 thanks—for making the Burgess matter so distinct.” And now not a word more.

My Brother came on Monday evg; has been out already investigatg “Norway Steamers”; found yesterday the excellt “Norway Steamer” to have “all its berths full,”—to me small matter! He is very intent upon steam-voyaging; I, so shivery and skinless, not very. We shall see.Lady Ashburton wrote: “As Norway does not seem possible I shall be most anxious to hear what is decided on—a cruise up this beautiful West Coast, would not be bad—& then perhaps I might see you again.” John A. Carlyle wrote to Janet Hanning, 19 Aug.: “I came here last Monday by Tom’s invitation, & on purpose to make some little excursion with him, but we have not yet decided in what direction it is to be. Mary Aitken is still here with him & has been since September last. She will go home to Dumfries as soon as we start.” Janet’s new house was apparently finished as he instructed her: “not to go into your new house until it gets dry & seasoned, otherwise you may get great injury from it, & take a dislike to it at the very outset” (MS: Yale).

Today, in the Daily Telegraph, somebody sends me an interesting Article abt Marshall Keith, & the setting up of his Prussian Statue at Peterhead:James Francis Edward Keith (1696–1758; ODNB; see 34:195TC to JWC, 23 Sept. 1858), soldier, exiled Jacobite, and finally field marshal in the Prussian army, born at Inverugie Castle nr. Peterhead, Aberdeenshire. For TC on Keith, see 37:100–103TC to LLA, 26 Jan. 1861. TC had heard of this statue the previous autumn; see 45:172TC to JSK, 21 Sept. 1868, 174TC to JSK, 21 Sept. 1868, and 178TC to JAC, 26 Sept. 1868; for the statue, see 45:176TC to JAC, 26 Sept. 1868. The statue had arrived at Peterhead, 6 Oct. 1868, and was unveiled on Tolbooth Green, 16 Aug. 1869. The Daily Telegraph reported, 19 Aug.: “PETERHEAD, in Aberdeenshire, has just witnessed a local celebration which has the advantage of not belonging to the centenary species. It has not been noised abroad in the newspapers; no literary or other ‘lions’ had been invited to roar at the ceremony. The Scottish town has done its own hero-worship, in its own quiet, prudent, self-possessed, and earnest way.” Keith became a highly valued and trusted Marshal of Frederick the Great, and as such featured in Frederick, which led William I (1797–1888), king of Prussia, to offer to send to Peterhead a copy of the statue of Keith in Berlin. The Telegraph report continued: “There is something in this, we hope—in this deliberate expression on the part of the King ruling a great people—to console THOMAS CARLYLE for his laborious struggles with the ‘German Dryasdust.’ As for his long journeying, his patient visits to every Bohemian, Saxon, or Silesian battle-ground, they were all in his day’s work as a modern ‘Scot abroad.’ Peterhead has to thank THOMAS CARLYLE for the statue; and it is not the only thing for which the thanks of Peterhead, and of the British Empire in general, are due to that strong and generous writer—who, in his good hope, has done much noble work for the humanity of which he despairs.” See also Memoir of Marshal Keith, With a Sketch of the Keith Family, [ed. Norman Maclean] [Peterhead, 1869], notes ii—iii; and Skelton, “Prussia and Mr. Carlyle,” Fraser’s Magazine 78 (Nov. 1868): 657–59. —I will have it clipt out & sent to you in a day or two.
My hand can write today,—abt as fast as it once cd have engraved on some soft metal.

Good be ever with you, dear Lady,—Poor Mary sends her Duty: much grieved today that the last Sunday Proof-Sheets have, some way, made shipwreck betn Bailey and her;TC and Mary returned to Chelsea Sat. 7 Aug.; presumably some proof sheets (for the library edn.) were lost between Addiscombe and Chelsea. Lady Ashburton wrote: “I am indeed grieved to hear of the Proof sheets & wish they were in my power to recover—my love to Mary.” and that “uncle will have to do them agn.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-JA Jr. [JAJR], 22 Aug. MS: NLS 1763.306. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES AITKEN JR.

docBody.p: Here is yr Ten Pounds. You have managed that affair very well, and fully better in result than yr instructns were,—for I am better satisfied that poor Mrs B. (sunk in straits known only to herself, and certn to be ugly enough) shd have the money now,—provided only she dont bother with irregularities agn.TC sent money anonymously to James Baillie and his wife, Anna-Maria, through James Aitken Jr.; see TC to JAJR, 16 March. He recorded in his checkbook: “22 Augt 1869 / to Jas Aitken / (for Baillie (of 21 Octr next / £10 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753); payments were twice a year, normally in April and Oct. I have crossed the cheque; so if you return a Newspr merely, it will be sign suffict.

closer.note: TC was in correspondence with the Carlyles’ old friend Richard Plattnauer who had worked since 1849 for Lord George A. Hill (1801–79; see 24:73TC to JAC, 18 June 1849), originally as a tutor for Hill’s children at Gweedore, Donegal; see 24:159TC to JAC, 2 Aug. 1849.
