Plattnauer wrote from Gweedore, 14 Aug., sending TC a small pamphlet “concerning the improvements on his estate … at Lord George Hill’s desire.” TC wrote on his letter: “(Plattnr (Augt 1869): [TC inserted “Pler” above the line] Nichts [nothing]!),” and replied, ca. 20 Aug. (letter untraced); Plattnauer acknowledged the letter’s arrival, 23 Aug., remarking on “the interest which you have always shown for Irish affairs. … It was 20 years ago on the 4th of this month since we visited this place together and wished it success and prosperity.” For TC’s and Plattnauer’s visit, see 24:176–77TC to JWC, 5 Aug. 1849. Plattnauer suffered periods of insanity; JWC had been particularly concerned with this; see 18:173–77JWC to JW, [12 Aug. 1844], 190–92JWC to JW, [], 194–96JWC to JW, [ca. 29 Aug. 1844], 21:204JWC to JW, [24 April 1847], and elsewhere. Plattnauer made reference to his condition, 23 Aug.: “I know too well, how often I have been driven by my necessities into conduct, which must have appeared very strange, to put it mildly, to my friends.” His letter, 24 Aug., reported that he had read part of TC’s letter to Lord George (who was ill).

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 31 Aug. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Yr two Letters, especially yr last Letter to myself, were a great favr and pleasure,—of whh (were my hand in a human state, whh it isn’t) I cd say much in the way of thanks. But you know already how welcome the news wd be to us, that all had gone well with you since you left, and that you were now victoriously within sight of home,—not above 50 miles that “Balmacarra,”Balmacara, village on the north shore of Loch Alsh, Ross-shire, about 46 mi. (74 km.) SW of Kinlochluichart. Lady Ashburton wrote, 23 Aug.: “We hope to get home tomorrow—but the difficulties of leaving this far away place are indescribableȁ & the ‘machine’ & the 2 Mice that drag it don’t inspire me with courage— The dear poor people have been so touchingly affte—& my thoughts have been full of sadness—the man who bought all this great principality desired that I wd become the mistress of it—& as I leant over the seawall in the drivelling mist, with my one little creature gone to bed, and my love gone away from Earth—I cd not help shuddering at the contrast of my lonely present, with the full, busy life of earnest usefulness that might have been mine … & my mother & Bingham away.” “The dear poor people” were presumably the staff and locals on the estate; not further identified. as I judged and guessed;—from whh rugged scenes we can hope the two “little mice” of shelties with their shandrydanShandrydan: chaise with a hood; a rickety conveyance. have by this time actually set you down, Mama & little Mary safe, & yr purpose fairly fulfilled. All right, all right, let us hope! And may the tidings that it is so, reach us soon.

By the very date of this Note you see essentially what the end of our debates has proved to be;—and the impudent fact is, we are all here, Mary the Doctor two servtsSarah Warren and a maidservant, presumably one from Cheyne Row (possibly called Charlotte); TC referred to them being at Addiscombe “with our own servants” in Sept. (TC to JAF, 14 Sept.) and noted, 28 Sept., of their visit to Addiscombe: “Mary, Brr John (who had come from Dumfries, intending &c but not doing), and the two Servts” (TC’s journal; privately owned). and I, since yesterday afternn, in peaceable possessn of yr little palace here as if it were our own! There was endless consulting, speculating & projecting on the Dr’s part for my behoof and his own; but at last he confessed the fact (clear from Bradshaw and the “Gospels of this Epoch),Bradshaw’s Monthly Railway and Steam Navigation Guide and possibly other railway and steamer timetables. that Norway Steamers, Aberdeen Steamers, Shetld Steamers, Westn-Isles Steamers & all others) were become “impossible” to me at this advanced season; that he wd push on “to Vichy abt Septr” set; & that I and Mary shd go on “to Dumfries” (said he”),—to Addiscombe (privately said I; the intolerable heat, dust, noise, and baking smother of London, strongly pushing one
somewhither with the least possible delay!) Till abt Friday last, “Vichy on Monday” continued to be his program; but knowing of yr bright bounty in inviting him to accompany us hither, he at last began to mumble hypothetically abt “seeing us settled down” for a day or two &c &c; and, in effect, here he is, as I said; and I perceive will probably stay here till we unsettle agn, and only talk a little abt “Vichy” to keep his mind quieter! That is the way of our Doctor;—and indeed he seems to me in a weakish state of liver (bad sleep &c &c); and I like better to think of him as here in these “elysian fields” at hand of me for a couple of weeks more than at any Vichy and its uncertn tumults, water-doctorings and water-quackings. So, I think, it will be. Hitherto I do confess to a kind of shamefaced feeling, and that the transactn seems a little brazen; but I cannot help it;—and I know very well what yr endless kindness will bid you say to me in ansr; so you need not say it, Lady dear.Lady Ashburton replied, 6 [Sept.]: “[T]he pleasantest thing I have is to think of you at Addiscombe—that was really good, & kind of you—& I am so very grateful to you for this mark of true friendship—& how very nice of your brother too! I wish with all my heart I were with you all!” Surely we will try to do no harm here; and shall not want, any of us, for recognitn of yr goodness.

It is more necessary I shd assure you that we have not forgotten the “Jim Wortley” incident, and that shd these poor people wish to come hither abt “Septr 17” as they proposed, the place shall be clear for them before that day.Presumably James Archibald Stuart-Wortley (1805–81; ODNB), lawyer, and his wife, m., 1846, Jane, b. Thompson (1820–1900; ODNB), philanthropist. Lady Ashburton wrote: “The poor St Wortleys are not likely to be going there at all—as I fear he is … on quite another journey.” James Stuart-Wortley had been ill since 1858. Nay, indepdently of them there is a speculatn abt some possibility of quiet sea-bathing at Sandown Isle of Wight, just abt that time; and that is a thing I have had a great wish for, all summer, and if the “possibility” proved a reality, shd be strongly tempted to make trial of still.

You wd be charmed here cd you see how prompt, loyal and good all yr people are to us here; Cross,Joseph Cross (b. ca. 1830), head gardener at Addiscombe; see 43:96JWC to JOCO, 29 Dec. [1865]. the HousemaidUnidentified further. and everybody on the ground seeming to know perfectly that nothing can please my Lady better than kindness to these Guests.Lady Ashburton wrote: “I am truly glad when my people are so civil—they all know, who I like honor to be shown to.” Whh, I believe, is a fact; so singular a Being is My Lady. Since yesterday Cross has had flowers agn in the verandah; men mowing & sweeping &c, tho’ everything was already neat as a new pin,—outside & inside no prettier place, or more perfect hermitage for a sick soul and body, in all the Queen’s Dominns. “Elysian Fields,” I already called it,—and truly that is the thot that attends me as I stroll abt all this morng (just out of the roaring
horrors of London) in a place of azure silence, purity, immortal love, and immortal sorrow too,—for where, oh where are the bright Ones who have left me here?— But I must not go in that directn.

Our three rooms here are 1° mine, where the Russn gentnUnidentified further. was; 2° Mary’s a little crib (of her own choosing) next to that; 3° the Dr’s,—whh, by his own choice, was her old room, but where he didn’t sleep so well as I,—is changed this day for one of the Two where I successively was: conceive all that!Lady Ashburton wrote: “I don’t at all like your being all so squeezed up into the end of the house—but of course, you wd never hesitate about taking exactly the rooms you like best—so altho’ I don’t agree with yr taste, I hope you are really comfortable.” Mary Aitken wrote to Lady Ashburton, 5 Sept.: “Uncle … is completely satisfied with his bedroom (the pink room next yr. Ladyship’s Boudoir): … he likes the change” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). Yr Housemaid & Mrs Warren seem to go like a pair of jewels;—and I make no doubt we shall get along perfectly well.
But I am bound to “Rubbish”;Lady Ashburton’s pony; see TC to JAC, 23 [30] July. and ought to have been off an hour ago!
Adieu, dear Lady / Yrs ever faithfully / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-IS [IEB], 4 Sept. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. Isabella Emily Simmonds, b. Barnes (b. 1837, d. by 1899), a close friend of JWC.
div3.head: TC TO ISABELLA SIMMONDS

docBody.p: Those precious LettersLetters she had received from JWC. are all lying punctually locked up in Chelsea; waiting yr return.Mary Aitken had written to Lady Ashburton, 23 Aug., from Chelsea: “His sad task is now done (& locked away); though there is much he wishes to do to it still” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). The Simmondses might have been visiting her husband John’s family; they lived in Ashby de la Zouche, Leicestershire; see 37:139TC to IEB, [3 April 1861]. The Simmondses lived at 82 Oakley St., Chelsea. I am greatly obliged by yr loan of them; and beg (and desire) that you will not deny me a sight of any others you may still have or be able to discover.

Niece Mary has taken Copies of those you sent, as was my object in asking for them: but you may trust me there is no vestige of intention to print anything; on the contrary, a strict prohibition,—at least and lowest till all whom it cd personally concern are out of the scene.

On yr return I will ask you farther to help Mary whatr you can towards accurately dating these Letters.TC wrote a note to himself, now attached to this letter: “24 jany 1862? (ASK/ Mrs Simds the date of her wedding, of her first child &c!).” Isabella Barnes m. John Simmonds (b. 1829, still alive in 1899), barrister, 18 Feb. 1862; for JWC’s description of the wedding, see 38:69JWC to JAD, 8 March 1862. Their first child, Jane Ethel Carlyle, was b. 1 Nov. 1863 and d. 2 July 1865; see 42:117–18JWC to IEB, 10 July [1865]. Their second child, Amy Constance, was b. early Sept. 1865; see 42:237. TC’s note was written on a scrap of paper taken from a letter from James Aitken Jr., dated Aug. 1869, with mention of Mrs Baillie. Out of very pity, you cannot refuse!—
With best regards to Mr Simmonds & yrself,

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAF, 14 Sept. MS: Waldo H. Dunn. Pbd: Waldo H. Dunn, “Carlyle’s Last Letters to Froude,” Twentieth Century 159 (Jan. 1956): 51–53. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:383; Tim Hilton, John Ruskin, the Later Years (New Haven and London, 2000) 168.
div3.head: TC TO J. A. FROUDE

docBody.p: You punctually sent me from your Irish WildernessesFroude was spending the summer in Ireland; between 1868 and 1871, he leased the estate of Derreen from Henry Petty-Fitzmaurice (1845–1927; ODNB), 5th marquess of Lansdowne. The house and gardens lay on a promontory in Kilmakilloge harbor on the Beara Peninsula, near Kenmare, S County Kerry, Ireland. See Froude’s memoir, “A Fortnight in Kerry,” Fraser’s Magazine n.s. 1, 3 (April 1870, Jan. 1871): 513–30, 28–45. a gentle and pleasant little Note, full of friendliness and hospitality, which was naturally very welcome in my solitary Chelsea. As there went no answer, however, I could expect no more from you, much as I could have wished for a good many more! The fault of my silence, as I doubt not you understand, lay not in the heart, but only in the poor right-hand; which, as you perceive continues shaking & disobedient as ever,—pity and pardon it. There was the readier excuse in that instance, as the answer could only have been “Alas, no, it is not possible!” I continue my sad sticlishness and inability as to sleep; and all journeyings are sure to inflict on me an amount of pain both imaginary & real, which is inconceivable—to the healthy bystander however sympathetic, so that I justly shudder at the mention of a land journey (by sea I have not yet tried, since I became so ill); and often enough it strikes me there is only one “journey” ahead which I can make without pain in this world. When God pleases!—

I have not been worse in health since you left; but also not better, and, in essential fact, tho’ not in appearance, a good degree more solitary. The number of persons whose conversation is better than silence to me, and not worse, diminishes yearly, and is now very small indeed. Twice or thrice I saw Lady SalisburyMary Catherine, b. Sackville-West (1824–1900; ODNB), marchioness of Salisbury, society hostess, m., 1847, James Gascoyne-Cecil (1791–1868), 2nd marquess of Salisbury. Froude had introduced them to TC the previous year; see 45:96TC to LN, 18 Feb. 1868. after you left; an amiable sister soul, very clear, ingenuous
and gentle, tho’ I think not very deep hitherto. These visits, which were to be on Sunday, were interrupted and ended, by a sally out hither, two sallies out hither (to Lady Ashburton’s little country palace here)—both of which were rendered futile by that sad old question of sleep, which it was hoped came out insoluble mainly by reason of “the company” &c; in which I now grieve to find we were mistaken! My Brother, who had promised to come up, & try some sea-voyaging, delayed somehow till well into August; and then found that Norway, Shetland, even Edinburgh and Iona, had become unfeasible; upon which, after speculation about Vichy and other things, he agreed to come out hither with us, for a 3 weeks; and here we all are, (little Mary, he and I), with our own servants and appendages, in perfect solitude, lords paramount of the beautiful place, to me wonderful, almost miraculous when I look around & look back,—but not a whit more sleepy than before!TC wrote in his journal, 6 Sept.: “We have bn here since this day week;—Niece Mary, Brr John, and my now useless and unhappy self;—in circs of peculiar idleness, whh are otherwise very singular, to affect me, and to me full of memories that are sorrowful strange, affecting, and in part even sacred. For the rest, inarticulate mostly; and sad even when beautiful, sad as death and eternity! My bodily health is of the worst (insuperable want of sleep, want of &c &c); nor is my spiritual health much better. Being so utterly idle, for one thing, I have bethot me today that I might at least keep a journal of the inanities that are to ‘occupy’ the Week just begun; this farthings worth of Paper is prepared accordingly,—and here I start. / Today I have got nothing to record: I have spent two hours of my morng looking into a paltriest Book lent me by Miss Bromley (who is rusticatg near-by)” (TC’s journal; privately owned). TC continued to write most days during his stay at Addiscombe; he saw Miss Bromley often: “A very intelligent, clear and courteous Being; beautiful still, tho now upon the wane;—has really fine gifts and highish tendencies of all kinds: but all being inarticulate, no developt permitted them, in the commonplace (Court Gentleman) element where she has always been” (TC’s journal; privately owned). Mary Aitken wrote to Lady Ashburton, 5 Sept.: “Uncle is leading a life of complete idleness here, and enjoys the quiet very much after the noise at Chelsea. He reads all the morning; and about three o’clock every day mounts Rubbish and has a long ride. Yesterday he came home so pleased to have discovered a long road through plantations (that he knew long ago) quite unmolested, and exactly as it used to be.— I think when he goes back to Cheyne Row, he will most likely begin to write some sketch of his own life; but it is well to be idle for a little. … Uncle John is very happy here; he seems to have almost exhausted the resources of books; he reads the whole day long. Yesterday he began Robinson Crusoe & took it to his room with him at night! He had not read it since he was a little boy” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). Daniel Defoe, Robinson Crusoe (1719). Monday next I intend our term shall be out; for tho’ the days are Elysian (so beautiful, so rural, pure and silent, populous with the memories, great & sad and sacred of so many years to me),—the nights are too often tartarean. Monday next therefore, unless there come improvement not likely now. Patience, & shuffle the cards.

One day, by express desire on both sides, I had Ruskin for some hours. Really interesting & entertaining; a much improved Ruskin since he went in May last.Ruskin spent May—Aug. traveling in Switzerland and Italy; TC noted in his journal, 7 Sept.: “At 2 p.m. (half an hour beyond time) came Ruskin by appointt; staid till 5, copious of talking, and making me talk,—and did me a great deal of good, much ill as my imaginatn had expected even from him! … Rn was full of pretty sympathy; full of work, too, of plans, projects, & generous hopes and inquiries & discussions: I have seldom found him so truly interestg” (TC’s journal; privately owned). TC noted, 10 Sept., that Ruskin called “yesterday, in my absence … kind certainly & welcome; but, on the whole, better that I was out” (TC’s journal; privately owned). He is full of projects, of generous prospective activities, some of which, I opined to him, would prove chimerical. There is (in singular environment) a ray of real Heaven in poor Ruskin;—passages of that last book (Queen of the Air) went into my heart like arrows.See TC to JRU, 17 Aug.— I send you a Photograph printed in ink (verily); a Mr Tait is engaged in such an enterprise by way of counteracting that monstrous Blotch of a Portrait lately done by Watts and his High Art (with a murrain on it).Robert Scott Tait. For Watts’s portrait of TC, see TC to JAC, 6 March, and 19. TC noted in his journal, 10 Sept.: “Some ‘Portrait-Prints’ stuff from Tait this morng; no word of anor (disgusting botheratn all that, and of no real use or value to me)” (TC’s journal; privately owned); “anor (disgusting botheratn all that” may refer to Watts still working on his portraits; TC gave Watts two further sittings in Oct.; see TC to MAI, 10 Oct., and TC to JAC, 26 Oct. Tait was attempting to photograph portraits for use in the library edn.; he may also have been reproducing photographs of TC for the same purpose; see TC to LLA, 1 Oct.

My kindest regards and wishes to MadamHenrietta Elizabeth Froude. & family; also remember me kindly to the Stephens,James Fitzjames Stephen and his wife, Mary; they had eight children. if still with you. Adieu, dear F. return soon.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 15 Sept. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: It seems indeed ungrateful not to have forced my poor old shaking right-hand to write you some word of ansr to yr beautiful and generous Letter whh was so welcome here; but I had my reasons too,—as you will see.

The first Lr from Loch-Luichart did, as you supposed, perish by the way; and we heard nothing of that miserable “12 hours of rain,” of that “double wetting” (perilous to think of!)—till the second Despatch reported you victoriously all at Lh Luicht, and got into the “Hôtel-keeping” way.Lady Ashburton wrote, 6 [Sept.]: “Certainly one of my letters has miscarried—just to think that you have never heard of my safe arrival here!—when I wrote you a long account of our drive of 12 hours, in the most pitiless rain I ever was out in—& Mary got wet to the skin twice—but thank God has not suffered.” Whh is
right, and in the order of nature,—at least no worse than you expected. If only yr health, and that of little Marykin (who seems to be case-hardening, to judge by those “12 hours”) can escape uninjured! Have a care, have a care! Miss Bromley (day before yesty) reports you all flourishg,—and that there is even an accession of guests.Lady Ashburton wrote: “On my arrival I found a letter from Mr Story who with his family were waiting for my arrival at the Inn close by—very reproachful—& there was nothing for me to do, but have them all here—so here they came le lendemain [day after] of my arrival, & here they have been ever since! I find them very pleasant guests—& Browning a delightful man—dear Lady Marian [Alford] has now joined us, & old Sir Roderick Murchison—& so we go on—but I long for quiet—& solitude—& to be done with this Hotel-Keeping life—but there is alas! neither quiet, nor Solitude for me.” William Wetmore Story (1819–95), American sculptor, who was touring Scotland with his wife, Emelyn, b. Eldredge (b. ca. 1821), their sons, Thomas Waldo (1855–1915) and Julian Russell (1857–1919), and their da., Edith (1844–1907). They had been joined by Robert Browning, his son, Pen (1849–1912), and his sister Sarianna (1814–1903). Browning wrote from Kinlochluichart to his friend the novelist Isabella Blagden (1816? —73), 28 Aug., that he was at an “old friend’s,” “comfortable altogether” and that “all goes well … in this beautiful place” (Dearest Isa: Robert Browning’s Letters to Isabella Blagden, ed. Edward McTeer [Austin, Texas, 1951] 322). Lord help your bonny Ladyship:—I cannot fancy where you contrive to stow all those people; but you will get thro’ it handsomely, I doubt not. And yr Hungarns are coming or almost come;Count Kalmand Nakos (1822–1902), and his wife, Bertha (1820–82), pianist, composer, and painter. Lady Ashburton met them in Vienna in 1866 (Correspondence of Dante Gabriel Rossetti, ed. William E. Fredeman [Cambridge, 2003] 5:245). Nakos wrote to Lady Ashburton, 1 Jan., of his hope to visit Scotland that year: “I firmly hope that in 1869 will be realized what did not succeed in the former years.— Please in every case to tell your stags not to trouble themselves for this;—I am not exercised in shooting with the rifle, and I like more to climb on the mountains admiring nature and scenery, than killing poor creatures.” He then wrote, 15 June: “Bertha will have told you that we intend to go to see you.— If you will be in the beginning of September at Loch Luickhart Lodge we shall go there. … I should like to stop 2 days in London, and one day in Edinborough,—we would arrive at Dingwall about the 8th or the 10th September” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). and before long it will be all over, and you ejaculating “Thank Heaven!”— —“What to do with Lh Luichart?”Lady Ashburton was apparently considering selling Kinlochluichart but decided against it; she frequently rented out the lodge and the adjoining deer forest to shooting parties. The Dundee Courier reported, 12 July 1878, that the property was rented out annually for £2000. Yes, that is a questn. My first thot wd be, To set Mr MitchellJohn Mitchell (1815–81), agent for the National Bank, Dingwall, who helped Lady Ashburton with her Scottish affairs; see 45:13–14TC to LLA, 5 Aug. 1867. on fairly selling it at what it isnow worth (4 or 5 times its intrinsic value perhaps?), whh wd be a blessed deliverance from one superfluity! But perhaps there are objectns to that course; and my intrusive counsel good for nothing,—except for kind pardon, whh I know it will get from you.

We are all doing here as well as cd be expected,—i.e. all the others doing better than cd well be imagined,—and I do, except that sleep, as usual, refuses to fall on the guilty head, while all other blessings do! That was the reason of my not writing; I wanted to have first one right sleep to record,—one of the last seven and more. Indeed there have been just 3 in all, yesternt being one of them;—and our original term was “3 weeks,” i.e. till Monday next, when everybody (and even I tho’ still sleepless) will lament to go. Never was there a Hermitage whh is & was so like Elysian for a sick soul. Those railway whistles, those sad—in fact that bad “nature of the beast”!Lady Ashburton replied, 21 Sept.: “[H]ow much I have longed for a Telegram to say whether the ‘nature of the Beast’ is improved—& sleep come to you—I can’t bear to think of the long, wakeful nights.” For there lies the real fault; there the origin of those occasionally somewhat Tartarean nights to days so wholly like Elysium still. Days so pure so silent, everything so beautiful and soothing—bright with the memories, grand, sad & sacred, of the 25 yrs gone! Rubbish & I have had such pilgrimings, by woody solitudes, to Croham Hirst, to Purley Heath (16 years since I had seen it last),Croham, village about 1 mi. (1.5 km.) SE of Croydon, which included the estate of John Whitgift (1530/31? —1604; ODNB), archbishop of Canterbury 1583–1604. TC wrote in his journal, 10 Sept.: “Yesty I went riding, mournfully enough, yet not quite impiously, perhaps,—agn thro’ the Croham Lanes (the Archbishp’s precincts first, but found them all closed):—suddenly at a corner of the road, a fine carriage meets me; Miss Bromley in it, and our little Mary, ‘Child of Nature,’ for a drive! As they were uncertn witherwd, and knew nothing of the region, I recommended ‘Purley Down’. … They went, I (on suggestn of Rubbish who wdn’t stay behind) accompanied, trotting after or before; piloting the Coachn, to Sanderstand, thence to Purley (where I used to gallop, lonesome, and heavy with thots of my Mother’s deathbed, 16 years ago, and had never since been)” (TC’s journal; privately owned). TC had stayed at Addiscombe 13 Sept.–7 Oct. 1853 while work was going on in Cheyne Row building the sound-proof attic, and while his mother was dying; she d. 25 Dec. 1853. Sanderstead, village about 2 mi. (3 km.) S of Croydon; Purley, village about 4 mi. (6.5 km.) S of Croydon. to Beckenhm, by sevl routes; to Wickhm, AddingtonVillages in about a 4 mi. (6.5 km.) radius of Croydon: Beckenham to the NE, West Wickham to the E, and Addington to the SE. by do, &c &c. Daily I ride; mute, oftenest mournful, but not unblessed.— — Nor will I depart “on Monday,” if this improvt of sleep shall continue; no, dear Lady, I am too willing to stay,—and will hope till the last! Perfectn of behavr (literally that) is what I have to report of all persons & things here; from “Rubbish” up to the wise & excellt Mr Cross every item does continually its best for me. Please remember that, for my sake. And so—Esperons [let us hope] be the word.

Ruskin drove over to me, one day; staid 3 hours,—very interesting & kindly; much improved byWord repeated with a line over it at turn of page; Ruskin visited 7 Sept.; see TC to JAF, 14 Sept. his N. of Italy sojourn. Item there have been, at length,
rains (to Cross’s great joy); & also for 2 or 3 days “Equinoctl Gales” to almost a “tremendous” extent, tho’ witht damage here,—did nothing but beautifully sing to us like Job’s Whirlwind,Cf. Job 38:1.—& crash down two big old boughs,TC wrote in his journal, 14–15 Sept.: “On Monday [13th]: rode out in spite of threateng weather symptoms, and even danger from the crash of broken boughs (two, of a ton weight each, fell here, the latter of them that day, the former of them narrowly missing my poor Brr John” (TC’s journal; privately owned). The Times reported, 14 Sept.: “THE LATE GALES / The severe weather which was experienced in the metropolis and generally throughout the country on Sunday continued. … Soon after daybreak … the wind again commenced to blow hard, its force amounting to that of a gale, and about noon, and for several hours afterwards, its strength was frequently that of a hurricane. There was very little rain up to 1 o’clock, but subsequently it descended in torrents for nearly two hours, and with the wind caused vast destruction of property.” whh cd well be spared— Adieu, dear Lady, everT.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 1 Oct. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Surtees, Ludovisi 150.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: About a week ago there lay, like a bright sparkle on the breakfast-table, a Letter from you;—and this morng, not reproachful of my silence, but agn full of benignity, and cheerful anticipatn, came another, nay two others, one of whh was mine!The other letter was to John A. Carlyle; see below. Surely, in loving kindness, you have no rival living; I feel quite bankrupt before you, and that barren gratitude, whh is all I have, can never be of any real use to you. No man of my acquaintance was, at any time, valued so far beyond his worth, intrinsic or extrinsic; that is my true opinn, the truest I can form upon the matter!—

But the reason of my silence was not this; it was simply the wish to be able to report two consecutive nights of sleep, and leave you with the hope that the paltry and thrice-miserable “sleep controvery” was not to trouble you or myself any farther for the time.TC, Mary Aitken, and John A. Carlyle returned to Chelsea, 20 Sept. TC noted in his journal, 28 Sept.: “‘Try it for 3 weeks!’ said we, and did. Nothing but insomnia there, alas;—yesterday (Monday gone a week) we struck flag agn and removed all home, enterprise to me a total failure. … Don’t try that agn!— Cannot get even into my old average of sleep here; my grand effort still only to do so.— Mary, I think, will go to Dumfrs, John do; and leave me alone with my miserable confusions; that really seems my best chance in this bad battle. The ‘Task,’ in a sort, done; Mary finish my Notes (of 1866) this very day;—I shrinking, for weeks past, from any revisal or interference there, as a thing evidently hurtful, (evidtly anti-somnial even!) in my prest state of nerves.— Essentially, howr, Her Letters & Memorials are saved” (TC’s journal; privately owned; Froude, Carlyle 4:382 inc). But no, that is hardly yet the case; tho’ clearly
there is improvet; and one must keep trying, and hoping. “Hope springs eternal”;Alexander Pope, An Essay on Man (1734) 1:95. this is truly named the “Place of Hope.”See Carlyle, Sartor 121.

But to come to busss. I had a Hand, indeed Both Hands, plaster-cast, the other day, under Woolner’s inspectn, in obedience to yr imperial command:TC reported, [28 Sept.]: “Today Woolner is to take a Cast of my two Hands; these will be like!” (TC’s journal; privately owned). the result I have not yet seen, only that all promised well; and I expect Woolner with the thing in a complete state shortly,—whh shall then go straight to Stanhope Street,Lady Ashburton rented a house at 6 Stanhope St. (Surtees, Ludovisi 151). to wait yr Ladyship’s pleasure,—whh I rather think ought to be To throw it into the street (for benefit of the cart-wheels), tho’ I know well enough you won’t do that with it. Accept it as a little gift from me, a bit of humble obedience; and do what you like with it. I said there were Two Hands; Woolner wd not have it otherwise than that they shd be disjoined, and quite independt of each other: coming home, I felt that this wd be absurd; that the right-hand whh is back uppermost with a pen in it shd be yours; and that I wd give my Sister the other whh is the worse, & thoroughly an idle matter!TC wrote, 6 Oct.: “Hands were done duly,—result not yet come to me: right-hand shall satisfy Lady An; left-hand I will send to Sister Jean; and so finish that paltry affair,—the least absurdly I can. (Woolner wdn’t have the two together as I wished; two separate to one party,—think of them tumbling abt till they break! Pah!)” (TC’s journal; privately owned); see 90. A plaster cast and bronze cast of the hands (in Beinecke Lib., Yale) are each listed as “1 object”; see http://brbl-dl.library.yale.edu/vufind/Record/3522119 and http://brbl-dl.library.yale.edu/vufind/Record/3522118.

Tait announces himself at this moment,—no doubt, in referce to those immortal Photohs!Robert Scott Tait; see TC to JAF, 14 Sept.; TC wrote, [28 Sept.]: “Prints, ‘plates for Library Editn,’ much paltry trouble with that thrice-insignift matter. Nearly over now? ” (TC’s journal; privately owned). Lady Ashburton was apparently assisting in the payment for reproductions for the library edn. of the forthcoming vols. Tait wrote to Lady Ashburton, 6 Oct.: “The open cheque for the payment of the photographs arrived safely this morning. / It was very confiding and considerate in your Ladyship to send it, (which it would have been time enough to think of paying for the things when they were done), and I shall communicate full particulars to you on making any use of it. / I saw Mr Carlyle on Friday [1 Oct.],—after receiving your note in the morning: and 1250 impressions of the profile were ordered that afternoon. It was thought better we should see how they turn out that large number before going further” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). For Tait’s profile of TC, taken from the photograph of 31 July 1854 (but reversed), used as the frontispiece to On Heroes (1870), vol. 12 of the library edn., see TC to LLA, 17 Dec.. whh forces me to end abruptly.

No Haunch ever arrived;Lady Ashburton wrote, 21 Sept.: “I sent you a haunch [of venison] yesterday—& as soon as I can get any grouse, you shall have some—but as my shooting Lodge is filled with a succession of artists, Musicians, Literary Men, & scientific savants, the game laughs at us.” The haunch did eventually arrive; see TC to MAI, 19 Oct. some hungry thief in some railway statn must
have siezed, & eaten it; as, I am told, their frequt custom is. Never mind them, miserable sponges; it did not come, but the bright kindness of it did, and stays. No grouse either; please don’t send any;—to baulk those thieves at atWord repeated by TC in error. least.

My Brr is still here; mildly idle; was charmed with yr Letter this morng;Lady Ashburton wrote to John A. Carlyle from Kinlochluichart, 29 Sept.: “A thousand thanks for your kind letter—that was a very wise … decision I believe you made, in favour of Addiscombe over Vichy—I only wish you had not all left it so soon—& I wish still more, that it had brought sleep to that brain—we all have such an interest in caring for—Next year, please God, he must try this air—which is most soporific— I am so glad to have this chance of thanking you most sincerely for the present you long ago, sent me, of that delightful translation of Dante” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). See 44:146TC to JAC, 9 Feb. 1867. thanks, thanks. Greatly I wish you were rid of those illustrious AustriansCount Kalmand Nakos and his wife Bertha; see TC to LLA, 15 Sept. in good time! A kiss to Marygoldkin. Adieu dear Lady, Ever yrs

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR [JRU], 1 Oct. Addr: Denmark Hill. PM: London, 1 Oct. 1869. MS: Strouse. Pbd: Cate 148. Quot: Edward T. Cook, Life of John Ruskin (1911) 2:165.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: We have been here, away bodily from Addiscombe, since Monday gone a week,—situatn little “improved” by that change; I struggling, for my own poor share, to recover the faculty of sleep,—hitherto with quite imperfect success. Don’t neglect to call on me, the first time you are in Town; the sight of yr face will be a comfort; and I long for a little farther talk on the problems you are occupied with.

At prest, after 2 p.m. I am not a certainty here;—note that. And come;—and let us settle some weekly Evg agn: why not!Ruskin replied, 4 Oct.: “I am so very glad—always to have a note from you—but I can’t get out in the evening now as I used to—I am always so weary; but I’ll come some morning—when my poor wits are yet with me—I’ve so much to ask you about my work.”

closer.note: Emily Hill, “One of your many Debtors,” wrote to TC, 20 Oct., from 25 2d Ave., New York: “For years it has been my hope to see you in the flesh, but I now fear that cannot be, yet the thought is hard to me that you should have been in the world with me yet have never given me a thought. I want you to send me a few words written by you to me.” TC wrote on the letter: “‘Emily Hill’ / got Autogph, & even Photohs! / Octr 1869.” Emily Hill not further identified.

div3.sourceNote: TC-MA [MAI], 7 Oct. MS: NLS 1763.308. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO MARY AITKEN

docBody.p: That is a good little Letter you have sent me;—as many of these as you like when time serves.— — Poor Tom, I had not the least notion how ill he was till these few words of yrs!Mary Aitken had gone to Dumfries to see her dying brother, Tom. TC noted in his journal, 6 Oct.: “Mary is gone to Dumfries (‘for a fortnt’ she said), Brr John is going (soon? )” (TC’s journal; privately owned). Mary wrote, [6 Oct.]: “I shall never forget the shock I got when I saw Tom. I had tried to realize to myself how weak & ill he was; but never for a moment thought of finding him so much changed. He is very weak—requires to be lifted in & out of bed and I don’t think could be thinner. But he is very gentle & contented, and his face has the beautiful pure innocent look of a little child.” Poor fellow my heart is soft towards him; I always recognised in what he did and forebore to do a great deal of real dignity and sense (almost the cleverest of you all, had he not been so imprisoned!)Tom was deaf. and have a real sympathy and love to him. His ansr abt dying young is beautiful and affectg.Mary wrote: “Mama said to him ‘Would you like to live to be an old man? ’ He answered ‘No; sometimes God takes people from much trouble.’” I wish there were anything I cd do to help him in the least!— Save yr poor mother, all that you possibly can, you young ones; that is a clear duty!—Mary wrote: “Mother is looking pale & careworn with so much watching & so is Annie. We got Mother to go to bed last night & Annie & I sat up with him.”

Since you went, I have slept more or less every night. Am improving,—or am not?TC noted, 6 Oct.: “For a week past I am sleeping better; whh is a specl mercy of Heaven! I dare not yet believe that sleep is regularly coming back to me; but only tremulously hope so, now & then. If it does, I might still write something; my poor ‘intellect’ &c seems all here; only lying crushed down under a genl avalanche of things foreign to it! … [A]t no moment can I forget my loss—nor wish to do it if I cd. Singular how the death of one has smitten all the Universe dead to me! ‘Morbid? ’ I sometimes ask; and probably it is: but in that sadness for my loved one (to whom sometimes join themselves my Mother, Father, &c &c—) there is a piety and silent patient tenderness whh does hold of the Divine” (TC’s journal; privately owned; Froude, Carlyle 4:383–84 inc).

Oldendop is much what you say, a rapacious Bird more or less, and at any rate a Goose more than half-distracted. Quite right yr treatt of her.Mary Aitken wrote: “The Dr forwarded a letter to me from that ‘Madame Oldekop,’ to whom you gave some £2 .. 5/ or so, in spring, begging more & sending a great many testimonials. … She has not one testimonial from any body that knows anything about her. I think I shall send them back without a word & unpaid.” TC had recorded in his checkbook: “9 jany 1869 / to Louise Oldekop / Charity / £2 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). Louise Oldekop not further identified.— — I am
off to a call on Princess of Waldeck (amiable, gentle lady,—of Mentone in my time),Helena Wilhelmine Henriette Pauline Marianne (1831–88), b. a princess of Nassau, m., 1853, Georg Victor (1831–93), prince of Waldeck and Pyrmont; TC had met them in Menton, Feb. 1867; see 44:150TC to JAF, 10 Feb. 1867. The princess of Waldeck wrote, 3 Oct.: “I know you have not forgotten me, & by these lines I come to ask you for the favour and great kindness to pay my husband & myself a visit when we pass London on our way to France. … The remembrance of your great kindness to us at Mentone ever dwells in my heart with deep felt gratitude & if I had to leave England without seeing you it would be a real grief to me.” TC noted in his journal, 7 Oct.: “Have to call, today, on a certn Princess of Wal[d]eck, a well-meaning very amiable lady, who took great pains abt me at Mentone: she came to Torquay last summer with one of her poor invalid little Boys, whom Mentone cd not save, and whom the Doctors sent to Torquay to die,—as he has quietly done, some weeks ago; the poor Mother now returning, with her Husband, to Mentone (I understand) where the rest are. One hour, the last she will crave of me, will not be misspent on this gentle, high and pure-hearted Sister of mine. The Prince too is worthy and honourable, tho’ of voice and manner almost ridiculous.” He wrote again, 14 Oct.: “Saw duly these Waldecks &c (good people of their sort)” (TC’s journal; privately owned). It was one of their das., Sophie (1854–69), who d., 5 Aug. 1869, leaving the Waldecks with four das. and a son. & have not a minute more.

div3.sourceNote: TC-AT, 8 Oct. MS: Yale. Pbd: Wilson, Carlyle 6:195 inc; Sanders, CF 217; The Letters of Alfred Lord Tennyson, ed. Cecil Y. Lang and Edgar F. Shannon, Jr. (Cambridge, MA, 1987) 2:536. Quot: Hallam Tennyson, Alfred Lord Tennyson: A Memoir by his Son (1897) 2:237.
div3.head: TC TO ALFRED TENNYSON

docBody.p: Mrs Oliphant,Margaret Oliphant Oliphant, b. Wilson (1828–97; ODNB), prolific novelist, biographer, reviewer, and misc. writer; friend of JWC’s since 1860; see 37:62JWC to MO, [12 Dec. 1860]; she lived at 6 Clarence Cres., Windsor. whose Note this accompanies, is an old and esteemed Friend in this house; distinguished in Literature (Life of Edwd Irving,Margaret Oliphant, The Life of Edward Irving (1862). &c &c); and, what is best of all, a highly amiable, rational, and worthy Lady. Be pleased to answer her needful little Inquiry,See TC to MO, 8 Oct. —and oblige withal,

closer.note: TC noted, 7 Oct.: “Queen is coming to Drumlanrick, (no; a populr rumourmerely!) this year; whh excites in me a mournful kind of smile” (TC’s journal; privately owned). The rumors presumably came from the intended visits of Victoria’s children. She, staying at Balmoral with her extended family, wrote in her journal, 1 Oct., that her 3d da., Helena (1846–1923), and husband, Christian (1831–1917), princess and prince of Schleswig-Holstein, were leaving to visit Drumlanrig (about 3 mi. [5 km.] NNW of Thornhill, Dumfriesshire), seat of the dukes of Buccleuch; Albert (1841–1910; ODNB), the prince of Wales, and his wife, Alexandra (1844–1925; ODNB), also visited, leaving Balmoral 17 Oct.; Victoria herself did not mention any visit of her own at this time (Queen Victoria’s Journals [Princess Beatrice’s copies]: http://www.queenvictoriasjournals.org).

div3.sourceNote: TC-MO, 8 Oct. MS: NLS 5793. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO MARGARET OLIPHANT

docBody.p: I am very glad to hear of you agn,TC’s last recorded contact with Oliphant was in March 1868; see 45:104–5TC to AH, 6 March 1868. —tho’ my right-hand, you perceive, is highly indisposed to writing at this moment!—

Inclose yr questn in that Note to Tennyson;Margaret Oliphant had written to TC asking for an introduction to Alfred Tennyson on behalf of her friend John Frederick Bridge (1844–1924; ODNB), organist at Holy Trinity Church, Windsor; he wanted permission to set passages from Tennyson’s “In Memoriam” (1850) to music. TC enclosed his letter to Tennyson (TC to AT, 8 Oct.), so that Oliphant could write to Tennyson herself. and if he still don’t ansr,Tennyson wrote to Oliphant, 18 Oct.: “I forwarded your request to Mr. Strahan [Alexander Strahan (1833–1918; ODNB), publisher], because to him properly belongs the right over my published poems. What he says of my objection to having any part of In Memoriam published to music is perfectly correct. Those portions which you have seen so published have been granted to the solicitations of friends not to be refused, as this is now granted to Mr. Carlyle’s and would, I have no doubt, have been granted to your own, had I the privilege of your friendship” (The Letters of Alfred Lord Tennyson, ed. Cecil Y. Lang and Edgar F. Shannon, Jr. [Cambridge, MA, 1987] 2:536). Bridge’s musical setting of lines from Tennyson’s “In Memoriam,” entitled “Christmas Bells” (1869), is listed in Musical Settings of Early and Mid-Victorian Literature: A Catalogue, ed. Bryan N. S. Gooch and David S. Thatcher (New York and London, 1979) 549. let me know agn.— You ought to call, when you are in Town. I am here till 3 (or at soonest 2) p.m., and have Tea at half past 8.
All good be with you, / Yrs ever truly / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-MA [MAI], 10 Oct. MS: NLS 1763.307. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO MARY AITKEN

docBody.p: Will you at once warn the Tailor that I can have no more of that detestable glazed black canvas put into any garment of mine—least of all into the waste-band of breeches; when, the first hot day, it will be found to have painted a smear of black all round one’s shirt there, and be hanged to it!—Be punctual, peremptory!Mary Aitken wrote, [9 Oct.]: “I have told the Tailor about your trousers. He has got the cloth & promises to make them like the pattern in every particular.” She then wrote, [14 Oct.]: “I noticed what you said about the black canvas Thomson says he will make it all right.” The tailor was George Thomson (b. ca. 1838) of Howgill, Dumfries; see 45:171TC to JF, 17 Sept. 1868.—
I am sleeping, if not well, fairly better than for the last 8 weeks; hitherto no utterly miserable night, tho’ sevl (last night, for one) are bad enough.

Poor sick Tom; he is daily in my thots: I wish I but knew of anything I cd do to be of the least use to him! It is possible, that new Livrpool Doctor with his solid regimen &c may do some real good;Mary Aitken wrote, [9 Oct.]: “Jim [Aitken Jr.] came from Liverpool last night. … He had been to consult a Dr Braidwood who is famous in Liverpool for his skill in cases of the kind; & he gave him powders &c to give to Tom & ordered him chops & solid food of that kind in preference to so much liquid. So far poor Tom does seem better. The powders give him an appetite & he took a good dinner today & is asleep this afternoon. Dr Braidwood says as there is no trace of consumption in the family, & Tom’s face is not yellow, which is the fatal symptom, he may still get well.” Peter Murray Braidwood (1842–1905), M.D. and LRCS (Licentiate of the Royal College of Surgeons). He lived at 2 Delamere Ter., Birkenhead. hope the best, still hope all you can.— Tell Tom, poor fellow, not to fret or regret because he cannot write to me;Mary Aitken wrote, [9 Oct.]: “Poor Tom has been talking about you every day for a long time. About a fortnight before I came he said several times that he was wanting to write to you.” his wish is itself a kind Letter, and I can myself add all the rest. Bid him stedfastly “Hope in the great God that made him,” “still trust in God,” and know well that His Will cannot be other than divinely Good. This is the greatest of truths, to all men high and low, now & forever.— Give my sympathies, my encouragets to yr poor Mother. Save her wheresor you can, all of you! I know you will—— Say all manner of kind things to Miss AnnAnn Welsh, JWC’s aunt. Mary Aitken wrote, [9 Oct.]: “Miss Ann Welsh was to come to Dumfries yesterday to stay for a week or two. I dare say she will call here sometime so I shall see her even should I not be able to call.” Mary wrote later, [21 Oct.]: “Miss A. Welsh came yesterday when I was out. She staid a long time with Mother & asked me to go to tea at her Lodgings on Monday so I shall be able to bring you home all news of them.” from me.

p.note: TC had reported a comment by Woolner, [28 Sept.], on one of Watts’s portraits of him (presumably the one commissioned for Forster, the only one with hands): ‘Yr Watts Portrait is what I guessed it wd be, a Cross betn a Lunatic & an Impostor!’ said Woolner to me, the other night: a very truth, as I had myself felt” (TC’s journal; privately owned). Apparently Watts was still troubled by his portrait of TC as Forster wrote, 12 Oct.: “I am grieved to give you any further trouble in a matter which has not turned out so fortunately as perhaps its intention may have deserved. / Hoping to save you from the necessity of giving another sitting in what had become distasteful to you—I had requested the picture from Mr Watts, telling him I shall be quite content to accept it as it is— He writes in reply—‘If you will leave the picture with me yet a day or two I will ride over to Chelsea and see if Mr Carlyle will give me a sitting— If inconvenient to him now, I will send the picture to you & ask you to let me have it later when it may suit Mr Carlyle to sit.’ / It seems inevitable! and, if it were possible, I should ask you, just for my sake, to give him another hour. You shall have no trouble or annoyance beyond— If however (which I can well understand) you cannot go to him just now—I would ask you merely to ‘let him down gently’—not to tell him, I mean, of the decisive opposition the thing has provoked.— It troubles me beyond measure to ask all this, but I would not have the poor man suffer more than is needful—having done what he meant to be his best.” TC wrote on Forster’s letter: “Watts’s Blotch-Portrait (‘last sitting’ to be, Friday next, 2½p.m. to end at 4 forever).— So distracted a monster of Painting I have never seen before: ‘Cross betn a Lunatic & an Imposter,’—no fraction of me recognizable in it. Fie!” TC apparently wrote to Watts, suggesting Friday, 15 Oct., as Watts then wrote to TC, [14 Oct.]: “The time you fix will suit me perfectly, I return you many thanks & echo you, ‘may good luck attend.’” TC wrote on Watts’s letter: “Portrait” to be suppressed; no other remedy!—(22 Octr,” and on the reverse: “Watts: Horrible Picture (dare n’t / why agn? )—Octr 1869.” TC wrote in his journal, 14 Oct.: “Tomorrow am to give that ‘last sitting’ (last of Three ‘last’ ones) & so actually to dismiss the Watts abortion out of my head for ever” (TC’s journal; privately owned); for the previous “last sittings,” see 45:195TC to CPH, 31 Oct. 1868; for the next “last sitting” (27 Oct.), see TC to JAC, 26 Oct.

div3.sourceNote: TC-RR [RRA], 13 Oct. Pbd: W. H. Allen, Autograph and Manuscript Catalog (1982) (Philadelphia) inc. Richard Randolph (1822–1906), Quaker writer and physician.
div3.head: TC TO RICHARD RANDOLPH

docBody.p: I have duly recd yr letter, but there came no BookPresumably Richard Randolph sent TC a copy of his poem, Aspects of Humanity: Brokenly Mirrored in the Ever-Swelling Current of Human Speech (Philadelphia, 1869). Randolph quoted TC twice, once in the “Preface” (Aspects 13–14) from TC’s essay on Diderot (Carlyle, Works 28:239–40), and once in the “Appendix of Passages, Parallel and Illustrative” (Aspects 43) from The French Revolution (Carlyle, Works 2:5). … so that I can make no answer, as matters stand.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 15 Oct. Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N.B. PM: 15 Oct. 1869. MS: letter: NLS 518.43; envelope: EUL. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
May God be with you, and bring comfort to yr sad heart, dear Sister, in this sad and solemn Event,Thomas Aitken d. 13 Oct. His death certificate recorded “Diarrhea 2 months.” TC wrote in his journal, 14 Oct.: “At this Morng comes word that poor Jean’s Tom at Dumfries is dead. ‘At half past 8 last night.’ Wae, wae,—and yet perhaps mercy, and stern goodness to the poor good yg man & to us!” John Aitken wrote to John A. Carlyle, [13 Oct.]: “Poor Tom is gone from us forever! At half past eight o’clock the last scene ended so calmly that he seemed only to sleep. / All in confusion!” TC wrote on the note: “To Brr John here: came at 2 p.m. next day” (MS: NLS 1775D.89). —sad and solemn to us all, but to none so much as you, the mother who has been bereaved! Poor Tom; poor kindly, honest, valiant, much imprisoned Tom; he is now at rest, set free forever; gone, beautifully, to his Maker; and dwells in all our hearts, till we follow him, thither.— I am much touched, for my poor part, with some of the things Mary said to me
today;Mary Aitken wrote, 14 Oct., presumably referring to TC’s paragraph meant for Tom, see TC to MAI, 10 Oct. “We all thank you very much for the beautiful Letter you sent to me. Poor Tom took it in his weak shaking hands only the day before his death & read it all though it took him nearly two hours to do so. He was very ill then,—gradually getting worse. He said two or three times after ‘I cannot write to Uncle Thomas’ & shook his head. … He suffered great pain yesterday & we dreaded the struggle he might have before all was over, & were thankful when he sank so peacefully to his rest which shall never be broken. … His face is not at all distorted with the pain; but he looks very bonnie & innocent & happy & we would not wish him back to his vacant suffering life.” TC wrote on the envelope: “Death of poor Tom, my Nephew, at Dumfries. (Octr 1869).” for years back, I had more and more seen into Tom; and loved and respected him more and more. It is God’s will, dear Sister; His pure and blessed Will, perhaps meant in much mercy withal;—what more have we to say!

My thots will be with you tomorrow;Tom’s funeral, Sat. 16 Oct.; Jean Aitken wrote, [17 Oct.]: “James came thro’ on Friday night & is to leave tomorrow forenoon. Jamie & his two sons were here at the funeral yesterday—also both the Jas. Austins. All well.” my heart prays for you, and is wae, wae;—but that can help you nothing, alas no.
God help you and us all.

div3.sourceNote: TC-MA [MAI], 19 Oct. MS: NLS 1763.310. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO MARY AITKEN

docBody.p:
The Dr has fixed on Thursday for going;Thurs., 21 Oct.; John A. Carlyle had been with TC since 16 Aug. that evg if nothing happen, you will see him agn. I will give him what wrappages are useful (in the sudden cold); these he can handily leave with you to bring back.— I do not set any day or time for you; come when you like best. I have been thinking sometimes, might it not be good if yr Mother came with you, and changed the scene &c &c for a 3 or 4 weeks? Cautiously consult her on this point, and consider yr best abt it; then let me know.Mary replied, [21 Oct.]: “You are very kind indeed to think of Mothers coming to London with me I fear there is little chance of that for her at present—though I believe it would do her much good. Poor Annie feels Tom’s death very much & would be quite too lonely without her.” Jean Aitken last visited Chelsea 9 Dec. 1867–mid-March 1868.— She sent me a beautiful little Note last sunday,Sun. 18 Oct., when TC received it; Jean Aitken wrote, [17 Oct.]: “My heart has been sealed up in the way of writing for long weeks past. … [W]e knew how deeply you sympathised with us in our distress; but still the expression of it, helped us & did us much good. Tom often spoke about you of late weeks. ‘Poor Uncle Thomas—one now’ & held up one finger & shook his head. He read that long note of yours on Tuesday last & seemed to understand every word of it, holding it in his cold blue hand till he made out every word. He said ‘Mary has been telling Uncle about me. But I cannot write to him.’ I said never mind. ‘What would you have written if you had been well? ’ I would have told him—here his Father came in to the room & he put his finger on his lip. ‘Silence.’ He got rapidly worse soon after this & never spoke of it again. I think he wanted to have told you he was going Home! He was very good & pleasant during his illness delicate & considerate about giving me trouble. … We shd not mourn & grieve for our poor brave imprisoned Tom but rather feel deeply thankful that he has gone before; where the weary are at rest. It would have been my saddest thought in leaving this world to think he was left behind.” —very good, very tender, sad & true; for whh thank her. I read
also with emotn what you wrote on the morrow after the Event. A beautiful, and I believe a blessed and a merciful Event, tho’ it comes in dark colours, & is sad to flesh and blood.

I am sleeping habitually a little better;—never yet any night well. For the rest, idle, idle; whh is a state intolerable to me.— Enclosed here is a sample of the Annan string; 2 clues of it, if you please; yr Aunt MaryMary Aitken wrote, [14] Oct.: “I wonder if you would at some time send a little bit of the string you wish from Annan. I am very sorry to trouble you; but have lost or mislaid the piece I brought as a pattern.” A clue is a ball of string or thread. Mary wrote, [21 Oct.]: “I am just writing to Aunt Mary [Austin] about the string.” got it witht difficulty. Yesterday came a Box (4/) “full of Pipes” it was said, & seemingly quite right; but we have not opened it yet: what do I owe John for this?John Aitken; the payment was apparently included in a check TC later sent to Jean Aitken; see TC to JCA, 16 Nov. Mary Aitken wrote, [21 Oct.]: “Your trousers have come I have examined them all over & can discern no fault at all in them. Your shirts (the half dozen new ones) came yesterday & also look well; they are not done up yet, but will be before I come. … Jack does not rightly know about the price of the pipes yet.” —Lady Ashburtn is under way; that is her last Letter. I intend to wait here (not at “Ashridge”)Ashridge House, Hertfordshire, the home of Lady Marianne Alford; see 45:14TC to LLA, 5 Aug. 1868. Lady Ashburton was going there on her way to London. TC apparently sent her both Jean’s and Mary’s letters about Tom’s death, as she wrote, [21 Oct.], to thank him for “the precious letter I found waiting me—& its precious enclosures—I have read them with tears & now return them— That Mother’s heart must be happier now that her darling is free & has done with pain & sorrow. … I am so touched by your sending me those letters—thanks—thanks.” for her arrival! An“An” repeated with a line over it at turn of page. immense Quarter of Deer, from her Lp, came last week (cost 11/), ¾ of whh we had to despatch Forster at once, who recd it as with sound of trumpet.Possibly this is the haunch of venison from Kinlochluichart, which was apparently lost en route (see TC to LLA, 1 Oct.), or Lady Ashburton sent another. Forster replied, 17 Oct.: “Certainly—‘finer or fatter ne’er ranged in a forest, or smoked in a platter’ [cf. O. Goldsmith, “Haunch of Venison” 1–2]—and most kind of you to send it! When I had recovered a little my amazement at its size, I saw immediately that my only chance was to buckle to it without delay, and some steaks from it … were smoking in a platter at 7 last night.” TC wrote on the letter: “Venison (from Loch Luichart)!—Octr 1869.” John and I are dining on the remainder ever since; and really good it is, and wholesomer to me than most things are. The “Indian Princess”Presumably Catherine Phillipps, da. of James Achilles Kirkpatrick (1764–1805), Resident at the court of Hyderabad, and col. in the British East India Company army, and his wife, m. 1801, Khair-un-Nissa (ca. 1786–1813), a Hyderabadi noblewoman. For Catherine Phillipps’s husband and children, see 45:biographical notes. never came (“suddenly sent for” by something or other),
FroudesThe Froudes were presumably still in Ireland. are not come; Forstrs, you observe, are, &c &c. “Hands” have just come (strange to look upon!);Thomas Woolner had made a cast of TC’s hands; see TC to LLA, 1 Oct., and above. but John advises that he ought not to carry either of them off till Lady A. have had her choice.In fact, Lady Ashburton took both; see TC to JCA, 16 Nov. ——— Alas, here has Tait entered!— Yr affecte/ T. C.

figure.p:
Thomas Carlyle’s hands; plaster cast by Thomas Woolner
Courtesy of Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University

div3.sourceNote: TC-FA [FAL], 20 Oct. MS: Nigel Althaus. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO FRIEDRICH ALTHAUS

docBody.p: I yesterday recd Herr Decker’s pleast gift of the Volks-Ausgabe,Rudolf Ludwig Decker (1804–77), Prussian bookseller and editor; see 27:375TC to RLDADK, 27 Dec. 1852, and 36:27TC to JN, 19 Dec. 1859. Volksausgabe, “People’s edition,” unidentified further. whh I had not heard of before, but found to be a very suitable-looking Book. Nothing wanting in it that I notice,—except indeed that there is no Index to it; a rather lamentable want! Please thank Mr Decker for his kindness to me;—and say, I earnestly counsel him to give the Index (Register) in that 5th volume, witht whh the poor Book is blind—that is to say, all its serious Readers are!—

A day or two before, I had recd yr vol VI;Althaus’s translation of vol. 6 of Frederick: Geschichte Friedrichs II. von Preußen gennant Friedrich der Grosse (Berlin, 1869); see MAI to FAL, 12 Feb. and took idly to reading in it here and there,—more than I had or have yet done in any other part of the Book. I find the Translatn very fairly done; in parts quite successfully, and with a genial expressiveness and truth. But there seem to be a good few mistakes, too, principally errors of the press, I thot,—whh obscure the sense, to the length sometimes of eclipsing it altogr. I wish there were a remedy; but suppose there is now none,—except stoicism, whh indeed on my part is easy.— Yr footnote on the ‘Bankside Theatre’TC referred to the Bankside Theatre as meaning a place of great theater, as it was in the days of Shakespeare; see Carlyle, Works 19:15. In a footnote Althaus wrote: “In Bankside, am rechten Ufer der Themse, befanden sich mehrere der ältesten Volkstheater von London, die für den vorwiegend ‘sensationellen’ Character ihrer Aufführungen bekannt sind [In Bankside, on the right bank of the Thames, were several of the oldest folk theaters in London, known for the predominantly ‘sensational’ character of their performances]” (Geschichte Friedrichs II. 6:311). is wrong slightly; it was one of Shakespeares Theatres, 250 years ago, & had nothing to do with sensationalism as we now term it.

closer.note: TC wrote in his journal, 22 Oct.: “Dr Althausen (my Translator) ‘cannot get any vehicle’ for a record of Neuberg of his bit of Life. Ought not I, perhaps? He was the faithfullest Help, and volunteer servt, that ever I, or perhaps any man of my generatn, ever had. A loving, loyal elemt in that hard Jew nature of his;—clear insight too, and a grt deal of ready force and talent. Cd I? ought I? ” (TC’s journal; privately owned). For TC’s earlier description of Neuberg in his journal, 3 April 1867, see 44:187–88TC to RFR, [11 April 1867].

div3.sourceNote: TC-TW [TWO], 20 Oct. MS: W. Hugh Peal Collection, Univ. of Kentucky. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS WOOLNER

docBody.p: “Hands”See TC to MAI, 19 Oct.. all right; and in right time: many thanks, and payt to yr man.TC recorded in his checkbook: “20 Octr 1869 / to Woolner’s man: ‘the Hands’). / £1 .. 5 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 23 Oct. Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N.B. PM: London, 23 Oct. 1869. MS: NLS 526.98. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I punctually got yr NewspaperThe Carlyles put pen strokes on newspapers, then sent free of charge, to family members to indicate that all was well. TC noted, 22 Oct.: “John went yesterday morning; poor old Brr,—now growing old too! Has been unusually quiet and good and patit with me here: his visit has done me benefit, not harm” (TC’s journal; privately owned). (the first thing I looked for, on stepping out) yesty morning; and today there was a welcome Letter lying for me; for whh many thanks. Erskine’s Inclosure (whh I return) was also an interestg Piece to me; pray tell him so; and that I mean to write before long, in spite of the state of my hand.John A. Carlyle wrote, 22 Oct.: “The enclosed note has come from Erskine this morning, & I have already written an answer for him. Of course he would be much gratified by a few words from you too,—in pencil or in ink.” The Dundas who is dead is that Scotch Lord of Session, I suppose; a precise hard kind of man, whom I remember to have met at Erskine’s once in that to me too memorable spring of 1866.TC stayed with Erskine, April 1866, while in Edinburgh to deliver his rectorial address; see 43:153JWC to MO, [31 March 1866]. Erskine wrote to John A. Carlyle, 21 Oct.: “You will have learned from the news-papers, that my excellent & much loved friend George Dundas has had a very sudden call. … He was I think my chief social support in Edinburgh. His mother & mine were sisters … I knew him from his birth. He was an amiable man full of all good social gifts—& higher cultivations. … I hope your brother is well & sustained under his burden” (MS: NLS 526.99). George Dundas (1802–69), Lord Manour (then changed to Manor), lawyer, Scots law lord 1868–69. Dundas’s mother was Elizabeth, and Erskine’s mother was Ann, das. of William and Ann Graham. The Edinburgh Evening Courant, 8 Oct., noted that he “was gentle, honourable, and high-minded. Though to a superficial observer he seemed dry, musty, and abstract, in point of fact he was the reverse. He was an admirable companion, full of geniality, who liked to hear a song, and could himself give one.” His death must be a great loss to poor E;—who, howr, seems beautifully firm both in hand and spirit.

I am sitting or gliding abt, perfectly quiet ever since you went away, and still more perfectly idle,—very gloomy and lonely, especially when it grows
late at night. By and by I count on finding for myself some kind of work, better than none. I called at Stephen’s door;James Fitzjames Stephen; he lived at 24 Cornwall Gardens, Queen’s Gate. found he was out. Forster & Wife called on me yesty; the only people I have yet spoken to, even a word. F. brot me a Bundle of letters (whh he was dating),—whh will be only too interesting, & whh I dare not yet look into!Letters from JWC; TC read them by 11 Nov. when he wrote in his journal: “Was busy looking over some new Letters of Hers; 82, mostly short Notes, all addressed to Forster or his Wife, 1840–65, very beautiful, cheery, graceful, true:—in some of the dates he had fallen wrong; I had to correct as I best cd. A mournful fascinatn to me, the reading of them! I felt bereaved, as if I had lost Her agn, when they ended. My feeling on that side, I think, is never like to abate at all. Sorrow not so lacerating, poignant, but almost deeper and tenderer than ever. Interwoven, incorporated (I might say), with all of religion, of love, devoutness, goodness, that is in one. Let it accompy my now lonesome steps till I die” (TC’s journal; privately owned).—

Every night, meanwhile, I have slept; night before last, I considered it (abt 2 a.m.) utterly desperate (dinner of chicken broth, nay quarrel with my bed, and many turnings & tumblings,—till utter palpitatns came, and readiness to take wing!)—but saved myself, miraculously, by half a glass of that Chapman stuff;Possibly John Chapman (b. ca. 1837), physician, 25 Somerset St., Portman Sq.; M.D. St. Andrews, 1857; physician, Farringdon Dispensary. whh stilled everything in five minutes, & in less than 15 minutes had me sound asleep for the night. Nothing so like miracle did any medicine ever do for me!TC noted, 22 Oct.: “Narrowly, never more narrowly, escaped a sleepless night; Chap n’s medicine (½glass of it) operating almost like a miracle!” (TC’s journal; privately owned). I mention this, because I am persuaded it might now & then do you also real good, and help you clear over a crisis:—shan’t I send you the Prescriptn, therefore, of“[O]f” repeated at turn of page. whh I have two copies, and you none?John A. Carlyle replied, 24 Oct.: “As to your prescription, I made two copies of it for myself & have them here before me, & perhaps I may take a dose now & then if required. It was for that reason that I had got the bottle made up in London.” Be advised! I never swallowed anything whh was of such decisive and visible use on the instt.—— Forstr pressed me to dine tomorrow evg—I did not promise; but may as well do it, if things don’t alter.—

Sad, very sad to me is that House of Mourning,—poor Jean “looking pale,” poor James &c &cJohn A. Carlyle wrote, 22 Oct., of arriving at Dumfries: “James, John & Mary met me at the station. James looks thin & worn beyond usual. Jean too is pale, but quite composed under her sad loss.” I understand it too well.

I am sorry Jean is not to come; but they all, as well as herself, seem to think it unsuitable at prest, so what have I to say? Perhaps sometime by & by, before many weeks, she may take a more favble thot.

Tell Mary she is to come when she likes; ‘10 days hence,’ any day,—I will
not hurry her or tie her.Jean Aitken wrote, [21 Oct.]: “I think as Mary has had a cold … it might be as well to give her another week or two when she is here. But if you want her at all for anything she seems quite anxious not to put you about by staying beyond her time … only a week or ten days more wd do her good.” Mary returned 2 Nov. —n.b. you might advise her to get a bag of that “Dumfries arrow-root,”—and especially to make experimts on the cooking of it (boiling, not boiling &c) till she completely understand it,Mary Aitken wrote, 27 Oct.: “I think I shall be able to master the making of the arrowroot I have got 2 lbs of it at ¼d a pound.” whh evidtly nobody here does! Tell her ‘on monday.’—— The Peabody House has actually got a 4th story;George Peabody (1795–1869; ODNB), American merchant banker and philanthropist, settled in England 1837. He set up a fund for building housing in London for the deserving poor. The first Peabody Mansion opened in Spitalfields, 1864, and the Peabody Mansion, Lawrence St., Chelsea, was completed April 1870. William Allingham noted in 1874 that a “large house, one of the Peabody Mansions, is now built on a plot of ground abutting on Cheyne Row” (“Green London,” Fraser’s Magazine 89 [April, 1874]: 511). complete abt an hour ago.— My affectionate regards to all the kind and sore hearts around you. Yrs ever T.C.A monument to Leigh Hunt (1784–1859; ODNB), paid for by public subscription, was unveiled in Kensal Green cemetery, 19 Oct. 1869, by TC’s old friend, Richard Monckton Milnes (1809–85; ODNB), 1st Baron Houghton. TC wrote, 22 Oct.: “The other day, ‘Unveiling Inaugtn of Leigh Hunt’s mont’: I had subscribed (even twice), and been bothered with pretty Letters abt it; but didn’t think. Nobody of the best mark seems to have been; whh a little disappointed me. Hunt was a truly gifted, pretty and amiable nature; did, of purpose, no ill to anybody. I still remember his Examiner at Mainhill (abt1821) as a useful advent to me: ‘Not an Editor of them worth naming beside this one!’ And now Ld Houghton alone officiates at his unveiling’; all the rest send ‘excuses’; poor I, not even that. It is an age of breakneck haste; & confuses not itself only, but all who are in it, even tho’ not of it. Surely I wrote something abt Leigh Hunt (some Note in these Letters) last year? I thot of doing it here, & then recollected.— Not one of all that set, I shd say, [Samuel Taylor] Coleridge himself not, had more of Nature’s melody in him, than Hunt. Poor good soul, adieu” (TC’s journal; privately owned). TC wrote a note on Hunt when editing JWC to MAC, [ca. 10 Sept. 1831], in which he also wrote “perhaps I already wrote somethg abt him” (see 5:448JWC to TC, [27 Sept. 1831]). TC was probably remembering the long paragraph he wrote on Hunt, 22 June 1866, in his reminiscences of JWC; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 138–39. T. Wemyss Reid wrote that the unveiling was “a congenial task” for Lord Houghton as “he had known him for many years, and was not one of those who allowed his foibles of taste and his eccentricities of life to prevent a full recognition of his genuine worth” (T. Wemyss Reid, Life, Letters, and Friendships of Richard Monckton Milnes, First Lord Houghton [1890] 2:204–5).

div3.sourceNote: TC-GT, [25 Oct.]. Pbd: Spiritual Magazine (Dec. 1869) 536. George Tommy, 7 Unity St., Bristol; unidentified further.
div3.head: TC TO GEORGE TOMMY

docBody.p: By volitn, or except passively and by accidt, I never did; nor have the least intentn of ever doing.George Tommy sent TC a clipping from the Western Daily Press, 19 Oct. 1869, containing TC’s letter to William Denovan, 19 Jan. 1869 (see TC to WDE, 19 Jan.); Tommy wrote, 23 Oct.: “Have you at any time, by the aid of your own senses, investigated the phenomena of modern Spiritualism? ” TC sent the clipping to John A. Carlyle, writing on its margin: “a ‘Mr Tommy’ of Bristol sends me this, with a passionate desire to know ‘If I ever with my own senses investigated the &c? ’ Ansr: ‘Never did; nor have the least intentn of doing.’—Send me this back.” He wrote on the reverse: “Spiritualism Octr 1869” (MS: NLS 1769.144). John replied, 28 Oct.: “I return the scrap from the Western Daily Press, though I should have liked to send it on to Syme in his retirement, as being most decided against an idle delusion which he too hates.” / T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 26 Oct. MS: NLS 526.100. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Today I return yr Christison History of Anaesthenics (or, -thetics?)Robert Christison (1797–1882; ODNB), physician and toxicologist. John A. Carlyle wrote, 24 Oct.: “I enclose a letter from Christison, giving a very clear & firm account of all that took place in regard to the discovery & use of medicines for relief of pain in operations. It is well worth reading.” The letter may have been an updated version of Christison’s journal entry on the subject of anæsthetics, 29 June 1868 (The Life of Sir Robert Christison, Bart., ed. “by His Sons” [Edinburgh, 1886] 2:350–52). John instructed: “Please send both sheets back to me punctually, for I keep the cover here ready for them, & should like very ill to lose them.” whh is a very succinct, clear & precise little Piece,—well worth one’s reading (after diner, as was yesty its fate). It is singular how like his Fathers,Robert Christison’s father was Alexander Christison (d. 1820), prof. of Humanities at Edinburgh University 1806–20, where he taught TC; see 1:56TC to TM, 21 June 1815; he also helped TC acquire his teaching job in Kirkcaldy; see 1:81TC to RM, 15 July 1816. this Christison’s hand is,—and this Xtison’s Son’s is!Robert Christison’s second son, David Christison (1830–1912), was physician to Lord Ashburton, and wrote often to the Carlyles when Lord Ashburton was ill in 1862; see 39:18JWC to BB, [25 Dec. 1862], and 170TC to LOA, [1] Aug. 1863.— — Simpson, it seems, had little to do with the real busss;Sir James Young Simpson (1811–70; ODNB), obstetrician and physician; Christison, wishing to refute the general belief that Simpson had “discovered” chloroform, laid out in his journal entry the history of the discovery of and experimentation with chloroform from 1832 until 1847 when Simpson started applying “this anæsthesia to the treatment of disease, the management of surgical operations, and the painless delivery of women in labour!” (2:350–51).main Discoverer is certainly Sir Hy Davy.Sir Humphrey Davy (1778–1829; ODNB), bart., chemist and inventor; he experimented with laughing gas and wrote Researches, Chemical and Philosophical, Chiefly Concerning Nitrous Oxide (1800), in which he recommended the gas as an anæsthetic in minor surgery, but the idea was not pursued at the time.

Forster’s dinner was a variatn,—hardly better otherwise than silence here. One Fitzgerald (Author of Sterne’s Life)Percy Hethrington Fitzgerald (ca. 1831–1925), Anglo-Irish lawyer, author, critic, painter, and sculptor; The Life of Laurence Sterne, 2 vols. (1864). was there, with his young Irish “Ladyship” of a Wife; innocent people both, and radiant with “happiness” for the time being,Fitzgerald m., 8 July 1869, the Hon. Dorcas Luisa, b. Skeffington (d. 1876), da. of John Skeffington (1812–63), Viscount Masserene and Ferrard and Olivia Deane, b. Grady (d. 1874).—nichts zu bedeuten [of no importance] farther. I narrow—narroley escaped the sleep penalty,—agn by aid of that medicine, and beyond my hope! I seemed to have eaten too little vegetable stuff (by accidt, not choice); cd think of no other mistake. Sorrow on it;One of TC’s phrases; see 26:36TC to JAC, 20 Feb. 1851, and 38:61TC to JCA, 17 Feb. 1862. especially on all dapes-et-obsonia [rich and plentiful food] “entertaints”TC also complained about rich and plentiful food at an earlier dinner at the Forsters; see 45:95TC to LN, 18 Feb. 1868. as they are reckoned!—

Yesterday Painter Watts came, appoints me for Thursday to that Monster of Portrait, “half-madman, half impostor.” He shall have one hour; then rigorously Satis [enough]. If this is, was man von Freundenerlebt [what one experiences from a friend], what will Feindes [enemies] do, I wonder?— Lady Ashbn too I saw for a moment (by accidt),—hurrying home to Melchet; with her HungariansCount Nakos and his wife, Bertha; see TC to LLA, 15 Sept. sent on ahead: she is to be “back here in a week”; will then be plentifully visible “for 4 or 5 days.” Town is filling rapidly,—to my joy not.Among the people returning to town were William Frederick Pollock (1815–88; ODNB; see 43:274), lawyer, and his wife, Juliet, b. Creed (1818–99). Pollock wrote, 24 Oct., that they had just returned home, “after an absence of some weeks”; he wanted to bring a “copy of certain essays” (by TC) on Samuel Johnson and “one Robert Burns” for TC to sign (“as may be most convenient for you”) as a present for a friend’s da. His wife sent her love and hoped to see TC soon. For a dinner with them while JWC was still alive, see 43:49TC to JAC, [27] Nov. 1865. Weather good, tho’ always cool or cold.TC apparently called on Forster during his walk, as Forster wrote, 26 Oct.: “So vexed I did not wait 5 minutes longer today—for you came immediately after, I hear!”

Poor Jean’s Letter of Sunday was very affecting; very sad, wae-hearted; and is seldom out of my head since. I felt in it a genuine tone of piety, howr, of
weeping resignatn; whh was my comfort. Give her an eldest Brr’s blessing, if it be good for anything— My love to you all.

closer.note: TC was also written to by George William Novice (b. ca. 1806), 26 Oct., praising him for “vindicating the character of Oliver Cromwell” and asking him “to write something, however brief,” to defend George Gordon Byron (1788–1824; ODNB), 6th Baron Byron, against attack by Harriet Beecher Stowe (1811–96); Stowe had published a defense of Annabella, Lady Byron, against a perceived attack by Teresa Guicciolli (one of Byron’s last lovers) in her Recollections (1869); Stowe published the claims about Byron’s relationship with his half-sister, Augusta Leigh, in her article (“The True Story of Lady Byron’s Life,” Atlantic Monthly24 [Sept. 1869]: 295–313, Macmillan’s Magazine20 [Sept. 1869]: 377–99). TC wrote on Novice’s MS: “EdinrOctr 1869 / ‘vindicate Byron, won’t you!’— Bah!—.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 27 Oct. Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N.B. PM: London, 27 Oct. 1869. MS: NLS 526.101. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote this letter in blue pencil at the end of a note from Forster, 26 Oct., inviting TC to dinner: “Stephen has fixed Wednesday in next week (the 3d of November) for our little dinner here—and I am writing by this post to Tyndall and Venables. That will be all our party.” This was presumably a farewell dinner party for James Fitzjames Stephen who was appointed legal member of the council to the Indian viceroy, Richard Southwell Bourke (1822–72; ODNB), 6th earl of Mayo, and was due to leave early Nov.; he remained in India until April 1872. George Stovin Venables (1810–88; ODNB), lawyer and journalist.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: There has just come from Macmillan (by “Parcels Cy paid”) a Copy of the Icelandic Dicty Part I, A-H—whh, unless I mistake, is exactly the alter-idem [another of the same] of the Copy you used to be handling here. Shall I send it at once, or lay it by with care till some occasion rise? Speak!An Icelandic-English Dictionary, Part 1 A–H, by the late Richard Cleasby, enlarged and completed by Gudbrand Vigfusson (1869). John A. Carlyle replied, 28 Oct.: “That book sent by Macmillan must be the same as the one you used to see me making use of; & so there is no necessity for sending it on to me. Keep it in the meantime.” In the Preface to the book, John was listed as one of the Icelandic scholars who had been of assistance in compiling the dictionary, so perhaps he had had an early draft.
