He had been studying Icelandic since April 1863 (see 39:116JWC to LLA, 1 May [1863]), including during a visit to Chelsea in Aug. 1863 (see 39:179TC to JAC, [30 Aug. 1863]); Jean wrote of his table covered in “Icelandic Dictionaries &c &c,” Aug. 1864 (see 40:200TC to JWC, [23] Aug. 1864), so he presumably also had other dictionaries.—

Mary (Sister) has, this morning also, sent a little Box of eggs &c, whh I have been acknowledging. Cowman Collie, it appears, when his people sent a nest-egg,Henry Collie (1808–73), cowkeeper, living at 1 Upper Cheyne Row, Chelsea; TC presumably meant that they sent a bad egg which had been used as a nest egg and as result they stopped getting eggs from Collie for a while. & chucked us into sudden halt in that course, had broken a blood-vessel,
and was dangerously ill,—not“Not” repeated with a line over it at turn of page. yet by any means recovered altogr, poor creature.

Tait, the “Pernicketty”, has evidtly made a “mull”Making a muddle or a mess of; see 42:143JWC to TC, [22 July 1865]. of the Chapmn-Portrait negociatn.Tait had been negotiating with Chapman about the printing of portraits of TC for the library edn. of TC’s works, to be paid for by Lady Ashburton; see TC to LLA, 1 Oct. Misunderstandings about the numbers of copies wanted and the cost had arisen; Tait wrote to TC, 20 Oct. and 26 Oct., and to Lady Ashburton, 28 Oct. (MS: NLS Acc. 11388), explaining his position and saying he would have nothing more to do with the matter. Tait’s letter to TC of 26 Oct. is filed with the MS of this letter, so presumably TC sent it on to John. On Tait’s letter of 20 Oct., TC wrote: “Tait (‘Picture’: ach!) last one of many—Octr 1869”; and on the envelope he wrote: “Miscs, Lady An: abt Pictures &c &c / Septr–Octr 1869 (don’t open agn!).” I feel relieved that at least he has done with it; & shall be brief in my subsequt treatt of the paltry insignificance he has made so bothering!— Miss Bromley came last light;TC wrote “light” for “night.” Caroline Davenport Bromley had apparently been to Paris; she returned via Folkestone where she met John Tyndall; he wrote, 26 Oct.: “I saw Miss Davenport Bromley at the Station [? ] at Folkestone, She told me that Lady Ashburton was now in Scotland with a constellation of genius around her. I believe her affinity with genius is true & deep” (RI MS JT/1/T/149). and left a small Paris memento for Mary; whh awaits her here. My kindest sympathy & love to poor Sister Jean. Good be with you all.—T.C.Tyndall wrote from the Royal Institution, 26 Oct., about his trip to Switzerland: “One evening towards the end of August I stood upon the Knob of a mountain about 7000 feet above the sea; with the largest glacier in Europe just beneath me, the mountains around me, and the Sky, which was still red in the West, overhead. / I was in good health. This I had sought for weeks but had not found it. It came at last. The spell of sleeplessness was broken, the food well digested and well applied and I felt as I stood there, puffing my cigar, a joy of life—a pleasure in mere existence—such as I have not felt for years. It was moreover no flash in the pan—for day after day this feeling of health made life in the hills a pleasure to me. / You crossed my thoughts and got entangled among them as I stood upon my mountain Knob, and I wished intensely that I could have had you there for 10 days, to prove the effect of the mountain air upon you. The experiment of going there would be dangerous, for the hotel, though a comparatively quiet one would not be called quiet by you.” Tyndall injured himself after bathing under a cascade: “My clothes were 20 yards distant from the cascade, and in returning to them I crossed—unnecessarily—some loose blocks of granite. It was the shortest way. The thought of caution never occurred to me, for there was nothing to excite it. So I slipped and fell.” His injuries became inflamed: “on the whole this paltry stagger lost me 6 weeks of bed & the loss of all my splendid health. I came … to Folkestone a fortnight ago—there I halted for I could hardly walk 50 yards. Before I quitted it I was equal to 10 miles. On Tuesday night [19 Oct.] I came here—I have thought of writing to you daily since but could not get so far until this morning” (RI MS JT/1/T/149). TC presumably sent the letter on to John A. Carlyle as he wrote at the end: “needn’t send back / T.C.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-AS, 31 Oct. MS: NLS 3823.186. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO ANTHONY STERLING

docBody.p: The EngraverJoseph Brown; see TC to JAF, 14 Sept. For his engraving of John Sterling’s portrait for the frontispiece of The Life of John Sterling (library edn., 1870), see 100 and Carlyle, Works 11:frontispiece. has done with that Falmouth PortraitThe portrait of John Sterling belonging to Caroline Fox (1819–71; ODNB; friend of the Carlyles since 1840; see 12:147–48TC to MAC, 20 May 1840), who lived in Cornwall. Sterling lived for some time in Falmouth and become friendly with the Fox family; see Carlyle, Works 11:200. that we know of; & has made, I think, a very tolerable Plate,—Proof Copy to be sent to you, whenevr I hear you have returned home.

figure.p:
John Sterling, portrait by Benjamin Delacour, 1830,
engraving by Joseph Brown, 1869
Thomas Carlyle, The Life of John Sterling (1897)

docBody.p: What I now want is that you wd (again) tell me the Painter’s name (Delaporte or what?)—and the year,The portrait was by Benjamin Delacour (ca. 1795–1843), painted 1830. or yr nearest guess at the year, of his Performance.— So soon as you can convently manage.

“Miss Caroline Fox, Falmouth,”Caroline Fox lived at Penjerrick, near Falmouth, Cornwall. She wrote, 8 Nov.: “The portrait has safely arrived & the four beautiful proofs for which I am greatly obliged. I think the picture is wonderfully copied & the degree of likeness which we remember well retained.” Mary Aitken wrote on the envelope: “Misses Fox / About Sterling Portrait.” is the Address for returning the Picture to its Owner? Isn’t it?—

div3.sourceNote: TC-EF, 31 Oct. Pbd: John Glyde, Life of Edward FitzGerald (1900) 230–232. Quot: A. M. Terhune and A. B. Terhune, Letters of Edward FitzGerald (Princeton, 1980) 3:163 and 174. Edward FitzGerald (1809–83; ODNB), writer and translator, TC’s friend since 1842.
div3.head: TC TO EDWARD FITZGERALD

docBody.p: Dear Fitz-Gerald,—I have not much to say in reply to your kind letter of inquiry,FitzGerald wrote, 27 Oct.: “You know I call on you for a little bit of a Letter once a Year: about this time too, when we are all of us shutting in, I suppose. I dare say you have not much more to tell me than I you.” He was in the habit of writing annually to TC; see 45:209TC to EF, 7 Dec. 1868. except that it is very welcome to me, and my regret only is that the like come so seldom, and the inquiry in person never at all! The sight of you again would no doubt bring mournful memories, but it would surely do me good withal.

For the last year I have been extremely bothered with want of sleep; a miserable
kind of suffering—coming always at intervals, though too frequently, and much deranging my poor proceedings for the time it lasts. Within the last few weeks, it has again nearly withdrawn, and I am again flattering myself that it will not return, but leave me at my old poor level, which you know was never very high! A brother of mine (M.D. by profession)John A. Carlyle. asserts, plausibly rather, that good part of the mischief has arisen from the employment I was at:—sorting, etc., etc., of old papers pertaining to the dead and vanished; which naturally kept me in an altogether sombre state of mind, and that now this or the tenderest part of this being mainly done, rest will follow. We shall see, we shall see!

I hadThus in printed source; TC probably wrote “lead.” a most still life here; my thoughts turned mostly far elsewhither, as is now fit and suitable. They are printing a “Library Edition,” as they call it, of my poor books; five or six proof-sheets came to-day, which I think myself bound to read. This is pretty much my one prescribed employment, but I have enough of others very much more interesting to me. With one or two (I really think hardly four in all) I have now and then some pleasant conversation, the other mostly I am better without. In short, I am becoming a land hermit as much as you are a sea one.FitzGerald wrote: “All the Summer I was afloat, if not sailing: and I came up the River here yesterday”; he lived at Markethall, Woodbridge, Suffolk, on the river Deben.

Browning’s book I read, insisted on reading: it is full of talent, of energy, and effort, but totally without backbone or vein of common-sense. I think, among the absurdest books ever written by a gifted man.FitzGerald wrote: “I should rather like to know what you think of Browning, and his big new Book, which the London Critics are trumpeting. … I have tried three times at the Book and Ring, and three times failed. I dare say you won’t care to say a word about it—even if you have ever read it.” For TC’s earlier comments on Browning’s The Ring and the Book (1868–69), see TC to JAC, 11 Jan., and TC to JCA, 11 March. Do you know the late Arthur Clough and his Writings and Biography, edited by his widow (Macmillan & Co.)?Arthur Hugh Clough (1819–61; ODNB), poet, friend of TC’s since the mid-1840s; his widow (m. 1854), Blanche Clough, b. Smith (1828–1904) pbd. privately Clough’s Letters and Remains (1865); for TC’s comments, see 43:58–59TC to BC, 30 Nov. 1865. Macmillan & Co. recently pbd. the larger work: Poems and Prose Remains of Arthur Hugh Clough, with a Selection from his Letters and a Memoir, ed. Blanche Clough, 2 vols. (1869). Let me recommend that to you: I knew Clough, and loved him well.
Adieu, dear F., you see what my right hand is gone to, though my heart is still alive as ever.— Yours truly, / T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 3 Nov. Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N.B. PM: London, 3 Nov. 1869. MS: NLS 526.104. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Yesterday I went to Chapmn’s ab yr Two Friedrichs,TC omitted “t.” John A. Carlyle wrote, 28 Oct.: “The copies of your Stereotype Frederick for James Jr and me, which we ordered at Chapmans in August, have not come or been heard of at all. I suspect they were never sent off at all.” among other things. OrrAn associate of Chapman’s, possibly William Somerville Orr (ca. 1801–73), publisher and publishers’ agent, living at 129 Clarendon Pl. stedfastly asserverates that he did (in Augt) straightway send the Two Copies in questn, with correct Address “by Caledonn Railway” &c;—is to write off to his Edinr peopleJohn Menzies & Co., Edinburgh and Glasgow wholesale distributor of books and newspapers, agents for Chapman & Hall since 1837 (see 45:148TC to DL, 12 June [1868]); their warehouse was at 2 S. Hanover St., Edinburgh. at once, and either dig out the Books there, or send a new pair of copies, “Within a week hence.”

As to Margt Austins lease,Margaret Stewart; see TC to JAC, 6 May. I am perfectly willing to go step by step along with you in regard to that £328; the only thing I shd think requisite wd be some certificate or solid testimony that I had advanced it,—whereby, on my departure, it might fall into the genl stock of Heritage—and nobody get more than his share. The same precautn, I suppose, will be necessary for yrself by a like reason.John A. Carlyle wrote, 12 July: “The chief difficulty is that the name of poor Tom’s brother [James] still stands in the Lease & he is a very violent-tempered man, might interfere at any time, & some £350 which Tom owed him is still unpaid & has been since the farm [Ernhirst] was taken. The £300 I lent to Tom was all expended in draining & otherwise improving the land, & the £350 in buying stock, interest for it being paid by Tom every year since the brother left. … [Margaret’s] only plan of getting rid of the farm is to cease paying rent for one year, after which the landlord has the right to take it into his own hands again. If she could pay off the brother, & get him to come under a legal bond not to interfere during the lease after getting his £350–which he seems willing to do—that would be one method of settling the matter.” He then wrote, 31 Oct./1 Nov.: “Nothing has yet been arranged about [Margaret’s] farm, & she looks rather thin & worn. … Today I have seen Mr Symmons. There is but one way of settling the matter he says. The old lease must remain but Stewart can make over his share of it to Margaret or to her eldest boy, & [the landlord] would not object at such arrangement. Stewart says he wishes to get rid of the whole concern & to have the sum of £328 belonging to himself & his brothers or sisters. Would you be willing to advance the half of that sum? … Young James of Craigk & his Father should look to the farm if Margaret remains & let her confine herself to her dairy & household work. I for one shd not have confidence in any management of Margaret’s father. Would you? ” Mr Symons, Adamson’s partner in the British Linen Co. Bank; see TC to JAC, 6 May; unidentified further. John replied, 5 Nov.: “Your letter about Ernhirst is clear & right, & I will do my best in the matter, but must wait for farther information.” To follow you in this point, therefore, will be my course;—as
indeed I must do in regard to the Prosperity of the Thing itself; having of my own not the least real knowledge of it, or means of getting any.

Mary dropt in upon me yesty morning while I was still at breakfast.Mary Aitken, now returned from Dumfries; John wrote, 31 Oct./1 Nov.: “Mary starts tonight, to go right through to London, & hopes to be with you sometime between half past ten & eleven tomorrow morning.” I saw she was very wae, poor thing; but she kept busy at various bits of work all day; slept before and after dinner; and at 9½ p.m. I packed her off to bed altogr,—where she seems to have had sleep in abundance; and is looking as well need be, over her work beside me.

She will go to Tait this afternoon; and, if she can find him at once, will (one wd think) at once manage in some good way that matter of the Photh Negative,—whh Tait, as you have heard, was anxious to have sent by you for Mr Erskine, had you been going direct for Edinr.Erskine wrote to John A. Carlyle, 1 Nov.: “I am much obliged to you for your offer to help me in the matter of Mr Tait’s negative photograph. I should like to be able to make use of it, as my friends sometimes ask me for a photo—& it is by far the best I understand. … The old glass negatives are liable to fracture & the modern ones are on paper & I believe that the glass ones can be transferred to paper” (MS: NLS 1776.148). Possibly a glass negative of a photograph of TC or JWC; but also possibly a negative of Tait’s photograph of Erskine’s sister, Christian Stirling (1789–1866), taken 25 May 1855; see 31:186TC to JWC, 21 Aug. 1856, and 189JWC to TC, [23 Aug. 1856]. A safe conveyance; that is the one difficulty: and I will instruct Mary to assure the scrupulous & punctilious Tait, that safety is the point of points; and that any and all expense he incurs abt this “Negative” (getting it changed to paper if he like, &c &c) will be at once repaid by me in Mr Erskine’s name, with many thanks all round.John A. Carlyle sent Erskine’s letter to TC, 2 Nov., writing: “I daresay Mary will be able to negociate with Tait & get it sent off direct to Erskine in some safe package, who will at once pay the cost of doing so.” Erskine wrote to TC, 14 Nov.: “Mr Tait’s negative has arrived in perfect entireness. I have to thank you for your share in this transaction. … I should like to know what I owe him.”

This journey to Edinr seems a very likely thing; pleast, and will do you good. My gratefullest remembrances to Mr Syme; of whom I shall be anxious to hear news at first hand.John A. Carlyle, planning to visit friends in Edinburgh, 5–8 Nov., wrote, 31 Oct./1 Nov.: “I intend accepting Syme’s invitation … after much hesitation—from Friday night till Monday night following.” He wrote, 7 Nov.: “I have found Mr Syme looking better than I expected. He can walk pretty freely without halting, writes without difficulty in his old hand.” James Syme had suffered a stroke, 6 April; see TC to JAC, 28 April. The like to my good and dear Mr Erskine: you may well assure him it is nothing but my right-hand that hinders me writing,—and sha’n’t long.John A. Carlyle wrote: “I saw Erskine twice. … He looks as well as when I saw him in May. … Your letter had come by the morning post, & was most welcome & cheering to him.”— I have taken such a time over this, e.g.; cd have engraved it (on lead) sooner once!TC repeated “once” with a line over it at turn of page.— — We are very glad to hear of Jean’s hand mending.John A. Carlyle wrote 31 Oct./1 Nov.: “Jean got her arm burnt last week in lifting the lid of a boiler, & did not use the proper remedies for it in time.” He then wrote, 2 Nov.: “Jean’s arm was nearly well this morning, you can tell Mary, & will scarcely need more bathing.”—
I have had 2 bad nights in successn (the Chapmanium,Sleeping draught recommended by John Chapman; see TC to JAC, 23 Oct. John replied, 5 Nov.: “A somewhat larger dose of that medicine of Chapman becomes necessary if one uses it often in succession.” only half availing!)—am in rather low case than otherwise. Yr affecte alwaysT. Carlyle

postscript.p: Mary detains the Erskine; but it shall be carefully sent

div3.sourceNote: TC-CM [CMU], 9 Nov. MS: Draft version NLS 518.44. Pbd: Scotsman, 11 Nov. 1869; Robert Paterson, Memorials of the Life of James Syme (Edinburgh, 1874) 309. Notes below refer to the text in Memorials of the Life of James Syme. Charles Murchison (1830–79; ODNB), surgeon and physician, author, and treasurer of the British Pathological Society 1869–77. He studied medicine in Edinburgh, 1847–51, working under Syme 1850–51. He had been living and working in London since 1855.
div3.head: TC TO DR. CHARLES MURCHISON

docBody.p: It gives me real pleasure to hear of a Testiml to Mr Syme;A public meeting was held, 10 Nov., in St. James’s Hall, Piccadilly “For the purpose of initiating a testimonial, on the occasion of [Syme] resigning the chair of Clinical Surgery in the University of Edinburgh” (Memorials of the Life of James Syme 306). Concluding the meeting, Murchison moved that “The form of the testimonial be, first, a fellowship for the promotion of Surgery in the University of Edinburgh, to be called the Syme Surgical Fellowship; and, second, a marble bust to be placed in the University library, or in the hall of the new Royal Infirmary” (Memorials of the Life of James Syme 309). It was announced that £735 had already been raised for subscription, and that other donations were promised. to my judgt there have been few in our days that were as well deserved. Yr plan or scheme of a result, is likewise altogr to my mind. I will at once subscribe my poor £10 to it,TC recorded in his checkbook: “15 Novr 1869 / to Dr Murchison (Syme Testimonl) / £10 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753); Murchison sent TC a receipt, dated 15 Nov. and wish you all manner of speed. Unhappily I cannot attend to-morrow, nor be of the Comee,The printed text read “not being of.” TC’s “Comee” has a line over “m,” indicating a double “m.” nor at all concern myself with managet, even in name.The printed text ended: “— Yours sincerely. T. Carlyle. / Dr. Murchison.” I remain

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 12 [11] Nov. MS: NLS 526.105. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated; Thurs. was 11 Nov.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I am glad you are safe home agn,John A. Carlyle wrote from Dumfries, 10 Nov., having just returned from Edinburgh. and have found the Excursn answer to you. I got all yr Letters, the first two together, all the others in regr time. I was struck very sad by what you say of poor David Aitken.John A. Carlyle wrote, 10 Nov., of his visit to David Aitken: “He seemed much downcast by the loss of his wife. She died of a kind of paralysis which came upon her one morning immediately after getting out of bed. She lingered two or three days & seemed partially sensible, but could speak very little, & sank gently at last by slow degrees.” David Aitken (1796–1875; see 4:192TC to DA, [17 Feb. 1827]), retired minister of Minto, Roxburghshire, m., 1836, JWC’s childhood friend Eliza (“Bess”), b. Stodart (ca. 1794–1869; see 1:199JBW to EA, [26 Sept. 1819]), who d., 5 Oct., at 4 Charlotte Sq., Edinburgh. Poor old feckless man, left solitary too; his dilettantism now changed to reality so stern. The death of “Bess” herself struck upon old chords, never silent in my own heart, and has been often prest to me since I first heard of it.TC wrote in his journal, 11 Nov.: “Poor ‘Bess Stoddart’ (Mrs D. Aitken) once of Minto), a young intimate of [JWC’s] (some years older than She) was suddenly summoned two weeks ago,—‘stroke of paralysis just after getting out of bed:’—poor Aitken left suddenly alone too! They were a commonplace pair of people; but Death has made them also tragic to me” (TC’s journal; privately owned). TC had probably last seen them at a dinner at Erskine’s, 2 April 1866, after his rectorial inauguration; see 43:158TC to JWC, 3 April 1866. You did not see Stirling,James Hutchison Stirling (1820–1909; ODNB); see 45:87–88TC to JHS, 23 Jan. 1868, and elsewhere. it seems? No great matter.— Yr acct of Syme is satisfactory. Yesty there was a Public Meeting here abt a Testimonial to him; one “Dr Murchison” the originator, and very many, chiefly medical people supporting. I didn’t go; said, I cd not be of the Comee, or take any managet, but wd subscribe £10, and approved heartily &c. Probably you have got their Papers, or will get;See TC to CMU, 9 Nov. John A. Carlyle replied, 12 Nov.: “I send you the report of that meeting for the Syme Testimonial, from the Scotsman of yesterday, which you can at least look at. I intend subscribing myself too, for I think Syme deserves such a testimonial, & the Surgical Bursary with his name may do good.” if not, I think they are still here, & can be sent.

Erskine’s Negative, it appears, will arrive today; Tait says he “made the Box himself,” so will probably accept of no payt.For Tait’s negative being sent to Erskine, see TC to JAC, 3 Nov.— Lady Ashbn is here; came down last Friday after dinner, and cut off my sleep; but has done no other mischief with her kindness; nor will, I think. Tonight, indeed, “at 10 p.m.,” she is to take me to Lady Wm Russell’s (where I have long been due);Elizabeth Ann Russell, b. Rawdon (1793–1874), widow of Lord George William Russell (1790–1846; ODNB), always known as Lady William Russell; see 43:275–76; she lived at 2 Audley Sq. She was a particular friend of JWC; see 43:167JWC to GCMC, [5 April 1866], and Carlyle, Reminiscences 187. but I mean to come away speedily, and will neither eat nor drink.

We are going on very quietly here, Mary busy enough, very assiduous poor little soul; and my sleep, I begin to really believe, seems to be on the improving hand. No drug swallowed for, I think, almost a fortnight now, and no night utterly bad.— We too are getting winter; yesterday a sudden whirlwind of sleet overtook Froude & me on the streets, and whitened us both for abt 5 minutes; and last night we had real frost,—thickish ice on the puddles this morning, but stillness & sun, whh latter continue.— Froude as you hear has come home; somethg of a real acquisitn to me. Stephen went away on Tuesday.James Fitzjames Stephen; see TC to JAC, 27 Oct. Forster—but enough of that at prest.

T. BallantyneThomas Ballantyne (1806–71; ODNB; see 11:32TC to TB, 23 Feb. 1839), originally from Paisley, author and journalist, associated with various magazines and journals. was here yesty; by appointt, a second time,—very ill of cold, poor wretch; but getting some vestige of employt in the Newsprs,—and just abt ready for press with 2d & enlarged &c editn of some Book of Extracts from me.Ballantyne was working on a 2d edn., with alterations and additions (1870), of Passages Selected from the Writings of Thomas Carlyle, with a Biographical Memoir (1855). TC had presented the 1st edn. to Lady Harriet Ashburton; the copy (now in NLS) has “The Lady Ashburton, 1855” in TC’s hand, with a “Melchet Court, Romsey” stamp on the half-title page. TC bracketed and scored out “[the parish of Middlebie, about half a mile from]” from the first sentence of the “Introductory” (the sentence otherwise read: “Thomas Carlyle was born on the 4th of December, 1795, in … the village of Ecclefechan, in the pastoral district of Annandale” [1]); he wrote in the margin: “very uncertain, much of this!—T.C.” There were no further marginalia in the copy. His main Errand I found was abt this, and had refce to you. “Did I think you wd look over the Proofsheets for him (after him)?” “Cd not in the least say. Possibly you were extremely busy (unknown to me). He might ask, I thot, witht offence,” as I doubt not he instantly will!— “Secondly, did I think you wd help him with facts for continuatn of my Biography?” No I don’t; nor is it needful,—the continn of my Biogy contains only one fact, and that is known to everybody.”Ballantyne extended his “Introductory”; he included reference to TC’s work on Frederick (with volumes published 1858, 1862, and 1865), then commented: “For the last few years [TC’s] only literary occupation has been the careful editing of a Library Edition of his works” (28). He mentioned TC’s rectorship of Edinburgh University and JWC’s death while TC was away. He briefly detailed TC’s return to London, the journey to Haddington with JWC’s body, and the funeral (see vol. 43); he included the inscription written by TC for the tombstone (see 43:236TC to WDO, 21 June 1866). Ballantyne concluded: “In 1867 an article on the Reform Bill crisis, entitled, ‘Shooting Niagara: and After? ’ appeared in the August number of Macmillan’s Magazine and, although without signature, was at once recognised as the utterance of the author of ‘Chartism, Past and Present,’ ‘Latter-Day Pamphlets,’ and other writings in which Mr. Carlyle has shown his marvellous power of prevision. … / In the present edition of ‘Passages’ from Mr. Carlyle’s works, the original date of each article or book from which a quotation is made has been given. This will enable the reader, who has not yet read many of Mr. Carlyle’s works, but who may have been familiar with many of the noteworthy ideas and observation of so original a thinker, as they filter through the press, to trace such ideas to their source. It may be useful and interesting, also, to social reformers, by reference to such dates, to compare the practical suggestions of Mr. Carlyle on some of the most urgent questions of the day, at various periods during the last forty years” (30–31).— In short, my dear Brr, I engaged to write; and the
purport of all I have to write is: “Do wholly as you yrself like.” To me, nonmeiest [It is not mine];Phrase repeated at turn of page. to me the word is gar Nichts zu bedeuten [nothing at all of importance]; that is pretty much altogr the truth, in my prest mood of mind;—& the things are “printed correctly” elsewhere! Consider a little; and do what you like. “And can’t I advise at all?” No, hardly. Perhaps, if idle, you might try a sheet or two, & then cease if &c?John A. Carlyle replied, 12 Nov.: “I answered a letter of Ballantyne’s, which came along with yours in the morning as you had anticipated, & told him I could not undertake what he asked, adding that his course seemed quite clear: To print as correctly as he could whatever passages he might select, just as they are already printed; & that no Biographical additions seemed necessary. I find occupation enough of another kind, & would rather have nothing to do with his selections.” But even that I don’t say, or know at all!—
docBody.closer: Yrs ever / T. CarlyleAfter his thoughts about JWC’s letters to the Forsters (see TC to JAC, 23 Oct.) and about the Stodarts (see above), TC continued, 11 Nov.: “Except the above bit of employt, nothing but idle triviality has been my histy, day after day, & week after week. Cannot help it, then? It is very dreary and humilatg to me; but there is hitherto no remedy. Several things I cd partly wish to write,—especly two, (on Eloquence … and on the Basis of Morality), things known to me & much unknown to nearly all my contemporaries Things of supreme importance, especially the latter, of all-including supremacy! On whh the head has something to say; but the wary worn-out heart is wanting. Tried something on the subject 3 or 4 days ago; but it went so ill, I am now abt burning it.— / Have burnt it; must if I ever try more, try anew.” He then commented on the ongoing demands of the library edition and hinted that Watts was still trying to improve his portrait of TC: “Proofsheets go on, and bother of Prints, of improved Watts Portrait &c &c; but there is nothing of real interest in all that to me me [TC’s repetition]. Plenty of proofs of the world’s respect &c &c; whh of course is better than the opposite while I remain here, but is singularly grown a matter of indiffce too” (TC’s journal; privately owned).

postscript.p: My love to Jean; say I expect a Letter shortly; all being wellJohn replied: “On Jean’s arm, above the part which was burnt & is now quite healed, there is a little boil, but it too will soon disappear. She will write I daresay on Sunday.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 16 Nov. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: On sunday morng the “Grouse” (with their tail of Partridges & Hare) came flying in;—and brot this message at least, “Did you ever see such a Lady Bountiful in the world before!” Yesty one of the Grouse got eaten; an excellt Dinner for Two. Please, dont send any more, till farther notice!See TC to LLA, 1 Oct. Lady Ashburton had already sent TC venison; see TC to MAI, 19 Oct.

As to Saty,—alas, alas, I must not dream of it; und[er]TC omitted “er.” penalties! Two nights ago, by trifling accidts, and mismanagets still more trifling, Sleep took pettishly his flight; and I had agn a six hours, and a 24 following them! My path (towards common Sleep) is like that of the Moslem Soul towards Paradise,—on the Edge of a Sword.According to George Sale’s translation of the Koran (1734), used by TC when he wrote about Mahomet (Muhammed) (see Carlyle, On Heroes 257), the way to paradise is across the bridge laid over the midst of hell, which is “finer than a hair and sharper than the edge of a sword” (Koran 91). Can’t help it; ought to be silent, and have patience—for a little My homage to Lady Marian:Lady Marianne Alford; see TC to MAI, 19 Oct. —I don’t think the Ecumenic CouncilThe 20th Ecumenical Council of the Catholic Church, also known as the First Vatican Council, was to begin in Rome, 8 Dec. Lady Alford often spent winters in Rome. will be edifying to hear. Pity there were no Guy FauxGuy Fawkes (ca. 1570–1606; ODNB), member of a Catholic conspiracy plotting to blow up James VI and I (1566–1625; ODNB), king of Scotland, England and Ireland, and his parliament; the conspirators were unsuccessful. at least for that! But perhaps he is on the road, too,—he or an equivalent. The Heavens are long-suffering; but they were never known not to be sternly just withal.
My blessings to yr bright Little Mary; who I hope does not forget me. Do, do to yr bright Self.— Yrs ever truly

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 16 Nov. MS: NLS 518.45 inc. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
Yr Letter was very welcome and agreable to me;—seldom indeed that I get the like, among my ever-increasing and ever more beggarly “Correspondence” with my prest fellow creatures! If my hand were what it
was, I shd have enough to say in ansr; but you see what it is grown to; and I must touch only on the essential.

Thank for yr punctual care in regard to Shirts, clothes, and whatr you have in charge for me.TC later recorded in his checkbook: “8 decr 1869 / To Sister Jean (Tailor, shirts, pipes &c) / £3 .. 3 .. 6½” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). The Shirts are perfect, do the poor black studs Mary has got for me; the sight of whh makes me soft and sad, poor wae mortal that I am. I mean to have 5 other new shirts of the same; don’t be rigorous in refitting these old ones (the remaindr of whh shall be sent soon),—any questionable one of them, reject at once & send to the Gill.Presumably for James Austin.— I don’t feel in need of stockings; but I don’t absolutely reject yr flattering notion abt grey-brown, four-ply and that fine Shetland type; a two or 3 such pairs might be warmer & softer, & welcome on grim Winter day. Consider farther, send the exact particrs, price &c; and we will settle Yes or No.— The grandest thing I always think you cd do for me were a Web of excellt Scotch Plaiding (exactly like the last Drawers you gave me), but of a dark colour,—to make Dressing-gown, breeches, jackets, and all manner of daily Upper Clothes for me.Presumably to be made by John & George Sampson, tailors, of 2 Princes St., Leicester Sq.; see 44:96TC to JAC, 28 Nov. 1866. They had done work for TC earlier in the year, as he sent them checks in Jan. and July. I always think it cd & shd be possible and impossible; cloth being veritable Plaid so far as I can ever see, and merely the dark-grey colour wanted. That black web we made is of the exact colour (and capital enduring cloth too); but as to the “softness” & suppleness,—oh dear, that is not there; & I wish it were! Try, study; I always feel sure you cd do it.— By the bye has the Dr got his Cape (the fac-simile of mine) made yet? Push him on; he will get a great deal of good by it. And don’t forget to line, with some soft silky stuff; the cloth, for its part, is perfect.— This, I think, will suffice for the C[l]othesLetter omitted by TC.—& shirts Chapter.

I am wae to read what you tell me of poor Miss Cunningham.Wilhelmina Cunningham (1793–1875), living at 60 Irish St., Dumfries, with town councillor Alexander Stuart (b. ca. 1817) and Jane Stuart (b. ca. 1820) and family; she had a life annuity of £60 derived from the sale of property in Dumfries; see 36:254TC to JWC, 18 Sept. 1860. She was the sister of Allan Cunningham (1784–1842; ODNB), poet and songwriter, known to the Carlyle family since the 1820s. Forster, merely by the bye, remarked, the other day, “I have never quite forgiven FrankFrank Cunningham was the son of Allan Cunningham and Jean Cunningham, b. Walker (1791–1864), living at 18 Clarendon Rd., Kensington; his sister Mary (ca. 1822–67) and his brother Peter (1816–69; ODNB), a close friend of Forster’s, had also lived there; see 45:36TC to JAC, 21 Sept. 1867, and 39TC to JF, 23 Sept. 1867. for that treatt of his Aunt.”Presumably Frank Cunningham had some control over his aunt’s income, unexplained further. For the trouble with Forster, see TC to JAC, 20 March. Neither have I, nor shall,—tho’ I always
think he is labouring under some darkness abt it, and will repent perhaps when it is too late!Peter Cunningham d. 18 May after a long illness; Frank Cunningham wrote to TC, 20 May, telling him about it. The deaths of his sister (Sept. 1867) and brother may have contributed to TC’s cautious sympathy for Frank. But any way, he is out of the concern; and it falls to others. I wish you to change the Inclosed into £10;TC recorded in his checkbook: “16 Novr 1869 / to Sister Jean (for Miss Cunm) / £10 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). and take it at once to Miss Cm in the quietest manner; not mentioning any name if you can help it (truly that wd please me better, and save idle talk):—I have bn thinking farthr that Forster, John and I shd privately engage with one another that this worthy and interestg old Sister shd from us annually have £20; £10 every half-year;—& I mean to speak to Forstr the very next time we meet (3 or 4 days hence) to this effect,—mentn it you to Brr John; from whom indeed I expect no reluctance, whether Fr agree or don’t. To Miss Cunningham, of course, you say nothing express upon this point; only that she in genl be of sure hope, good old soul!—

I had a bad night agn (rather considerably, tho’ by the slightest mischances, and thrice do mismanagts); that was 2 nights ago; and I am still shaky, tho’ I hope coming round.— I am very sorry you are not to get a “Hand” at prest; Lady Ashbn carried them both away;For Woolner’s casts of TC’s hands, see TC to LLA, 1 Oct., and TC to MAI, 19 Oct. I hope you don’t much care;—there was no “casting mould” taken; the mere 2 hands cost 25 shgs, whh seemed to me dear for such a toy.— By mistake yesty, Mary enclosed this Erskine Letter to Tait, insteadMS ends here.

div3.sourceNote: TC-RWE, 18 Nov. MS: RWEMA; in Mary Aitken’s hand, with insertions by TC. TC’s draft of the first two-thirds, MS: NLS 518.50 inc. Pbd: Norton, CE 2:341–44; Slater, CEC 554–56.
div3.head: TC TO RALPH WALDO EMERSON

docBody.p:
It is near 3 years since I last wrote to you; from Mentone,TC’s last letter to Emerson was 27 Jan. 1867; see 44:140–43TC to RWE, 27 Jan. 1867. under the Ligurian Olive and Orange trees, and their sombre foreign Shadows, and still more sombre suggestings and promptings; the saddest, probably, of all living men. That you made no answer I know right well means only, “Alas, what can I say to him of Consolatory that he does not himself know!” Far from a fault, or perhaps even a mistake on your part;—nor have I felt it otherwise. Sure enough, among the lights that have gone out for me, and are still going, one
after one, under the inexorable Decree, in this now dusky and lonely world, I count with frequent regret that our Correspondence (not by absolute hest of Fate) should have fallen extinct, or into such abeyance: but I interpret it as you see; and my love and brotherhood to you remain alive, and will while I myself do. Enough of this. By lucky chance, as you perceive, you are againTC inserted “again” into the final MS; it was not in his draft. to get one written Letter from me, and I a reply from you, before the final Silence come! The case is this.

For many years back, a thought, which I used to check again as fond and silly, has been occasionally present to me, Of testifying my gratitude to New England (New England, acting mainly through one of her Sons called Waldo Emerson) by bequeathing to it my poor Falstaff Regiment, latterly two Falstaff Regiments, of Books, those I purchased and used in writing Cromwell, and do those on Friedrich the Great. “This could be done,” I often said to myself, “this could perhaps; and this would be a real satisfaction to me! But who then would march through Coventry with such a set!”See Henry IV, Part I 4.2; Falstaff was supposed to be gathering a regiment of good fighting men; he had allowed them all to buy their way out and was left with only the dregs (the old, the young, the infirm, the criminals) and was too ashamed to ride with them through Coventry to meet the rest of the army. TC used the same reference in a letter to Emerson in 1842; see 15:57TC to RWE, 29 Aug. 1842. The extreme insignificance of the Gift, this and nothing else, always gave me pause.

Last Summer, I was lucky enough to meet with your friend C. E. Norton,Charles Eliot Norton; see TC to JTY, 20 March, and TC to JF, 26 May. and renew many old Massachusets recollections, in free talk with [so]Mary Aitken omitted “so” but it was present on TC’s draft. congenial, gracefully social, intelligent and cheerful a man; to him I spoke of the affair; candidly describing it, especially the above questionable feature of it, so far as I could; and his answer, then and more deliberately afterwards, was so hopeful, hearty and decisive, that—in effect it has decided me; and I am, this day writing to him That such is the poor fact, and that I need farther instructions on it so soon as you two have taken counsel together.

To say more about the infinitesimally small value of the Books would be superfluous: nay, in truth, many or most of them are not without intrinsic value, one or two are even excellent as Books: and all of them, it may perhaps be said, have a kind of symbolic or biographic value; and testify (a thing not useless) on what slender commissariat Stores considerable Campaigns, 12 years long or so, may be carried on in this world. Perhaps you already knew of me, what the Cromwell and Friedrich Collection might itself intimate, thatTC’s draft ends here. It is substantially the same as the copy with TC’s customary abbreviations. much buying of Books was never a habit of mine,—far the reverse, even to this day!

Well, my Friend, you will have a meeting with Norton so soon as handy; and let me know what is next to be done. And that, in your Official capacity,Emerson served as a member of the Board of Overseers of Harvard Coll. 1867–79; see 45:183TC to JHS, 12 Oct. 1868. is all I have to say to you at present.

Unofficially there were much,—much that is mournful, but perhaps also something that is good and blessed, and though the saddest, also the highest, the lovingest and best; as beseems Time’s Sunset, now coming nigh. At present I will say only that, in bodily health, I am not to be called ill, for a man who will be 74 next month; nor, on the spiritual side, has anything been laid upon me that is quite beyond my strength. More miserable I have often been; though as solitary, soft of heart, and sad, of course never.

Publisher Chapman, when I question him Whether you for certain get your Monthly volume of what they call “The Library Edition,” assures and again assures me that “it is beyond doubt”:—I confess I should still like to be better assured. If all is right, you should, by the time this Letter arrives, be receiving or have received your 13thMary wrote “10th” and TC corrected it to “13th.” Volume, last of the Miscellanies.TC inserted this last phrase and added his signature and the final address line.
docBody.closer: Adieu, My Friend / Ever truly yours / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-CEN, 18 Nov. MS: NLS 518.47 inc; TC’s draft in blue pencil. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:191.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES ELIOT NORTON

docBody.p: Yr kind and obliging Note came duly to hand, on yr leaving London;See TC to JF, 26 May; Norton had been traveling in Europe since the end of May. and produced in me a dim but fixed impressn, that I ought to comply with yr advice; and wd fulfil in effect my poor bit of pious intenn in regard to Harvard Univty & the Books that had served me in the Histories of English Oliver and Prussn Frh. After long sick languorous delays, & impedimts, I now announce to you that such is the final resolutn come upon; and that I once more need some help & guidance from you in respect of the same.

n.l.New line; TC’s instruction to Mary Aitken when copying. For unhappily yr Letter has fallen aside (laid up not wisely but too well),Cf. Othello 5.2. and cannot now be found: all I distinctly recollect is that I shd write to Emerson on the matter,—who, I think, is an Officl Guardian of the University,See TC to RWE, 18 Nov.
besides his other relatns to me. By todays post I write to Emerson; you & he, I doubt not, will kindly consult together, and with little delay be able to send what farther instructn is needed in this small affair.

The intended Books, of which I have bn endeavouring to get a List taken (not yet very exact) seem to be in number abt 300; of all sizes from big folio in 10 voll., to tiny 12mo in 1; in baddish binding a good many of them; not of signal value as Books almost any, in fact a most insignft Bequest, not worthy Harvard’s acceptance, unless as a proof of my grateful loving & hopeful feelings to New Engld & it, of my true, essentially kind & deep regard to the gt New-Engld Natn and America at large, where I believe myself to have long had many friends, & certnly have always felt to be a friend.

The only other precept from me is Absolute Silence on the matter; that no hint or whisper of it get into the Newsprs, to raise importunate impertt and empty rumourings & noises, till once I be out of hearing of them.
docBody.closer: With many regards, dear Sir, Yrs sincerely

div3.sourceNote: MA [MAI]-CAW, 19 Nov. Addr: 1 Chapel St. West, / Mayfair / W. PM: London, 19 Nov. 1869. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. Charles Augustus Ward (1828–1914), vintner, author, antiquarian, and book collector (see 29:123–24TC to CAW, 6 July 1854). He often wrote under the pseudonym Feltham Burghley; see 36:262–64TC to CAW, 24 Sept. 1860.
div3.head: MARY AITKEN TO CHARLES AUGUSTUS WARD

docBody.p: Mr Carlyle, my Uncle, bids me say he yesterday received your beautiful box of plums.Ward sent regular gifts of fruit, particularly plums, to the Carlyles each autumn; see 45:19TC to CAW, [20] Aug. 1867. He is much obliged to you for yr continued regard which it symbolizes to him; & wd himself have written to thank you for your kindness; but his hand shakes so much that writing is very disagreeable & sometimes impossible for him.
Mr Carlyle says he wd like if you sent him a copy of the BelgraviaBelgravia, a monthly literary magazine; Ward’s article unidentified further. that is to contain your article.

closer.note: TC wrote in his journal, 20 Nov.: “Two unpleast little things this week: first (and entirely witht moment), the expert swindler, introduced by the little servant (Mrs Wn. being absent) as a Gentn I knew;—who, with considerable dramatic and other art, taking advantage of my surprise, of my pity for ‘24 Chelsea Families getting shipped for Melbourne’ &c &c, and of my impatce to have done with him, dexterously wiled a sovn from me for ‘children’s clothing’ to said poor Emigrants! He was not gone two minutes till I found he was likeliest a ‘Ticket-of-leave man’ … and that I had … sent my sovereign on a bad road. A handsome enough yg fellow, 35 or so; with a look of intelligence, but also of pain, misery, and sadly-varnished devilry, whh I might easily have read had I been attentive at all [the “little servant,” possibly Charlotte, otherwise unidentified; the “ticket-of-leave man,” not further identified]. … My secd unpleasantness was due to good Mrs Warren’s bad temper yesty [i.e., 19 Nov.]; whom I had to rebuke, with grave distinctness, for poor little Mary’s sake;—whh ended in Mrs W.’s (indistinctly) giving in ‘warning.’ This, I may hope, and pretty much do so, will come to nothing (being totally unreasonable on her part); but whatr it comes to, I must be prepared to meet it and deal with it; and indeed partly am.— Oh, my lost Dear One how sad agn, sad and loyal is the thot of Thee in this care; my continl Protectress agt all such!— / Have been sleeping badly agn, twice-over badly; but last night I slept well; am much refreshed thereby;—and will now out into the bright winter sun (2 p.m. ‘Work,’ is now, alas, zero or infinitesimally small: done for today)” (TC’s journal; privately owned). For this and earlier difficulties with Sarah Warren, see TC to JAC, 18 Dec.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 22 Nov. Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N.B. PM: London, 22 Nov. 1869. MS: NLS 526.106. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Not being able to get any light abt that Scotsbrig Friedh, whether or not it ever arrived there, and is or is not in the hands of Jamie Senior (for whom it was not inted, and who has the Big Frh already)— I decide to bid Orr, the first time I get to Chapns (probably tomorrow), to send you, by his first Edinr Parcel, a Copy for yrself:See TC to JAC, 3 Nov. John A. Carlyle replied, 23 Nov.: “Jamie … is still at Birmingham, & I waited for his return before writing about the copy of Frederick. There was no name on the one copy sent here, & as John had taken possession of it gladly, his father already having a copy of the large edition, you have settled it in the best way, by ordering a copy for me too. Young James took his with him last wednesday & was very glad to find it waiting for him here.” He then wrote, 28 Nov.: “The Frederick in 7 vols, & 6th vol. of Essays came safely last week from Chapman’s; & I have written for the 5th vol. which will probably soon come too.” the potentl Scotsbrig Copy, if superfluous there, can be put to some other good use;—and so, at any rate, we have done with that small matter.

You did wisely in regard to Ballantyne;For Ballantyne’s request, see TC to JAC, 12 [11] Nov. of whom I have not since heard the least whisper.— Erskine has written to Tait; all the “payt” possible;—so there is another small matter finished.For the negative for Erskine, see TC to JAC, 12 [11] Nov. I sent some lumber of Pamphts last week; one or two of whh I fancied you might glance at for a moment.John replied: “I got your bundle of pamphlets last week, & thought they been acknowledged. Several of them were amusing.”

Jean perhaps spoke to you abt Miss Cunningham, and a little project I had,
including yrself and Forster as well as me.For TC’s suggestion about Wilhelmina Cunningham, see TC to JCA, 16 Nov. John replied, 23 Nov.: “I gladly consent to the arrangement you propose in regard to poor Miss Cunningham. … I have asked Jean whether it might be well to give her another £10 for this half, as she may have been expecting such allowance for more than one half year past; but Jean thinks it is better not to do so, as Miss C. might give it away to relations we know nothing of. The three of us might engage to give her the £20 a year, so long as anyone of us lived to give it? ” I did not see Fr till yesterday; but he at once flamed up into exuberant assent; eagerly willing to send his £10 at once, instead of 12 months hence, as is the more likely date! The questn now alone remains, Will you be one of the three? A man is to be asked in such a case, even tho’ one presupposes his Ansr! If it be what I guess, you have only to tell Jean,—and all is done there too. Yr £10, midsumr next, will be the first needed; then Forster’s, Xmas; then mine, midsumr following (if I be here then); and so, in ellyptic orbit of 18 months we make our revolutn. Tell Jean, to whom I inclose a word.— —

“The Academy No 2,”The Academy. A Monthly Record of Literature, Learning, Science and Art. The second issue was pbd. 13 Nov. John replied: “I get the ‘Academy’ here. You might send your stamped copy to Craigenputtock or Scotsbrig.” whh came this morng is a more solid-looking than I expected. I hope it may be able to subsist; but it seems a little too German in its form of Solidity! The Editr,Charles Edward Cutts Birchall Appleton (1841–79; ODNB), Oxford Univ. philosophy lecturer with a particular interest in German philosophy; founder and editor of The Academy. an Oxonian unknown, joyfully invites me to write (on some Ranke dud of a thing)Leopold von Ranke (1795–1886), German historian; see TC to CA, 23 Nov. for him, and seems to have no doubt I will;—I vow that I will not by any means!— n.l.New line, followed by “I wish” indicating new paragraph on next page.
I wish“Wish” repeated on new page, headed “(2).” I cd write more easily! But this is dismal work; and I must end it.

I have been sleeping rather badly for above a week; never quite intolerably (thank Heaven); & still keep hoping I may gradually get into a human track agn. Our weather is generally good; tho’ fickle as possible: Saty & yesty clear frost, today (since 1 a.m.) s.w. rain & tepid calm. Mary & I are due at Forstr’s to meet Froude with DaughterFroude and probably his eldest da., Georgina Margaret. Forster wrote, 19 Nov.: “I am counting on you for Monday—when Froude comes expecting you—you and your good little niece. And I pray (humbly and contritely) for no disappointment.” & no more. I hope it won’t hurt; easily enough it might be an improvet on last night!—
Not a word more, dear Brother,

div3.sourceNote: TC-CA, 23 Nov. MS: Strouse. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with signature and final address line added by TC. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES APPLETON

docBody.p: Your “No. 2 of The Academy,”See TC to JAC, 22 Nov. and Ranke’s PamphletLeopold von Ranke, Briefwechsel Friedrich des Grossen mit dem Prinzen Wilhelm IV. von Oranien und mit dessen Gemahlin Anna, geb. Princess Royal von England (Berlin, 1869). have duly arrived here. In the former I am well pleased to notice some real symptoms of your contemplated Improvement in British Reviewing; certainly an Improvement much wanted in all departments of that Art! The Ranke Briefwechel I propose to myself to look through, this evening and the next two or three;—but ought to say at once that there is not the smallest likelihood of my writing anything upon either Ranke or it. Indeed, except in very peculiar cases, I have latterly, for reasons too valid to me, as good as given up writing altogether.

A week from this date, if you please to allow me so long, the Ranke shall lie ready for any messenger of yours; or be put under way again, if you will order whitherward. The other two BooksUnidentified further. I do not wish to see. Believe me
Yours with hearty wishes for your Enterprise,

div3.sourceNote: TC-Sir CAM [CAM], 23 Nov. MS: EUL, in Mary Aitken’s hand, with salutation, signature, and final address line added by TC. Pbd: Herbert Eustace Maxwell, The Hon. Sir Charles Augustus Murray: a Memoir (1898) 76–77. Sir Charles Augustus Murray (1806–95; ODNB), diplomat and author.
div3.head: TC TO SIR CHARLES A. MURRAY

docBody.p:
Your agreable Letter from LisbonMurray was with the British Legation at Lisbon, 1867–74. found me yesternight; and I am happy to be able to throw some little light on your Inquiry.Murray later remembered: “In 1869, nearly forty years after my visit to Goethe, never having met with the above quatrain among his published works, I sent the stanza with a note to Carlyle, asking him whether it was to be found among Goethe’s printed works” (Murray: A Memoir 76). n.l.TC’s insert; i.e., new line. The Goethe
Quatrain, given you in those interesting circumstances, and afterwards lost, has hung here, in “facsimile of Autograph,” attached to a Lithograph Portrait of Goethe,For the portrait, see above. for about 43 years, now and always regarded as one of the Penates of the House. Where this Lithograph Portrait was got I cannot now recollect; but I think it must have been from Hamburg in 1826,The engraving had apparently been sent to TC by John A. Carlyle when he was in Munich, 1827–28; see 4:404TC to G, 25 Sept. 1828. It remains in Carlyle’s House; see Carlyle’s House 104. —as the readiest attainable Portrait of Goethe;—and in German Printshops, most probably it is still on sale as such. It does tolerably resemble, though quite without flattery: an earnest patient heavy-laden old Man, cheeks hollow, upper front-teeth gone &c. “Bendixen” and “Vogel,” names unknown to me, are Painter and Engraver;The lithograph portrait of Goethe, after the painting by Carl Christian Vogel (1788–1868), was engraved by Siegfried Detlev Bendixen (1786–1864). length of the Print, epigraph and all, is about 14 inches (epigraph itself about 3 inches). It was from this Portrait that I took your Quatrain, translated it, printed it somewhere,TC used the lines as an introduction to “Signs of the Times” (1829); see Carlyle, Works 27:56. —not as the barbarous timber-headed Editor gives it, but accurately thus:

lg.l: “Know’st thou Yesterday its aim and reason,
“Work’st thou well Today for worthy things;
“Need’st not fear what hap soe’er it brings.”

docBody.p: The original and your remembrance of it, differ only in one monosyllable, frey instead of treu,—important only for the rhyme;—and the Hand is evidently Goethe’s, in good strong Roman Letters,—facsimile completely correct. Date “Weimar. 7. Nov. 1825.”

figure.p:
Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, portrait by Carl Christian Vogel,
engraving by Siegfried D. Bendixen
Courtesy of the National Trust

docBody.p: Not having the Index to my Goethe’s Werke (the final Cotta one),J. F. Cotta (1764–1832), publisher of Goethe’s Werke, 54 vols. (Stuttgart, 1828–33). I cannot at once ascertain whether these lines are in Goethe’s Printed Works or not; tho’ I rather think they are.The lines are from Goethe’s Zahme Xenien (1827); see Goethe’s Werke 4:337; see also TC to JAC, 18 Dec. If you wish it ascertained, I will with pleasure have that done. If you return to London while I continue here, pray call and see the Picture and me.
Glad of this pleasant unexpected passage between us; and begging always a place in your remembrance, I remain,

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 29 Nov. Addr: Palace-Gate House. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Chapman came punctually; reported fair progress in the Friedrich Prints (CundallJoseph Cundall (1818–95; ODNB), publisher and photographer; previously partner in several photographic firms, including Cundall, Downes & Co. (1859–65); his present firm was Cundall & Fleming (1865–71), photographers, 168 New Bond St. For a photograph of Cundall taken early to mid-1860s by an unknown photographer, see 120. doing them),—mainly those you have copies of, as yet:—all right on that side.

figure.p:
Joseph Cundall, carte de visite, early to mid-1860s
©National Portrait Gallery, London

docBody.p: In regard to Cromwell, I also undertook to see what cd be done; and indeed have being busying and bothering on that point (searching yr GraingerJames Granger, A Biographical History of England from Egbert the Great to the Revolution, 3d edn., 4 vols. (1779); Forster also owned a copy of the 1st edn., 2 vols. (1769), and the 5th edn., 6 vols. (1824); all three were bequeathed to the South Kensington Museum (now the V & A) by Forster as part of FC. James Granger (1723–76; ODNB), print collector and biographer. &c &c) ever since. For Vol I of Crll I hope I can do something (to make it correspond“[S]pond” repeated with a line over it at turn of page. at least with Volume Last or 5th),—also perhaps for the intermedte Voll.; but am beset, in regard to these latter, with doubts & consideratns. The Crll’s Father,Cromwell’s father, Robert Cromwell (d. 1617); no pictures of him were used in the library edn. for instance, I find to be incredible, inadmissible; the MotherCromwell’s mother, Elizabeth, b. Stewart (ca. 1565–1654); TC included a portrait of her as frontispiece in the library edn., Cromwell 3, labeling it “Reputed Portrait of Oliver Cromwell’s Mother / (certainly) Facsimile from a Miniature by A. Hertocks”; A. Hertocks (fl. 1626–72), Anglo-Dutch artist. A different portrait of Cromwell’s mother was used in Cromwell 2, Carlyle, Works 7:frontispiece.almost do, &c &c; and am still studying & sifting. No bad, especially no doubtful Print shd in any case be admitted.— Till some beging of work can be definitely pointed out, I purposely abstain from seeing Chapn;—and it is with a view of now ‘seeing’ him, & pushing him afloat so far that I now write to you the two following requests or questns:

1° Will you permit Chapn’s Regent Street PhotogrPossibly the London Stereoscopic Company, 108–110 Regent St. to try his hand on Watt’s Portrait of Me, straightway? This, of course, has nothing to do with Crl; but is for the purpose of annihilating & superseding that frightful Engraving (Frontispe to Vol I of Essays),Forster replied, 30 Nov.: “As to the Watts picture by all means too let the photographer be instructed. / He can take it, I suppose, where it now is—at any rate without removing it from the house / If however this is not feasible—I will ask that he delay proceeding till my return Saturday next—as I should like to be present when the picture is removed. / I say this, assuming that the delay will not be material—but if the interval between this & Saturday is important, I give you carte blanche to act as you think best.” Whether the portrait was photographed at this time is not known. An engraving of Watts’s portrait, by William Holl the younger, had been used as the frontispiece to vol. 1 of Critical and Miscellaneous Essays; see TC to JAC, 6 March, and 19. —a step on whh Cn & I have long been determined, if a method turned up.

2°
In one of yr Grainger Voll now here, I find a rare & very curious Print of Essex on Horseback, with a Map under his hoof, & date there of all his glorious “Victories,” up to its own date, “9 Octr, 1643”Robert Devereux (1591–1646; ODNB), 3d earl of Essex; the etching is by Czech artist Wenceslaus Hollar (1607–77; ODNB). The print is in Forster’s 1779 edn. of Granger, vol. 2, part 3, on the reverse of f. 29; the date, “9th October 1643,” was written on the print under the engraved inscription; TC then added “[In the London Printshops, Two days before Winceby Fight! (T.C. 1869)].” A photograph of the print with TC’s notation on it was used in the library edn. of Cromwell opp. 1:182. (2 days before Oliver’s Winceby real victory):The Battle of Winceby, Lincolnshire, 11 Oct. 1643, where Royalists were routed by Cromwell’s army; see Carlyle, Works 6:174–77. a really queer old Print;—whh wd make a fine counterpart to the Installatn one in vol. V!“Faithorne’s muted Emblematic Print, on the Protector’s second Installation (26 June, 1657) / Miniature facsimile from a proof copy extremely rare” became the frontispiece to the library edn. of Cromwell 5. William Faithorne (1616–91; ODNB), engraver. Now there is no doubt you wd at once consent to our Photogrg this (or any one in Grainger),—and I might proceed at once, were it not for one chance circe in regard to this, viz: It seems to be a rare & high-selling Print; and, owing to a fatal lurch or wrinkle in the Paper it is pasted to, it cannot be photogrd witht cutting out, steeping, pressing &c,—possibly (for I don’t know, tho’ the Photr will) a process of risk; oh whh I want yr permission first. If you write to me a simple Yes in regard to this,Forster replied, 30 Nov.: “Your letter has just reached me—and I write the most hurried answer that a post may not be lost. / As to the Grainger and its contents, act exactly as if all were your own—as indeed they are, and it is my pride that they should be, for every purpose.” The print must have been very carefully removed and then replaced, as there is no evidence on the copy of that process. and to Chapn a do in regard to the Watts, you may bid Chn expect me that day his Letter arrives. Enough, eng; oh what writing, slow & crabbed, like engraving on lead!—

Mentn in yr Letter what has become of the Cough;Forster wrote, 1 Dec.: “my enemy has been with me, unrelentingly, all the time of my journeyings.” all is tolerable here; sleep not intolerably bad, tho’ baddish now & then. Ever Yrs, dearF.—T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 2 Dec. MS: NLS 526.107. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I called yesty at Chapman’s; found Orr,See TC to JAC, 3 Nov. who had already despatched by Post yr volume,Critical and Miscellaneous Essays vol. 5; see TC to JAC, 22 Nov. John A. Carlyle wrote, 3 Dec.: “The wanting volume of your Miscellanies came punctually on Monday, with a note from Mr Orr, stating that a copy of it had been sent before. I did not make any reply to his note; for the volumes (11 in all) are put into the same shelf whenever they arrive.” —and was clear & positive that he had sent another Copy at its due day, by the same conveyance! “Something wrong in the Dumfries Post-Office,” thot Orr; whh I assured him was impossible. The volume, howr, and its shilling stamp have disappeared. I directed Orr, in all future cases (of weight), to send by Menzies of Edinr,John Menzies, wholesaler and distributor; see TC to JAC, 3 Nov. carefully marking “by Caledonian Railway”; whh he undertook.— Along with the next vol (Past & Prest, with a Photogh) whh shd come abt the middle of this month,The photograph used for the frontispiece of Past and Present (library edn. [1870], vol. 13) was Robert Scott Tait’s full face photograph of TC, taken 31 July 1854, see above. The vol. came out during Dec. A reverse detail of Tait’s photograph of TC in profile, also taken 31 July 1854, was used as the frontispiece to On Heroes (see TC to LLA, 17 Dec., and 128) and then to the centenary edn. of Past and Present; see Carlyle, Works 10:frontispiece. you will get a small Parcel addressed, “Mrs Ewart, Nithbank Thornhill,”Alicia Ewart, b. Yorstoun (d. 1882; see 40:193–94JWC to TC, [19 Aug. 1864]), friend of JWC’s; TC visited her Aug. 1868; see 45:165TC to WTHO, . whh I will beg you to frank (4d. ? tell me) and despatch at once. It contains only an odd copy of Sartor for good Mrs Ewt,—ah me!—and the Copy of Beale’s “Protoplasm”Lionel S. Beale, Protoplasm; or Life, Force, and Matter (1870). Lionel Beale (1828–1906; ODNB), prof. of physiology at King’s College, 1853–69, recently appointed as physician to King’s College Hospital. In Protoplasm, he advanced a vitalist religious argument against the materialistic doctrine (which had appalled TC) advanced by Thomas Huxley in his lecture “On the Physical Basis of Life”; see TC to JAC, 20 Feb., and TC to JTY, 20 March. Beale wrote: “[In] Huxley, no distinction is drawn between that which is living, growing, and forming; and that which has been formed and is destitute of all powers of life and growth. No distinction between living matter and lifeless matter! Both are confused together under the term ‘protoplasm’” (Protoplasm 18). for Dr Russell.Dr. James Russell.

figure.p:
Thomas Carlyle, photograph by Robert S. Tait, 31 July 1854
Thomas Carlyle Papers, 1865–1896, Rare Book & Manuscript Library,
Columbia University in the City of New York

docBody.p:
We are doing not amiss here; sleep not so bad as you saw it, nay sometimes promising to get genlly tolerable and better, but always relapsing. Ruskin’s last visit (this night gone a week, who arrived 40 min. before time, just while I was lying down to siesta), cost me 2 nights or 1½, but I have appointed him for daylight in future,—“Saty 3 p.m. &c walk 2 hours togr” is the next turn.Ruskin wrote, ca. 30 Nov.: “I will if I may [come] on Saturday. I saw how wrong it was that you were disturbed that evening. You will think I never notice anything you say. … [L]ast Thursday I had indeed noticed, but mistaken.”
He is among my tolerable sorts of compy; but no compy does me almost any good, or is preferable to that of my own sad quiet thots. Very sad, but also peaceable, loving, & resigned or even hoping.

I was agn agt my will set into quest of Prints; for Cromwell this time, Frh being, for my part of it, abt done. It involves much fash, but it may have a little use in future time; and I am otherwise totally useless for work, so may as well take this.—— (And here, accidtly has Chapman been, & has taken his orders, & is off with one of Forsters Grainger voll.See TC to JF, 29 Nov. &c &c,—it has completely swallowed all my time!)— Yesty I sent, in Mary’s Wrapping, a lot of Prints (waste mainly) whh I thot Jean might like.John A. Carlyle wrote, 3 Dec.: “Jean received her photographs yesterday, & is very much pleased with them.” Her HareskinJohn A. Carlyle wrote, 28 Nov.: “By this day’s post I send you the usual annual Hareskin from Jean. … It looks as if it might be very useful for the winter.” Jean had first sent him a hareskin breastplate to wear against the cold in 1858; see 36:24TC to JCA, 10 [11] Dec. 1859, and had apparently sent him several since; see 43:46TC to JAC, 23 Nov. 1865. is on (massive and soft, thanks, thanks), sudden frost having come.— Affecte ever / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 10 Dec. MS: NLS 526.108. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
The week is drawing to an end; and I ought to write you some notice, were it even of the Nothings that my history consists of here. I am not suffering from want of sleep, but I am from a disordered interior (liver &c, I suppose) and an exterior sadly the worse for the wear! Sleep is precious and priceless; but its effect hitherto is much to stupefy and hebetate and overload me; add to whh the dark clammy skies, and genl element of dirt (whh, howr, does not crack one’s hands,TC often suffered from cracked skin on his hands in cold weather; see 28:39TC to MAC, 13 Feb. 1853, and 45:79TC to MCA, 1 Jan. 1868. as frost does): I seldom felt more idle solitary and degraded;—indeed I have as it were become totally idle, and for the first time these many years fairly sink to “reading in the forenoon!” I say to myself, “Well, thou canst not work any more!” whh is a doleful kind of reflexn, even if it cd be accepted as a quite literal fact!— I take long walks still daily; talk drearily when I must, muse drearily otherwise, whh is the oftenest case: Froude comes twice or almost thrice a week, and at least makes my walk less a labour to me. For weeks past I have quite given up the midnight walk (as
you will be glad to hear);John A. Carlyle previously suggested that TC should forego walking late at night (see 44:213TC to JRU, 13 June 1867), and replied, 12 Dec.: “That you have given up those late walks, which are not suitable now as they used to be when you were younger & stronger & had much hard work to do, is an especially welcome piece of news for me.” for 3 days, in the late frost, I gave up my cold bath, but did not like that omissn, and was glad to resume. Robson hangs fire not a little in printg: Chapn do in the picture departt; but I study to “keep never minding.”Coterie speech; see 43:44TC to JAC, 22 Nov. 1865. In effect, what can one do else?

Abt a fortnight ago, I despatched to America, to Norton and to Emerson, announcing tht that Bequest of BooksTC repeated “that” at start of new line; for the bequest, see TC to JF, 26 May, TC to RWE, 18 Nov., and TC to CEN, 18 Nov. was really to take effect: some response (whh you shall hear of & see) may be expected soon. Mary has tried three successive “Catalogues” since she returned (mainly copied and completed from yrs); today she has done the third, whh I decide shall be accounted “correct enough,” and go to Emerson when he wishes.The 1888 HCC catalog noted a “Scrap-book”; its contents included TC’s catalog with his note on it: “Catalogue, Harvard, for R. W. EMERSON when his ansr comes.— 3d or 4th editn; not yet quite correct, nor capable of being made so in prest circs! (T.C. 16 decr 1869)” (William Coolidge Lane, The Carlyle Collection [Cambridge, Mass., 1888] 22). My Bother abt Prints (for Cromwell at prest), spoken of above, has been considerable; nor has yet come to much of certn fruit. Agn never mind; “keep never -minding!”

I shd like to know conclusively how Jean is; bid her write if it won’t [hurt] her; otherwise tell me pointedly yrself,—how that rib isTC omitted “hurt”; “is” repeated with a line over it at turn of page. &c &c. I got her nice warm stockings (very welcome, were they even warmer! I wish I knew what she thinks now of a run to London, & when?John A. Carlyle wrote, 28 Nov.: “Jean still has pain in the upper part of her chest, especially when she has anything heavy to lift. The pain is in the ribs & their cartilages. It is a mercy that both breasts entirely escaped, as otherwise cancer might have been the consequence of her fall.” Jean wrote, 12 Dec.: “You kindly enquire about that hurt on my breast bone. It was very troublesome for some time, owing to my having too much to do; it got hurt anew every day & abt ten days since threatened to lay me up altogether. I am glad to say that is all right now—since I have had it in my power to get it taken care of. / You wish to know ‘what I think of a run to London.’ Much as I shd like to see you alas! I fear I must finally decide that I cannot manage to go from home this winter. I feel like a poor stricken deer that has been chased for months. The thing I need is rest & composure at home.” As well as her son Tom’s death in Oct., Jean’s servant had been ill, so she was even busier than usual.

You did quite wisely to refuse Ballantyne’s proposals,See TC to JAC, 12 [11] Nov. —better give him sea-room! He was here yesty; and I am almost sorry for the treatt he met; poor devil, after all!Coterie speech; see 1:211TC to AC, 15 Dec. 1819.— — Wd you like Froude’s Two volumes (just out, and
ending his task)?Froude’s History of England from the Fall of Wolsey to the Defeat of the Spanish Armada, vols. 11 and 12 (1870). John replied, 12 Dec.: “Thanks for your offer of the last volumes of Froude, but I can get them here without any difficulty from the Circulating Library whenever I need them.” They are very good reading, capital in parts: I ended them night before last. Speak the word, and they come to you.

Abt the turning of this page, Lady A’s Letter (after a 3 weeks of utter silence came to me,—like a shot among a Covey! I have had to say, Yes.Lady Ashburton wrote inviting TC to dinner with her and Lady Alford, followed by a performance by Charles Albert Fechter (1824–79; ODNB), actor and playwright, at Royal Princess’s Theatre. TC presumably included Lady Ashburton’s letter with his own to John A. Carlyle, as John replied, 12 Dec.: “I fear the sudden invasion of Lady A. & Lady M. [Lady Marion Alford] with their project for dinner & the theatre might derange you for at least one night.” For the theater visit, 10 Dec., and its after effects, see TC to LLA, 17 Dec.— Good be with you all

postscript.p: Jean’s Letter has just come: so far well, & my thanks to her

div3.sourceNote: TC-JG [JGRA], 11 Dec. MS: Offered for sale by Henry Sotheran Ltd., London, 1983. Hitherto unpbd. James Grant (1802–79; ODNB), newspaper editor and historian; identified as recipient by TC’s note, Froude, LM 3:27.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES GRANT

docBody.p: All is now corrected; by yr kind help in looking at the originals,At the request of Sir George Sinclair’s family, Grant was preparing Memoirs of Sir George Sinclair, Bart., of Ulbster (1870); he wanted to include some letters to Sir George from both TC and JWC, and had sent them to TC, together with the draft printing, for correction and for permission to publish. Sir George Sinclair (1790–1868; ODNB), 2d bart., politician, of Thurso Castle, Caithness; TC visited him there Aug.–Sept. 1860; see vol. 36. and bridling the Printer’sTinsley Bros., 18 Catherine St., Strand, London. impetuosities, I can now hope all will get correctly to Press.

Please offer my kindest remembces to Miss Sinclair,Olivia Sophia Sinclair (1823–94), travel writer, youngest da. of Sir George. For TC’s letter to her on the death of Sir George (9 Oct. 1868), see 45:190TC to OS, [ca. 23 Oct. 1868]. in returning her these 4 poor Notes (inclosed here); a Fifth by Another Hand, and much more precious to me than it can be to anybody else, I will confidtly beg her permissn to retain (as now).For JWC to Sir George Sinclair, [ca. 9] Aug. 1860, see 36:167–68JWC to SGS, [ca. 9] Aug. [1860]. In TC’s introduction to the letter, dated 13 Dec. 1869, he wrote: “To Miss Sinclair’s poor request, I said reluctantly yes—could not say no: corrected the five letters (not without difficulty); returned my own four originals, retained (resolutely) the original of this” (Froude, LM 3:27). The five letters were included in the memoir; see Grant, Memoirs of Sir George Sinclair 422–28.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 17 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Two evengs ago there came, rushing off to us, 2 brace of Pheasants 2 do of Partridges, followed by an eager Hare;—of course there is only one Hand in the world capable of such excesses! Long may you live to shower kindnesses on yr fellow-creatures,—of whom, in that senseWord repeated at turn of page. I may reckon myself the chief, tho’ among the unworthiest.— Send nothing more, I pray you, for abt a month; in fact, till you are just coming yrself!

The gas of Fechter’s TheatreCharles Albert Fechter performed at the Royal Princess’s Theatre, Oxford St., between 29 Nov. and 10 Dec., before departing for New York. The Athenæum reported, 11 Dec.: “Mr. Fechter has repeated at the Princess’s during the week ‘Hamlet’ and ‘Ruy Blas.’ His performance of the latter character is a piece of fine and eminently picturesque acting.” Ruy Blas, tragic drama (1838) by Victor Hugo (1802–85), French poet, novelist, and dramatist. TC, Lady Ashburton, and Lady Alford went to Fechter’s final performance; see TC to JAC, 10 Dec. JWC had seen Fechter playing Hamlet July 1861; see 37:195TC to JCA, 3 Aug. 1861. (whh I observed burning straight beneath us,Theaters were lit by gaslights. ready to be breathed as fast as it cd mount to our level),—that or something must have “poisoned” me, I think; for I have hardly ever since been up to par; struggling with the old enemy,—rather miserable; tho’ not quite, as sometimes formerly. I fear there is not the least chance (except unwisely and with penalties) of a visit to Melchet in the weeks that remain. Such contradictn is very mournful to me; but it is not to be helped. How many things are mournful, and cannot!—

figure.p:
Thomas Carlyle, detail of photograph by Robert S. Tait, 31 July 1854,
frontispiece, On Heroes, Hero--Worship, and the Heroic in History (1870)
© National Portrait Gallery, London

Thomas Carlyle, photograph by Robert S. Tait, 1855
© National Portrait Gallery, London

docBody.p:
The “Portrait” has come out very well, tho’ Tait wd take no charge of it! See in yr Copy of “Heroes”;The frontispiece of On Heroes, Hero-Worship, and the Heroic in History (library edn. [1870], vol. 12) was a reverse detail of TC’s left profile, taken 31 July 1854 by Robert Scott Tait, see 128; for a reproduction of the full-size original photograph, see 27:frontispiece. John A. Carlyle wrote, 26 Dec. (having received his copy of On Heroes, 25 Dec.): “The photograph in H.W. we all think very good, & it will help to neutralise the one from Watts.” whh ought to have arrived or be arriving. Tait has “lost the Negative” of the principal other Portrait we proposed:Lady Ashburton had been assisting in the payment for the production of photographs for the library edn.; see TC to LLA, 1 Oct., and TC to JAC, 27 Oct. The lost negative is unidentified further, but it might have been a negative of the photograph of TC taken by Tait that the National Portrait Gallery dates to 1855 and describes as a “salt print on cream card mount”; see 129. —I decide
therefore that we must stop with this one; and insert no more; whh really wd have been the honrable & preferable plan, indeptly of Tait’s accidt! I beg of you not to gainsay: Fate itself having spoken, in Tait’s loss of that glass article. No, you won’t, but will be a good child!
Send a word of tidings, some day soon; the shortest word is better than none.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 18 Dec. Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N.B. PM: London, 18 Dec. 1869. MS: NLS 526.109. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I am rather in low water all this; bad sleep (tho’ nothing like so bad as once was), low spirits utterly, and various botheratns assaulting me, rather beyond the average, from day to day. Yesterday, e.g. whh was beautifully,Thus in MS. I found my sad little-toe & comradeTC had had problems with his toes before, particularly while in Menton, 1867; see 44:143–45TC to JAC, 9 Feb. 1867. so wretched with the drenching & neglect that had got, the day before (whh was a perfect deluge of warm Italy), that the wretches had quite struck work, and I absolutely cd not walk, except as with red hot nails in my shoe; and had to go to Chapman’s and return by omnibus both times! Poor little Mary fomented it, steeped it in hot water &c in the evg; and this morng all was fallen quiet agn,—and the horrible apprehensn “Not able to walk? What on Earth will become of me!” had withdrawn itself agn.

I was at Chapmns abt Pictures:—hang these “Pictures”;—I get more and more impatt with them, & decided to fling them mostly in the fire!
