The Tait Photh, howr, has come out really well,—as you will see, or do see, in the volume On Heroes;—the other Two Tait Phoths I settled to dismiss; & let the Cromwell Engraving be our next. If Heroes & the poor Thornhill Parcel be not come, the[y]TC omitted “y.” will straightway: Orr assures me they “often send thrice a week, never less than once.”John A. Carlyle had written, 12 Dec.: “The parcel for Mrs Ewart & Dr Russell has not yet come, & may not soon come, for Chapman does not send weekly packages by the Edinr steamers.” You mt write a word to “Menzies Booksr Edinr,” in some case of delay; yr name & Caledon n railway, wd be a flap to himJohn wrote to John Menzies, who replied, 22 Dec.: “We beg to say that we have at present no parcel from Messrs Chapman & Hall London for you— The last one we recd was forwarded for Caledonian Railway immediately on receipt” (MS: NLS 1775D.129). On Heroes for John and the parcel for Thornhill arrived from Edinburgh, 25 Dec., shortly after Menzies’ reply.

We at once found the Goethe Passage;The lines from Goethe’s Zahme Xenien, Werke (Stuttgart, 1828–33) 4:337; see TC to CAM, 23 Nov. John wrote, 12 Dec.: “I had no difficulty in finding [the four lines], & the version of Murray is so very incorrect & ungrammatical that it might be charitable to send him a real copy wh I enclose. … Your edition of Goethe is the same as mine; so you may easily verify if you choose.” sent yr snip of writg with compts, in an other wise empty cover, on to Lisbon & the [word/s illegible] Head there:Murray was head of the British Legation; see TC to CAM, 23 Nov. the circe put Goethe on the table; and I have been reading in him most evgs; the one consolatn I have had. What a height beyond anything we now have,—high as the skies beyond the gilt weathercocks; & no “30,000” climbing thither all in a heap!Goethe mentions the gilt weathercock on a bridge in Frankfurt, near the beginning of his Autobiography (see Carlyle Works 27:408), and TC refers to this in Frederick (see Carlyle Works 13:309). The population of Frankfurt in Goethe’s day was about 30,000. Otherwise unexplained. Well, well.

Jas StephenJames Fitzjames Stephen presumably passed through Egypt on his way to India; see TC to JAC, 27 Oct. Stephen’s letter untraced. sends me that Letter (I see not well why) from the Red-Sea, came the other morning;—it may serve you for a few minutes, so direct from Pharoah’s old country:—send it back please.— Jean’s Letter, you can tell her was carefully read, you can assure her; and I am candidly turng over with my best consideratn what is wisely to be done in sight of such circs & their per contra.Mary Aitken was apparently intending to leave TC and Cheyne Row because of Sarah Warren’s attitude to her. Jean Aitken wrote at length about her experience and opinion of Sarah Warren, 12 Dec.: “I see by Mary’s three last notes [she is] suffering from a cause wch she hardly even so much as hinted to me before but wch I knew by my own experience in the Spring of ’67 must be more or less in constant operation ever since Mary threatened to become permanent in the house. At home we always thought Mary very prudent for not meddling in any way with the servants. She would rather have tried to hide their faults than speak of them. But I noticed a suspicious way Mrs W. had whenever you had occasion to find fault with the hard mutton for instance—or the dirty room she always laid the blame to my account & banged about trying to […] me into proper subjection, by refusing perhaps to let the lassie do an errand for me or sending my lunch up an hour or so later than usual—fragments of something wch she & Charlotte had dined off long before! This I took the liberty of declining to touch or make the least remark upon. We never had words that I recollect of; but I felt if I had staid much longer we would soon have come to the unbearable point. / I can see by the sad but temperate tone of Mary’s letter that she has probably born a good deal before she came to the full determination of leaving for I know she is very fond of you & I believe has done her best to be a comfort to you while she staid: but looking at the thing on all sides I really cannot think her decision wrong or rash; when I think of the cruel unjust way Mrs W. bullied those little lasses I for one shd never wish a child of mine to be at her mercy. Let Mary come home where we have plenty of work for her & Mrs W. when she finds that she has the ground to herself will probably be all right for a time at least. It wd never do to unsettle her further. I would rather have ‘taken a toad by the face’ than had to write all this but I thought it only just to let you see that it was impossible for Mary to go on farther as she is. / I am sorry to bother you my dear kind brother.” For TC’s comments in his journal, 20 Nov., about Mrs. Warren’s bad temper, see MAI to CAW, 19 Nov. Adieu, dear Bro-Brother;“Brother” repeated in full, with a line over both at turn of page. here has Froude come, and I must out. Blessings and love to you all.T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-TK, 18 Dec. Addr: (of The Town Council, &c.) / Haddington / N.B. PM: London, 18 Dec. 1869. MS: NLS 546.47, in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature. Hitherto unpbd. Thomas W. Kemp (1815–91), Haddington; Kemp’s death certificate listed him as “Inspector of Poor.”
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS KEMP

docBody.p: There is something very mournful to me in this request you make;TC noted in his journal, 19 Dec.: “Friday evg last came a Letter from ‘one of the magistrates of Haddington’ (Kemp his name),—asking me to give their new (or new-awakened) ‘Town Library’ a Copy of my Books—on what ground may be imagined. … The Letter was studiously respectful; but to myself it was mournful, painful; and kept me busied all day with sad thots and most pathetic retrospects. As a Bequest from Her (‘the noblest Daughter Haddn ever bore!’ [JWC]) what is this poor Nothing that I shd refuse it to such a Haddn? — I ordered off the Books, at once; wrote the little Note yesterday,—recommending silence. … ‘Mournful,’ yes, yes; but also beautiful and blessed!” (TC’s journal; privately owned). and yet not mournful alone, but beautiful, and almost as if with a touch of sacredness in it:—a request that must not be denied!

I have ordered my Publishers to send you, at once, the Three and Twenty columes of Writings that there are (Collected Works 16 voll. and History of Friedrich 7 voll.; uniform, and in the usablest common shape, short 8 vo., bound in cloth): these you will probably receive in the course of next week;—and I hope Haddington will accept them, not only as a present from me, but rather as a mute bequest from one of the noblest Daughters Haddington ever bore; who loved her Native Place well; who, to me and my struggling life, was a pearl beyond price,Cf. Matthew 13:46. —and whose dust now rests, beside her Father’s, in the Abbey Kirk there.For pictures of JWC’s memorial tablet, her father John Welsh’s tombstone, and the Choir of St. Mary’s Church, Haddington, see 43:236TC to WDO, 21 June 1866, 240TC to JCA, 23 June 1866, and 241TC to JCA, 23 June 1866.

If any delay or mistake occur, please write to “Mr Orr, Messrs Chapman & Hall, 193. Piccadilly, London”: so soon as the Books arrive, and all is settled, be so good as send me a short word. I have no “conditions” to prescribe: Haddington, which held for me a Gift inestimable, accepts, and will piously
use, this small Gift, in silent memory of the fact. I beg only that there be no noise, no needless proclaiming (if any proclaiming be needful) in regard to this our small transaction; and that any mention made of it, in your Records, may be brief and exact.
Believe me, / YrsFrom “Yrs” the writing is in TC’s hand. sincerely / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-CD [CDE], 20 Dec. MS: NLS 518.48, draft of letter, written by Mary Aitken with TC’s additions and corrections in blue pencil. Pbd: Proceedings of the Massachusetts Historical Society 1869–1870 (Boston, 1871): 198–99. Charles Deane (1813–89), antiquary and historian; recording sec. of the Massachusetts Historical Society and member of the American Antiquary Society.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES DEANE

docBody.p: Many thanks for your Serial No of “Proceedings”;A section or sections of Proceedings of the Massachusetts Historical Society 1869–1870. which arrived duly the other night; and which, especially the Paper on Montcalm’s Letter,“Remarks of Mr. Parkman on a Letter from Gen. Montcalm to M. de Molé,” Proceedings of the Massachusetts Historical Society 1869–1870 (Boston, 1871) 112–28. I have read with interest and pleasure. Mr Parkman’s faithful industry is worthy of all recognition, equally so Marquis de Montcalm’s accuracy and candour, and yr Society’s wise decision on that strange Document.Francis Parkman (1823–93), American historian, visited André Dieudonné Victor de Montcalm-Gozon (1825–1901), marquis de Montcalm, in Paris the previous spring, and had examined the correspondence of the marquis’s great-grandfather Louis-Joseph de Montcalm (1712–59), commander of the French army in North America during the Seven Years’ War. Among this correspondence was the letter supposedly written by Montcalm, 24 Aug. 1759, to his cousin Matthieu François Molé (1705–93), in which he predicted that the fall of Canada would result in the revolt of the British Colonies; TC quoted this letter in Frederick; see Carlyle, Works 18:144–46. The marquis de Montcalm had two versions of the letter, in different handwritings; Parkman had them copied, and on his return to Boston he conducted further investigations, which led him and the Committee of the Massachusetts Historical Society to believe that the English version of the letter was probably the original, and the French copies two separate translations, and that therefore the letter was a forgery (Proceedings 125). Parkman wrote to the marquis de Montcalm, 10 Sept., asking him to confirm whether the handwriting in either copy of the letter was Montcalm’s; the marquis replied, 2 Oct., that neither copy was in Montcalm’s handwriting: “They were, I think, sent over from England at the end of the last century, and then translated into French” (Proceedings 127).

Here in Engld, for above a year past,—when a new Edition (7 voll. post octavo)
of that Book on Friedrich was sent forth,—there has been no doubt left but the Almond Pamphlet was a forgery.TC had received two newspaper articles from Boston, April and May 1868, suggesting that the letter was a forgery (see 45:131TC to JCA, 18 May 1868) and, on investigation, had agreed with them. John Almon (1737–1805; ODNB), printer of the forged pamphlet, Lettres de Monsieur le Marquis de Montcalm, Gouverneur-Général en Canada; à Messieurs de Berryer & de la Molé … Avec une Version Angloise (1777). In p. 117. vol. VI of that new Edition, there has, to the foot-note of Editn1865, in reference to that Letter of Montcalm’s as you already have both Footnote and it, this conclusive postscript been added; whh, since you evidently have not yet seen it, I here copy & inclose. n.b. (Enclosure here)TC included a new note, dated July 1868, in the uniform (cheap) edn. (1869), explaining that the letter was a forgery; see Carlyle, Works 18:146–47. This note was the enclosure sent to Deane.

If Mr Parkman ever thought of publishing those indisputable Montcalm Letters,Parkman noted that the marquis had 49 letters from Montcalm to his mother and sister (Proceedings 112). —still better, if the Marquis de Montcalm should think of going into the French Archives, and publishing, as well a judicious selection of the many that must be there,—I should be very anxious to see them. Believe me, yoursFrom “yours” to the end, the text is taken from the pbd. version. sincerely, / T. Carlyle.

postscript.p: To Charles Deane Esq., Recording Secretary &c., &c.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 22 Dec. MS: NLS 526.110. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Here is the small Newyears remembrance;TC noted in his checkbook: “22 decr1869 / to Sister Jean / £10 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). small symbol of very many remembrances & thots abt you; whh you will accept kindly as such.— I cannot write, you see, witht difficulty & reluctance: must, howr indicate a few practical things.

First, then, the stockings are excellt, and have fairly more warmth in them than thanTC repeated “than.” any other. Send me the rest so soon as they are ready. The Old Shirts, Mary instructs me, were before settled not to come at prest, but to be worn a little farther. I have one of them, quite whole, on my back at prest. Send the other 5 New, along with the stockings,—a fairly better & warmer 5, whh I shall resume; and leave the old, till winter go. Yesterday I wrote abt
some Books to the Dr; are up to Chapman’s this day, & ought to see Dumfries early next week. Some poor Print for you, I think, is inclosed by Mary. Item a Xmas Book for yr John.

The Mary-and-Warren affair I consider to be settling into a good footing;—principally by good patience grounded on impartl discernment on my part. I have spoken once, twice, with abundt clearness & emphasis, must not a third time, till the necessity be absolute & evidt! It is certn what you give as yr experience of Mrs Wn is thro’ out conformable to what I have myself observed; certn that she spoke twice to Mary in a way to be rebuked & suppressed:For the difficulties between Mary Aitken and Sarah Warren, see MAI to CAW, 19 Nov., and TC to JAC, 18 Dec. yes;—& withal, it is to myself, as good as evidt & certn that she actually wishes Mary to continue here, to be of use and of comfort to me, in my loneliness! Upon these bits of certainty I purpose to stand; and to hold my tongue well, as the item most essential to a good result. And so let us rest, in fair hope as to that little bit of devil’s-burble that has threatened to rise in our affairs!—

I am very sorry for yr poor neighbor Mrs Bates;Elizabeth Bates (ca. 1812–76), whose son TC and Jean had helped the previous year; see 45:166–67TC to JTU, 5 Sept. 1868. almost still more so for poor blind M Richardson.Wilhelmina Richardson; see TC to JAC, 20 March. Poor soul, Oh what a contrast since I used to see her beside her mother—who was a Lady of real worth and distinctn; furthermost of a gentlewoman I ever saw in Dumfries!Catherine Eliza Richardson; see 5:21TC to JAC, [11 Aug. 1829], and Carlyle, Reminiscences 130 and 366. Be patt with poor “Willie”; do not you forsake her, for my sake! Adieu, dear Sister.— Yrs ever / T. CarlyleTC enclosed a letter from W. H. Waldron, Worcester, 18 Dec.: “During a recent fit of illness, a friend lent me the second volume of your ‘Miscellanies’; and I have received more good, even physically, from the perusal of your essay on Jean Paul Richter than I feel I could have received from any friends or doctors, or by any other means. I hope you will forgive my writing a line of deepest heart-felt thanks for your beneficial, inspiring words; and that God may bless you for all the good which you have already unconsciously done, (and which your writings will do, to the end of time, to many poor fellows like myself).” TC wrote on the back of the letter: “For Sister Jean to read. Return this / It really gave me one moment’s pleasure!” In his journal TC noted, 19 Dec.: “Note from a poor young soul at Worcester; whh was evidtly true, and did me good all the rest of the evg!” (TC’s journal; privately owned). Probably William Henry Waldron (1838–90), b. and d. in Worcester.

div3.sourceNote: TC-KRHM, 29 Dec. Addr: 8 Tavistock Place / Tavistock Square / W.C. PM: London, 29 Dec. 1869. MS: Berg, in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature. Hitherto unpbd. Kenneth Robert Henderson Mackenzie (1833–86), linguist and translator; see TC to KRHM, 11 Nov. 1853.
div3.head: TC TO K. R. H. MACKENZIE

docBody.p: Accept many thanks for your German Life of Bismarck brought to legibility in English.Mackenzie sent TC a copy of his translation of J. G. L. Hesekiel, The Life of Bismarck, Private and Political; with Descriptive Notices of his Ancestry (1870). I have gone through the whole of it with great curiosity to learn something certain about that most remarkable of living Politicians; and have found at least in his own Letters and pieces of Speech, authentically given, considerable conviction as to the rugged strength, promptitude, veracity, and generally manful character of the man. In other respects your poor Hesekiel,Johann Georg Ludwig Hesekiel (1819–74), German journalist, author, and editor. was but an uncertain flary kind of light, largely intermixed with smoke and confused intermittency of pitch-droppings, ashes and darkness; welcome truly in our great need, but only to be welcomed on that ground. Could not you, from Hesekiel and other [of] your own resources, contrive some Account of Bismarck and his Procedures, thoroughly intelligible to English readers, and really applicable to our English wants about him? To all intelligent readers, it would be right welcome at present.

As to this Hesekiel, he is somewhat an enigma to me. Where did such a tawdry fellow get hold of Bismarck Letters? A good many months ago there came to me the First Abtheilung of his Buch vom Grafen Bismarck,J. G. L. Hesekiel, Das Buch Vom Grafen Bismarck (Bielefeld and Leipzig, 1869). and this morning there comes Abtheilung third,—you, in the meanwhile, having done him the honour of translating it and the other two. I wish much you would abolish Hesekiel by a right Book of your own!

Meanwhile, I am much obliged by what you have already done,—the whole enhanced, in my particular case, by your peculiar civility in sending me a Copy and such proofs of your goodwill.Mackenzie wrote in the preface to The Life of Bismarck: “The combination of an honest minister with a noble-minded king … is rare. In Frederick the Second of Prussia, as to some extent in the first Napoleon, there was a will to be honest; but where the latter failed in his task, the former prevailed in the hearts of the people, and the admiration of the world. Have we not the exquisite book of Mr. Carlyle as evidence of it? ” (Bismarck xviii).

closer.note: Ruskin wrote, 30 Dec., asking to visit “tomorrow” with a relative: “a good—clearheaded clearsighted—and to you most reverent and faithfull—young English Merchant.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 1 Jan. Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N.B. PM: London, 1 Jan. 1870. MS: NLS 527.1. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: You ought to be, and shall be, the first to whom I write this new date; I am thus, as it were, yr “first foot,”—tho’, alas, I fear, this is of little real use to us: and indeed I have not even means to write you a reasonable Note today. Yesternight I slept badly, or indeed strictly did not sleep at all: but only half-sleep and intermittently doze till 6 a.m., and then awake altogr: let this be my excuse;—and understand too that it is almost the first such accidt for 3 or 4 weeks past; & that my sleeping faculty in genl seems fairly improved. Ruskin & a visitorUnidentified further. were: that was part of the Cause, not all.

We have had dark unpleast weather: keenish frost for some days (whh I rather think is wholesomer, tho’ so bitter to the aged skin); in the last two days we have got to mud & tepid wet agn; sky visible today agn for the first time.— — I am heartily weary of these “Happy Newyears!” “Merry Xmases, and many of them!” &c—happy? merry? Ach Gott!

We dined at Forster’s (perforce) on Xmas; had Browning there, and one or two unbedeutenden [of trifling interest]. Brg is grown much hoarier, fatter, and begins to have gout & a double-chin. Ach! We went on no other dining or visiting errand; refused resolutely to big Houses & small!— — I am still greatly bothered abt the paltry concern of “Pictures”; but have to reflect, What other art thou good for?—& hope I am now nearly thro’.— Jean’s Parcel, tell her with my thanks, came yestdy.— Henry CooperProbably the Hon. Henry Frederick Cowper (1836–87), M.P. for Hertfordshire 1865–85; see 45:96TC to LN, 18 Feb. 1868, and 131TC to JCA, 18 May 1868.intrudes (by permissn), & I must end.— May God’s blessing be on you all. Yr affecte/ T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-RWE, 4 Jan. MS copy, in an unknown hand: RWEMA. Pbd: Slater, CEC 557–58.
div3.head: TC TO RALPH WALDO EMERSON

docBody.p:
A month ago or more I wrote, by the same post to you and to Norton abt those Books for Harvard College; and in late days have been expecting yr joint ansr. From Norton yesternight I receive what is here copied for yr perusal;TC enclosed a copy of Norton’s letter of 31 Dec., which explained that he was in Florence, and so had only just received TC’s letter (see TC to CEN, 18 Nov. 1869). it has come round by Florence as you see, and given me real pleasure & instructn. From you, who are possibly also away from home, I have
yet nothing; but expect now soon to have a few words. There did arrive, one evg lately, yr Two pretty volumes of Collected Works,Emerson’s Prose Works, 2 vols. (Boston, 1870). Emerson wrote on the flyleaf of vol. 1: “To Thomas Carlyle, Esq. / With unchangeable affection of his old friend, R. W. Emerson / October 30, 1869” (Sotheby’s [1932] lot 50). a pleast salutatn from you—whh set me upon reading again what I thot I knew well before:—but the Letter is still to come

Norton’s hints are such a complete instructn to me that I see my way straight thro’ the busss, and might by Note of “Bequest,”Norton wrote: “if your precious gift take the form of a testamentary bequest, it will be best that it should be made directly to the University itself, under such conditions as you may deem best,—not merely that it may have a certain dignity as a species of public act,—but also because the University is entitled under our laws to receive such a gift without payment of taxes or import duties. If the books were left to Emerson as your Trustee, to be given in your name to the Library of the University, he might have some trouble to free himself from the payment of duties upon them. We are so unwise as to levy an import duty upon foreign wisdom when it comes to us in the form of books.” and memm for the Barings,Norton wrote: “The agents of the College in England are Messrs. Baring Brothers & Co. 8 Bishopsgate St within London. It might save trouble if a memorandum were made giving directions that when the books are to be sent they should be put in the hands of the agents to be forwarded.” finish it in half an hour nevertheless I will wait for yr Letter and punctually do nothing till yr directns too are before me. Pray write, therefore, all is lying ready here Since you heard last, I have got Two Catalogues made out, approximately correct; one is to lie here till the Bequest be executed; the other I thot of sending to you agt the day?See TC to RWE, 24 Feb. This is my own inventn in regard to the affair since I wrote last Approve of it, and you shall have yr copy by Book-post at once. “Approximately correct”; absolutely I cannot get it to be. But I need not doubt the Pious Purpose will be piously & even sacredly fulfilled;—& yr Catalogue will be a kind of evidence that it is
Adieu, dear Emerson till yr letter come.This sentence is from the pbd. version.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 6 Jan. MS: NLS 527.2. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:259–60 inc. Quot: Slater, CEC 561.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
One of these inclosed Letters, the Norton one,See TC to RWE, 4 Jan. I meant for you 2 days ago; the AlickTheir brother Alexander; see TC to AC, 12 Jan. came only yesterday late,—and I found myself agn
(in spite of determined effort) incapable of managing to get it forwarded with a line, and not witht! I am become bankrupt in sleep agn; feel myself in fact “sair hadden doun.” But to busss!—

Norton’s Letter (whh I had expected straight from Boston) was very welcome to me; and points out, as you will see, a quite brief way of finishing the Busss; way whh I design to follow. From Emerson nothing has come: but I forthwith got Norton copied and despatched it to him (Tuesday last), with intimatn that I now clearlyWord repeated with a line over it at turn of page. saw my way to doing the thing “in few minutes” (my part of it); but wd wait till he Emn spoke. For the rest, that I had two catalogues ready, one for him instantly, if &c—& second impatt rather to have done.— You can read Norton carefully; you, dear Brr, will, as is like, have to act upon it by & by! Norton & his Photoh (item Alick’s Photh);—this is all I want returned.Norton sent a photograph from Florence of Michelangelo’s statue of David; see TC to CEN, 2 March. John apparently returned the photographs quickly as TC reported to Alick, 12 Jan., that his photograph was in TC’s “dressing-closet” (the dressing room was at the back of the house, with a door into his bedroom; for the second floor plan, see 45:173TC to JSK, 21 Sept. 1868). The photograph can be seen in Thomas Carlyle Photograph Albums, vol. 3.

Alick’s Letter affected me not a little, in my prest sickly & downcast humour. Poor fellow, he too is looking into the silent Eternity, with all the sadness & solemnity, and not quite with all the composure, whh some others of us are used to! Poor Alick, he was always very affecte, tender of heart: his Letter has nothing of bad news, and is yet very sad. I mean to write (even in pencil) to him one other Letter very soon.—— This nearly all of busss, dear Brr;—and my time isTC repeated “time is” with a line over both words at turn of page.up, or rather more!

Abt Bismarck, there never came any Part II of the Buch des Grafen &c;J. G. L. Hesekiel, Das Buch Von Grafen Bismarck; see TC to KRHM, 29 Dec. 1869. John A. Carlyle wrote, 2 Jan.: “I got the 3d part of Bismark on Friday, & at once read the best portion of it. Part 2nd I have not seen. Is it not lying in some of your waste bags, as my fancy tells me? I have the 1st part here, as well as the 3d, & could have them simply bound if I had the 2nd too.” John A. Carlyle added at the end of his letter, 2 Jan.: “In the Bismark I found a photograph of Essex the Parly General on horseback—intended perhaps for the Cromwell—from an old print of 1645”; possibly TC had put it in by mistake; for the print, see TC to JF, 29 Nov. 1869. but Mary is gone to Wms & NorgateWilliams & Norgate, 14 Henrietta St., Covent Garden, dealers in foreign books. (inter alia [among other things]) to inquire if they have it, & what price. Meanwhile somebody has translated it hereKenneth R. H. Mackenzie; see TC to KRHM, 29 Dec. 1869. (a biggish Vol. with all the Prints) and I have it gratis here, & ready for you by Menzies,John Menzies; see TC to JAC, 3 Nov. 1869. middle of this month, if you don’t prefer the German at once by post?
Adieu, dear Brother. Mary & [I]TC omitted “I.” are due at Froude’s, to dine there with Ruskin, tomorrow evg:—no help for it, “over shoes over boots”Proverbial. perhaps it will matter little!
Heart’s love to you all.

postscript.p: Dr CarlyleTC wrote this on the reverse of his final page, probably as instruction for Mary to write the envelope.

div3.sourceNote: TC-FA [FAL], 7 Jan. MS: Nigel Althaus; in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO FRIEDRICH ALTHAUS

docBody.p: Your BookFriedrich Althaus, Englische Charakterbilder, 2 vols. (Berlin, 1869). has come to me as announced; many thanks for your kindness. It seems a Book likely to interest many Germans, and throw light upon our bewildered England to them,—as we hope it will!

I have gone through most part of the First Volume; find it all very rational, conciliatory, clear and candid; correct to the notions of the day, the ulterior issues and tendencies not gone into. You are abundantly kind to all your British Heroes, no fault on that side, wherever else! The Disraeli Article I reckon the best; something of real Portrait there,—though not quite crowned with hemlock, as perhaps it might have been. To others of us (myself not excepted),The essay on TC in this book is a slightly revised version of Althaus’s 1866 biographical sketch; see 44:8–9TC to FAL, 12 July 1866; for a trans. of that essay, together with TC’s marginal annotations and notes, see “Thomas Carlyle: A Biographical Literary Portrait by Friedrich Althaus, with Thomas Carlyle’s Notes,” Two Reminiscences of Thomas Carlyle, ed. John Clubbe (Durham, NC, 1974) 1–122. —nor still less the Cobden, Mill & Co) you are far too kind; though doubtless that is the safe side to err on.Althaus’s other “British heroes” were Lord Palmerston (1784–1865; ODNB), Whig politician, prime minister; W. M. Thackeray (1811–63; ODNB), novelist, friend of the Carlyles; see 30:biographical notes; J. M. W. Turner (1775–1852; ODNB), artist. Vol. 1 also included essays on “Irland und die Fenier” (Ireland and the Fenians), and “Reform and Zukunft” (Reform and the Future). The Athenæum reviewed both vols., 5 March: “Of Dr. Althaus’s literary biographies we give the preference to his sketch of Mr. Carlyle. As one of the translators of the ‘History of Frederick the Great’ Dr. Althaus is naturally interested in its author; and the account of the manner in which that book was written will probably be new to the English public. Dr. Althaus says that, with a view of insuring quiet and guarding against interruption, Mr. Carlyle added another storey to his house; the whole of the new storey consisting of one large room, which was given up to his library. The only books admitted into this room were those that related to the history of Frederick the Great, but they occupied a considerable space, and, as the work advanced, the pile on the library-table became more and more formidable. Dr. Althaus contradicts the further report that the room was filled with a cloud of smoke from Carlyle’s pipe, and that the composition of the History was carried on under this cover. Mr. Carlyle, he says, is as indefatigable a worker as those German Dryasdusts to whom this habit is ascribed, but he does not equal them in smoking. It may be that this has caused him to fall so far short of them in obscurity.”
I return you many thanks; and remain,From here, the writing is TC’s. Dear Sir,

div3.sourceNote: TC-DW, 10 Jan. MS: BL, in Mary Aitken’s hand with TC’s signature. Pbd: Shepherd, Carlyle 2:288–89. Daniel Wilson (1816–92; ODNB), anthropologist, artist, author; prof. of history and English Literature at Univ. Coll., Univ. of Toronto 1853–80.
div3.head: TC TO DANIEL WILSON

docBody.p: Accept many thanks for your Volume on Chatterton,Daniel Wilson, Chatterton: A Biographical Study (1869). Thomas Chatterton (1752–70; ODNB), poet. which I received two or three days after your Letter; and have read with unusual interest and attention.

The Narrative, in spite of its abstruse and much obscured subject is at once clear and concise; and throws an unexpected illumination upon Chatterton. Indeed it is the first time I have fairly been able to understand what Chatterton and his affairs really were. To sympathetic minds, it is a deep and painful tragedy; and to all minds, it is a wonderful physiological prodigy,—in which latter sense at least it may long have its interest among mankind.—

Beyond doubt you are abundantly sympathetic to the poor Boy: and his fate and history are indeed sad in the extreme. But I had here & there a feeling withal that perhaps he was incapable of being saved, that besides these lamentable obstructions of his childhood, there was something wrong in the original conformation of him. Too much of vehemence and violence for any piety & loyalty he had;—clearly a considerable want of reverence, and an enormous overplus of mere ambition, and egoism.— I remark too, in his marvellously precocious Poetry, far more of shining colour and grandiloquent sound than of any finer spiritual element:—in short, one has a feeling that,
perhaps his thrice-miserable death at that early stage, may have been the least miserable ending for him.Chatterton d., age 17, from an accidental overdose of arsenic and opium. Poor Boy; poor, erring, struggling, vainly soaring brother mortal, what a dismal painful bit of Human History however that may be!

I remember well your pleasant visit here, and also my reading of your former Book.Wilson’s visit to Cheyne Row is untraced; his many previous works include Memorials of Edinburgh in the Olden Time (1848) and Archaeology and Prehistoric Annals of Scotland (1851). With myself much is mournfully changed since then; but not my goodwill towards you, and such as yours. Believe me,From here, the writing is TC’s. dear Sir,

div3.sourceNote: TC-AC, 12 Jan. MS: MUL. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:260–63 inc; Marrs 760–62. Quot: D. Brown Anderson, Reminiscences, with Occasional Essays (Peebles, 1906) 401–2.
div3.head: TC TO ALEXANDER CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Three or four days ago I was agreably surprised by a very kind and interesting Letter from meTC wrote “me” in error for “you.”; welcome, as you may fancy, beyond almost any other that cd have come! After twice reading, I despatched it next day to Dumfries, where also it naturally gave much pleasure. You and I don’t write so often directly to each other as we were wont; but both of us know that it is not from decay of affectn;—ah no,—but from far other causes!—and that, in our silence, we think of each other, almost every day of our lives, with a sad and solemn tenderness, with wishes, hopes and memories, that only deepen as the End draws nigh! Yr Photograph is in my dressing-closet, yr true old face well known to me; among the Shadows of my other Loved Ones who are far away,—far, far, into Eternity itself all but one or two:—it is there, every morng, that I see myself surrounded as with a Cloud of sacred witnesses;Helen Allingham recorded, 1881, that the W wall of TC’s dressing room included “Photographs (mounted together) of his brothers, Alick, Dr. Carlyle, and James; and his sisters, Mrs. Austin and Mrs Aitken” (Carlyle’s House 109); they were placed around a photograph of Margaret A. Carlyle’s portrait. The top line of photographs is of Jean Aitken, Mary Austin, and Alexander Carlyle; the bottom line of James Carlyle and his grandson, John James Carlyle Scott, a clean shaven Alick (with his wife Janet cut out of the photograph; for the full photograph, see 42:222TC to JAC, 14 Sept. 1865), and John A. Carlyle. Their mother Margaret A. Carlyle’s portrait (see also 13:frontispiece.) is in the center. See opp.
and am silently admonished to send my sad thots Heavenward, and to silently worship if there be anything of piety and goodness left in me! Alas, the sadness and the longing wishes do not fail, nor can ever; but the “piety,” the faith and goodness are not so constant. One’s poor heart can say only, in its heavy-laden state “Great unknown God, King & Maker of this Universe, be merciful to us all.”— But I will quit this; all this is already as good as known to you: and my Writing talent (nearly gone, as you see) must confine itself to narrower practical limits.

figure.p:
Photographs of Jean Aitken, Mary Austin, Alexander Carlyle, James Carlyle and grandson, a slightly younger shaven Alexander, John A. Carlyle, and, in the
center, a photograph of the portrait by Maxwell of Margaret A. Carlyle
Courtesy of the National Trust

docBody.p:
It is a great comfort to me to know that you are in fair old-man’s health; and furthermore that your Boys & Girls seem all to be good promising creatures and all doing well. These young ones springing up are now a great wealth
to you, dear Brr; I now feel what a stern poverty the want of all such in my own case is! Since April gone 3 years,JWC’s death, 21 April 1866. I feel at all hours entirely left solitary; no joy, or cheerful promise of a social hearts-communion in this world, now possible. Nevertheless be complaint far from us. I[n]TC omitted the “n.” noble sorrow there is, or can be, a blessedness too. I am far sadder & gloomier of mind than I used to be; but ought not to say that I am to be called unhappier,—the contrary rather. This wretched blockhead & beggar of a world can now do nothing for me, nothing agt me. I look upon it (if at all, whh is not often) with authentic & nearly complete contempt; sometimes (what I hope may become more frequent) with a great deal of pity. All is going (as you too feel) into unspeakable downbreak; and must either re-make itself on a truer basis, or else die forever:—in either case, with long misery and agony; sad to contemplate: but yet it is a blessed alternative, too; & we can calmly, with Hope still tremulously alive, leave it to The All-Mighty & All-Wise!— Enough of that too. What I had practically to say had reference to yr Children, Tom & the rest of them; whose starting in the world is of real interest to me, and a thing I ought to help in if I cd.

Understand then, dear Brr, that, tho’ not to be called in the modern Englh dialect, by any means rich, I have plenty of money, far far beyond any wants I shall now ever have;—and that if, at any time, yr own Household, or the outfit of any of yr Young Folk, get to need a lift over any hard hill, I bid you, and agn bid you, at once apply to me; & tell you, what is true, that it will be a comfort to me to be of help. Believe that always; do, witht my speaking farther of it.— Tell Tom he might write to me;Alick’s eldest son, Thomas, had been in the habit of writing to TC; see 44:74TC to AC, 20 Oct. 1866. For an 1870 photograph of Tom, see 42:223TC to JAC, 14 Sept. 1865. I have not forgotten him at all;—say I cd ansr him by a word in pencil at any rate. And yr Jane, poor little Jane, whom I figure still as a wee wise Lassie,—I pray you let me know something precise abt her: I fear often she is heavily burdened;Alick’s eldest da., Jane Welsh Sims; apparently her marriage to Robert Sims had not turned out well. but she utters no complaint, or none audible here. What is Alick going in for, at Toronto College?Alick’s third son, Alexander; he studied science at the Univ. of Toronto, and became a schoolteacher (Marrs 552). The Photh represents to me a modest, stedfast, likely fellow;Presumably a photograph of Alexander had been sent also; untraced. but of him I retain no other portraiture; only Tom & Jane are prest to me as actual little human beings still completely luminous.Tom was 10 and Jane 12 when Alick and family emigrated (June 1843), and TC knew them (see 16:172TC to AC, 19 May 1843); John was only 4 then, and TC did not mention him; Alexander was b. 29 April 1843 (see 16:153TC to AC, 4 May 1843), just before the emigration. He was to visit TC and become engaged to Mary Aitken, 1871.

I am myself in a little better health perhaps, at least I visibly sleep somewhat better, for the last 3 months or so; whh is a great blessing and relief from paltry fears & do miseries; tho’ my strength of any kind seems hitherto as if it were rather weakened by the change. In particr, I never in my life was so idle; have no heart at all for work; languid, silent, weary, wae. Little Mary writes for me; but I cannot yet learn to write by dictating to her; willing, swift and eager as she is, poor little soul. She is a wise little thing, honest I think as spring water; pretty to look upon & shines here like a small taper, slightly breaking the gloom of this my now element. I think I will send to Dumfries, & get you a Photoh, if I can, for next Letter!— What is more importt, I think all is in its usual way with our kindred there & thereabts; Sister Mary old but still tough and helpfully busy at The Gill; Brr Jamie seems to go to Birmingham annually on a longish visit;Their brother James’s da., Jenny Scott, lived with her husband and children in Birmingham. Presumably the photograph of James and his grandson was taken on one of James’s visits. he has returned this year with a Scott Granddr,Isabella Scott. a good gleg little Creature as they all report. His two Boys, at Scotsbrig the junr, at Craigenputtock the elder, seem to be doing usefully & well.James Carlyle Jr. and his wife, Catherine, lived at Craigenputtoch, and John Carlyle and his wife, Margaret, at Scotsbrig. I made a visit to poor Craigk last time I was in Scotland;TC visited Craigenputtoch ca. 25 Aug. 1868; see 45:165TC to WTHO, 20 Aug. 1868. looked over all things with these old eyes; sight melting my very heart: “So sad, so strange, the Days that are no more!”See Alfred Tennyson, “Tears, Idle Tears,” The Princess (1847) 4.35.— — Some time ago they sent me from Dumfries, a poor old dud of a book, Andrew M’Nay’s Book of DoggrelAndrew M’Nay (b. 1800), b. at Relief, 2 mi. (3 km.) N of Ecclefechan, The Poetical Works of Andrew M’Nay, Ecclefechan. Comprising a number of poems and songs, chiefly written in the Scottish dialect, and illustrative of the manners of the peasantry of Scotland (Dumfries, 1820); TC and Alick mentioned this poet in letters several times while Alick was living at the family farm at Mainhill; Alick had described the poems as “tasteless doggerel” (see 1:308TC to AC, 10 Jan. 1821), although TC was kinder; see 2:128TC to AC, [5 June 1822], and 396TC to JJ, 8 July 1823. (of 1823 or so, whh I remember at Mainhill so well): it is at the Binder’s to have some cover put on it; next week I meanTC repeated “mean” with a line over it at turn of page. to despatch it to your care, for Tom as a memorial to him of his poor old birthland.— Today, I inclose some copies (all there are) of a Print they have put into Vol XII of a New Editn, they are printing of me;Tait’s photograph of TC, 31 July 1854, used as the frontispiece to the library edn. of On Heroes (1870); see TC to LLA, 17 Dec. 1869, and 128. scatter them as you like.— God’s blessing be on you & yours, dear Alick. Ever yr affecte BrotrT. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JKH, 14 Jan. Pbd: Shepherd, Carlyle 2:290–91. Quot: Wylie 342 inc. John Kelso Hunter (1802–73; ODNB), cobbler, portrait painter, and author.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN KELSO HUNTER

docBody.p: Many weeks ago I should have thanked you for the pleasant volume you were kind enough to send me.John Kelso Hunter, The Retrospect of an Artist’s Life: Memorials of West Country Men and Manners of the Past Half-Century (Greenock, 1868). My excuse is, I have been in weak health, am occupied with many things, and have a growing aversion and inability to the act of writing.

Your book is not a very serious one, but it is a swift and flowing, full of good humour throughout—of canny shrewdness, too, with a subdued vein of just satire perceptible, like a suspicion of good cognac in a wholesome tumbler of new milk. I can say that it throws an authentic straggle of illumination over actual Scottish life in our generation, and pleasantly reminds me of what I knew so well long ago,—that the photograph of that briskly peaceable, contented, and independent shoemakerThe book contained only landscape illus. Presumably Hunter enclosed a photograph of his 1847 “self-portrait of a shoemaker”; see above. It had been exhibited at the Royal Academy, 1847. awakens nothing but good-will in me, and that I have known many thousands of books which cost far more trouble and were less deserving of being written.

figure.p: John Kelso Hunter, self-portrait of a shoemaker, 1847 Wikimedia Commons

docBody.p: Believe me yours,
With hearty thanks and good wishes,
docBody.closer: T. Carlyle.TC wrote in his journal, 14 Jan.: “Meant to at least write something here; but now cannot even manage that. Idle, languid, sad, with a hand that refuses; oh, what an idle, lonely, sad and useless life! Will it mend, I wonder? It ‘ought to,’ or else end.— Some of Goethe’s old things turned up for evg reading lately; how incomparably superior & supreme, over all others what! [see TC to JAC, 18 Dec. 1869]— ‘Earthly Paradise’ (rather wearisome and infantile, 4 voll- of it already!) by one Morris, once a Prae-Raphaelite Painter, now a prosperous Glass-stainer for Churches &c; I trace in him a real and even high talent for that kind of thing; a mind full of clear sensibility to colour, of innocent, pious temper too, really ‘a loving child,’— his dialect too, freeflowing, disdaining grammar &c, may be counted childlike or childish; abounding in slipslop, and singing itself in a monotonous croon.— Finished him, night before last” (TC’s journal; privately owned). William Morris (1834–96; ODNB), designer, author, utopian socialist; The Earthly Paradise, 4 vols. (1868–70), a sequence of narrative poems, was begun by Morris, 1866. TC was presumably reading one of the last two vols., pbd. 1870.

postscript.p:
Mr. John Kelso Hunter,
Gourock, near Greenock.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 18 Jan. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Thanks for yr kind little word. Yesterday I was seriously studying the Melchet questn, with a mixture of hope and apprehension, and have not yet given it up; but last night, to my considerable surprise, proved bankrupt agn in the matter of sleep; whh naturally does not increase the “hope” element today!— My advice wd be: Go to Castle Ashby if you have pleast friends there;Castle Ashby, Northamptonshire, estate of Charles Douglas-Compton (1816–77), 3d marquess of Northampton. Lady Ashburton replied, [23 Jan.]: “I gave up Castle Ashby for the present, to my great regret—as he is ill—& his sisters being all in Italy.” His only surviving sister was Lady Marian Alford.—& then let me hear from you on yr return.

Certainly I will speak to Mrs Froude; nor neglect any slightest chance I may have of helping you in that anxious matterHenrietta Elizabeth Froude; Lady Ashburton was again looking for a governess for Mary Florence Baring; see TC to LLA, 24 Jan.

Be patient with BurgessAndrew Hutton Burgess, who was cataloguing Lady Ashburton’s library at Melchet; see TC to LLA, 19 Aug. 1869. & the Harness-room;Unexplained. Burgess wrote a detailed letter defending his work to Lady Ashburton, 22 Jan.; his list of the rooms where the Melchet books were did not include the harness room: “I asserted that I was not at all responsible for any delay that has taken place in the arrangement of the books, giving as a typical instance the fact that in less than half an hour after the last four presses were handed over to me by the Carpenter on Friday afternoon 14th, the arrangement was finished and I was on my way for home. / The addition from time to time of so many presses in and out of the Library not only delayed the completion but modified the plan of my arrangement. And if my work is anything more and better than the packing of books—as I think it is—it is this—that the presses in Boudoir are not only filled but filled with the books of all in the house which ought to be there and that the same is true of the Corridor, the Library and the Billiard Room: so that there are no books (with a few exceptions wh I hope to alter) in any one room or press in the house which ought to be in any other room or press. / I also wished to be able to finish a Catalogue for upstairs use, and for which I got a suitable handy blank book in Library, which will show you what a very complete and readable collection of books are in Boudoir, Corridor & Drawing Room” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). See also TC to LLA, 24 Jan. I think it certn he will now soon disappear.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 22 Jan. Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N.B. PM: London, 22 Jan. 1870. MS: NLS 527.3. Quot: Slater, CEC 561.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: This morng I counted on a little Note from the Hill; but none has come (at 3 p.m. now);—and indeed I had no right to expect any. Probably yr Life, like my own, is empty and stagnant at this stagnt epoch,—with no histy that seems worth writing. This is eminently my own case; day after day I seem to do Nothing; to arrive, sad, wearied, sore at 1 a.m. and tumble amid dreary reflexns into bed,—where, happily Sleep does mostly swallow me to some tolerable degree.John replied, 23 Jan.: “Your kind letter with its enclosures has come today, & I am very glad to hear that you are at least as well as usual. … You conjecture rightly that I had no news to send & therefore did not write.” A great mercy, in comparison:—and Sleep, we all know, has a Brother now not far off, whose beneficence will not fail us,—if it please God. Amen.

I read in the evgs; seldom Books of grt worth,—the best that come to hand. Few that I meet, almost Froude alone, & Ruskin hardly & at rare times, are worth much talking to; silence is better; and I have neither strength nor heart for work; most likely, shall never agn have.— Our weather latterly has grown very dry, east-windy & cold; considerably wholesomer, I think, than the late mud-elemt; only rather severe in the bath-departt, first thing one does. I wrote, in pencil, a longish letter to Alick, last week; Thursday last I sent him off poor Andrew M’Nay (John’s gift to me, whh I got bound in a way), for behoof of Nephew Tom & our poor old Birthplace & his.See TC to AC, 12 Jan. How lively, strange, almost preternatl, that Old morning of Andrw & his Book, at Mainhill, now looks! “We are such stuff”See The Tempest 4.1.—! I suppose Andrw & his Brr are both long dead;John A. Carlyle replied, 23 Jan.: “I am glad you wrote to poor Alick & sent him M’Nay’s poems. Mary was here when John got the volume, & said she remembered the death of Andrew at Langdykes of consumption long ago. The brother she could say nothing of”; the brother was possibly John M’Nay (b. 1806). at any rate that you know nothing of either? I remember only 2 creatures now that were alive at Ecclefn in my first; two poor old women.Presumably Barbara Irving, b. Moffat (ca. 1791–1873) and Jenny Halliday, b. Ker (b. ca. 1787); TC had sent Jamie £1 each for them Jan. 1866; see 43:110TC to JC, 22 Jan. 1866.— By the by, Jamie never yet told me to whom he gave the addl mite I sent some weeks ago, or even that he ever recd it safe.TC noted in his checkbook “25 decr1869 / To Brr Jamie (Ecclefn Charity) / £3 .. 0 .. 6” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). The recipient of the other £1 is unidentified. John replied: “I have not heard from Scotsbrig lately, but I will write to Jamie & ask if your letter & enclosure reached him safely.” John indeed wrote from Scotsbrig
that the Letter had reached him & been forwarded to Craigenpk where his Fr was:—but more I never heard. Little or no doubt the thing was all right and has been rightly & punctually done: but a word wd have been welcome. Ask by some opporty if you can recollect.

From Emerson I still hear nothing—and begin rather to wonder. N’importe, howr; n’importe du tout [of no importance at all]. Forster has been absent all this while, “coughing dreadfully,”Forster suffered from a persistent cough; see TC to JF, 29 Nov. 1869. “at Ld Lytton’s, Torquay”;Edward George Earle Lytton Bulwer (1803–73; ODNB), 1st Baron Lytton, writer and politician, one of Forster’s closest friends; he usually spent winters at Argyll Hall, Torquay. is now better since the weather dried into the east. Mary & I are engaged to dine with him tomorrow, nobody but Dickens more.—— — You will get little good of that scrubbery of Letters; but may read and burn.

postscript.p: I hope the Menzies-Chapn Packet has come today? Not sooner, I fear.— “Vol.” was out on Tuesday18 Jan.; vol. 13 of the library edn., Past and Present. John replied, 23 Jan., saying nothing had so far arrived; he then wrote, 3 Feb.: “Chapman’s parcel of books, prepaid, has come direct from London today. It contains Chatterton for Miss Sinclair … the volume for Dr Russell … & the vol. of Bismark, with Past & Present for myself.”—

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 24 Jan. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I have forwarded Burgess’s Letter;Lady Ashburton wrote to TC, [23 Jan.], enclosing a letter from Burgess to herself, 22 Jan., and apparently a letter from herself to Burgess for TC to forward. Burgess wrote to Lady Ashburton, 22 Jan.: “Mr Carlyle whom I saw on Thursday [20 Jan.] has dictated my going to Melchet on Wednesday night next week with a helper. / I stated that a little delay at present would in no way postpone the completion of the Catalogue: that I wished to return when your Ladyship left for town so that my use of high steps in the Library wd be in nobody’s way. … If it is inconvenient I shall be glad if you wrote to Mr Carlyle not to do anything in the matter of a scribe & to myself: otherwise I shall have to go down on Wednesday by last train” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). For more of Burgess’s letter, see TC to LLA, 18 Jan. Lady Ashburton wrote to TC: “I got this note fr Mr Burgess to which I answer, that I will provide an amanuensis—so I hope he will appear on Wednesday.” you may expect him on Wedy night, & have yr “scribe” ready for Thursday & Friday—whh is to be the last of him at Melchet, if you keep firm.— N.b. there was no “ £5 inclosed”; this mistake I sd wd be rectified on Thursday in the course of nature,—or he cd have the money here if he cared to call.— I believe all this Book-busss will be really well done at last;—“March 20” stands as fixed date; let us keep it!—

I am sorry to hear of this Chill;Lady Ashburton wrote: “I write today from my bed—I got a bad chill a few days ago, & have not been well since, but I hope I shall DV. be all right again very soon.” —but indeed you go abt like a Highlander, forgetful that you have an appointt far prettier than that, if a little softer & tenderer: I hope you will take warning!— For the rest, be in no apprehension abt the Governesses; but take right time & quiet to recover: Mary has written to Frn Bruhn not to fly away till you have seen her; Hullah is not yet discovered, nor will be on the wing where she is.Lady Ashburton wrote: “I like the report of both [governesses] so much, that I shall go up to town to see them as soon as I can … will Mary write … a note to both the Ladies, as will prevent them take a place, till I have seen them.” Fraulein Bruhn and Fraulein Hullah not further identified. Lady Ashburton wrote: “I shd at once thankfully secure Mlle Bruhn if she were younger—but with a solitary child, this is a drawback.” Nay, yesty, at the Reichenbachs’,Oskar and Friedericke von Reichenbach and family, at 5 Carlisle Ter., Kensington. TC had previously approached them about a governess for Mary Baring; see 44:53TC to LLA, 7 Sept. 1866, and 70–71TC to LLA, 16 Oct. 1866. little Mary discovered another rather likely person: a young German, “of the type of yr Albatine”;Unidentified further. ladylike, rational, “splendid musicn” &c; who had been coming hither to a Place, but was detained at Paris by a Sister’s illness, and found the Place filled,—whh Place I didn’t hear. So that, you see, there is no lack of Govsses. The Belton NotePresumably from Lady Alford or her son, Lord Brownlow; Belton, Lincolnshire, was Lord Brownlow’s estate. you need not return: I have excused myself there; if I go any-whither, for certn it shall be Melchet.Lady Ashburton wrote: “I cannot tell you how deeply I am touched at the ready help you always give me in every difficulty. How can I thank you, as I feel for all the trouble you have taken about the governesses. … How can I thank you enough for offering me the valuable help of dear Mary? I shd only accept of her, on the condition of your coming also—oh! how happy I shd be if I cd persuade you to do that—but I hesitate to urge it in this very severe cold.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 28 Jan. Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N.B. PM: London, 29 Jan. 1870. MS: NLS 527.4. Quot: Slater, CEC 561; K. J. Fielding, “Carlyle and Dickens or Dickens and Carlyle? ” The Dickensian 69 (1973): 118; Peter Ackroyd, Dickens (1990) 1064.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Before the week quite end, I ought to send you a word in continuatn of my No-Histy,—for such it is thus far, more almost than I can ever recollect,—and to satisfy you that there has nothing at least of minus newly befallen. An old
man ought to be Content with doing Nothing! Alas no, I am not “content” at all; but need not trouble you with my impotent reflexions & remorses in that respect. My lame hand hinders all free writing: I have tried once or twice; but find hitherto mere negatn; the dark weather too— But it is needless continuing that subject. Except reading some Proofs (Life of Sterling is now the “vol.” on hand,— vol 20), and bothering abt insignificant “Prints,” I genlly do nothing, beyond brushing-off from me (with the extreme of brevity) a selectn of the foolish Notes that come, and reading silly Books, only not so silly that
I cannot stand them at all. Till last night, and then not to any high degree, I have not had any misfortune in sleep; whh is an immunity I always recognise with thankfulness. The gloomy mists seem to be quitting our bit of Frost, moreover; today is beautifully sunny. Perhaps I shall improve a little in better weather. Two days ago we had ice in all the washbowls, tho’ the essential temperature cd not be much below 30°, only that the fog was complete, & kept the hoar-frost lying round us all day.

I hope you got the Menzies Parcel this week? It is probably the only ‘news’ you wd have had to send me. I had a Letter from Jean at Lrpool; who sends cheerful accts, & does not expect Maggie & James Senr till next week, as preliminary to her return. No Letter has yet come from Emerson; I begin to conjecture he must be from home: I have never yet ansd Norton, always waiting till the Emerson come. Last night, by request of his, was here with his pretty Daughter;TC omitted the name; possibly Oskar von Reichenbach with one of his two das.; otherwise unidentified further. very useless to me both of them, tho’ both very kind. Mary dressed herself, and smiled placidly on the affair, good little soul. In a silly Book called the Leisure HourThe Leisure Hour: A Family Journal of Instruction and Recreation, a weekly journal pbd. by the Religious Tract Society. (I think for Feby, the monthly Part) whh Mr WarnThus in MS, possibly for Mrs. Warren; otherwise unidentified. had brot up to me for the sake of a feeble Article on Ruskin,“John Ruskin,” The Leisure Hour (1 Feb. 1870): 119–24. I found a poor little Piece called Leisure Hour at Haddington,“A Leisure Hour in Haddington,” The Leisure Hour (1 Feb. 1870): 90–92; it contained an account of JWC’s education, her marriage, and TC’s inscription on her grave (see 43:236TC to WDO, 21 June 1866). the reading of whh, tho’ it was altogr kind at once and altr insignift, made me very wae, yet thankful withal. I know [not]Omitted by TC. whether it is worth 6d of yr money: but at Dumfries too, I doubt not, it is attainable. One of Blunt’s Curates here, a weakish earnest man, Aberdeen-French, “Demaus” by name) is guessed by Mary to be the writer.Gerald Blunt, rector of St. Luke’s, Chelsea. Robert Demaus (1829–74; ODNB), cleric, teacher, and biographer; senior curate of St. Luke’s, Chelsea, 1865–74. Demaus had been educated and previously worked in Scotland, so might have visited Haddington and been interested in the clerics (including John Knox [see TC to WFR, 8 July 1869]) mentioned in the article. The personal information about JBW and Edward Irving’s links with her could have been drawn from Margaret Oliphant’s The Life of Edward Irving (1862) which had published the story (mentioned in the article [92]) of the young JBW wanting to learn Latin (“Penna, pennae”; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 69). Ah me, ah me!—

Dickens was very cheery at Forster’s that evg, a son, a dr, and Miss Hogarth with him:Charles Dickens; probably his eldest son, Charles Culliford Box Dickens (1837–96; ODNB), magazine editor and compiler of guidebooks; his eldest da., Mary “Mamie” Dickens (1838–96), or possibly his 2d da., Kate Macready Collins (1839–1929); and his sister-in-law Georgina Hogarth (1827–1917; ODNB). he has got, I doubt, some permant nervous damage from that conquest
of that £20,000 in Yankeeland,Dickens had toured the U.S. Dec. 1867–April 1868 (see 45:51TC to CKE, 20 Oct. 1867), earning over £19,000. and is himself rather anxious now & then abt it,—a foot that goes occasionally wrong (part powerless, I think), and now latterly some fingers of a hand do:Dickens suffered from a painful foot for some years; he had a stroke, 18 April 1869, which left him partly paralyzed on the left side of his body, including his hand. Forster later wrote: “On the 23rd of January, when for the last time [Dickens] met Carlyle, he came to us with his left hand in a sling” (John Forster, Life of Dickens [1872–74] 3:493). —but he has now very nearly done with these final Londn “Readings,”Dickens had been forced to abandon his earlier tour of readings; see TC to JAC, 28 April 1869; however, he decided to give 12 final readings in London, 11 Jan.–15 March 1870. For an illustration of his final reading, 15 March, see 152. & promises to be all himself agn. What a tragedy, & hideous nemesis were it otherwise! He talked to me abt America as a wonderer, by no means as a lover.——
Illustrated London News (Supplement), 19 March 1870
It is not impossible Lady Ashbn may come up on Monday or so (abt “Governesses”), and hurry Mary & me down with her for aTC repeated “a” with a line over it at turn of page. few days! But of course you shall hear.— Good be with you all, my remnant of Loved Ones. Ever yr Affecte Brother

div3.sourceNote: TC-TA [TAL], 3 Feb. Pbd: Wylie 345. Rev. Thomas Alexander (1817–72), originally from Dundee; minister of the Ranelagh Presbyterian Church, Chelsea, ca. 1850–65; see 39:75JWC to GWE, [2 March 1863], and Wylie 344–45; now minister of Halkin Street Chapel, Halkin St. W, Belgrave Sq., and living at 18 St. Leonard’s Ter., Chelsea.
div3.head: TC TO REV. THOMAS ALEXANDER

docBody.salute: Rev. T. Alexander, with many regards.

lg.l: There was a Piper had a Cow,
And he had nocht to give her;
He took his pipes and play’d a spring,
That mirth wad never fill her;
Gie me a pickle ait strae,

And sell your wind for siller.Apparently Alexander had asked TC for a subscription towards the building of a church school; TC often quoted the rhyme in letters (see TC to JAC, 15 Aug. 1834, and TC to MAC, 22 March 1836), or wrote it out as an autograph (see TC to LS, 12 Aug. 1860). According to Wylie: “The minister did not get the expected subscription at the time; but, by threatening to have the verse lithographed for sale, he succeeded in his object” (Wylie 345). Wylie presumably meant that TC gave some money; nothing is recorded in TC’s checkbook of the time.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 3 Feb. MS: NLS 1775D.145. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: “Carlyle” Places in Dumfrre, whh I want to know (see Douglas’s Peerage and especially this Letter.TC referred to a letter from Capt. Carlisle, now untraced, enclosed with this note (for Capt. Carlisle and his enquiries, see TC to [TAC], 3 [4] Feb.). John A. Carlyle replied, 4 Feb.: “I can at once answer your queries in regard to places connected with the Carlyles in Dumfriesshire.”

Cronington;John wrote: “I have Wood’s corrected edition of Douglas’ Peerage [John Philip Wood (1762–1838; ODNB), reviser and ed. of The Peerage of Scotland by Sir Robert Douglas (1694–1770; ODNB), 6th bart. of Glenbervie (Edinburgh, 1813)], & don’t find Cronington in it. The ‘Cronanton’ &c … is from Nicholas Carlisle.” “‘Cronanton, Molyn, Monykipper, & Rahill’ (Raehills) ‘in the Barony of Kirkmyell’ (Kirkmichael) [Nicholas Carlisle, Collections for a History of the Ancient Family of Carlisle (1822) 80], now belonging to the Duke of Buccleuch, I think.” Farms and estates ca. 13 mi. (21 km.) NE of Dumfries.
Coulyn=Co’lyn?John wrote: “Coulyn & Ruchane=Collin & Roucan.” Collin, village 3½mi. (5.5 km.) E of Dumfries; Roucan, village 3 mi. (5 km.) NE of Dumfries.

BoytathJohn wrote: “Boytath ‘two markland, 1½miles North-west of T[orthorwald] Castle’” (Carlisle, Collections 145 and 167). Torthorwald Castle, 3½mi. (5.5 km.) NE of Dumfries. Boytath, farm 4 mi. (6.5 km.) ENE of Dumfries. Markland was an old Scottish land measurement, based on the value of the merk, a Scottish coin.

Banks (our Ancestor’s,—Son gets “Supplebank” nr Ecclefn)John wrote: “Banks, now called Pearbanks, ‘1½miles South-west of Torthorwald Castle.’” The entry for this in Carlisle, Collections is untraced; however, there is a farm called Pierbanks 1 mi. (1.5 km.) SW of Torthorwald Castle. TC believed that his ancestors had owned Banks for two generations, before moving to Supplebank, farm ½mi. (1 km.) S of Ecclefechan.

Locharthur (where, exactly; & any Carlyle there now?John wrote: “Locharthur, about five miles from Dumfries—I have often been there—in the parish of New Abbey, a mile to the left of the road to Dalbeattie, behind Mabie House, & included now in Mabie estate. Lough very deep water still—‘40 or 50 feet’—neither house nor Carlyles there now.” Loch Arthur, loch 5 mi. (8 km.) SW of Dumfries.

Pettinane (ours first,—never heard of it!)John wrote: “Pettinane, now Pittenain (in Postal Guide) near Lanark.” Pettinain, small village 7 mi. (11 km.) E of Lanark, ca. 50 mi. (80.5 km.) N of Dumfries. There is some evidence that TC’s branch of the family descended from Robert of Pettinain; see TC to [TAC], 3 [4] Feb.

{{Newton Aird (never heard of it either)John wrote: “Newton Aird (now Newtonaird) is on the east side of the cairn (water) opposite the Rontan Brig, Irongray Parish.” Newtonairds, estate 6½mi. (10.5 km.) NW of Dumfries.

{{Shawhill (do)John wrote: “Shawhill, 3 miles from Kilmarnock, in the parish of Riccarton. John [Aitken] will write, & ask if there are any Carlyles there now.” Shawhill, 3 mi. (5 km.) WSW of Kilmarnock, 60 mi. (96.5 km.) WNW of Dumfries.

These two in particr, for this Letter’s sakeJohn wrote: “I keep the letter of Captain Carlisle, & can return it if wanted. Judging by his handwriting, he must be a precise, conceited man like his grandfather Sir Anthony whom I knew.” Capt. Carlisle was the grand-nephew of Sir Anthony; see TC to [TAC], 3 [4] Feb.

Forgotten yesterday, in the hurry! To be attended to quàm primùm.Presumably TC forgot to enclose Capt. Carlisle’s letter to himself in a letter to John, probably dated 2 Feb., now untraced; it probably mentioned Capt. Carlisle and the inquiry about Thomas Carlyle, advocate, to which John replied 3 Feb.; see TC to [TAC], 3 [4] Feb. Quàm primùm: as soon as possible. (3 feby)

div3.sourceNote: TC-[T or AC] [TAC], 3 [4] Feb. MS: NLS 1775C.142; TC’s notes inserted in blue pencil onto John A. Carlyle’s letter to TC, 3 Feb., for Mary Aitken to copy. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 1:46. According to Wilson’s informant, Macleod Stewart, TC dated his letter to Col. T. Carlisle 3 Feb., but the letter must be dated 4 Feb. as John’s letter could not have reached London until the following day, 4 Feb.; for her clean copy, Mary Aitken probably followed the date, 3 Feb., which TC put at the end of the blue pencil notes added to John’s letter. Recipient identified as “Col. T. Carlisle. r.a.” (Royal Artillery) by Wilson. A “T. Carlisle” was made lieut. in 1854 in the 75th foot regiment of the Royal Artillery; he was still a lieut., 1861, and seems unlikely to have gone from lieut. to col. in 9 years; he has not been traced further. Macleod Stewart could have misread the writing on the original letter. Carlisle might be conjecturally identified as Capt. Anthony Carlisle (1829–1905) of the 60th King’s Royal Rifle Corps. John A. Carlyle identified him in his letter, 4 Feb. (that crossed with this letter), as the grandson of Sir Anthony Carlisle (1768–1840: ODNB), surgeon and anatomist (see TC to JAC, 3 Feb., and Carlyle, Reminiscences 290); but Sir Anthony had no sons and no grandsons; Capt. A. Carlisle was the grandson of Sir Anthony’s brother John Hubback Carlisle (1766–1828). TC had written to John A. Carlyle (MS untraced, probably dated 2 Feb.) with questions connected with the letter he had received from Capt. Carlisle (see TC to JAC, 3 Feb.); TC’s inserts, to be copied along with John’s paragraph, were drafted on John’s reply, 3 Feb.
div3.head: TC TO [T. OR ANTHONY CARLISLE]

docBody.p:
[I certainly am not the representative of the late Lord Carlisle. By all evidence that exists, I descend….]Wilson quoted these words in sq. brackets as “beginning” TC’s letter to Capt. Carlisle. The address and date line are also from Wilson. I excerpt for you the following,The quotation marks are by TC, indicating that this paragraph of John’s letter should be copied. “The ‘Thomas Carlyle,’Thomas Carlyle (1803–55; ODNB), Edinburgh advocate and apostle in the Catholic Apostolic Church; see 6:132TC to MAC, 18 Feb. 1832; 29:67TC to JAC, 17 April 1854; and 35:73TC to JN, 13 April 1959. He m., 1826, Frances Wallace, b. Laurie (1808–74). which Captain Carlisle takes to mean you, was ‘born in
1803; a Student of Scotch Law, in 1822,’ as I see by the book ‘of Nicholas Carlisle’;Inserted by TC in quotation marks above the line; Nicholas Carlisle (1771–1847; ODNB), antiquary and librarian, Collections for a History of the Ancient Family of Carlisle (1822). Nicholas was the brother of Sir Anthony and John Hubback Carlisle. & can be none other than the T.C. who used to get letters of yours [i.e., TC’s] long ago both in Edinr & London, & died I think in Germany some years ago, as ‘Apostle’ there. I often heard that he was considered heir of the title of Lord Carlyle;Thomas and Frances Carlyle’s last surviving son, Hildred Edward (ca. 1843–1904), was the last holder of the title Lord Carlyle; see also Wilson, Carlyle 1:42. so that I suppose the ‘John Carlyle of Shawhill’ (Ayrshire) must have died childless.John Carlyle of Shawhill (d. 1821/2) was unmarried. For Shawhill, see TC to JAC, 3 Feb. Perhaps John ‘a Nephew of ours’Inserted by TC in quotation marks above the line. or I may be able to ascertain this, tho’ we don’t know the precise locality of Shawhill. If so, you shall hear of it.” J. A. Ce (The Hill Dumfries 3 febyTC presumably inserted John’s address so that Capt. Carlisle could contact John directly.

[Col. T. Carlisle, R.A.]Addressee information taken from Wilson 1:46. It would seem from Wilson’s introduction to the first sentence extracted from TC’s letter (see above), that TC laid out his line of descent from Robert of Pettinain, 2d son of John Carlyle (d. ca. 1500), 1st Lord Torthorwald; see Wilson, Carlyle 1:43. TC apparently had not heard of the place Pettinain; see TC to JAC, 3 Feb.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 10 [9] Feb. Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N.B. PM: Romsey, 9 Feb. 1870. MS: NLS 527.5. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:263–64 inc. Written on Melchet Court headed notepaper. TC misdated.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
You know that we are here since Saty Evg last; my first bit of writing is to you, that you may hear a little what is happening to us here. Our journey down, escorted by the Lady in person, was perfect; no stoppage till Basingstoke (51 miles); the whole distance, whh is as far as from you to Edinr, done within three hours,—thro’ a country pleast to the eye, and so soon as one was out of London & its anarchies to the mind as well. The happiness of breathing clean air, and tasting divine silence, or rather drinking it in draughts, “like a chapped flute thrown into pure water,”Cf. 13:191. —has not yet ceased to be gratefully
sensible. For the rest, I need not add, our welcome continues to be unsurpassable, or indeed inequallable: Lady & child are alone with us here; the jewels of the house we two, & you know it already for one of the best-appointed, beautiful & solidly resourceful houses in Engld. Surely I ought to be very well; but alas I am not,—for what reason you guess! Sleep hitherto is well nigh unattainable; and these 4 nights especially the last 2, have been the worst I have had since you saw me last. Yesternigh[t]TC omitted “t.” especially was one long misery,—tho’ I had ridden 14 miles on an excellt trotting nag, high and swift, my best ride for many years back.— — Strange enough, I really feel better today than usually in Chelsea after sleep in abundance; good part of whh result I impute to my ride,—and mean to repeat that operatn,TC wrote in his journal, 14 March, about his rides: “I rode twice or thrice; sharp trot of 12 or 10 miles,—twice to Ramsey [probably Romsey], twice towds Salisbury till the City and Cathedral were in view, but it was witht shadow of enjoyt, or of profit traceable: no pleasure now in riding. … How can or shd there be!” (TC’s journal; privately owned). tho’ there is a kind of powdering of snow driving abt (better indeed than do of rain, whh has been pretty continual ever since Sunday).— It is my fixed resolutn not to be impatt, but to try every scheme I can invent to get into sleep, and so utilize this friendly Harbr of Melchet, whh might be now one of my chief resources in the Earth, were sleep but added. Till Saty at soonest I don’t mean to give in. And this all, on the dietetic side, that I had to tell you today.

This morning Emerson’s LetterEmerson wrote, 23 Jan.: “’Tis a sad apology that I have to offer for delays which no apology can retrieve. I received your first letter with pure joy, but in the midst of extreme inefficiency.” He went on to explain that he was supposed to be writing a book (Society and Solitude; see TC to RWE, 24 Feb. as well as various other difficulties. Of TC’s proposed bequest to Harvard, Emerson wrote: “Heartily I delight in your proposed disposition of the books. It has every charm of surprise & nobleness & large affection. The act will deeply gratify a multitude of good men who will see in it your real sympathy with the welfare of the country. … Norton’s letter is perfect on his part, & needs no addition I believe from me. … [A]fter conversation with two or three friends, I had decided that Harvard College was the right beneficiary, as being the mother real or adoptive of a great number of your lovers & readers in America, & because a College is a seat of sentiment and cosmical relations. … I shall then write to Norton at once that I concur with him in the destination of the books to Harvard College, & approve entirely his advices in regard to details.” For TC’s proposed bequest, see TC to JF, 26 May 1869, and TC to CEN, 18 Nov. 1869. at last arrived; satisfactory altogr,—as I think you will judge,John replied, 10 Feb.: “Emerson’s letter is perfectly satisfactory, & unusually warm & affectionate. I should suggest only that a complete set of your own works, Library Edition, might be added to the bequest.” HCC did not include a library edn. of TC’s Works. if you remember Norton’s.TC presumably sent Norton’s letter of 31 Dec. 1869 to John, early Jan. He had sent a copy of it to Emerson; see TC to RWE, 4 Jan. Today is American mail; and I ought to have written both to Emn & Nortn today, but can’t: this is all I will
write, or have done since Friday last. Miss Brly’s Letter also came this morng. Send me both back,—E’s at least is essentl, but no hurry. We are longing to hear that Jean has got safe back,John began his letter: “I write at once to tell you that Jean came back on Monday evening from Liverpool, looking very much better than when she started from home.” and in genl how & what you are all doing.— Ever yr affecte Brr

div3.sourceNote: TC-RWE, 14 Feb. MS: RWEMA, in Mary Aitken’s hand. Pbd: Norton, CE 2:314 inc; Slater, CEC 561–62. Written on Melchet Court headed notepaper.
div3.head: TC TO RALPH WALDO EMERSON

docBody.p: Three days ago I at last received your Letter;Of 23 Jan.; see TC to JAC, 10 [9] Feb. with very great pleasure and thankfulness, as you may suppose. Indeed it is quite strangely interesting to see face to face my old Emerson again, not a feature of him changed, whom I have known all the best part of my life.

I am very glad, withal, to find that you agree completely with Norton and myself in regard to that small Harvard matter. n.b.TC inserted “n.b.” in his own hand. This is not Chelsea, as you perceive, this is a hospitable Mansion in Hampshire; but I expect to be in Chelsea within about a week: once there, I shall immediately dispatch to you one of the three Catalogues I have,For the catalogs, see TC to JAC, 10 Dec. 1869. with a more deliberate Letter than I at present have the means of writing or dictating.

You probably have written to Mr Norton;Emerson wrote to Norton, 23 Feb.: “I had difficulty, hesitations in writing to Carlyle after three years’ silence—so much had I from time to time thought to say to him yet had met his uniformly kindest overtures by brutish silence. … I see no bar to the design [TC’s proposed bequest to Harvard], which is lovely and redeeming in Carlyle, and will make us all affectionate again” (Norton’s Letters 1:340–41). when you do again, fail not to express to him my lively gratitude; as I shall myself take the first good opportunity of doing.

closer.note: TC signed the letter. He noted in his journal, 14 March: “Abt a month ago [5 Feb.], Niece Mary and I went to Melchet; abundt kindness, real affection to us there;—sleep impossible except in fractns; visit whh lasted 16 days, definable as pain and failure. Venables and Richd Doyle, for a 3 days also Tyndall, hearty friends of mine, came down for a meeting; had it, and went;—grateful I to them sincerely—yet it was a little more tolerable to me to be left alone agn, in more dialogue with my own sad memories, and the song of the winter-winds. … Ye Spirits of the Past!” (TC’s journal; privately owned). George Stovin Venables; Richard Doyle (1824–83; ODNB), artist and caricaturist; for a previous meeting between TC and Doyle, see 32:154TC to JWC, 24 May 1857; John Tyndall. The reason for the meeting is not known.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 23 Feb. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: What an Enthusiast my Lady is! We went because we had staid twice the allotted time; and it was necessary to change agn, from one sick side to the other do: in no House in the world was I ever treated with such perfect kindness, and unconquerable patience, under all temptatns to the contrary,—from one whose real place now shd be the Hospital of Incurables.Hospitals for Incurables appeared in the mid-nineteenth century, mainly established in large houses to provide comfort in a domestic environment. Verily so, I assure you, tho’ you never will believe it.

For the rest, the “new side” actually feels its fortnight of furlough; Melchet, I clearly perceive, has done me good, not harm; & good not bodily only: let that be a shadow of reward for yr immensity of trouble!TC wrote in his journal, 14 March: “It was good I gave up Melchet too, as I have done all other Great Houses:—it is the boundless unwearied anxious kindness of the brave lady there that alone drags me to Melchet; but ought even it agn? The mode of life in such places (mode of dieting were there nothing else) is radically incompatible with me: a thing to be avoided; Nature herself says to me (in the shape of physical Pain, annoyance, mournful lonesomeness, & misery of body & mind), ‘Avoid it!’ On the other hand, evidt Benificance of aim and endeavour; affect truly singular (to myself, inexplicable); real wish to have so ugly an object within sight and hearing, &c &c! One fancies there always might, with good will boundless, wealth do, by earnest study and effort, something beneficl be arranged to come of it: but I, for my own part, am reduced to admit that in practical fact, there nearly for certn never can!— My notablest visit was to Broadlands (cidevant Ld Palmerston’s), & our talk there 2 or 3 hours with Hon. W. Cowper & his Wife. A pretty manner; and oh what singular kind of talk! I really was wild of tongue; a barbarous sincerity in me, clean agt polite rule; while Hon. W.
