C. was Tolerance itself, House-of-Commons amenity and ‘hope of the best.’ House-of-Commons Sophistry, that is a curious elemt too, and a copious, and an undesirable,—as I had occasn to reflect!” (TC’s journal; privately owned). William Francis Cowper-Temple (1811–88; ODNB) (later Baron Mount-Temple), politician; M.P. for S Hampshire 1868–80; Lord Palmerston’s step-son, and possibly his illegitimate son, Cowper had added Palmerston’s surname, Temple, to his own, 17 Nov. 1869; Palmerston’s estate Broadlands, which Cowper-Temple inherited, was half a mile (less than a km.) S of Romsey, on the road to Southampton; Melchet, to the W of Romsey, was about 3 mi. (5 km.) from Broadlands. His 2d wife, m. 1848, was Georgina Cowper-Temple, b. Tollemache (1821? —1901), spiritualist and friend of Ruskin’s. TC also knew Cowper-Temple’s nephew Henry Cowper, also an M.P.; see TC to JAC, 1 Jan.— — I had my doubts abt Allinghm after sending him on.William Allingham; Mary Aitken wrote to Lady Ashburton, 23 Feb.: “We are once more back to our own Life at Chelsea; and according to your wish, I gladly take pen in hand to tell you how we, or rather how he has prospered. … When we changed carriages at B.stoke [Basingstoke], we were much surprised to see Allingham, who was looking the picture of uncertainty—but as he at last made up his mind to venture to Melchet, he will already have told you about the mistake of the telegraph people &c. Uncle said to me that if he had known Allingham was coming yesterday he wd have staid till his own visit was over; for he was afraid you wd find him very dull as you did not know him” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). But I am happy to hear it all went so well;
may it be only the beging of better, so long as you are near each other. Allm is a thoroughly transparent creature; simple-hearted, talky and ingenious.

I think sometimes, with a shock of pain, on poor Cross & yr task with him!Joseph Cross (ca. 1831–1918), formerly head gardener at Addiscombe, now at Melchet Court. He was possibly thinking of moving, as he was listed as “Bailliff,” Melchet, in the 1871 census, but he was listed as “Land steward,” East Mellow, Hampshire, in the 1881 census. To be silent, and consider himself into perfect clearness of resolution; in the meanwhile, to do nothingrashly: this is almost the sole advice one cd give him at prest.

I have yet seen nobody whatr; I am still neck-deep, fighting (with far more will than strength) to shove down into its fit gutters the mass of Confused impertinencies and inanities that had accumulated in my 2 weeks of abeyance.Mary Aitken wrote to Lady Ashburton: “As soon as we came here we began to open some fifty or sixty letters, Books, Pamphlets &c &c. They were mostly uninteresting but among them was a large box (a yard long or so). It had arrived on Valentine’s day & had in it a large grey owl made into a pretty hand fire-screen—on a piece of paper pinned to it was written in Brookfield’s hand. / ‘To Wisdom lit with fire divine / Minerva comes as Valentine / “Tu whit tu whoo” he says to you / Your part the wit, & hers to woo.’ He seemed pleased with the little attention & says he thinks the lines are very clever” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). William Henry Brookfield (1809–74; ODNB), clergyman and school inspector, known to TC since 1841. Far from done yet,—ay de mi.

If you know Allingham’s Address, & have a moment of time, you might put that Dublin missiveUnidentified. in a Cover to him, with or witht indicatn whence?— But indeed it isn’t of the least value to me; if you throw it into the fire, ce sera le plusbref [that will be the quickest].
Miss Bromley called a minute ago; seems well to do; and asks much abt the probable time of “Louisa’s” Advent.

Good be with you all, dear Lady, yr little darling MarykinMary Aitken also wrote to Mary Baring, 23 Feb., sending back Mary’s repaired doll: “I send off your little daughter today & she ought to come to you tomorrow. She has been to a distinguished Surgeon and had a pair of new legs. He assured me that none were made without boots which seems to me very strange when none of us are made WITH boots! so I was obliged to choose this pair, which I hope you will not dislike. I feel quite sure however she will be glad to get home to her Mother & little brother even with such limbs as she has. … Sartor pere is pretty well. He was much pleased with your message & sends you a kiss in return. We were both very sorry to leave Melchet on Monday; & my Uncle has seemed very sad ever since” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). & you!

div3.sourceNote: TC-RWE, 24 Feb. MS: RWEMA. Pbd: Norton, CE 2:315–17; Slater, CEC 562–63.
div3.head: TC TO RALPH WALDO EMERSON

docBody.p: At length I have got home from those sumptuous tumults (“Melchet Court” is the Dowr Lady Ashburton’s House, whose late Husband, an estimable friend of mine, and half-American,William Bingham Baring, Lord Ashburton; his mother was Anne Louisa, b. Bingham (d. 1848), of Philadelphia, where Lord Ashburton was born. you may remember here): and I devote to ending of our small Harvard Busss,—small enough, but true and kindly,—the first quiet hour I have.

Yr Copy of the Catalogue, whh accompanies by Book Post of today, is the correctest I cd manage to get done; all the Books mentioned in it I believe to be now here (and indeed, except 5 or 6 tiny articles, have seen them all, in one or other of the 3 rooms where my Books now stand, and where I believe the insignift trifle of “tinies” to be): all these, I can expect, will be punctually attended to, when the time comes, and proceeded with accordg to Norton’s scheme & yours;—and if any more “tinies,” whh I cd not even remember, shd turn up (whh I hardly think there will), these also will class themselves (as Cromwelliana or Fredcana), and be faithfully sent on with the others. For benefit of my Survivors and Representatives here, I retain an exact Copy of the Catalogue now put into yr keeping; so that everything may fall out square betn them and you, when the Time shall arrive.

I mean to conform in every particr to the plan sketched out by Norton & you,—unless, in yr next Letter, you have something other or farther to advise:—and so soon as I hear from you that Harvard accepts my poor widow’s mite of a Bequest, I will proceed to put it down in due form, and so finish this small matter, whh for long years has hovered in my thots as a thing I shd like to do. And so enough for this time.

I meant to write a longish Letter, touching on many other points,—tho’ you see I am reduced to pencil! & “write” with such difficulty (never yet cd learn to “dictate”, tho’ my little Niece here is promptitude itself, and is so swift and legible,—useful here as a cheerful rushlight in this now sombre element, sombre, sad, but also beautiful and tenderly solemn more & more, in whh she bears me company, good little “Mary”!) But, in bar of all such purposes, Publisher Chapman has come in, with Cromwell Engravings & their hindrances, with money accts &c &c; and has not even left me a moment of time, were nothing else needed!

Vol XIV (Cromwell, I)Vol. 14 of the library edn., vol. 1 of Oliver Cromwell’s Letters and Speeches (1870). ought to be at Concord abt as soon as this. In our
Newspaprs I notice yr Book announced, “half of the Essays new”;R. W. Emerson, Society and Solitude (Boston, 1870). The Athenæum reported, 12 Feb.: “The title of Mr. Emerson’s new volume of essays is ‘Society and Solitude.’ The essays are twelve in number, and one half of them are reprints.” Emerson sent TC a copy of the book with the inscription: “To the General in Chief from his Lieutenant, March 1870” (Slater, CEC 49). whh I hope to get quàm primùm, and illuminate some evgs with,—so as nothing else can, in my prest comon mood.
Adieu, dear old Friend. I am & remain

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC, 28 Feb. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: Yr little Story of the Collier’s WidowCorrespondent and the “Collier’s Widow” story unidentified further. is well done; goes to the reader’s heart,—and shews a genial quality in the writer.

I lament to hear of the severe treatt you have undergone, when quite other was expected. Complaint, howr, is useless; good effort, I calculate on yr part, will gradually bring all round agn. Courage, silent diligence, vigilance!—

As to my own bits of writings, I believe there is already an editn (some 5/-a volume) accessible to writing men that really want them; and I am too old and too busy otherwise, to concern myself with editns, & plans of publication,—leaving all that to the Messrs Chapn & Hall, Booksellers, whom I suppose to understand it far better than I.
With many sincere good-wishes, I am truly

div3.sourceNote: TC-CEN, 2 March. Addr: Villa d’Elei (fuori di porta San Gallo) / Firenze / Italy. MS: Houghton. Quot: Ian Campbell, Thomas Carlyle (1974) 144. Envelope addressed by Mary Aitken.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES ELIOT NORTON

docBody.p:
Yr prompt and altogr friendly, gratifying and obliging Letter reached me many weeks ago in due course; & had from me welcome & thanks as few have.See TC to RWE, 4 Jan. It is completely illuminative as to the little Transactn on hand; gives a
most short, clear, and easy road to the result;—and awoke in me the hope and desire that Emerson might confirm it in every particular. As, you probably by this time know, he readily does.

It has been altogr his delay (at length grown nearly unaccountable to me)Emerson wrote to Norton, 23 Feb.: “My part in [the Carlyle] correspondence has been deplorable by delays; his first letter reached me in the worst moment, when the printers were at my door. … Then I wrote him simply to the matter in hand, endorsing all your words. … You & I were to confer & settle on the execution. … I see no bar to the design, which is lovely & redeeming in Carlyle, & will make us all affectionate again. Your own letter to him I found perfect in its instructions, in its feeling & tone. I am now looking daily for a final letter from him on the matter, with his Catalogue, & shall then carry my report to President Eliot” (Norton’s Letters 1:340–41); see also TC to RWE, 14 Feb. Charles William Eliot (1834–1926), president of Harvard Coll. that has delayed my ansr and the expressn of my thanks to you so long: no sign of response had come at the time when yrs, by such a circuit, reached me; nor cd a second message to Concord (inclosing Copy of the beqt part of yrs) bring any response for a great while, or what seemed such: till at last there did, two weeks ago, while I was among country friends in Wiltshire,TC had been staying at Melchet Court, Hampshire, 5–21 Feb.; TC was confused about the county as Melchet was very close to the Hampshire / Wiltshire border. a veritable Emerson Letter appear, redolent of the old time; and explaining everythg,— and also confirming everythg. The poor man had been in birth-throes agn; there couldn’t a word of harshness be used towds him! Last week, on getting home agn, I at once inclosed for him a List of the Books, and said cheerfully, Proceed, proceed! Harvard College is to be warned of the thing by En and another Officl Gentn;Presumably Charles William Eliot. Harvd College is to ansr Yes, yes;—and as for the poor tho’ pious “bequest,” that shall be put on paper at once; and indeed in all essentials is already made, and independt of paper. A second List of the Books, facsimile of the Emerson one, is laid up here, with note of my intentn by it, whh wd itself be suffict to those that come after me. And now, on all hands, Silence, Silence;—and from me thanks to everybody that has encouraged me to dare this little act of piety (symbolical widow’s mite), and testify silently, what in words were not always permitted me, a feeling I have long had. Enough, enough!

You perceive I am reduced to write with a pencil,—disagreeably to myself and others; but with pen it is still worse. For the rest, a perpetual reminiscence to me how excellt is Brevity, the soul of wit!See Hamlet 2:2.— I have still to thank you for that Florence Photoh; everythg from MichelangeloNorton had sent TC a photograph of Michelangelo’s David; see TC to JAC, 6 Jan. bears for me some stamp of greatness; there is a clear prophecy of such in his very face. That
David of his, and the actual bit of old stone-wall behind it, true as the Sun“Sun-picture” was another name for a photograph; see 38:7TC to CGD, 10 Nov. 1861. cd paint it, brings Florence strangely near to me:—as if it had just left its card here!—

A Lady in New York has sent me the other day, a couple of big handsome Voll. (Harvard Memorial Biographies,Harvard Memorial Biographies, ed. Thomas Wentworth Higginson, 2 vols. (Cambridge, MA, 1866–67). The book contains memoirs of 95 graduates and undergraduates of Harvard Coll. who died in the civil war. “Each [memoir] was written, so far as practicable, by the person who seemed best adapted to that particular task, through personal intimacy or kinship” (Harvard Memorial Biographies iv). whh doubtless you know), with a few pretty and affectg words,—to whh I am giving due compliance, namely, reading at least the Biographies she has put a mark to, friends of her own, I suppose. The Biographies are unexceptionably written, too like one another perhaps, but credible, clear; and fill one with reflexns manifold, and emotions manifold. It is probable the Lady herself may be known to you: “Josephine, Shaw, Lowell,”Josephine Shaw Lowell (1843–1905), author, social reformer, and philanthropist; see TC to JSL, 10 March. North Shore, N. Yk; a Niece-in-law or Sister-in-law of yr distingd Poet Friend?James Russell Lowell (1819–91), poet, critic, editor, and diplomat, close friend of Charles Eliot Norton; Josephine was the “niece-in-law” of James Russell Lowell; his nephew, her husband, m. 1863, was Charles Russell Lowell (1835–64).

My health is not quite so troublesome as when I last wrote; but the utmost wariness is always rigorously needed, & the result in genl is smallish,—tho’ as big as cd be looked for at this time of day.— I count always, you will return by London; and that I shall see you agn in this world. Yrs with many regards

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 6 [4] March. MS: NLS 527.6. Hitherto unpbd. TC apparently suspected he had misdated, as he wrote “? ” after “6.” Friday was 4 March.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Unless I write today (tho’ belated and tired), you will get nothing Monday,—whh must not be.

Yr accts of Erskine are a good deal more favble;Erskine had been ill for some time; see TC to TE, 11 Feb. 1869; John A. Carlyle had been in Edinburgh since 15 Feb. and visited Erskine regularly. He wrote, 20 Feb.: “I saw Mr Erskine on the Wednesday [16th] morning, & found him weak & excited by some fixed idea he had taken about himself. … I called also on Dr John Brown, who attends him, & he told me about the same fixed idea which has given him (Dr B.) great uneasiness for some time past.” He then wrote, 24 Feb.: “The ‘fixed idea’ when I saw him was that he had done something on one occasion, which he could not tell to any human being, & which took away all his strength & made him most miserable whenever he thought of it.” He wrote, 27 Feb.: “I did see Erskine on Friday as I expected. … He looked considerably better; had dined at 3, & had just finished tea when I called a few minutes after 7; & spoke to me quite in his old style. Today (Sunday) I have called to ask for him, & heard that he is much better … & considered out of all danger.” I trust the next will continue
so; for whh I shall be thankful.John A. Carlyle replied, 4 [5] March: “Yesterday I saw Erskine for ten minutes. He looked better, was quite composed, but still weak. He goes out daily again in an open cab, & Dr John Brown, whom I also saw, reported him better; but visits still seem burdensome, so I content myself with enquiring daily.” Say everything that is kind to him from me, if you have opportunity. Alas, “old age is dark and unlovely”;Cf. James Macpherson, “Carthon,” The Poems of Ossian (2d. edn., 1765) 201; intro. John Macqueen, “Carthon,” Poems of Ossian (Edinburgh, 1971 [reprint of Edinburgh, 1805 edn.]) 1:346.better perhaps to have one’s discharge when one’s work is done!—

You have called doubtless on other people; any of them that you know me to care for, let me hear of. The innocent rattling Blackie,John Stuart Blackie (1809–95; ODNB; see 43:267), prof. of Greek at Edinburgh Univ. John wrote, 11 March: “On Wednesday I dined with Blackie. He proposed your health after dinner & was warmly seconded by all the company.” poor lonesome feckless David Aitken,Rev. David Aitken’s wife, Eliza, had died recently; see TC to JAC, 12 [11] Nov. 1869. John wrote, 11 March: “David Aitken I saw yesterday & gave him your message; & in return he desired me to send you his best respects.” &c &c. BurtonJohn Hill Burton (1809–81; ODNB), historian and political economist, appointed historiographer-royal of Scotland 1867; see 45:77TC to JHB,10 Dec. 1867. I find to have already spilt himself when here; a vulgar fluffy Dud,—filled with self-conceit; and of a rash ignorance (in Historical matters) whh in a Writer of “History,” the more astonishes me the more I reflect on it! No more of his History Book do I mean to read,TC had been reading the early vols. of Burton’s History of Scotland, from Agricola’s Invasion to the Revolution of 1688, 7 vols. (1867–70); see 45:5TC to JAC, 5 July 1867, and 10TC to JAC, 16 July 1867; the complete work, History of Scotland, from Agricola’s Invasion to the Extinction of the last Jacobite Insurrection, 8 vols., was finally pbd. posthumously, 1890. —unless better accts arrive of him & them!— — If you have not seen Masson,David Masson; see TC to JAC, 28 April 1869. John replied, 4 [5] March: “Last night I went & smoked a pipe with Masson. He is always very kind & cordial, & we get plenty of talk together. … He asked many questions about you, & we had just seen a photograph of the house in which you were born at Ecclefechan. He knows the loose & heartless scribbling which always takes place about noted literary men; & expressed a strong & ardent desire that you yourself would write the biography of your younger years at least. … Such a biography, from your own hand, would save the friends, that may survive you, from a quite terrible amount of pain. I agreed with him very cordially.” I wish you wd call on him; he was kind and punctual abt a certn matter you
know of.Masson was instrumental in helping TC with the bequest of Craigenputtoch to Edinburgh Univ.; see 44:216TC to JF, 16 June 1867. Tell him he must not entirely omit me the next time he comes to London (tho’ I understand his reasons too;—and that I am looking out for his “Book on the Sonship”Unidentified. (he himself knows what I mean) all this while! Item why not go & see the absurdist Bust ever hewn or baked of any man? I mean Mrs D. O. Hill’s of myself;Amelia Robertson Hill, b. Paton (1820–1904; ODNB); her marble bust of TC, completed, 1866, was exhibited at the Royal Scottish Academy, 1867, and at the Royal Academy in London, 1868; see 43:166TC to JWC, [5 and 8 April 1866]. whh Woolner tells me they have fairly voted into some College Museum or Library, as a thing poor I am like,—Goodness help us! It was here in the Exhibitn 2 years ago, & I saw it for an instant, “inextinguisable laughter” its accompanit all round. I suppose there wd be no method, by violence or entreaty, of getting at it with a hammer; braying it to fine powder and scattering on the Water of Leith,Water of Leith, river flowing through Edinburgh to the Firth of Forth. that at least all the Pigs might drink thereof! It is very considerably worse than Watts’s first Picture of me;For some of TC’s reaction to Watts’s painting, see 45:195TC to CPH, 31 Oct. 1868, and TC to MAI, 10 Oct. 1869. This is TC’s only reference to Watts having painted more than one portrait of TC in the same period of time; for the three portraits, see 45:142TC to JAC, 30 May 1868. & that is saying a grt deal.

For the last week or so (tho’ I tremble to brag of it), I am sleeping visibly better:—I sup habitlly this long while on a small portn of brown soup, hot & with a good deal of pepper in it: did you ever try that? Do!— Poor Forster is decidedly ill, “something wrong in the inside,” whh much beats him down & discourages, tho’ the Dr (Quain)Sir Richard Quain (1816–98; ODNB), physician, specializing in heart diseases; see 45:101TC to JF, [2 March 1868]. declares it to be going.— We had no trace of ‘snow’ here; on the contrary, pretty weather, till midnight last,—when a change came, into blusterous E. wind rain, whh still continues. Adieu, dear Brother.— Yr ever affecteT. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JGD, 7 March. Addr: &c &c / Hartlepool. PM: London, 7 March 1870. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. TC’s letter is written on a letter to himself from Douglas; envelope in Mary Aitken’s hand. Pbd: Northern Echo, ca. 10 March, Pall Mall Gazette, 12 March, Dundee Courier, 14 March, Glasgow Herald, 15 March. J. G. Douglas unidentified further.
div3.head: TC TO J. G. DOUGLAS

docBody.p: No, never was; nor a Pot-theist either.Douglas wrote, 5 March: “Certain would be critics of your works in this town and district, amongst whom is a somewhat notable preacher & platform orator, have alleged through the medium of the press and openly in public that you are a pantheist, One of them imputes to you the dogma that the soul of man after death is absorbed into the mysterious essence of God-Nature. Having a profound admiration for your character and respect for your great and honourable reputation and remembering nothing pantheistical in your writings, I should like exceedingly by a line or two from your pen to see these shameless libellers covered with confusion. / Are you a pantheist? ”— For the rest, never mind these poor people. So far as they don’t mean well, the damage is all their own.
docBody.closer: T.C. (7 March, 1870)The Pall Mall Gazette, 12 March, printed a report from the Northern Echo: “A correspondence has for some time been carried forward, in the South Durham Mercury, as to whether Mr Carlyle is a Pantheist. Mr J. G. Douglas, of Hartlepool, having in a private letter called the attention of Mr Carlyle to the public correspondence referred to, and put the question point blank, ‘Are you a Pantheist? ’” It then printed TC’s reply.

div3.sourceNote: TC-FA, 8 March. MS: Harry Ransom Center, Univ. of Texas Lib. Pbd: Frederick Anderson, “The Mask of Cromwell,” English Illustrated Magazine” 14 (Nov. 1895): 115–16.
div3.head: TC TO FREDERICK ANDERSON

docBody.p: If you wd be so good as call on Mr Chapman (Chapman & Hall, 193. Piccadilly) any day after tomorrow, he wd shew you the page on whh the Vignette is to go;TC wanted a picture of Cromwell’s death mask, to be placed at the end of the final vol. of Cromwell (vol. 5), vol. 18 of the library edn. and give you his ideas abt the size & posture of it. After whh (same day, for I am usually here till 3 p.m.) you might call on me, and we cd definitely settle how the matter is to be. If not too riskish & inconvent, it wd be useful that you had with you the actual mask, to shew it to Mr Chn & me.Anderson later recalled his letter from Thomas Woolner, 6 March: “Mr. Carlyle wants a wood-cut beautifully done of the mask of Oliver Cromwell, and as I have a cast from the original, he asked me to get this done for him, as he purposes putting it in his final edition of the Life of Cromwell. … [Y]ou had best communicate with him or his publisher as to the size, etc., if you can conveniently undertake it. I have the mask, and will show it any time you please to call” (Anderson, “The Mask of Cromwell” 115). Anderson then wrote to TC for instructions.

My own idea is, the vignette shd be of the same size, posture &c as the Living Face in Frontispiece to Cromwell vol i:The engraving of Cromwell’s head, “by Francis Holl from a Miniature by Cooper in the possession of the Revd Archdeacon Berners,” was used as the frontispiece of vol. 1 of Cromwell in the library edn. (vol. 14); see Carlyle, Works 6:frontispiece. Francis Holl, engraver; Samuel Cooper (1607/8–72; ODNB), miniature painter; Henry Denny Berners (1769–1852), archdeacon of Suffolk 1816–46, of Woolverstone Park, nr., Ipswich, who had given permission for TC to use this engraving in the 1st edn. of Cromwell; see 19:95TC to EF, 10 July 1985. lately come out. But I wish you, first of all, to call on Mr Woolner (even if you already have the mask), and ask for me his serious advice on all these points: size of the vignette; full-face or ⅔ (like the frontispce)? positn, horizontal or vertical? and any other questn that occurs to yrself. Also the exact dimensions (length and breadth)
of this mask, and the do do of the Common One (whh is bigger, inferior, of whh I have a Copy here);TC had been given a cast of the death mask by John Sterling, probably about 1843; see 31:40TC to [TWO], 2 March 1856, and 32:33TC to RST, 21 Nov. 1856. TC later (1873) gave Woolner’s cast to Charles Eliot Norton, who wrote: “[TC] said he had long had one of the common casts such as may be found in the plaster workmans’ shops, that had been given to him by John Sterling. It had hung in his dressing-room for years, and his associations with it made it more valuable to him than the one that he gave me; but the cast I was to have was far the better, and much the more faithful likeness”; Norton then gave the cast to Harvard Coll. Lib. (1881; William Coolidge Lane, The Carlyle Collection [Cambridge, Mass., 1888] 6) so that it could be with TC’s collection of books there (Norton’s Letters 1:478). and finally the exactest history he can give me of the Mould his mask is taken from,—at least who owns it, & since when.Woolner had apparently acquired the death mask from Paul Garbanati (ca. 1814–77), carver and gilder, and had had seven casts made, one of which he gave to TC, together with a memorandum saying why it was a more authentic likeness than other casts, and describing its provenance; see 31:40TC to [TWO], 2 March 1856. Anderson later wrote: “The mask, in Mr. Woolner’s opinion, must have been the first and only one out of the mould, as it had on its surface the chip-marks where the mould had been chipped away, and as far as I can recollect there was a clear history of it for close on a hundred years. … I carried the mask to Cheyne Row, and Mr. Carlyle viewed it with the utmost reverence, slowly raising his right hand to his skull-cap, and uncovering his head in the presence (as he described) of the veritable mask of the dead Oliver” (“The Mask of Cromwell” 116). The library edn. of Cromwell duly ended with the reproduction of the mask. But all these latter things, matters of fact, he had best put on paper; and can send them hither at his leisure.

This seems to be all I have to specify at prest. Not doubting but you will do yr carefullest on this occasn—and bring out a right Likeness of the Dead Oliver (whh in that case may endure for thousands of years, actually so!)—
I remain / Yrs sincerely / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-AH, 8 March. MS: NLS 3823.220. Pbd: John R. DeBruyn, “Thomas Carlyle and Sir Arthur Helps,” Bulletin of the John Rylands University Library 64 (1982): 426–27.
div3.head: TC TO ARTHUR HELPS

docBody.p:
I can at least best bid you dismiss the “tremmock,”A kind of trepidation; Arthur Helps wrote, 6 Feb.: “I am always rather ‘in a tremmock’ (that is a Hampshire expression) when I send a new work of mine to you. However I take heart, and dare to do it.” or any remnants of it, and change it altogr for a cheerier suitabler feeling: and I ought to have done so sooner,—tho’ in truth yr Letter found me, not here, but on a visit in Wiltshire (Melchet-Court, Lady Ashburton’s); and it was weeks before I cd get hold of CasimirArthur Helps, Casimir Maremma, 2 vols. (1870). himself and fasten on him. After whh all was plain sailing. I
read the Book at a stretch, and with the reverse of difficulty; ready to read as many more of the same sort as you like to try me with: this is a plain matter of fact;—whh sends the “tremmock” clean over the hills.

Casimir, you may depend on it, is a true Helpsian Book. Full of humanity, sincerity, clearness, good-sense and good-nature; beautiful really like the face an ingenuous pretty Child,—and with a trickle of the old queer humr everywhere tinkling thro’ it, such as cd belong only to a head getting gray.Helps replied, 9 March: “You have relieved me from my ‘tremmock’… for I greatly value your good opinion. … It is evident to me that you rather like the book, though you think the author a queer fellow—an opinion which I had some dim notion before now, that you entertained. … I wish you would not talk about a head growing gray. In the first place I deny the fact: there is not enough hair left for anybody to say what colour it is. In the next, it would seem to insinuate that I am growing old, whereas I never felt so young as I do now. My troubles and my sorrows seem to have educed from me some latent juvenility to bear them.” For Helps’s financial troubles, see 45:203TC to JAC, 26 Nov. 1868. It is a strange and to me very taking element, this. Pathetic, sarcastic, cheerfully patient, always full of tenderness, ingenuity and smiling pity.

For the rest, one of the strangest Books (except Realmah)TC read Helps’s novel Realmah (1868), two years before; see 45:105TC to AH, 6 March 1868. that I ever read! And all the more, as it does not, like Realmah, plant itself in any Lacustrine antedeluvian scene and epoch, but quietly presents itself in the streets and drawingrooms of hodiernal London, and goes abt them as if it were quite like other people! Whh it is so amazingly far from being. But I suppose the Author understands his trade, all the same; and do not enter upon this. With his ideas on Colonizatn, and the crying necessity for it just now, I entirely and heartily concur;In Casimir Maremma, Helps’s protagonist echoes his own views about emigration and colonization: “My ideal is … that emigration should be conducted by men whose minds are strongly set upon gaining for the colonies they establish all the benefits of our present civilization, together with some provisions against its dangers. Say that this is Utopian, if you like; I put it only as an ideal” (Casimir Maremma 1:66). For TC’s views on emigration, see TC to JAC, 15 March. —and with regard to that strange Child (strange as any other of them) “the Lady Usefulness”Helps’s character Maggie Lauder, a young woman from the slums of London, is introduced incognita into a grand house, where her sense of practicality and resourcefulness are much admired, and she is given the soubriquet “Lady Usefulness.” will recite only the old Scotch stave she brot, dancing and haha-ing, into my head, from a half-century’s distance:
“A Piper met her gawn to Fife” (not Londn at all!)
“And spier’d what was’t they ca’d her:—
Jog on yr gates, ye blatherskates,
My name is Maggie Lauder!”Cf. “Maggie Lauder” by Francis Sempill (ca. 1617–82; ODNB), Scottish poet.— —
Adieu, dear Helps, with many thanks and good-wishes, and true regards,

div3.sourceNote: TC-JSL, 10 March. MS: Argosy Book Store, New York, NY. Pbd: William Rhinelander Stewart, The Philanthropic Work of Josephine Shaw Lowell (New York, 1911) 50–51; Joan Waugh, Unsentimental Reformer: The Life of Josephine Shaw Lowell (Harvard, 1997) 86 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPHINE SHAW LOWELL

docBody.p: I recd your gentle, kind and beautiful message;Josephine Shaw Lowell wrote to TC from North Shore, New York, 8 Feb., sending him Harvard Memorial Biographies, ed. T. W. Higginson, 2 vols.; see TC to CEN, 2 March. and, in obedience to so touching a command, soft to me as sunlight, or moonlight, but imperative as few cd be, I have read those Lives you marked for me;Lowell marked several names whose biographies she particularly wanted TC to read; both her husband and her brother were among them. with severl of the others; and intend to read the whole before I finish. Many thanks to you for those Volumes & that Note.

It wd need a heart much harder than mine not to recognise the high and noble spirit that dwelt in those young men, their heroic readiness, complete devotedness, their patience, diligence, shining valour & virtue in the cause they saw to be the highest;—while, alas, any difference I may feel on that latter point, only deepens to me the sorrowful and noble tragedy each of their brief Lives is.Lowell wrote: “From the time when they were first printed I have felt that you of all men should see them; you, whom many of the young men whose lives are here told, so loved and honoured; you, who can so entirely appreciate the heroism, devotion and earnestness these young men showed; you, finally, who have so grievously mistaken them and the cause they died for. … Will you accept my wish that you should do justice to such characters, as a slight indication of the respect and affection I feel for you.” W. R. Stewart wrote that TC and Lowell had met earlier in 1870 but that is not established from what TC and Lowell wrote. Stewart continued: “[TC’s] sympathies … were with the South in the Civil War, and Mrs. Lowell, who had several interesting conversations with him about the great Rebellion, thought he did not fully appreciate either the quality or the patriotic motives of the young men who had fought in the armies of the North” (W. R. Stewart, The Philanthropic Work of Josephine Shaw Lowell 49–50). You may believe me, Madam, I wd strew flowers on their graves along with you, and piously bid them, Rest in Hope! It is not doubtful to me that they also have added their mite to what is the eternal Cause of God and man; or that, in circuitous but sure ways, all men, Black & White, will infallibly get their profit of the same.—
With many thanks & regards, dear Madam, I remain,

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 15 March. Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N.B. PM: London, 15 March 1870. MS: NLS 527.7. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Trifling causes have come betn me & writing to you, on Friday and ever since: nor can this poor Line be anythg but a “poor welcome home!” to you, the morng after your arrival.John A. Carlyle had been in Edinburgh for a month; see TC to JAC, 6 [4] March. I hope you are on the road thither, prosperously (well wrapt in woollens, for one thing!), this day; and that a good sleep will be the preface to yr reading what I now try to write. Sunday morning last, when I sallied out, it was into a universe of slobber,—2 inches of snow fallen overnight, and the Sun diligtly thawing it. By noon or 2 p.m. the pavets were all dry; but snow still lay in shady nooks, and is still partially visible (shady side of our bit of Garden, for example); and ever since, with a good deal of wind, it has bn disagreably cold.The Times reported, 14 March: “The bitter north-easterly wind which has prevailed for several weeks past was accompanied yesterday by the heaviest fall of snow in London this season. It began at 2 o’clock, and continued till 6, lying on the ground in many places to the depth of about four inches. The temperature yesterday was considerably milder than on the previous day, and the sun which shone brightly in the morning, soon melted the snow.”

I have not been out of common health & share of sleep, nor am; but, alas, I am useless for all manner of work; do go essentially idle for most part (reading &c even in the forenoon); and instead of remorse abt it, there is a kind of sulking torpid sorrow.TC noted in his journal, 14 March, an impending interview with the woodcutter, Frederick Anderson: “A wretched interview (due within the next half-hour) with a Woodcutter abt Cromwell’s ‘Dead Face,’ intended as vignette to vol. v,—bids me end here. Alas, I feel myself to be the idlest of all mortals; having indeed, in the last months, ceased to profess doing any work beyond that of vegetating in sorry silence, dull expectancy. Ah me, woe’s me!” (TC’s journal; privately owned). For the long entry preceding this about his visit to Melchet and the people he saw there, see TC to JAC, 10 [9] Feb, TC to RWE, 14 Feb., and TC to LLA, 23 Feb. For Frederick Anderson and Cromwell’s death mask, see TC to FA, 8 March. The loss of my writing hand is a very great loss in this respect;—and, alas, the loss more & more of heart and interest in things going on is a still greater!—

We got no hurt of Forster & his dinner,—where were some Irish people (1 man & 2 ladies of his,Possibly Percy Hethrington FitzGerald (1834–1925), Anglo-Irish author, critic, painter, and sculptor, m., 1869, Hon. Dorcas Luisa, b. Skeffington (d. 1876); they were close friends of Forster; see Davies, John Forster 120. The other lady may have been one of Dorcas’s unmarried sisters, Olivia Margaretta Mary (d. 1914) or Florence Cecilia (d. 1906).harmless as possible), and a Daughter of Rt Chambers, nearly the ugliest woman I ever saw (nose nothing but a red blister, &c &c); but shrewd enough; and one of the best Pianists I ever heard, married
to a German mercht here,Nina Lehmann, b. Chambers (b. 1830), pianist, eldest da. of Robert Chambers (1802–71; ODNB), Scottish publisher and writer. She m., 1852, Frederick Augustus Lehmann (1826–91), German-Jewish businessman, b. Hamburg, naturalized British citizen 1858. who is rich, and now in Japan. Qu’il y reste [There it stays],—till wanted!—

I have seen nobody worth mentn,—unless perhaps Sir Geo: Grey (once Govr of New Zealand) who came one evg to renew an old acquaintance, and talk to me abt his grand scheme for universal Colonisatn,Sir George Grey, colonial governor 1841–68; returned to England from New Zealand 1868. He was a passionate advocate of emigration and colonization; see TC to SGG, 25 March. Previous acquaintance with TC untraced. whh I much approve of, and have hope in real tho’ horribly distant.

Yesterday, I questioned OrrWilliam Somerville Orr; see TC to JAC, 3 Nov. 1869. abt the double “Cromwell vol. 1”;—I think you will find 1 of the voll. is for Dr Russell.Vol. 1 of Cromwell, library edn., vol. 14; Dr. James Russell. John A. Carlyle wrote, 18 March: “I forgot to say in my last letter that I found the two copies of Cromwell waiting here on Tuesday, & at once sent off one of them to Dr Russell.”— Adieu, dear Brr; I feel as if you were nearer me agn. May yr Edinr visit have done you good. Yr ever affecteT. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 19 March. MS: NLS 527.8. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:264–65 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Yr two Letters have come. All right;—except that you don’t seenThus in MS, for “send.” Our Canadn Niece Jane’s Address;Jane, da. of their brother Alick in Canada. John A. Carlyle wrote, 20 March: “None of us knows our niece Jane’s address in Canada. Anything sent to her father would of course find her. Her husband’s name is Sims we think, but don’t feel certain, only remembering that Gloucester is his native place.” Her husband was Robert Sims. perhaps don’t know it? JohnProbably John Aitken. sent us some other particrs abt yr Edinr visit, whh were interestg; especially yr Portrait by Kirkpatrick (Scholar become Painter,John replied, 20 March: “Kirkpatrick has two pictures in this year’s exhibition. … For years past he has been asking me to sit to him. … I had some 10 or 12 sittings, & the likeness promises to be both faithful & spirited. Mr K. still teaches, & paints only at leisure hours.” Portrait untraced; Edward Kirkpatrick, living at 5 Picardy Pl., Edinburgh; he exhibited at Royal Scottish Academy Exhibitions 1867–78; unidentified further; portrait untraced. John and TC had tried to find work connected with education for him, early 1865 (see 41:148–49TC to JAC, 16 Jan. 1865); later in 1865, he was working as a private tutor in Edinburgh (see 43:33TC to LLA, 7 Nov. 1865). The references to Sir Charles Sharpe Kirkpatrick’s family are incorrect in both cross references. in whh I wish him every success,
poor fellow!),—the opossum rug is anothr incidt whh I am glad to hear of. The Article will actually be useful to you, who above all others deserved it. I had mine on my knees just once for half an hour; but I suppose it may have cherished Forster’s vital caloric now & then, & served me in that way.John wrote, 18 March: “I sent my opossum rug to Syme on Tuesday night, having asked him beforehand whether such a thing could be of any use to him, & been told by him he would be very glad to have it.” TC was given an opossum rug, autumn 1867, and had intended giving it to John Tyndall (see 45:54TC to HP, 22 Oct. 1867), but apparently gave it instead to John Forster. I have not seen Fr since that night of the dinner; found yesty, in passing, that the cough was still baddish, & that poor Mrs F. was laid up with cold; but that F. still meant to be off next week.

It is very sad & dreary all this that you have to record of poor Erskine’s gliding away from among us, as he seems now to be doing.John A. Carlyle reported, 16 March, his last visit to Erskine: “On Monday afternoon … I had by appointment a short sight of Erskine. He sleeps very often in the day … though only for a few minutes each time; & I was taken into the bedroom while he was asleep, & waited only a minute or two when he awoke, recognised & shook hands with me. … Told me he had no pain in any part, but only extreme weakness, was quite prepared for the change that seemed at hand, & liked to see as much as possible of his old friends. I gave him your message of affection & love, on which he remarked that your relation to each other had been uniformly the same ever since you first knew each other, & he knew what heartfelt truth there was in the message.” The way of all the Earth,—and especially of all us Earth’s Children! Good, pious, loving soul! One cd not wish him to linger on those terms; but the end itself, of such a pilgrimage and such a fellow pilgrim, is sad & solemn to one’s heart. As you hear any tidings, do not fail to impart hitherward.

This Letter inclosed has come from Norton;Charles Eliot Norton’s reply to TC to CEN, 2 March; see TC to RWE, 24 March. pray return it when read. I have not yet got Emerson’s Answer to my last missive along with Catalogue sent him; but I have already marked down (in pencil, pen being so unhandy) the Bequest itself, and shall repoint it beside the already written (two bits of sheets, I think, sealed up long since), so soon as I have added a name or so from Emn’s expected Letter, and adjoined any directn that may be needed. I hope you will find everything clear as can be; and it is to you dear Brother (if you survive me as is natl and desirable)John A. Carlyle died Jan. 1879, two years before TC. that I trust for fulfilling everythg as if I were myself still there. That is truly my thankful feeling at this and all moments. Accept my thanks while I can still give them!— To set my house in order, is surely very becoming, now when I have as it were fairly ceased all working of the old sort. Witht and within all seems to say to me: Be content to cease; thy work is done, and thou art done; cease!

I am still much bothered with the paltry Prints to those poor volumes;
everybody (Chapn eminently to begin with) treating me to his specific negligence & consequt break of promise:—today I am even obliged to walk up to WoolnerThomas Woolner lived at 29 Welbeck St.; TC took Anderson’s drawing of Cromwell; see TC to FA, 20 [19] March. abt some point of the kind.— Adieu, therefore. Jean talked to me abt writing tomorrow; tell her not to forget. Good be with you all. Ever yr affecte

div3.sourceNote: TC-FA [FAN], 20 [19] March. MS: Harry Ransom Center, Univ. of Texas. Pbd: Frederick Anderson, “The Mask of Cromwell,” English Illustrated Magazine 14 (Nov. 1895): 116–18. TC mis-dated; Saturday was 19 March.
div3.head: TC TO FREDERICK ANDERSON

docBody.p: Yr Pencil Drawing deserved Mr Ruskin’s praises, for its force & spirit: yet it is not completely like; the wart quite wrong-placed (close to the eyebrow, shd have been); and in those half-open eyes, something almost horrible to me!Anderson had sent TC his drawing of a Cromwell death mask, made some years previously under instruction from Ruskin, who had praised his work; see Anderson, “The Mask of Cromwell” 116.— With the actual Photogh you will far surpass this—

The very day I saw you, I gave orders that the Cromwell PortraitThe portrait in vol. 1 of Cromwell; see TC to FA, 8 March. shd be sent at once, to save you the trouble of writing at all. I believe it to quite ready (many copies of it already given forth); pray insist on having a copy!

Mr Woolner is quite mistaken as to wart, & yr possibility of putting it in; the wart is not there to give vivacity to the mask, but because it was a feature of Oliver’s Face, and no mask that has it not from Nature can be accepted to engrave from, or be thot worth photohing! Truth, above all things, is indispensable to us.Woolner and Anderson communicated with each other as well as with TC about the placing of the wart. Woolner wrote to Anderson, 19 March, after TC had given him the drawing: “Mr. Carlyle showed me your drawing of Cromwell’s Mask, which is not the least use for your purpose, as the pimple is in the wrong place. By careful examination you will see where it has been broken off, and in case you cannot find it and you will call on me when in my neighbourhood I will show it you; with this print and the likeness by Cooper you will see exactly where to place the pimple. You must not be afraid of making use of me for this purpose as I am anxious the work should be of the apex. … Carlyle gave me charge of your drawing, which I will keep till you call” (Anderson, “The Mask of Cromwell” 116). Anderson commented later: “There was no apparent developed form of a wart or mole on the brow of the mask, and if there had been it would be very slight, and easily destroyed, as it probably was, in removing the mould. … [T]here were several indications where it might have been, and the difficulty was in selecting the right one. Mr. Woolner chose one, Mr. Carlyle another, and I was supposed to select the correct one” (Anderson, “The Mask of Cromwell” 116).

I mean to call on Mr Woolner this very day and settle abt these points: but if I don’t find him you will already understand what the points are, & that they are fixed: a sharply defined mask, fit for photohging,—and that no mask whh has not a wart can be considered fit.

I am sorry there shd be so much bother abt these preliminary matters: but if nobody except you and I will be perfectly strict, it is the more necessary we two shd be so.TC wrote under the engraving of Cromwell’s death mask in the library edn. of Cromwell: “Face of Oliver Cromwell Dead. From a Cast now (1870) in Mr. Woolner the Sculptor’s hands; which is judged, on historical and still more surely on intrinsic technical evidence, to be the first Cast taken, and the Original of all the Casting and Recastings on sale in the statuary shops ever since. Note withal, that there circulates in said shops, for many years back, an altogether spurious Cast,—of roundish, hairy, aggressive aspect,—taken from some bust or bit of sculpture, and without any real resemblance to Cromwell” (Cromwell [1870] 5: end of appendix; vol. 18 of library edn.).
Trusting in yr punctuality / Yrs sincerely

postscript.p: I leave the Drawing (with yr Address on it) at Mr Woolner’s, wishing to shew it him, if we meet as I hope.

div3.sourceNote: TC-RWE, 24 March. MS: RWEMA, in Mary Aitken’s hand, signed by TC. Pbd: Norton, CE 2:320–21; Slater, CEC 565.
div3.head: TC TO RALPH WALDO EMERSON

docBody.p:
The day before yesterday, I heard incidentally of an unfortunate Mail Steamer, bound for America, which had lost its screw or some essential part of it; and so had, instead of carrying its Letters forward to America, been drifting about like a helpless log on the shores of Ireland till some three days ago,The Cunard steamer Samaria left Liverpool, 26 Feb., bound for New York, and was reported missing, 17 March. The Times reported, 22 March: “the Samaria is now in Cork harbour, having been towed in by a steamer which met her about eight miles out of the harbour. The conduct of the captain and the crew is warmly eulogized.” when its Letters and Passengers were taken out, and actually forwarded thither. By industrious calculation, it appears probable to us here that my Letter to you may have been tumbling about in that helpless Steamer, instead of
getting to Concord; where, if so, said Letter cannot now arrive till the lingering of it have created some astonishment there.

I hastily write this, however, to say That a Letter was duly forwarded a few days after yours arrived,—Enclosing the Harvard catalogue, with all necessary etceteras, ‘endorsing’ all your proposals; and signifying that the matter should be authentically completed the instant I should hear from you again.Emerson wrote, 21 March: “On receiving your letter & catalogue I wrote out a little history of the benefaction & carried it, last Tuesday, to President Eliot at Cambridge, who was heartily gratified, & saw everything rightly, & expressed an anxiety … that there should be no moment of delay on our part. … [He] ‘would call a special meeting [of the Corporation] this week to make the communication to them.’ He did so: the meeting was held on Saturday, & I have received this … morning from him enclosed letter & record.” I may add now that the thing is essentially completed,—all signed and put on paper, or all but a word or two, which, for form’s sake, waits the actual arrival of your Letter.

I have never yet received your Book;Society and Solitude; see TC to RWE, 24 Feb. and, if it linger only a few days more, mean to provide myself with a copy such as the Sampson & LowSampson Low, Son & Marston, publishers, Crown Buildings, 188 Fleet St. people have on sale everywhere.
I had from Norton, the other day, a very kind & friendly Letter.
This is all of essential that I had to say. I write in utmost haste. But am always, Dear Emerson,

div3.sourceNote: TC-Sir WSM [WSM], 24 March. MS: Glasgow City Archives. Hitherto unpbd. Sir William Stirling Maxwell (1818–78; ODNB), art historian, book collector, and politician; known to TC since 1848.
div3.head: TC TO SIR WILLIAM STIRLING MAXWELL

docBody.p:
I recd yr beautiful, I might say splendid, Book;Sir William Stirling Maxwell, The Chief Victories of the Emperor Charles the Fifth. Designed by Martin Heemskerck in M.D.LV., and now illustrated with portraits, prints, and notes (London and Edinburgh: privately printed for the Philobiblon Society, 1870). Stirling Maxwell wrote, 21 March: “I have sent you today a book of mine … in which I know your love of portraits will enable you to take some interest.” and am much obliged by that mark of yr kindness. I have been extensively looking thro’ the work; find it everywhere well done; the renewed Old Prints wonderfully lively and exact-looking; the connecting bits of Narrative always lucid, succinct, correct, and entertaining to read:—in short, this is a labour of love perfectly achieved; and
a singular proof of yr piety towards the grt Kaiser,Charles V (1500–58), Holy Roman Emperor 1519–56. —greatest of them all since Barbarossa’sFrederick I, known as Barbarossa (1122–90), Holy Roman Emperor 1155–90. time, and still full of meaning to us moderns.

The Portraits of him (of whh, naturally, I like yr Titian much the best)An engraved portrait of the head and shoulders (in a reverse image from the original portrait) of Charles V by the Dutch engraver Théodorus van Kessel (1620–96), taken from the portrait of Charles V on horseback (1548) by Titian (ca. 1488–1576); Stirling Maxwell reproduced the engraving in The Chief Victories 53. seem to me to have, almost all, an unusual degree of likeness; the essential physiognomy traceable in nearly every one of them;—my model “Charles V” is the Full-Length of him by Titian whh used to be at The Grange in Hampshre,Presumably Titian’s portrait of Charles V seated (1548), as the only other portrait of him by Titian has been in the Museo del Prado since 1821. John Duthy (1771–1834), Sketches of Hampshire (1839), wrote: “As a correct catalogue of the paintings [in The Grange] cannot be given, it may be proper to mention … an original of the Emperor Charles V. by Titian, brought from the Escurial by Sebastiani” (Sketches of Hampshire 10). Horace François Sébastiani de la Porta (1771–1851), French soldier, politician, and diplomat; he fought in the Spanish campaign, 1808–11, and possibly looted the Titian then; he spent a year in Britain after Napoleon’s final defeat, 1815, and was later ambassador to Britain 1835–40. El Escorial, royal palace and monastery near Madrid. TC first visited The Grange in 1844; see 18:198JWC to TC, [11 Sept. 1844]. and whh, after much survey cursory & considerable, for a 20 years or more, got itself fixed into my head, I hope not quite by accidt, as the real Proximum to the ocular Fact.— How well I cd have liked a Portrt of Karl’s Father, of poor mad Juana his mother,Philip (1478–1506), son of Maximilian I (1459–1519; Holy Roman Emperor 1493–1519); his wife, m. 1496, Joanna (1479–1555), queen of Castile 1504–55, and queen of Aragon 1516–55; she was deemed mentally ill and confined to a nunnery from 1506 until her death. of &c &c; for there is no limit to one’s greedy demands!—

Did you ever see Theuerdank, Kaiser Max’s “Epic Poem”?Maximilian I, Theuerdank [Precious Thanks] (Augsburg, 1517), an allegorical account of Maximilian’s journey to his marriage with Mary of Burgundy (1457–82), 1477. Written by Maximilian himself, or possibly by his chaplain Melchior Pfintzing (1481–1535) at his instruction, the book contains 118 woodcuts by various artists. Ruskin has a Copy, folio still perfectly clear and bright,—full of strange and excellt Prints, engraved by Max’s own order, but the Plates of [word obscured on MS] lost for above 300 years, and at length found agn at Gratz in Styria, & published nr a century ago.The woodcuts were rediscovered in Graz, Styria, town and state in Austria, and pbd. in Vienna, 1775, by Joseph Kurzbock. The manuscript was found at Ambras Castle, Innsbruck, 1665. He that cd reproduce those Plates in facsimile, and withal explain the symbolism in whh Max thus veils his Autobiography,—both of whh feats are not now impossible altogr,—wd do a welcome service!— Enough, more than enough of all this.

Ever since Tuesday morng I have had that sad & solemn news in Edinr prest to me. Our good and dear old Erskine gone away from us;Stirling Maxwell wrote, 21 March: “I am grieved to hear from Edinburgh that our dear friend Erskine is departing from amongst us. … He is a man of whom his friends will often think as a type of man uncommon in this world.” clear now of all his weary sufferings, patient sorrows; and at rest forevermore! Amen.— His end wasTC repeated “was” with a line over it at turn of page. perfect peace; his last words, says Dr Brown, were “Lord Jesus!”—whh also pathetically stick to me.John A. Carlyle wrote, 21 March: “You will see by the enclosed note of 11 p.m. last night, from Dr John Brown, that our dear friend Erskine has passed away in peace.” Dr. Brown’s note to John is untraced, but he wrote a similar letter to another friend, 21 March: “Our dear sweet-hearted friend is away. He died very gently last night at a quarter to ten, laid his pathetic weary head on the pillow like a child, and his last words were ‘Lord Jesus’” (William Hanna, ed. Letters of Thomas Erskine of Linlathen [Edinburgh, 1877] 2:345). We shall never look upon his like agn.
Adieu, dear Sir; with many regards to the Lady,Stirling Maxwell’s wife, Lady Anna Maria (ca. 1825–74).Yrs alwaysT. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Sir GG [SGG], 25 March. MS: Auckland Lib. Pbd: W. L. Rees and L. Rees, The Life and Times of Sir George Grey, K.C.B. (1892) 2:449. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:202.
div3.head: TC TO SIR GEORGE GREY

docBody.p: Thursday before yesty, I fell in accidentally with Lord Derby;See TC to JAC, 25 March. and talked a few minutes (all the time we had) abt Emigratn and you. With pleasure to both parties, as seemed to me.

His Lordp is by no means an adherent of the hide-bound Political-Economt system; rather a despiser of it, I shd think; desires warmly that Colonies & Mother-Country shd be kept together by every rational & feasible method; objects strongly to the notion of shovelling-out Paupers & other unfit canaille upon the Colonies; but is “clear for Emigratn,” cd the great difficulties be overcome.

In short, he seemed to me a man well worth yr attending to and investigatg farther; and when I proposed sending you to him for a little conversatn, he at once, and with evidt pleasure, assented; and I really believe desires to hear you explain yrself.Grey believed no “effort had ever been made to help the industrious poor, the labouring classes, to settle upon the waste lands of the Crown beyond the seas. … He proposed that the counties and parishes should become owners of large tracts of territory in the different colonies, that they should settle upon these great estates the redundant labouring population from their respective localities, advancing all monies necessary, and making such monies charges upon the properties of the various emigrants so assisted” (Rees and Rees, Life and Times of Sir George Grey 2:435). How importt the help or countenance of such a Personage
might be at this stage of the affair, I need not suggest: a man of such positn; a man of sense too, of quietly independt judgt, and not suspected of disloyalty of mind or charactr by anybody. I decidedly think it might be worth yr while to go.

Here accordly is my Card inclosed;TC enclosed his card with his message added in ink around the printed “Mr. Carlyle” and above the address: “To the Earl of Derby &c &c / Mr. Carlyle’s Compts/ by Sir George Grey K.C.B / 25 March 1870 / 5. Great Cheyne Row. Chelsea.” —whh please do not take for an impertinence (tho’ probably you know nearly as much of Ld Derby as I), but for a piece of punctuality and sign of willingness on my part,—to be used or not used as you yrself judge fittest. Believe me

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 25 March. MS: NLS 527.9. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: If the right-hand were willg, I wd write oftener; but that is a sad discouragt, and amounts oftenest to a flat prohibitn, involving such as expenditre of time, were there nothing more! I got all yr Notes duly; I will today at least send you back that mournful Note of Dr Brown’s,See TC to WSM, 24 March. whh natlly you wish to preserve as precious. Poor Erskine, dear and good old man; he has now got gently to his Home, leaving us to follow him, one after one; and is at rest forever from all infirmities and sorrows.TC wrote on the envelope of TE to TC, 5 April 1867 (MS: NLS 1769.112): “Sunday 20 March 1870, at 9¾ p.m., Erskine is dead;—Tuesday 22 March. Letter meets my eye; & an hour after comes the woeful news.” The 1867 letter had announced the death of Erskine’s sister, David Paterson, 23 March 1867; see 44:184–86TC to TE, 1 April 1867. TC wrote on the envelope in 1869: “Erskine, a second Sister gone. / (April 1869).” These last words of his, “Lord Jesus!” (pronounced whether as an invocatn or as a pious ejaculatn) will not go out of my mind. Today or yesterday, I think, must be the day of Funeral.Erskine was buried, 28 March, in Monifieth churchyard, nr. Linlathen (Scotsman, 31 March). Amen, amen!—

The other Letter is from Stirling Maxwell; came accompanying ITC wrote “I” instead of “a.” thin splendid wide 4to of Reproduced Prints of and belonging to Kaiser Karl V,—upon whom Stirling has spent no end of trouble, time, and money; with honest
diligence & talent, but witht much chance of bringg any serious man of his time into close or fruitful comunicatn with that great Kr.See TC to Sir WSM, 24 March. I spent my yesty’s daylight hours in looking thro’ the Book; and then shoved it away,—probably for good. It is really well & handsomely done; but to me of no use, or too little. Day before yesterday, to spare myself the expense of writing a Note, and in hope of finding somebody to speak with abt Erskine, I called at Stirling’s House;Stirling Maxwell’s London home was at 10 Upper Grosvenor St., Mayfair. but all were gone out, and the Note itself remained indispensable.

Sunday last MacmillanAlexander Macmillan. came, with one Geikie the Geologist,Sir Archibald Geikie (1835–1924; ODNB), Edinburgh geologist and historian. Geikie was traveling through London on his way to study the volcanic districts of the Lipari Islands in southern Italy. He later wrote: “When the door … was opened by a little housemaid, the philosopher himself was seen standing at the far end of the narrow lobby, looking as if he would rather receive no callers. As soon as he recognised my friend, however, he came forward to meet us. He was wearing a black velvet cap, a grey coat or dressing-gown that reached to his feet, and had a long clay-pipe in his mouth. He … led us upstairs to his drawing-room—a quaint little chamber, with a number of antique pictures on the walls, some of them, perhaps, portraits of Mrs. Carlyle’s forbears, and with old-fashioned nick-nacks dotted over the room. The grate with Dutch tiles up each side of the fireplace, the antique chairs and the various stools were all in excellent harmony, and one could see that some woman’s hand, guided by good taste, had attended to the furnishing of the room. … But the man himself was the chief centre of attraction. He sat between us right in front of the fire. Fortunately he was in the mood to talk, and soon found himself dealing with Daniel Wilson’s recently published biography of Chatterton [see TC to DW, 10 Jan.]. … He looked on Chatterton as one who never seemed to get into the essence and truth of things, but was more taken up with the roll, and the marching, and the trumpet-clang. He passed on to David Gray [1838–61; ODNB], the poor Scottish poet, who, he said, had something in him, but lost himself from the foolish desire to be famous. No one, he thought, has any business to wish to be famous, but should be content to do his own work honestly and well. He enlarged on the ‘jackassery’ of the world in its craving for novels. … [H]e gave us some graphic glimpses of scenes in his own life. He remembered having climbed the Lomond Hills of Fife with Edward Irving, and found the Ordnance Survey sappers at work there, one of them a surly fellow, who at last was fairly won over by Irving’s imperturbable good nature. … I was able to tell him some anecdotes of Ayrshire lairds and clergymen, and had the gratification of evoking from him such peals of laughter as I hardly ever heard before. He seemed sorry when we rose to leave, came down to the door with us, halting two or three times on the staircase to ask questions about the rocks of his native Dumfriesshire” (Archibald Geikie, A Long Life’s Work: An Autobiography [1924] 133–34). a gleg little fellow; both of whom bragged of having met you at Masson’s just before yr leaving. Geikie, as you probably know, is bound for the “Lipari Islands, to study volcanoes,” with an eye to the extinct of these latter that he meets in Scotld: à la bonne heure [well and good]. I think he and a Preacher CousinJohn Cunningham Geikie (1824–1906; ODNB), minister and author; b. in Edinburgh, he moved to Toronto with his family ca. 1835, where he trained as a minister. He returned to Britain, 1860, calling on TC, 9 Dec. 1860; see 37:61TC to JAC, 9 Dec. 1860. He ministered in Sunderland until 1867, then Islington Chapel, London, 1867–73.
he has here must be Sons of two Barbers Geikie, in Nicholson Street once,Archibald Geikie, grandfather of Archibald and John, was a hairdresser and perfumer at 25 Nicholson St., Edinburgh, 1812–34; his sons James (father of Archibald) and Archibald (father of John) worked with him for several years. who used to cut my hair, and were quick intelligt bodies, not unlike this one— I also had an “Emigratn” Sir George GreySir George Grey; see TC to JAC, 15 March. one evg, who was rather entertaining (proprietor of the Houghton “Philobiblon” ignorant Dud that I sent;The Philobiblon Society, a club of rare-book lovers, founded by Richard Monckton Milnes (1809–85; ODNB), 1st Baron Houghton, 1853, disbanded 1884. Grey had contributed a piece to the Society’s Miscellanies vol. 6 (1860–61), and Stirling Maxwell’s book was pbd. for the society, but it is not clear to what TC refers. another day I incidentally fell in with Ld DerbyEdward Henry Stanley (1826–93; ODNB), 15th earl of Derby, politician and diarist, foreign minister 1866–68 and 1874–78, but out of office at this time. for a few minutes,—and have just been sending the said Sir George to him, in hope of forwarding said Emigratn Cause. People urge me to “write” upon it; but I absolutely cannot; did write with all emphasis 20 or 30 years ago;See, for instance, Chartism (1840) and Past and Present (1843). and now have no heart, nor even any head available!—— I fear I shall never be able to manage what Masson & you advise either,To write a biography of himself; see TC to JAC, 6 [4] March 1870. John wrote again, 20 March: “I wish you wd consider what Masson & I suggested about writing a little Biography of your early years. You could do it infinitely better than any one else—say up to the publication of French revolution—biography for the sake of your friends only.” —for the like reasons & others. Thanks, thanks:—but to write my Life wd at any time have been a frightful enterprise to me! Let it lie unknown, till the jackasseries trample it out of memory altogr, and then leave it silent in the silent Eternities.— No Letter from Emerson yet; I suppose yr guess abt it is right. Jas junrJames Aitken Jr. is expected from Lrpool abt 11 p.m. tonight; has busss for a few days, & will lodge here. Tomorrow afternoon Mary & I are to go and see “Natl Portrait Gallery (private view),” in its new lodgt (old Dish-Covers);The National Portrait Gallery had moved from 29 Great George St., Westminster, to the South Kensington Museum, 1869; for TC’s previous use of the term “Dish-Cover,” see 44:26TC to JAF, 2 Aug. 1866. whh makes me write today instead of then. (Here comes Miss Bromley: then Froude!)— Adieu, ye loved ones all. Yrs ever affecteT. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: MA-MH [MP], 28 March. MS: Harry Ransom Center, Univ. of Texas. Hitherto unpbd. Maria Ann Henshaw, b. Price (1839–1910; see 43:biographical notes), JWC’s last protégée. She m., 1868, Henry Henshaw (1845–80), corn merchant; for her visit to TC and Mary Aitken two days before her marriage, see TC to JRID, 12 Nov. 1868.
div3.head: MARY AITKEN TO MARIA HENSHAW

docBody.p: My Uncle duly recd your nice little note & wd himself have answered it; but as you know he much dislikes writing & latterly his hand shakes a good deal, so he has commissioned me to write. I have nearly every day intended to write on my own basis to thank you for the kind Letter you sent me—but what can I say by way of excuse? I have much writing to do & am often stopped in my attempts [at] Letter writing by any straw that lies in my path— My Uncle used often to remark to me that I ought to take for my motto “Never do today, what you can put off till tomorrow!” Your Letter was very kind & I felt much obliged to you for writing it tho’ I did not thank you in words for it.

My Uncle wishes much he could think of any way of helping your Sister to get copying to do.Maria Henshaw had three sisters, Ellen Price (b. ca. 1840), governess, Martha Price (b. ca. 1842), and Mary Price (b. ca. 1844); it was probably one of the two younger sisters who wanted copying work. He himself is writing nothing at all just now—and does not know of any one likely to forward her plans; but if he should by any chance hear of any copying, he will not forget to mention your Sister. He is very glad to hear of your being comfortable & happy in your own home.— He himself is pretty well just now—much better than he was last year. We have been at Chelsea all the time since I last wrote to you except for a fortnight that we were at Melchet (in Hampshire). Our little visit did us much good.TC and Mary Aitken were at Melchet 5–21 Feb.; see TC to CEN, 2 March.

I am my dear Friend writing in utmost haste today—unwilling to miss another day in answering your Note. One of my brothersJames Aitken Jr.; see TC to JAC, 25 March. is here and is going away in a few hours so I am unsettled & very busy. But you will excuse this & I shall write a long Letter one of these days.
With kind Love believe me

div3.sourceNote: MA [MAI]-Sir GG [SGG], 29 March. Pbd: W. L. Rees and L. Rees, The Life and Times of Sir George Grey, K.C.B. (1892) 2:450.
div3.head: MARY AITKEN TO SIR GEORGE GREY

docBody.p: My uncle bids me say he has received your telegram; and you yourself know how heartily he wishes you success in the object you have in view by getting into Parliament.Sir George Grey was standing for the parliamentary seat of Newark-on-Trent in Nottinghamshire, left vacant following the death, 26 Jan., of Edward Denison (1840–70; ODNB), Liberal M.P. and philanthropist. Grey wished to stand as a Liberal, but prime minister Gladstone opposed his candidacy because of Grey’s more radical views on the colonies, emigration, and Home Rule for Ireland. Gladstone later supported Home Rule. For he considers emigration by far the most important question now on foot in England,Grey stood as an independent Liberal, committed to “promoting measures calculated to foster and advance the morality, welfare, and commerce of this vast empire . … [and] opposed to the views of those who advocate the severance of the colonies from Great Britain, believing that they add to her strength, wealth, and glory. In accordance with these opinions, I have striven to initiate a policy of emigration, by which, if conducted under proper conditions, our colonies would be regarded as the natural outlet for our excessive population, and instead of being looked upon as places of exile would be considered … a home and heritage for the people of England” (Rees 2:448). and you of all Englishmen the most likely to bring it to a useful result. But for many years he has been resolved ‘neither to vote nor be voted for, nor in any way to concern himself’ with any Parliament that can now be in England. But I am copying the parts out of his books in which he speaks of emigration,Passages untraced, but presumably some from Chartism and Past and Present; see TC to JAC, 25 March. and shall forward them to you to-morrow. Perhaps you may be able to make some use of them instead of a letter from him, for the thoughts there expressed have in no way changed except always to grow more strong and decided.—

div3.sourceNote: TC-Sir GG [SGG], 30 March. MS: Auckland Lib., in Mary Aitken’s hand, signed by TC. Pbd: W. L. Rees and L. Rees, The Life and Times of Sir George Grey, K.C.B. (1892) 2:451.
div3.head: TC TO SIR GEORGE GREY

docBody.p: Having had, for the last half century, these notions about Emigration;This letter presumably enclosed the passages from TC’s works that Mary Aitken promised to send; see MAI to SGG, 29 March. and believing now, in the days which have come upon us, that the Question of Emigration is the most important of all others for this Nation; and that you of all men are the man to urge and guide it towards a successful issue,—I need not say whether or not I wish you success at Newark against all comers!—

div3.sourceNote: TC-Sir GG [SGG], 1 April. MS: Auckland Lib. Pbd: W. L. Rees and L. Rees, The Life and Times of Sir George Grey, K.C.B. (1892) 2:451.
div3.head: TC TO SIR GEORGE GREY

docBody.p: Send me, with yr first moment of leisure, one word of tidings; so soon as the result comes, do at least let me have that at once.As an independent, Grey’s candidacy was threatening to split the Liberal vote, and lose the seat for the party; therefore a few hours after the poll opened, 1 April, Grey retired from the contest; the seat was won by Samuel Boteler Bristowe (1822–97), lawyer and Liberal politician. The Times reported, 2 April: “Sir George Grey attempted to address the electors in the Corn-exchange, but was refused a hearing, and the meeting terminated amid great uproar. The town became very excited, and large crowds paraded the streets. At the commencement of the polling Mr. Bristowe took the lead, and at 9 o’clock his majority was 19. … The Conservatives now came more freely to the poll, and at 11 o’clock Mr. Sleigh was in a majority of seven over Mr. Bristowe. … Shortly afterwards Mr. Bristowe announced from the window of his committee-room that Sir George Grey had retired, and called upon the Liberal electors to support him, and not disgrace the town by returning a Tory.” I see no Newspr almost ever; and am more interested in this one Membership (as matters have come to stand) than in all the other 657!There were 658 M.P.s at this time. Hoping good news,

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC, 1 April. Pbd: Poet-Lore 3 (1891): 48–49.
div3.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: Your letter manifests a great deal of good will to me; for which I am much obliged. It also bespeaks in yourself an amiable and honorable disposition, and a stock of natural faculties and aspirations, which, if well cultivated and wisely guided, may turn to excellent account for you in life.

I by no means advise you to look towards ‘Literature’ as a goal! I do advise you to continue seriously devoting all your leisure hours to acquirement of solid knowledge and clearer and clearer understanding of yourself and of the world that is about you; if, in the course of years, you should clearly feel yourself to have attained some real wisdom of Conduct and Thinking, and then to have actually something to say, there can be no harm whatever in your saying it by any honest method; but probably also there may be little or no advantage (to yourself, above all); and it is dangerous to count as certain that such a result (the one real sanction for literary enterprise) will arrive in one’s own case while still undecided! It is true, multitudes of persons do rush into Newspaper and other Literature without the shadow of any such ‘sanction’; but their life, accordingly, turns out to be miserable, mad, and despicable, almost beyond that of any other class of men I know! You may believe me, an honest, rational, and really good printer’s course of life offers far more capabilities in the world at present;In the introduction to the letter the editor wrote: “His correspondent, with much temerity, had asked his advice concerning the pursuit of journalism in lieu of the printer’s craft, and the advice given … in this instance followed for a time at least” (Poet-Lore 48). especially in the British world, with its many colonies, etc., etc.
Be wise, be steadfast, modest, diligent, you will infallibly arrive at something good,—and if it be a quiet thing instead of a noisy, think yourself all the luckier! Wishing you heartily well,

div3.sourceNote: TC-HB [HBO], 2 April. Pbd: Scotsman, 5 April. Henry Bowie (1812–85), secretary and treasurer of the Edinburgh Philosophical Institution, 1847–85. TC was elected president for life 1868; see TC to HBO, 10 Aug. 1868.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY BOWIE

docBody.p: I received with welcome the notice that your annual meeting has again elected me president, and I am much obliged by that testimony of their kindness and continued regard. Sorry only that I can be to them little or nothing more than the name of a president, capable of no real service:—for good wishes, I doubt always, must count as an imaginary thing! Please to return my thanks to all parties concerned; and doubt not, if I come again to Edinburgh, I will at least try to see your locality, which to me in a sense may really be considered the “house of a friend.”— I am, &c. T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 2 April. MS: NLS 527.10. Pbd: A. Carlyle NL 2:265–266 inc. Quot: Sanders, CF 2:218; Letters of Alfred Lord Tennyson, ed. Cecil Y. Lang and Edgar F. Shannon Jr. (Oxford, 1987) 2:545.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I hope you are getting as good a day for yr journeyJohn A. Carlyle was going to visit the Russells at Holmhill for the afternoon; he reported, 3 April, that Dr. James and Mary Russell were well, as was Alicia Ewart whom he and Dr. Russell also called on. as we have here,—our first really bright day for almost a fortnight past; and this too was dirty yellow fog till abt 11 o’clock!—

I had a second night of insomnia, and a weary walk yesty, seeking out Alfred Tennyson’s London lodging,Tennyson was staying in London, address unidentified. —upon whom I felt bound to “leave a card”; he having called here last sunday on very good-natured terms, and borne me do compy on my walk.Tennyson wrote to his wife, Emily Tennyson [28 March]: “Carlyle could not see us at night being poorly but I walked with him in the morning instead” (Letters of Alfred Lord Tennyson 2:545). Good-natured, almost kind; but rather dull to me! He looks healthy yet, and hopeful; a stout man of 60,—with only one deep wrinkle, crow wrinkle just under the cheek bones.— I was lucky enough (for my then mood, lucky) to find nobody; nothing required but a card.

Emerson’s clever little Book I finished, night before last; and now send,Society and Solitude; see TC to RWE, 24 Feb. John A. Carlyle wrote, 1 April: “I should like to see that book of Emerson you speak of, whenever you have got quite done with it.”—
having judicsly eschewed lending it elsewhither. You will find it a high, radiant & searching kind of thing; but in genl much too ideal and unpractical and impracticable,—totally neglecting the frightful amount of Friction and perverse Impedimt, perverse but insuperable, whh attends every one of us in this world!— — I fancy my Letter & message to him must have gone the way you guessed. If so, a Note I sent since will explain the delay to him.

Please send me Paterson’s Letter back;James Erskine Paterson, Thomas Erskine’s nephew. He wrote to TC, 1 April: “Knowing the more than common regard my Uncle had for you—& the interest which you took in him—I desired a copy of the Scotsman—containing a sketch by Principal Shairp—to be sent to you. … Your kind brother saw him as you are aware near the end. … I believe your brother recd his last message for you”; for John A. Carlyle’s last visit to Erskine and the latter’s last message to TC, see TC to JAC, 19 March. I ought, if I cd, to write him some kind of Ansr. Who is “Principal Shairp”?John Campbell Shairp (1819–85; ODNB), literary scholar, principal of the United College at St. Andrews. TC had met Shairp when he stayed with Erskine in Edinburgh for his rectorial address, April 1866; see 43:158–59TC to JWC, 3 April 1866. The Scotsman, 31 March, printed Shairp’s obituary of Erskine, which included mention of TC: “It will be remembered that a few years ago, when Mr Carlyle revisited Edinburgh, after many years, to be installed as Rector of the University, he was the guest of Mr Erskine, his old and much-loved friend. With what wise and gracious courtesy did he then perform the duties of hospitality, on the one hand securing for his guest the repose he needed and desired, on the other according to as many as possible the much-desired privilege of meeting the sage of Chelsea!” I recd a third Copy of that Scotsman notice,John had also sent him the clipping from the Scotsman. this morning; Copy from poor old Betty;Betty Braid, whom Erskine had often visited; see TC to BB, 14 July 1869. whh was altogr touching to me.
