I sent that one to Tom in Canada,Their brother Alexander’s son. not liking to burn it.— My love to Jean & everybody. Yr affecte

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], [4 April]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by TC’s tooth extraction, 5 April; he apparently saw the dentist first on Mon., 4 April, and returned the next day for the successful extraction; see TC to JAC, 13 April.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Alas, alas, I shall miss you agn today; I am bound (as you see by the other leaf of this) to a dental Artist,Dentist unidentified further; the other half of the page has been torn off. at an hour’s distance,—and shall lose a tooth &c by way of consolatn!— —

I expect he will leave me time to call at 9ALady Ashburton was staying with her friend Margaret Coutts Trotter (ca. 1811–82; see 45:102TC to LLA, 3 March 1868) at 9A Upper Brook St. abt 4; and if I can find you will drive with you anywhither for one hour.
Failing all that, I will call tomorrow (Tuesday) betn 4 & 5 p.m.

closer.salute: Yrs ever (afflicted, as all sinners are)

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A, [LLA] 5 April]. Addr: 9A. Upper Brook Street. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by TC to LLA, [4 April].
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I am making ready to accompany, this afternoon,—lest I don’t see you agn at all!
Shall expect you to pick me up here at 4½ p.m.

div3.sourceNote: TC-RWE, 6 April. MS: RWEMA. Pbd: Slater, CEC 565–67.
div3.head: TC TO RALPH WALDO EMERSON

docBody.p:
The day before yesty yr welcome Letter came to hand with the welcome news in it;Harvard’s acceptance of TC’s offer of a bequest; see TC to RWE, 24 March. yesty I put into my poor Documt here the few words still needed; locked everything into its still repository (yr Letter, Presidt Eliot’s, Norton’s, &c &c); and walked out into the sunshine, piously thankful that a poor little whim, whh had long lain fondly in my heart, had realized itself with an emphasis I cd never hope, and was become (thanks to generous enthusiasm on New Engld’s part) a beautiful little fact, lying done there, so far as I had to do with it. Truly yr acct of matters threw a glow of life into my thots whh is very rare there now; altogether a gratifying little Transactn to me,—and I must add a surprising, for the enthusiasm of good-will is evidtly great, and the occasion is almost infinitesimally small! Well, well; it is all finished off and completed,—(you can tell Mr Eliot, with many thanks from me, that I did introduce the proper style, “Presidt and Fellows,” &c, and have forgotten nothing of what he said, or of what he did);—and so we will say only, Faustum sit [may
it turn out well], as our last word on the subject;—and to me it will be, for some days yet, under these vernal skies, something that is itself connected with the Spring in a still higher sense; a little white and red-lipped bit of Daisy pure and poor, scattered into Time’s Seedfield,Cf. Goethe, “Die Zeit ist mein Besitz, mein Acker ist die Zeit,” West-östlicher Divan (Goethe, Werke 5:55); see Chartism, Carlyle, Works 29:193. and struggling above ground there, uttering its bit of prophecy withal, among the ox-hoofs and big jungles that are everywhere abt and not prophetic of much!—

One thing only I regret, that you have spoken of the affair!Emerson wrote, 21 March: “It is very amiable & noble in you to have kept this surprise for us in your older days. Did you mean to show us that you could not be old, but immortally young? & having kept us all murmuring at your Satires & sharp homilies, will now melt us with this manly & heartwarming embrace? Nobody could predict & none could better it. And you shall even go your own gait henceforward with a blessing from us all, & a trust exceptional & unique. I do not longer hesitate to talk to such good men as I see of this gift, & it has in every ear a gladdening effect. People like to see character in a gift, & from rare character the gift is more precious.” For God’s sake don’t; and those kindly people to whom you have,—swear them to silence for love of me! The poor little Daisykin will get into the Newsprs, and become the nastiest of Cabbages:—silence, silence, I do beg of you to the utmost stretch of yr power! Or is the case already irremediable? I will hope not. Talk about such things, especially Penny Editor’s talk, is like vile coal-smoke filling yr poor little world; silence alone is azure, and has a sky to it.—— But, enough now.

The “little Book”Society and Solitude. never came; and, I doubt, never will: it is a fate that seems to await three fourths of the Books that attempt to reach me by the American Post; owing to some informality in wrapping (I have heard);—it never gave me any notable regret till now. Howr, I had already bot myself an English copy, rather gaudy little volume (probably intended for the railways, as if it were a Book to be read there), but perfectly printed, ready to be read anywhere by the open eye and earnest mind;—whh I read here, accordingly, with great attentn, clear assent for most part, and admiring recognitn. It seems to me you are all yr old self here, and something more. A calm insight, piercing to the very centre; a beautiful sympathy, a beautiful epic humour; a soul peaceably irrefragable in this loud-jangling world, of whh it sees the ugliness, but notices only the huge new opulences (still so anarchic); knows the electric telegraph, with all its vulgar botheratns and impertinences, accurately for what it is, and do do the oldest eternal Theologies of men. All this belongs to the Highest Class of thot (you may depend upon it); and agn seemed to me as, in several respects, the one perfectly human voice I had heard among my fellow-creatures for a long time. And then the “style,”
the treatt and expressn,—yes, it is inimitable, best-Emersonian thro’out. Such brevity, simplicity, softness, homely grace; with such a penetrating meaning, soft enough, but irresistible, going down to the depths and up to the heights, as silent electricity goes. You have done very well; and many will know it even better by degrees.— Only one thing farther I will note: How you go as if altogr on the “Over-Soul,” the Ideal, the Perfect or Universal & Eternal in this Life of ours; and take so little heed of the frightful quantities of friction and perverse impediment there everywhere are; the reflections upon whh in my own poor life made me now & then very sad, as I read you. Ah me, ah me; what a vista it is, mournful, beautiful, unfathomable as Eternity itself, these last 50 years of Time to me!—

Let me not forget to thank you for that fourth page of yr Note; I shd say it was almost the most interestg of all, News from yrself at first hand; a momentary glimpse into the actl Household at Concord, face to face, as in years of old! True, I get vague news of you from time to time; but what are these in comparison?— If you will, at the eleventh hour, turn over a new leaf, and write me Letters agn,Emerson wrote on the last page of his letter, 21 March: “I think I must mend myself by reclaiming my old right to send you letters. I doubt not I shall have much to tell you, could I overcome the hesitation to attempt a reasonable letter. … I shall have to prate of my daughters—Edith Forbes [b. 1841], with her two children at Milton; Ellen Emerson [b. 1839] at home, herself a godsend to this house day by day; & my son Edward [1844–1930] studying medicine in Boston,—whom I have ever meant & still mean to send that he may see your face when that professional curriculum winds up.” —but I doubt you won’t. And yet were it not worth while, think you? Nνξ ερχεται [the night cometh],Cf. John 9.4. —will be here anon.—— My kindest regards to yr Wife.Emerson’s wife, m. 1835, was Lydia, b. Jackson (1802–92). Adieu, my ever-kind Old Friend.

closer.note: TC wrote on Emerson’s letter: “Emerson’s 2d Letter abt Harvard recd, April 4th 1870.” He wrote in his journal, 8 April: “Despatched yesty my final letter to Emerson on that Affair of the Harvard Books,—comfortable ultimatum of that. Bequest &c all that to the last verbal insertions had been written weeks before, ‘Catalogue’ done & despatched months before, original plan or purpose first hinted almost a year ago;—long drawn wearisome haggle of consultns, preliminaries, & paltry little preparatns: but it is now all done, has much pleased Harvard, Emerson & New Engld (astonishgly much, such a day of small things! [Cf. Zech. 4.10])—and is now out of my hands, & into those of others that follow after me. For whh I feel thankful: one little thing handsomely finished to my mind of whim” (TC’s journal; privately owned).

div3.sourceNote: TC-DD, 7 April. Addr: (in Mary Aitken’s hand) Woodcroft / Edinburgh. MS: Montague Collection, New York Public Lib. Pbd: David Davidson, Memories of a Long Life (Edinburgh, 1890) 322–23. David Davidson (1811–1900), army engineer and inventor.
div3.head: TC TO DAVID DAVIDSON

docBody.p: Yr letter awakens many thots in me whh are very mournful, yet also very beautiful, tender and solemn.Davidson later wrote: “Not long after Thomas Erskine’s death, some unknown person … sent me … notes, written from the lips of the dying saint. … The original of these notes I immediately enclosed to Mr. Carlyle, with a few hurried lines, in which I told him of my last meeting with Thomas Erskine” (Memories of a Long Life 321). Indeed yr mere signature, at any time, wd do that!Davidson had been a childhood friend of JWC’s in Haddington; see 35:36JWC to DD, 14 Feb. 1859.

I much esteemed and loved the now departed Thomas Erskine for the pious, lucid and loving character whh always shone in him; and for the ingenuous, simple, pure and cheerfully devout Life he led,—everpatient amid so many sufferings & impedimts: tho a Nathaniel indeed, in whom there was found no guile!Cf. John 1.47.—

In a Note of Dr John Brown’s to my Brother I observed, and ever since remember, that the last words he was heard to utter were “Lord Jesus.”See TC to WSM, 24 March. His end appears to have been perfectly peaceable; such as his kindest friends cd have wished for him, now that the great hour was come.

One of the most touching latter things to me in Mr Erskine was the constant regard he had to poor “Old Betty,” whom you may remember young as a Servt at Haddington: the good Erskine seemed to have taken on him as a bequest the love that was felt for her here: he had a high and real respect for the character of Betty, and never long failed to drive out to her poor Cottage at Green End, and see the really venerable sister woman for a while.JWC and Erskine were also longstanding friends, and Erskine visited Betty Braid for JWC’s sake when he was in Edinburgh; see 43:222TC to TE, 1 May 1866. TC wrote about Erskine in his journal, 8 April: “On Sunday 20 March 9.40 p.m., Thomas Erskine, nearly my last Scottish friend (except my own Kindred), died; weary and heavy-laden, but patt, true & revtly peaceable to the very last. Another of my few last-links severed: Abt whh, & whom, the flutter to me had not yet ceased, witht or within. Night before last [6 Sept.], just as I was falling asleep, visn of him, in Princes Strt, as if face to face; clear discernt of what a pure and beautiful & brotherly soul he had been, and that he too was away forevr,—whh at once awoke me agn, usefully for some minutes. / Have been for a fortnight past below par in health and still am; puddle of that sort, whh lay in store; no avoiding it, it much augments my heart-sorrows too; shakes the nerves into shivering, I suppose: but now perhaps, in the good weather, will subside. Four years all but 13 days I have stood contemplatg my calamity. ‘Time’ was to bring relief, said everybody: but Time has not to any extent;—nor in truth did much wish him—no” (TC’s journal; privately owned. Froude, Carlyle 4:392 inc). From
Betty herself I got a poor old Edinr Newspapr with some obituary Notice of him in it;See TC to JAC, 2 April. addressed in her poor old hands, one of the most pathetic things to me.

Adieu, dear Sir: I am surely much obliged by this Letter; by yr evidtly kind feelings and intentns towards me in sending it. I will beg you to remember me a little, & you are safe to do it kindly, always while I continue here. With you too may all things, temporal & eternal, go ever well.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 13 April. Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N.B. PM: London, 13 April 1870. MS: NLS 527.11. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Yr Letter, whh I am very glad to see, has just come (Wedny 2 p.m.) I meant to write Saty last, as well as on previous days,—“Saty for certn!”—but found agn that, for impedts & impotences, I cdn’t! Whh vexed me considly. The truth, all last week and the previous one, I was on the sleepless tack agn; also had a considerable creeping dose of cold upon me, face-ache, toothache superadded, and felt a good deal stranded. All this is now clearly on the mending hand; weather become dry and genial;—catarrhal feeling shrunk withn limits, sleep tolerably come back, nothing but dyspepsia (in the form of languour, total indolence & nausea) to complain of, and no ache but the natural heartache whh I cannot hope to forego!— Tuesday gone a week, after one of my bad nights, I went vehemently up to the Dentist’s, and had a big eye-tooth wrenched out (à deux reprises [on the second try]); whh, alas, I think is the principal feat I have done since you heard last! The tooth was perfectly sound, only the sheath abt the root of it was unsound (part of my old “gum boils” I used to have in my last Friedrh years),See, for example, 42:11TC to JAC, 5 May 1865. and the cold weather had struck into it, favd by the bile one always has. Poor old tooth, it must have stuck above 60 years in its place, doing duly whenr called on; I was rather sorry it had not staid till we all went together!—

This roaring London has got very loud agn; and interferes a little even with me & my poor evgs,—tho’ I cannot say it contains almost anything I care
much abt! Sir G. Grey (Ex-Govr, in New Zeald &c &c) has come home abt “Emigratn,”See TC to JAC, 15 March, and TC to Sir GG, 25 March. and I believe or hope will stir up all the country on that enterprize, and force “The People’s Willm” to give up his insane course of cutting all the Colonies loose and mistinkering wretched Ireland into new madness & habit of murder!William Gladstone, prime minister; the nickname had been given to him by the Daily Telegraph. Gladstone’s colonial policy was not so extreme as TC seemed to think, and his current Irish policies, disestablishing the Anglican Church and enacting land reform, were less radical than those of Grey, who advocated “a State Legislature, sitting in Dublin, composed of two elective Houses—a House of Representatives and a Senate, and having the same legislative powers as a State Legislature in the United States of America” (W. L. Rees and L. Rees, The Life and Times of Sir George Grey, K.C.B. (1892) 2:443). See also MAI to SGG, 29 March. Sir Ge is a clever pleast man; & I thoro’ly approve what he is abt,—but do not retain any vivid interest in it when left to myself; I myself feeling to have done with it, and with all similar things. Froude is going to Vienna, to the Archives there, abt Ann Boleyn’s case;In an Appendix to a new edn. of his History of England vol. 2 (1870), covering the trial and death of Anne Boleyn (ca. 1500–36; ODNB), Froude explained: “Anne Boleyn was divorced as well as executed, and the cause of the divorce was left a mystery. … The English records being silent on these points, it became an object to learn what the foreign ambassadors resident at the English Court had to say about them” (601). Froude had recently learned that the letters and papers of Eustace Chapuys (ca. 1490–1556), imperial ambassador to England, 1529–45, for Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor, were in the Austrian archives in Vienna: “The collection contains not Chapuys’s correspondence only, but Queen Catherine’s and Princess Mary’s, all of it of the very deepest interest, and throwing light from all sides on the great questions with which England was agitated” (602). Queen Katherine (1485–1536; ODNB) was the aunt of Charles V, so he was particularly interested in the events of the time. Princess Mary (1516–58; ODNB), da. of Katherine and Henry VIII (1491–1547; ODNB), king of England and Ireland. expects to return within 3 weeks. Last night, Peter Swan of Kirkcaldy stumbled in; dreadfully fat, tho’ good and kind,—poor old fellow, he has lost all his Brothers & kindred;Patrick Don Swan (1808–89; see 45:144TC to PDS, 2 June 1868), known to family and friends as Peter, provost of Kirkcaldy 1841–46 and 1860–86. One of eight children, his only sister, Sophia (b. 1810) and three youngest brothers, David (b. 1815), Robert (b. 1817), and James (b. 1819), all d. in childhood; his remaining brothers, Thomas (1811–40), William (1812–59), and Alexander (1814–67) were all now dead, as were both his parents, William Swan (d. 1833) and Margaret, b. Hutchison (d. 1855); he was unmarried (see L. Macbean, Patrick Don Swan, Provost of Kirkcaldy, 1841–86 [Kirkcaldy, 1893]). is very opulent in money, but poor in all things else; fallen so lonely in the world. Tonight (much more oppressive, but not evitable) Mme Venturi with a Southn AmericanEmilie Venturi; American friend unidentified further; presumably from the southern states of U.S. are coming; tomorrow Darwin & Mrs Wedgwd;Erasmus Darwin (1804–81), friend of the Carlyles since 1835; see 44:76TC to FW, 22 Oct. 1866. Frances Wedgwood, b. Mackintosh (1800–98); she and her husband, Hensleigh Wedgwood (1803–91; ODNB), were old friends of the Carlyles; see 9:106–7TC to HWE, 11 Dec. 1836. Hensleigh Wedgwood and Erasmus Darwin were cousins.—& so
it tumbles on! Yesty Ly Ashburtn carried Mary & me on a fine sunny drive Norwood-Dulwih way; & is now gone Eastering!Easter Sunday was 17 April.— — Thank Jean for her Note; write agn soon. Every yr affecteT. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[FA], 13 April. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO [FREDERICK ANDERSON]

docBody.p: I expected long before this to have seen yr preliminary PhotohSee TC to FA, 20 [19] March. of Cromwell’s mask; but it still does not come. I hope & trust you are not neglecting the affair! But it wd surely be safe to let me have sight of the Photoh before you begin cutting. To save time you might send it by post (if yrself satisfied with it); I cd then answer, either “All right,” or what else might be expedt.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 22 April. MS: NLS 527.12. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I return the 2 Canada Letters, whh are welcome & bring favble news. Is not that “20 dollars” (or abt £5) a rather poor wage for A’s son John, who has skill in Frame-building? Wdn’t it be worth while, so long as we are both alive to make some Gift & help into a Farm of his own?John Carlyle, second son of their brother Alexander in Canada. John A. Carlyle replied, 24 April: “Young John’s wage of 20 dollars amounts only to four guineas at most, but his Frame-building is probably a very healthy occupation & the wage is of little importance, & he will get some wholesome experience. It may be well, as you say, to endeavour to get him into some farm as soon as possible after his time is out.” I wish you wd consider this, and having come to a clear conclusn, speak to me.— I have ever since I asked you abt his “Jane’s” name,See TC to JAC, 19 March. abt making Tom & her each a Gift (whh wd avoid exceptionalities in what they will inherit from me:—but I am so utterly lamed and useless, I have yet done nothing in it; and cannot yet fix upon the sum. £500 apiece? Tell me candidly what you think.John replied: “Last week I thought of sending some remittance to Alick himself to distribute as he found best, but could not fix on the exact sum. The £500 for Tom & £500 for Jane would be enough, I think for the purpose you speak of; but of course you must decide for yourself in such a matter.”

A 3d “Canada Letter,” from a Son of Half Brr John’s,Their half-brother, John Carlyle (see TC to JAC, 9 Feb. 1869, and TC to JAC, 15 April 1869) had three sons, John, James, and William; it is not clear which one TC refers to; John and William were both married with children; William had visited TC, Aug. 1864 (see 40:182TC to JWC, 12 Aug. 1864). whh gave me no pleasure, & seemed rather to indicate a kind of forward (blue pencil done!)Up to this point, the letter was written in blue pencil; from here until “Emerson’s Letter,” TC wrote in red pencil and then reverted to blue. fellow, is also inclosed; you need not return it. We have made no ansr, nor perhaps shall make any.John A. Carlyle replied: “I should say that free & easy & ungrammatical letter of our half-brother John’s son need not be answered at all. Of course he means no ill, & is quite unconscious of any impropriety in writing such a letter, but he is clearly a man one would get no good of seeing.” Certainly I don’t design much any “visit” of the sort proposed,—tho’ the silly creature shd be welcome to his board & lodging here, provided he found us from home, as I hope he will at that roasting season of the year! Emerson’s Letter is merely in answer to the Note I had despatched à propos of that helmless belated Steamer whh I feared mt have been the first undertaker of my previous Letter, and so have been keeping Emerson waiting. Was it so, think you.See TC to RWE, 24 March. John replied: “I don’t think your letter to him could have gone by that disabled steamer. … You could not have got his first reply so soon, if your letter had been delayed so long.”

The 5th Letter has just come from Adamson’s and you see what heap of fash it throws on yr punctuality. I depend altogether on yr looking into everythg till you see thro’ it.Samuel Adamson, TC’s banker in Dumfries; see TC to JAC, 6 May 1869. John replied: “Yesterday I went to Adamson’s after receipt of your letter, & got the cheques for the past twelve months & compared these with his account. I find it all correct, & need hardly send it back to you. ‘Balance in your favour,15th April 1870, £2575 .. 4 .. 2’; & it would be well to note this in your cheque book to save further trouble, & testify settlement of Acct up to that date.”

My liver has evidtly gone quite wrong in this heavy burning weather. I have nothing but nausea left by way of stomach; and never felt so weary and useless in myTC repeated “my” at turn of page. life before.— With many blessings to you all

closer.note: TC wrote, 16 April: “Thursday next [21 April] is the anniversary of my irreparable Loss. Four years ago now; and the sense of it not lightened or lessened,—on the contrary brot home to me, practically sore and sad, many times every day I live. Indeed at no moment is my Lost One absent from me; but lies behind every thot I have or thing I do,—even in the presence of other people, when it is expected that I am to have totally forgotten (as they have done) the Calamity that came. Ah me, ah me. And yet there is occasionally (as this morning) a blessed balm in this mournful remembrance; a sacredness, something more like ‘worship of God’ than anythg else I do.—/ Good Tho’ Erskine is dead—at Edinr20th March last. Death peaceable, gentle; he was utterly worn down; death welcome, even to friends, much more to himself.— I loved Erskine very truly, and had a high opinn of his gifts and virtues, his modest nobleness, lucidity, and innate piety of character and life. But I cd see little of him, for a long time past, nor cd always get into very close contact when I did; it is now ended,—now ended. Another niche in my old heart stands empty henceforth” (TC’s journal; privately owned).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 29 April. MS: NLS 527.13. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I must at least send you the Adamson Paper witht more delay, that you may deliver it before the week end! I did my best to fill it up yesterday, but wasn’t quite clear abt some points. Are you perfectly sure that the actual Balance dates April 15, and not jany 1? I suppose you to be.John A. Carlyle replied, 1 May: “Yesterday I took your note to Adamson. You need not have taken the trouble of sending it at all; for after careful examination of your Account, I signed the Ledger for you, as I was requested to do … stating that I had found the account correct. Your ‘actual balance’ dates 15th April. That is the day on which British Linen Co always makes annual balances; & it would be well if you noted that balance in your cheque book to save further trouble” (MS: NLS 1775D.190).

For nearly 3 weeks past, I have [been]TC omitted “been.” palpably below par in health; not sleeplessness specifically, but such a conditn of liver as I have seldom been in. The fruit, I perceive, and ripened crisis (may we hope?) of what has been going on all winter,—and holding me down not a little; a sad enough additn to my spiritl laziness, dreariness, sadness & uselessness. Within the last 2 days I am in hopes it is beginning fairly to go.— This summer I ought surely to try for a bit of real Sea air;—and for that it will as surely be well to take time by the forelock, instead of trying by the hindlock (as last year), and finding that there is no “lock” there, nothing but bald scalp there!— Lady Ashburton talked greatly abt sailing, to Norway, to America even; abt having a yacht of her own, &c &c: but since the Easter days, she has vanished, broken her day here, by above a week,—and may have gone to the Ecumenic CouncilThe 20th Ecumenical Council of the Catholic Church; see TC to LLA, 16 Nov. for aught one can say! TyndallJohn Tyndall. too was very pressing. One must look out with one’s own eyes, howr; nothing else will do.

I am getting much bother with the stupidities of mankind in reference to these mis-ableThus in MS. “Prints” for “Library Editn,”—especially at prest with Frk Chapn’s inconceivable carelessness abt a certain Frontispiece to vol IV of
O. C.!The frontispiece of Cromwell, vol. 4 (vol. 17 of the library edn.) was “a facsimile of a contemporary print” of John Owen (1616–83; ODNB), theologian, vice chancellor of Oxford Univ. 1652–57; print by Robert White (1645–1703; ODNB), engraver. I am going up to him abt that just now: he was here yesty abt the genl questn of Prints, whh I hoped was pretty nearly settled for good. If I had a right Voltaire,TC put two portraits of Voltaire (François-Marie Arouet, known as Voltaire [1694–1778], French writer and philosopher) in Frederick vol. 5 (25:318 in the library edn.); for one of them, see Carlyle, Works 14:frontispiece. I think it wd be.

Is it not a long while since Jean wrote to me? I have no right to murmur, since I can myself make so little return. But a loving word is welcome sometimes to the wearyWord repeated at turn of page. heart, “old & weary” sure enough. There is nothing of news with us but what you may spell out of these inclosed Lettrs.One of TC’s enclosed letters, 29 April, read: “Mrs Frederick Poynder has been informed that new eggs are acceptable to Mr Carlyle, she therefore does herself the great pleasure of sending him a few, in grateful admiration of his writings.” TC wrote on the letter: “Return me this; I liked it! The 2 Dozen eggs are an honest article, in themselves & otherwise.” John replied, 1 May: “The little note about the eggs is also very good, & must have been really welcome amid the unreasonable rubbish to wh your position exposes you in this imperfect world” (MS: NLS 1775D.190).

p.note: TC wrote in his journal shortly after 21 April (anniversary of JWC’s death in Hyde Park, 1866): “On the solemn ‘21st of April,’ when I hoped at least to be left alone and was taking measures for that end, Interruptn came (Allingham & Tait came): and I had to visit the ‘sacred spot’ as if merely ‘walking in the Park,’ in vague Colloquy with these Two! How harsh, stupidly cruel are the rubbings of idle accidt (or seem to be), when you yrself have no skin! Why shd I make pilgrimage to that strange point of space? It is as if to say agn a mute Farewell; and I often b[en]d thitherwd to do it” (TC’s journal; privately owned). He noted, 1 May, Froude’s absence in Vienna (see TC to JAC, 13 April): “my main compann he; tho’ there are plenty of others, did they profit me”; he continued with reference to a walk in the last week of April with his old friend Thomas Story Spedding (1800–70; see 45:biographical notes), visiting from Cumberland: “T. Spedding is here … my style of talk to him, so fierce, exaggerative, scornful of surrounding men and things painful to me to think of now” (TC’s journal; privately owned).

div1.title: Appendix of Jane Welsh Carlyle’s Letters to Isabella McTurk / Dinwoodie, Found Too Late to be Placed Chronologically
div1.p: This appendix in the CL includes Jane Baillie Welsh’s / Jane Welsh Carlyle’s letters to Isabella McTurk, then Dinwoodie, 1823, ca. 1831, 1848, and 1857/58. In the CLO, these letters have been moved to their proper chronological location (see the links provided below). The print edition also includes two letters from Grace Welsh, JWC’s mother, to Isabella Dinwoodie. They are placed chronologically below. The McTurk / Dinwoodie letters are followed in the CL by Appendix Two, consisting of some of JWC’s letters to various correspondents, 1850–66, also found too late to be placed chronologically. We introduce them with a letter from Susan Stirling, novelist, to John Riddle Stodart, both Edinburgh friends of JWC’s from the early part of her marriage before the Carlyles’ departure for London in 1834. Susan Stirling’s assessment of JWC’s brilliance in this letter provides an appropriate introduction to this series of JWC’s letters, showing as it does the private reputation that JWC had among her friends and acquaintances.
div1.head: SUSAN STIRLING TO JOHN R. STODART
div1.p: Susan Stirling [SS]-John R. Stodart [JRS], 20 July 1867. MS: NLS Acc. 7012. Pbd: Carlyle Society Papers (2015) inc. John Riddle Stodart (1793–1871; see 24:222JWC to TC, [5 Sept. 1849]) had sent some of JWC’s letters to him to Susan Stirling, b. Hunter (1799–1877; see JWC to TC, [5 Sept. 1849]).
SUSAN STIRLING TO JOHN R. STODART

I am very sorry to have missed your visit, as shd have much enjoyed a little talk with you about the writer of these letters whom I think I knew well & who always interested me deeply,—as the letters do now.The JWC letters that Stodart sent were [30 Sept. 1849], [10 Sept. 1852], and her last letter to him, 30 Dec. 1865. She was the most brilliant women I ever did know—& I used to feel that the very thought of her made my heart beat fast— Many are the personal histories I have listened to with interest from her long years ago— She had such a remarkable power of narrating! and cd chain me down for hours & command my most intense sympathy— I have heard her speak of you—& with the same kindly heartiness as these letters express. She was very different from yr Jemima;Jemima Henrietta Stodart, b. Brown (1807–65; see JWC to TC, [5 Sept. 1849]), m. 1826. As you say they were both strong-minded—& they had another point of resemblance, neither
of them were happy women but still they were widely different—& yet I loved them both—and miss them painfully out of life—& very often think of them -& feel myself poorer for the loss.

We shall talk of these things easier than write— Like you I think far more about people than I seem to think—and tho’ you and I shd not meet often we shall not I am sure forget or lose interest in one another—
div1.closer: I am Yrs always / S Stirling
div1.title: Jane Welsh Carlyle’s letters to Isabella McTurk, later Dinwoodie
div1.p: The folder (MS: NLS Acc. 12039) which contains JWC’s letters to McTurk / Dinwoodie has pages of etched sayings attached to it with the last page signed in the bottom right hand corner “To Isabella McTurk / from / Jane Carlyle.” As well as the letters, it also contains an undated note: “This Folio was Etched and mostly written by Jane Carlyle some of the writings being original and some copies. As will be seen it was presented by her to Isabella McTurk (my Mother) and has never been out of our possession[.] We have also in our possession a pencil Portrate [sic] of Mrs Welsh done by her daughter Jane Welsh or Carlyle when 12 years of age[.] / M. A. Dinwoodie” (MS: NLS Acc. 12039). For the portrait of Grace Welsh (previously owned by Joan Gillan, widow of Dr. James Gillan, descendant of Isabella Dinwoodie; see also 30:260), see 203. Previously we have followed JWC’s usage of Dunwoodie as Isabella’s married surname (see, for example, 34:257JWC to MR, 30 Dec. 1858, and 36:280) but we are now using Dinwoodie, the spelling used by her daughter, Mary Agnes Dinwoodie, and by Grace Welsh in her letters to Isabella after her marriage (see below); Dinwoodie is also the spelling on Isabella McTurk and William Dinwoodie’s marriage listing recorded in the register (Register House, Edinburgh). For the portrait of Isabella Dinwoodie, painted during her widowhood (donated to the Carlyle Society by her descendant John Beddoes), see JWC to IMD, 21 April [1848].

div1.title: Grace Welsh’s letters to Isabella McTurk Dinwoodie
div1.p: Grace Welsh also corresponded with Isabella McTurk after Isabella’s marriage to William Dinwoodie. To give context to JBW / JWC’s friendship with Isabella and to the closeness of Isabella to the extended Welsh family, we include the two Grace Welsh to Isabella Dinwoodie letters that are in the same folder of material (NLS Acc. 12039). They give useful indications of Mrs. Welsh’s letter writing style, undoubtedly similar to the way she would have written to JWC, most of those letters having not survived. Unusually we are including the addressee’s name in our headnotes to Grace Welsh’s letters to Isabella to provide further evidence that Dinwoodie was the preferred family spelling.
GW-IMD, 19 Feb. 1838. Addr: Mrs Dinwoodie / Townhead / Kirkmichael. PM: Dumfries, 20 Feb. 1838. MS: NLS Acc. 12039. Pbd: Ian Campbell, Carlyle Newsletter, no. 1 (March 1979) 19–20.
div1.head: GRACE WELSH TO ISABELLA DINWOODIE
div1.p:
I regretted much not seeing your goodman,William Dinwoodie (1790–1848), farmer, Townhead, Dumfriesshire. when he was so near too—but it did not surprise me—for I would not have gone one step out of my way such a day—to have seen the bonny young Queen herselfVictoria was 19; she succeeded to the throne of Great Britain and Ireland 20 June 1837. —so give him my kind regards, and say I hope he will come the sooner on purpose—and bring you along with him—but let me know before hand, if you can—for I would be sorry to miss you— Now my purpose in writing this very day—is to ask you if you need a Lassie—having got one on hand—that I should like very well to get a good place—such a place as would look to the walk of the creature, as well as the work. It is your old acquaintance Jessie McVeagh,Jessie McVeagh, presumably connected to the McVeagh family at Morton, nr. Thornhill; see 34:biographical notes. who came here at the termOne of the four days of the year legally marking the beginning and ending of contracts of employment, Candlemas (2 Feb.), Whitsunday (15 May), Lammas (1 Aug.), and Martinmas (11 Nov.). Jessie presumably came 2 Feb., and Grace Welsh expected her to stay until 15 May. —not having got a place or a home—by the next term she will I hope be pretty well drilled—for I spare her not at present, for her future good I hope—so if you should not need her yourself you will lend me a hand in finding one for her—having few to do so— How is the shawl? I told Jeanie WelshGrace’s niece in Liverpool. that you were nitting it for me & bid her get me the fringe, should she send it I will add to your pleasure—by sending it to sew on!! still the old woman, says you—so when I know her intentions I will let you know so dont send it until you hear—for I wd be quite horrified if it and the fringe were to meet here for the first time— I had a long letter from Jeanie Carlyle yesterdayTC noted to his mother, Margaret A. Carlyle, 15 Feb.: “Jane, who has just been down stairs to see me, and is writing to her Mother, charges me to send you her kind love; her prayers, she calls it, for all and sundry in this frosty time. She says she will take cold soon, unless the weather soften”. still keeping well—but sick to death of the confinement—and praying morg noon, & Night for Thaw & sunshine—were it not for letters—(which I really must say I have been by my friends well seen after in that respect) I would know nothing more of the world, than that the sky was above me & the Earth beneath me. I see no one, and I never move further than from the Chair
to the foot stool & back again by way of variety—but I never was in better health, and getting so fat besides—that I am on very comfortable terms with myself at present—which is saying not a little, as you know in a pinching frost.

I would tell you—if you did not see that I write as if I were chased. Jessie stands in waiting to take this, &c. to Wallace Hall, for Mrs MundellMrs. Mundell, wife of Robert Mundell (d. 1842), rector (1790–1842) of Wallace Hall School, Closeburn. Wallace Hall School, nr. Closeburn, Dumfriesshire, where the Mundells lived, was founded in 1723 by John Wallace, merchant in Glasgow and native of Closeburn, to give education in English, mathematics, and modern and classical languages. The dwelling house for the rector was built in 1795. to take to Dumfries tomorrow morg and it is fully late for a moonless road— How is Mrs Witt?Unidentified further; no Witt family has been traced in Dumfriesshire. I am never in Dumfries but for a start after steam importationsPossibly a version of steam inhalations. & etc———oh how I fear for all the people being here in summer— I had a long letter from Mrs AitkenProbably Eliza Stodart Aitken, living at Minto, Roxburghshire, rather than Jean Carlyle Aitken, who lived nearer to Templand in Dumfries. the other day—wishing me there—but I am too well here—to run any risk of my precious self. It is long since I have known health in winter before.

closer.salute: Yours Af hang the pen, Affectionately

div1.postscript: I do think I feel a little ashamed to send you such a production
div1.head: GRACE WELSH TO ISABELLA MCTURK DINWOODIE
div1.p: GW-IMD, [late Feb. 1838]. To Mrs Dinwoodie, Mr Watt’s Ironmongers / Dumfries. MS: NLS Acc. 12039. Pbd: Ian Campbell, Carlyle Newsletter, no. 1 (March 1979) 18–19. Dated after GW to IMD, 19 Feb. 1838.
GRACE WELSH TO ISABELLA MCTURK DINWOODIE
div1.dateline: Templand Sunday I do not know the day of the month which is Feby I believe [1838]
div1.p:
I received your letter this morning which I looked upon as a [miracle?]. Who [How] any biped could have made its way here after such a day & night. I thank you much for your speedy answer to my requests; with respect to the LassieJessie McVeagh; see GW to IMD, 19 Feb. 1838. one, I am glad to find you neither required her yourself, or found any that did, as it would have proved the day after the Fair, where she wished to go—where she went—& where she hired herself for “a note” to people of the
name of LorrimerLorrimers, previously of Keir, not identified further. —of black-something—within five miles of Dumfries—decent people they are said to be—old and old-fashioned—they once had a farm, in Keir.

Tho’ they are not the kind of people I should have cared about—or to speak more correctly, the sort of in-the-house, & out-the-house work that she is engaged to perform—for I think the two together never fails in producing a compound of incongruities. Yet I believe it is the best place she could have had—for a six months training to rise with the Lark, and to work for her food—which will teach her the value of it. so let us hope the best for the poor Orphans sake—nor let us lose sight of her— I had a long letter from the Liverpool Jeanie—she will send the fringe as soon as she canJeannie Welsh; see GW to IMD, 19 Feb. 1838. but it may be some time before she gets it. All well—my good BrotherJohn Welsh, Grace’s brother; merchant and retired brass and copper founder; he lived at 20 Maryland St., Liverpool. in good health and spirits, has been actually in the full enjoyment of the Curling from which you may guess whether the married or the unmarried carried the day. He has liked the frost so much, and been so very well during it, that I really cannot rejoice, as I otherwise would at the last decided thaw—surely the long severe storm is now drawing to a finish-line—but you like myself it would appear have no cause to complain of it—and glad I am to hear that your health is so much improved so take care of it, and be thankful, for the very Sun is cheerless, when health is not. To your kind SisterThe oldest sister, Mary (b. 1800), presumably d. young as there was a 2d Mary (b. 1809) McTurk; the sister might be the latter or Jean McTurk (b. 1804). return my best remembrance, I am truly happy to hear such good accounts of her happiness forgive me Isabella, but it is to me, as it must be to all your friends, a pleasure, that you both are where you are—to prize, and be prized. Many are the reports of Mr Gibsons MarriageMr. Gibson, not further identified. —do you believe in it—no me— For John McTurk’s Bairns I hope that will never be— Robt McQueenJohn McTurk (probably Isabella’s father) and Robert McQueen. is with him at present I wish he would make him his factotum, he could not have a more conscientious one, and it would be a windfall to him poor fellow—indeed to the other also—big man as he is

I have had many invitations to Wallace HallSee above, GW to IMD, 19 Feb. 1838.—& DabtonDabton, 1½mi. (2.5 km.) N of Thornhill, home of the Crichtons, see below. for a time—but, really I am so well I don’t see how I can be better I am very fond of Mrs Macveagh I like her honest heart & friendly ways. I hope she and her goodmanProbably Mary McVeagh (1784–1860); wife of a bank agent (not further identified), she lived at Old Manse, Morton, nr. Thornhill, and was a friend of Mary Russell. Her name was spelled variously Macveay, Macvie, Macvey; see 34:biographical notes.
will be in no hurry in leaving Mr Crighton, who would then feel his loneliness—oh what a sorry blank “she”The recently deceased Mrs. Crichton (an old friend of Grace Welsh’s); see JWC to JWE, 4 March [1837]; wife of Major Thomas Crichton (d. 1848) (spelled Creighton by TC in a letter to JWC, 23 March 1842), the Duke of Buccleuch’s chief factor in the area. makes

I had a long letter from Mrs AitkenEliza Stodart Aitken. again wishing me to write—they are downright angry at LiverpoolWhere Grace Welsh’s brother John Welsh and family lived. for my not coming there, the beginning of this month it seems I promised, which I do not recollect—and if I had, the frost would have frozen it like all other things I have a pressing invitation to Kirkcaldy too from Miss FergusJessie Fergus (b. 1794), sister of John Fergus (1797–1865), M.P. and flax merchant. —so you see what a strong hold Templand is for not one of them do I mean to accept—as soon asGrace Welsh repeated “soon as” at turn of page. this weather permits I mean to be like the little busy Bee, plant, and sow—for my friends—you amongst the number, to reap and enjoy, by the way can you tell me if the real marmalade orangesPresumably Seville oranges, which came into season late Dec.–mid Feb. For JWC’s marmalade making, see 23:5JWC to TC, [4 April 1848], and 8JWC to TC, [7 April 1848]. are come in yet—what a long story I have made of it—but I was anxious to save you any further trouble about Jessie, therefore took the opportunity of giving you a little myself—with best wishes Believe me

div1.title: Jane Welsh Carlyle’s Letters to Various Correspondents, 1850–66, Found Too late to be Placed Chronologically in the CL
div1.p: Links to the Letters published in CL 46:appendix two:

p.ref: JWC to Edward Coningham Sterling, 11 June 1852
JWC to Jean Carlyle Aitken, 16 Jan. 1857
JWC to Mary Carlyle Austin, 22 Oct. 1858

div1.p: Adamson, Samuel (1831–80), of British Linen Co., Dumfries, where TC had an account; son of Robert Adamson (1787–1861; see 10:23TC to JA, 14 Feb. 1838, and 37:261).

Aitken, James Jr. (1836–71), son of Jean and James; he worked in a mercantile house in London 1858—ca. 1864, then moved to work in Liverpool 1864–66, tried to establish himself as a shipbroker on his own in London 1866–67, and was now back working in Liverpool (“salary £400 & work easy & interesting for him” [JAC to TC, 27 Dec. 1868; MS: NLS 1775C.296]), and living at 29 Rock Terrace, Claughton, Birkenhead (across the river Mersey from Liverpool), with his sister Margaret Aitken (1845–1932) as housekeeper.

Aitken, Jean (“Craw”) Carlyle (1810–88), TC’s sister; m., 1833, James Aitken (1809–87) from Troqueer, housepainter of English St., Dumfries; they moved from Assembly St., Dumfries, to their new house, The Hill, Lochmaben Rd., Dumfries, 1863. They had two sons who d. in infancy (1834–36 and 1855–56), both named Alexander; their surviving sons were James Jr. (see above); Thomas (1841–13 Oct. 69), who had been at an inst. for the deaf in Glasgow (see 29:186TC to JAC, 4 Nov. 1854), but was now living at home; and John (1843–1911), a bank clerk at the Commercial Bank, Dumfries. Their das. were Anne (1839–1919), Margaret (see above), and Mary (see below).

Aitken, Mary (1848–95), worked as a pupil teacher in Peebles, March-Sept. 1867, then returned home. She accompanied TC to London, Sept. 1868, “for about three weeks,” but stayed on permanently. She m., 1879, her cousin Alexander Carlyle.

Alford, Marianne Margaret Egerton, b. Compton (1817–88; ODNB), Viscountess Alford, known as Lady Marian Alford; art patron and writer on needlework; widow of John Hume Cust, later Egerton (1812–51), Viscount Alford; they had two sons, John William Spencer Brownlow Egerton-Cust (1842–67), 2d Earl Brownlow, and Adelbert Wellington
Brownlow Cust (1844–1921), 3d Earl Brownlow, whom Tyndall later described: “a finer specimen of physical manhood I thought I had never before seen” (Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 22). They lived at 11 Princes Gate, Kensington, Ashridge, Hertfordshire, and Belton House, Grantham, Lincolnshire.

Allingham, William (1824–89; ODNB), Irish poet; he worked in the Customs Service 1846–70; friendly with TC since early 1850s. He m., 1874, Helen Mary Elizabeth, b. Paterson (1848–1926; ODNB), watercolorist; she later painted portraits of TC; she also compiled the list of pictures for Carlyle’s House Catalogue.

Althaus, Friedrich (1829–97), writer and historian. Althaus completed the German translation of Frederick, left unfinished by Joseph Neuberg at his death in March 1867; see 45:50TC to FAL, [15 Oct. 1867].
Anderson, Frederick (b. ca. 1833), wood engraver, 42 Warden Rd., Kentish Town; see 32:166TC to FA, 11 June 1857.

Ashburton, Lady Louisa Caroline, b. Stewart-Mackenzie (1827–1903), m., 1858, William Bingham Baring (1799–1864; ODNB; see 11:40TC to MAC, 8 March 1839, and later vols.), 2d baron, politician, and partner in Baring Bros., bankers. They had one da., Mary Florence (1860–1902). Lady Louisa was the da. of Mary Elizabeth Frederica, b. Mackenzie (1783–1862; ODNB), chief of Clan Mackenzie, and James Alexander Stewart (1784–1843); on their marriage (1817) the name Mackenzie was added to that of Stewart. Lady Ashburton lived at Melchet Court (see 38:8JWC to LLA, [11 Nov. 1861]), a country house 6 mi. (9.5 km.) W of Romsey, Hampshire, on the border between Hampshire and Wiltshire; she also owned a farm at Addiscombe, near Croydon, and Seaforth Lodge, Devon. Lord Ashburton’s first wife, m. 1823, was Harriet, b. Montagu (1805–57; ODNB; see 11:40TC to MAC, 8 March 1839, and 26:ix—xv); they met the Carlyles in 1839 and became close friends. Where necessary for clarity, we refer in notes to Lord Ashburton’s first and second wives as Lady Harriet Ashburton and Lady Louisa Ashburton respectively, although these are not the correct forms.

Austin, Mary Carlyle (1808–88), TC’s sister, m., 1831, James Austin (1805–78), farmer of The Gill, 6 mi. (9.5 km.) SW of Ecclefechan. They had eight das.: Margaret (see Stewart); Grace (1833–1922), who m., 1856, William Yeoward (ca. 1824–1911), of Toronto, Ontario; Jessie (b. 1836), who m., 1859, George Grierson (b. 1835); Jane (b. 1840); Mary Anne (b. 1842); Catherine (see James Carlyle Jr.); Isabella (b. ca. 1846); and Mary Carlyle (b. 1851); and one surviving son, James Jr. (b. 1848).

Baillie, James Augustus (ca. 1800–73), impoverished cousin of JWC’s mother, and his wife, Anna-Maria (b. ca. 1812); they were living in Dover; see 39:136–37JWC to BB, 22 May [1863]. By the 1871 census they were living at 12 Caroline St., London.
Baring; see Ashburton.
Blunt, Abel Gerald Wilson (1827–1902), rector of St. Luke’s, Chelsea, from 1860.

Braid, Betty, b. Pringle (1795–1875), Grace Welsh’s Haddington servant, close to JWC (see 21:82JWC to SS, [29 Oct. 1846], and 24:221JWC to TC, [5 Sept. 1949]); b. in Prestonkirk, E. Lothian; m. Alexander (1792–1874), stonemason and shopkeeper. Three sons d. in infancy: Alexander (b. 1826), James (b. 1829), and James (b. 1831); George (1827–65) was the only child who survived into adulthood. Previously living at 15 Adam St. (see 17:127TC to JWC, 12 Sept. 1843), they moved, 1858, to Upper Stenhouse, Greenend, Liberton, S Edinburgh.
Bright, John (1811–89; ODNB), radical politician.

Bromley, Caroline Davenport (1820–91), da. of Rev. Walter Davenport Bromley (1787–1862) of Wootton Hall, Staffordshire, and his first wife, m., 1818, Caroline Barbara, b. Gooch (1791–1827). A friend of Lady Louisa Ashburton, she became a close friend of JWC’s; she was now friendly with TC. Her London home was at 32 Grosvenor St.
Brown, Dr. John (1810–82; ODNB), physician and author, old friend of John A. Carlyle.
Brown, Joseph (1809–87), photo-engraver, Dartmouth Row, Forrest Hill.
Browning, Robert (1812–89; ODNB), poet. Friend of the Carlyles since mid-1830s.
Burgess, Andrew Hutton (b. 1835), b. Dumfriesshire, journalist, lodging at 36 Park Walk, Chelsea.
Burton, John Hill (1809–81; ODNB), historian and political economist.

Carlyle, Alexander (Alick) (1797–1876), TC’s brother; emigrated with his family to Canada, 1843; settled at the Bield, 4½ mi. (7 km.) W of Brantford, Ontario. He m., 1830, Janet, b. Clow (1809–91); they had six surviving sons: Thomas (1833–1921), m. 1867, Margaret, b. MacVicar (1847–1917); John (1839–1924); Alexander (see below); James (1846–1924); William (1849–1935); and Robert (1851–1932); and three surviving das.: Jane Welsh (1831–84), m., 1852, Robert Sims (1825–80); Janet (1836–1916), m. William Apps of Ontario, miller; and Margaret (1847–1935), m. Edward Marrs (d. 1927), widower from Okmulgee, Oklahoma; see 1:166. An unidentified son (1832–33), Margaret (1835–36), James (b. 1840), and Euphemia (1853–54) all d. in infancy; see 32:4TC to AC, 3 Oct. 1856.

Carlyle, Alexander (1843–1931; see 16:153TC to AC, 4 May 1843), Alexander and Janet’s son; m., 1879, his cousin Mary Aitken; lived with TC from 1879 and ed. various collections of the Carlyles’ letters and TC’s writings.

Carlyle, James (Jamie) (1805–90), TC’s brother, farmer at Scotsbrig; m., 1834, Isabella, b. Calvert (ca. 1813–59). Their children were James Jr. (see below); John Calvert (1836–1901), m., 1868, Margaret Little, b. Murray (b. ca. 1848), of Blackwood Ridge, Middlebie; Thomas (1839–41); and Janet (Jenny) (see Scott).

Carlyle, James Jr. (1835–71), m., 1866, his cousin Catherine, b. Austin (1844–1908); see 44:64TC to JCA, 6 Oct. 1866. Their first child, James, d. at birth 1867; their second child was Mary (b. 1868). James had taken on the tenancy of Craigenputtoch jointly with his father, June 1867; see 44:196TC to JAC, 11 May 1867.

Carlyle, John (ca. 1792–1872), TC’s half-brother; emigrated to the U.S. in 1837, then moved to Canada (see 12:228TC to AC, 15 Aug. 1840); he lived on a small farm at Mount Pleasant, nr. Brantford, Ontario. He m., 1817, Margaret (Peggy), b. Benn (1798–1867); they had six children: Janet (1818–89), m., 1844, John Randall Ellis (1811–1911), carpenter; Mary (1821–50); John (1825–26); John (1827–97), m., ca. 1852, Mary Catherine, b. Smith; James (1830–1900), qualified as a doctor but worked for most of his life as a teacher; and William (1833–1911), a teacher and later a school inspector, m., 1860, Emily, b. Youmans (1835–1912); their da. Florence Emily Carlyle (1864–1923), became a prominent Canadian artist. William visited TC in London, Aug. 1864.

Carlyle, John Aitken (Jack, “The Doctor”) (1801–79; ODNB), TC’s brother, physician, and translator. He m., 1852, Phoebe Elizabeth Hough Watt, b. Fowler (1810–54), wealthy widow of Fitzjames Watt (1809–48), from Leek in Staffordshire, with four sons; she d. in childbirth; the child was stillborn. John A. Carlyle assumed responsibility for his stepsons: Thomas Fowler (1838–62), went to Australia, 1861, and d. on his return (see 38:115TC to JWC, 2 July 1862); Henry (b. 1839), at sea from 1854 (see 29:121TC to JCA, 30 June 1854), m., 1863, Jane Wilson, b. Hunter (1837–1908), da. of John A. Carlyle’s friend John Hunter (1801–69; see 8:161) and Helen, b. Vary (1804–85); Arthur (b. 1840), joined the civil service 1862 and was currently serving in India; and William (b. 1842), an officer in the Dragoons, m., 1866, Mary, b. Smith, da. of E. H. Smith of Grouville, Jersey.
Carlyle, Margaret, b. Aitken (1771–1853), TC’s mother; TC’s father was James Carlyle (1758–1832); they m. 1795.

Chapman, Frederic (1823–95; ODNB), partner in Chapman & Hall; took over the management of the company 1864; he m., 1861, Clara, b. Woodin (1842–66); they had one surviving son, Frederic, and a baby who d. early 1866.

Dickens, Charles (1812–70; ODNB), novelist; friend of the Carlyles since the early 1840s; m., 1836, Catherine Thomson, b. Hogarth (1816–79); separated from her in 1858; see 33:233TC to RWE, 2 June 1858.

Dinwoodie (Dunwoodie), Isabella (1802–99), m., 1836, William Dinwoodie (1790–1848); the son of Peter and Margaret (b. Mitchell) Dinwoodie, he had four sisters. He may have been related to William Dinwiddie, hosier, High St., Dumfries (see 28:254TC to JCA, 28 Aug. 1853), and Marion Dinwiddie (1819–95), hosier, 131 High St., Dumfries (named “Miss Dunwoodie” by JWC;
see 37:16JWC to MCA, [18 Oct. 1860]). Isabella and William had six das. (see Appendix, JWC to IMD, 21 April [1848]), not five as previously noted (see, for example, 36:280).
Durival; see Otthenin.
Elliott, John Joseph (1835–1903) and Clarence Edmund Fry (1840–97), photographers, 55 Baker St., London. They photographed TC and JWC, April 1865.

Emerson, Ralph Waldo (1803–82; see 6:425), philosopher, essayist, poet, and transcendentalist. He first met TC in Aug. 1833; in spite of their differences they had close ties; he introduced many Americans to TC and played a leading part in arranging the publication of TC’s works in the U.S.

Erskine, Thomas (1788–20 March 1870; ODNB; see 10:18TC to JAC, 1 Feb. 1838), theologian and retired advocate, living at Linlathen, Dundee; known to the Carlyles since the mid-1830s. He had had two widowed sisters: Christian Stirling (1789–1866), m., 1817, Charles Stirling (d. 1830); she had lived with Erskine; during the winter they had usually lived in Edinburgh; and David Paterson (1791–1867), m., 1821, Capt. James Paterson (1795–1856); she had lived with her son, James Erskine Paterson (b. 1826), and his family at 8 Newbattle Terr., Morningside, Edinburgh.

Eyre, Edward John (1815–1901; ODNB), farmer, explorer, and colonial administrator in Australia and New Zealand 1832–53; colonial administrator in various Caribbean islands 1854–60; governor of Jamaica 1862–65. He m., 1850, Adelaide Fanny, b. Ormond (ca. 1826–1905); for their six children, see 44:243.

Forster, John (“Fuz”) (1812–76; ODNB; see 6:118, and 11:7TC to JF, [25 Jan. 1839]), historian, journalist, and biographer; ed. of the Examiner1847–55; sec. to the Lunacy Commission 1855–61, and a commissioner from Feb. 1861; friend of the Carlyles since the late 1830s and TC’s literary adviser. He m., 1856, Eliza Ann, b. Crosbie (ca. 1819–94), widow of the publisher Henry Colburn (ca. 1784–1855; ODNB); from late 1863 they lived at Palace Gate House, Kensington.

Froude, James Anthony (1818–94; ODNB), journalist and historian, ed. of Fraser’s Magazine1860–74; he m., first, 1849, Charlotte Maria, b. Grenfell (1812–60); they had two das., Georgina Margaret (1850–1935) and Rose Mary (1852–75), and a son, Pascall Grenfell (1854–79). He m., second, 1861, Henrietta Elizabeth, b. Warre (1824–74); they had a son, Ashley Anthony (1863–1949), and a da., May (b. 1867). They lived at 5 Onslow Gdns., Fulham Rd. Henrietta’s father, John Ashley Warre (1787–1860), had m., as his third wife, Charlotte Froude’s sister Caroline Grenfell (1809–86), and their sister Frances Eliza Grenfell m. Charles Kingsley (1819–77; ODNB), clergyman and author.
Fry; see Elliott.
Gladstone, William Ewart (1809–98; ODNB), politician; leader of the Liberal Party 1867–74, prime minister 1868–74, 1880–85, 1886, 1892–94. He m., 1839, Catherine, b. Glynne (1812–1900; ODNB).
Grote, Harriet, b. Lewin (1792–1878; ODNB), writer, m., 1820, George Grote (1794–1878; ODNB), historian and radical politician; see 42:190JWC to TC, 15 Aug. [1865].
Grey, Sir George (1812–98; ODNB), colonial governor of South Australia (1841–45), South Africa (1854–61), and New Zealand (1845–53 and 1861–68); passionate advocate of emigration and colonization.

Hanning, Janet Carlyle (1813–97), TC’s sister; m., 1836, Robert Hanning (1796–1878), who had emigrated to Canada in mysterious disgrace in 1841; she joined him in Hamilton, Ontario, Aug. 1851, with their two das., Margaret (b. 1838) and Mary (b. 1840), who m., 1864, Charles Coates Holden (b. 1836). In Canada they had two more das., Catherine (b. ca. 1852) and Jane.

Helps, Arthur (1813–75; ODNB), historian, civil servant, clerk to the privy council 1860–75; friend of the Carlyles since the 1840s. He suffered financial ruin and was given a “grace and favour” (rent free) residence in Kew Gardens by Queen Victoria in 1869.
Huxley, Thomas Henry (1825–95; ODNB), biologist and educator.
Irving, Edward (1792–1834; ODNB; see 1:92, later vols., and Carlyle, Reminiscences), the Carlyles’ great friend; religious leader and preacher.

Jewsbury, Geraldine Endsor (1812–80; ODNB; see 12:103–4TC to GEJ, 12 April 1840), novelist, reviewer, and misc. writer; friend of the Carlyles, particularly of JWC’s, since 1841. She lived at 41 Markham Sq., Chelsea.

Laing, David (1793–1878; ODNB), antiquary; librarian of the Signet Lib., Edinburgh, 1837–78. When TC became rector of Edinburgh University he chose Laing as his assessor on the Senatus Academicus. Laing’s youngest sister, Euphemia (1808–96), lived with him as his housekeeper after the death of their mother, Helen, b. Kirk (1767–1837); since 1845 they had lived in East Villa, 12 James St., Portobello (see 43:122TC to JRU, 14 Feb. 1866).
Macmillan, Alexander (1818–96; ODNB), publisher; for his family, see 42:235.

Masson, David (1822–1907; ODNB; see 16:312JWC to TC, [24 July 1843]); writer and editor, prof. of rhetoric and English lit., Edinburgh Univ., 1865–95. He m., 1853, Emily Rosaline, b. Orme (1835–1915); they had a son, David Orme (1858–1937; ODNB), and three das, Flora (1856–1937), Helen, and Rosaline (1867–1947); they lived at 3 Roseberry Cres., Edinburgh. He was also ed. of Macmillan’s Magazine1859–68.

Mill, John Stuart (1806–73; ODNB), utilitarian philosopher and economist; m., 1851, Harriet Taylor, b. Hardy (1807–58; ODNB), who strongly influenced his thinking. Mill met TC in Sept. 1831 (see 5:398); they remained
on friendly terms even after the MS of vol. 1 of The French Revolution was burned while in Mill’s keeping (see 8:66–68), but later became estranged because of many differences in temperament and attitudes to social questions; Mill also believed that TC and other friends disapproved of his marriage. Elected Liberal M.P. for Westminster 1865.

Neuberg, Joseph (1806–67; see 11:231TC to JN, 21 Dec. 1839), a Jewish German businessman who had worked in Nottingham; naturalized British, 1845, and retired from business, 1849; m., 1841, Marian (d. 1848; see 23:77JWC to JN, 22 July 1848). He was introduced to TC, whom he had long admired, by Emerson, 1848; helped TC as an unpaid sec., translated his work into German, and twice accompanied him on visits to Germany (1852 and 1858). From 1863 Neuberg lived at Roslyn Park, Hampstead, with his widowed sister, Rosetta (or Rosette) Frankau (ca. 1816–98); she m., ca. 1851, Adolph Frankau (1820–56; see 32:32TC to JAC, 19 Nov. 1856); they had two children, Frederick Joseph (b. 1854) and Gertrude Rosette Adolphine (b. ca. 1856).

Norton, Charles Eliot (1827–1908), author, journalist, and Harvard Coll. prof. of Art 1875–98. He m., 1862, Susan Ridley, b. Sedgwick (1838–72); they had six children. He and his family spent 1868–72 in Europe, mostly in London, where he became friendly with TC.

Otthenin, Jean, b. Johnston (ca. 1800–70; see 42:236), old school friend of TC, who had lived for several years with her das., Margaret and Irma (1838–97), at 33 Northumberland St., Edinburgh. Irma m., 1867, Jean Charles Louis Eugène Durival (1811–92), and now lived in Vassy, Haute Marne, France.
Paterson; see Erskine.

Reichenbach, Oskar von (1815–93), Silesian landowner, liberal deputy to the Frankfurt parliament 1848–49, exiled to London in 1850. His wife was Friederike, b. Plattnauer (b. 1817), sister of Richard Eduard Plattnauer (b. 1814; see 41:234), political refugee from Prussia (see 22:10JWC to HW, []), who suffered periods of insanity; old friend of the Carlyles. Their children were Elizabeth (b. 1843), Hedwig (1844–92), and Oskar (b. 1845). They emigrated to the U.S. in 1853 and moved back to London sometime after 1865; they lived at 5 Carlisle Ter., Kensington.
Robson, Charles (1805–76), TC’s printer since 1837; see 41:235.

Ruskin, John (1819–1900; ODNB), author, artist, and social reformer; m., 1848, Euphemia Chalmers, b. Gray (1828–97); marriage annulled 1854 (she then m., 1855, John Everett Millais [1829–96; ODNB], artist). Ruskin lived in the family home at 163 Denmark Hill, S London, with his mother, Margaret, b. Cock (1781–1871). His father, John James Ruskin (1785–1864), was a wine merchant. Ruskin was J. M. W. Turner’s foremost admirer and was strongly influenced by TC.

Russell, Mary, b. Dobbie (1802–75; see 6:145), close friend of JWC and her
mother. She m., 1829, Dr. James Russell (ca. 1796–1878); they had moved to Holmhill, nr. Thornhill, by Oct. 1859.

Scott, Janet (Jenny), b. Carlyle (1843–74), youngest child of James and Isabella Carlyle of Scotsbrig; m., 1864, William Scott (b. ca. 1829), draper; they lived at 27 Bradford St., Birmingham, and had a son, John James Carlyle (b. 1865), and a da., Isabella (b. ca. 1866).

Stanley, Arthur Penrhyn (1815–81; ODNB), dean of Westminster 1864–81. He m., 1863, Lady Augusta Bruce (1822–1876; ODNB), da. of Thomas Bruce (1766–1841; ODNB), 7th earl of Elgin; she was a former lady of the bedchamber and secretary to Queen Victoria.

Stanley, Henrietta Maria, b. Dillon (1807–95; ODNB), m., 1826, Edward John (1802–16 June 1869; ODNB; see 12:59TC to JAC, 27 Feb. 1840), 2d Baron Stanley of Alderley, Whig politician; living at Alderley Park, Cheshire; their London home was at 40 Dover St. Both were friends of the Carlyles. For their nine surviving children, see 45:biographical notes, and 45:biographical notes.

Stephen, James Fitzjames (1829–94; ODNB; see 41:24JWC to TC, [14 Sept. 1864]), judge and writer; m., 1855, Mary Richenda, b. Cunningham (1829–1912), they had eight children. They lived at 4 Cornwall Gds., Queen’s Gate.

Sterling, Sir Anthony Coningham (1805–71; ODNB; see 9:103, and later vols.), soldier; m., 1829, Charlotte, b. Baird (d. 1863), who suffered attacks of insanity and was jealous of JWC (see 18:266–67JWC to HW, [12 Nov. 1844], and 19:9JWC to HW, [9 Jan. 1845]); he lived at 3 South Pl., Knightsbridge. His brother John (1806–44; ODNB), writer, had been a particular friend of TC’s; see CL vols. 8–18 and Carlyle’s Life of Sterling (1851); his surviving children were Edward Coningham Sterling (1831–77), Julia Maria (1836–1910), John Barton (1840–1926), and Hester Isabella (1843–1908).

Stewart, Margaret, b. Austin (1831–74), da. of Mary and James Austin, m., 1859, Thomas Stewart (1832–20 April 1869), farmer from Hollybush, now living at Ernhirst (Ironhirst), about 5 ½ mi. (9 km.) SW of Dumfries; see 38:19TC to JAC, 1 Dec. 1861; they had a da., Mary (b. ca. 1861), and four sons, William (b. 1863), James (b. 1864), Hugh (b. 1866, dead by April 1868), and Thomas (b. 27 May 1869). Thomas Stewart’s brothers were Hugh (b. ca. 1826), James (b. ca. 1831), and John (b. ca. 1839).
Stirling, Christian; see Erskine.

Syme, James (1799–1870; ODNB), prof. of clinical surgery, Edinburgh Univ., 1833–1870; see 39:249TC to JAC, 26 Nov. 1863. He m., as his 2d wife, 1841, Jemima, b. Burn (1810–1 Feb. 1869); they had three das. and two sons, including James (b. 1849).
Symington, Andrew James (1826–98), Glasgow merchant, poet, and biographer, old acquaintance of the Carlyle family.

Tait, Robert Scott (1816–97), portrait painter and pioneer photographer;
friend of the Carlyles since 1853, he painted TC (see 31:84TC to AGI, 6 May 1856) and A Chelsea Interior (see 33:197JWC to MR, 29 March [1858]), as well as taking photographs of both Carlyles.
Tennyson, Alfred (1809–92; ODNB), poet; poet laureate 1850–92; m., 1850, Emily Sarah, b. Sellwood (1813–96); friends of the Carlyles since the early 1840s.

Tyndall, John (1820–93; ODNB), physicist, prof. of natural philosophy at the Royal Institution, Albemarle St., London, from 1853; TC’s admirer and friend from the mid-1850s; see 31:1–2TC to JF, 2 Jan. 1856.

Venturi, Emilie (ca. 1819–93; ODNB), da. of William Henry Ashurst (ca. 1791–1855; ODNB; portrait painter), supporter of Italian independence and campaigner for women’s rights; unhappily m. to Sydney Hawkes, whom she divorced 1861; see 30:215JWC's J, , and 235JWC's J, 21 Oct. 1855. She m., 1861, Carlo Venturi (ca. 1830–66). A strong supporter of Giuseppe Mazzini (1805–72; see 11:225TC to JSM, 6 Dec. 1839, and 28:xiii—xiv), Italian revolutionary, and the Young Italy movement, she published various English editions of his writings and Joseph Mazzini: A Memoir (1875).
Victoria (1819–1901; ODNB), queen of Great Britain and Ireland 1837–1901; m., 1840, Albert (1819–61; ODNB), prince consort.

Warren, Sarah (b. ca. 1812 in Norfolk), a widow with adult children (see 41:96JWC to MR, [17 Nov. 1864]), cook and housekeeper at Cheyne Row from Nov. 1864 until at least 1871 (listed in the 1871 census as still at 5 Cheyne Row). Sarah Warren was previously wrongly identified as Eliza Warren (ca. 1816–1905) in vols. 41 and 42.
Watt; see John. A. Carlyle.

Watts, George Frederic (1817–1904; ODNB), artist. He lived at Little Holland House, Kensington. He m., first, 1865, Ellen Alice, b. Terry (1847–1928; ODNB), actress, but they separated after less than a year; he m., second, 1886, Mary Seton, b. Fraser-Tytler (1849–1938).

Welsh, Alexander (Alick) (b. 1816), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John; m., ca. 1849, Sophy, b. Martin (b. ca. 1824). Their children were John (Jackie) (ca. 1853–64), Isabella Helen (b. 1856; see 31:201JWC to TC, [29 Aug. 1856]), Margaret (b. 1858), and Jean (b. 1860); they lived at Sandown Park, Wavertree, Liverpool.

Welsh, Ann (1799–1877), Elizabeth (1792–1877), and Grace (1801–67), JWC’s paternal aunts (see 14:67TC to JWC, 11 March 1842, and 16:219JWC to JW, [ca. 26 June 1843]), living at Craigen Villa, Morningside, Edinburgh.
Welsh, Grace, b. Welsh (1782–1842), JWC’s mother; m., 1800, John Welsh (1776–1819; see 1:202–3), JWC’s father, doctor in Haddington.

Welsh, John (1785–1853; see 28:286–87JWC to HW, [12 Oct. 1853]), JWC’s maternal uncle, brass and copper founder, who had lived at 20 Maryland St., Liverpool; m., 1808, Mary, b. Colliver (d. 1838; see 10:200TC to AC, 15 Oct. 1838); their children were Helen (ca. 1813–53); Walter; Alexander; Jeannie (Babbie) (1818–95), m., 1853,
Andrew Chrystal (ca. 1811–83), wine merchant from Glasgow, they had a da., Mary (1857–1937), see 40:226–27; John (1820–60); Margaret; and Mary.

Welsh, Margaret (Maggie) (b. 1821), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived in Auchtertool with her brother Walter; was JWC’s nurse, Dec. 1863–May 1864; she came to Chelsea to look after TC after JWC’s death, late April–mid-Aug. 1866; and again early June–early Oct. 1867; see 45:43TC to LLA, 7 Oct. 1867.
Welsh, Mary (1823–79), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived in Auchtertool with her brother Walter.
Welsh, Rev. Walter (1815–1879; see 16:12JWC to JW, [8 Jan. 1843]), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John; minister at Auchtertool, Fife, since 1842. His sisters Margaret (Maggie) and Mary lived with him.

Woolner, Thomas (1825–92; ODNB; see 26:37TC to TWO, [21 Feb. 1851], and 29:176–77TC to LA, 20 Oct. 1854), sculptor and poet; he lived at 29 Welbeck St., London. He m., 1864, Alice Gertrude, b. Waugh (b. 1845), da. of George and Mary Waugh; they had six children, including Amy (b. 1865), Hugh (1866–1925), and Geoffrey (1867–82).
